DOC.HEAD: Husband, Wife Sentenced in Cult Case
DOC.TEXT: Two members of a religious cult avoided prison terms Friday for their roles in helping to conceal the slayings of a family of five last year. Dennis Patrick and his wife, Tonya, got 18 months in prison, 90 days in jail and one year probation, but the prison terms were suspended and they were given credit for jail time already served. Judge James W. Jackson said Patrick must continue the counseling he is receiving along with his wife and their 10-year-old daughter, Molly. ``We're very happy, very much relieved with the sentence that was given,'' Patrick said. ``This has been a real tragedy in the lives of many people.'' In a separate courtroom, Mrs. Patrick wept as she read a statement to Judge Martin O. Parks. She said she had been afraid to notify authorities about the murders of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters because cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren told her he would kill her daughter if she did not cooperate. Investigators said Lundgren, who admitted to shooting the Averys, at one time also intended to kill the Patricks. The Patricks said they still feared Lundgren, who last month was sentenced to death. The couple pleaded guilty last month to one count each of obstruction of justice. Prosecutors had reduced their original charges of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. During testimony, witnesses said Patrick helped dig the pit under the Kirtland barn where the Averys were killed and buried in April 1989. He said he was told the pit was to be used for baptisms. Mrs. Patrick testified that Lundgren forced her to become his ``captive wife'' and live with him in his tent when the cult members moved to the wilderness in West Virginia after the slayings. Prosecutor Steven LaTourette said the Patricks should have revealed the murders to FBI agents who came to the farm the day after the killing. The agents questioned cult members about rumors that they were planning to take over the Kirtland Temple of the Reorganized Church of Latter Day Saints by killing its leaders. Lundgren's wife, Alice, is serving five consecutive life sentences in prison for complicity in the murders. The Lundgrens' son, Jeffrey, must serve at least 120 years in prison for his conviction on four counts of aggravated murder in the deaths of four of the Averys. He was acquitted in Cheryl Avery's death.

DOC.HEAD: Unocal Executive Fred L. Hartley Dead t 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 4th graf, `Hartley, a ...' to UPDATE with Hartley once sparring with Pickens. Pick up 5th graf, `In 1953 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Fred L. Hartley, whose push for innovation and alternative energy boosted Unocal Corp. from a small oil company to an international conglomerate, died Friday. He was 73. Hartley, the first to hold the chairman emeritus title, died at his Palos Verdes Estates home after a long illness, said spokesman Mike Thacher. ``Mr. Hartley was a creative engineer, an executive of vision and a man of great integrity who led Unocal for a quarter century,'' said Unocal chairman Richard J. Stegemeier. Hartley, a chemical engineer, joined Unocal in 1939. As a research engineer at the refinery in Los Angeles he helped design, patent and run numerous petroleum processing plants. Hartley once sparred with raider T. Boone Pickens. In 1985, after a three-month skirmish, Pickens surrendered a takeover battle against Unocal and agreed to sell his stock back to the company at a slight loss. It was Pickens' first defeat in three years of assaults on big oil firms. In 1953, Hartley proposed a program to sell and license Unocal technology to other companies. He became vice president of research in 1956, senior vice president four years later and president and chief executive by 1964. He became chairman a decade later and served as a director until his death. Hartley is best known for worldwide licensing of Unicracking, a process that converts heavy, sulfur-filled crude oil components into high-grade transportation fuels. He was a strong advocate of alternative energy sources, including oil shale and geothermal power.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Winners for Appealing, Pretty Ideas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR1 sent Oct. 18.
DOC.TEXT: Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garcons is being saluted for a summer ready-to-wear show keyed to wearability. Some think it was her prettiest ever. When a way-out designer like Kawakubo goes straight, the results might be boring or pretty. There was a little bit of both in this show Thursday, as some of Kawakubo's minimalist styles - simple gray chiffon tunics over tights or lean jumpsuits - looked cool and wearable, though not exciting. However, she presented some stunningly attractive numbers: a whole line of white heavy-lace guipure jackets and jumpsuits or simple V-necked dresses to the knee. They were terribly appealing for summer. Her most beautiful idea of all was in the cathedral-window silk prints. Lightly veiled in chiffon, the slim pants, tunics and skirts glowed with the colors and motifs like the rose or lunette windows of Chartres. Another Japanese going for prettier commercial ideas was Yohji Yamamoto. He threw in some of his usual black or navy ideas, with a tad of asymmetry. But with little flared shorts and jersey tank tops or A-line short tunics, the effect was quite perky. Yamamoto went in for some color over black body stockings or catsuits - beautiful in royal blue or emerald cotton crochet tunics, jackets, or cap sleeves. He often tied the crochet work on with satin ribbons, a fun new idea if perhaps a bit complicated for dressing. White and black were worked in with similar tying on of various sleeves, cowls, collars and skirt shapes - sometimes in stiffened white linen with drawstrings. Pantsuits often came out with cutouts and asymmetrical details - perhaps a shoulder wrap turning into a criss-cross sleeve feature. The sculpted or ``crimped-paper'' effect, effect, however, looked more suited to the runway than to a traveling woman today. The Japanese clothes had a figure-hiding side to them - concealing the body with the panels, the tunics, the lace. Angelo Tarlazzi, on the other hand, spared the body nothing. His collection was angled for the youthful figure with tiny, clinging stretch mini-suits, or leg-revealing full skirts. Like many other designers, Tarlazzi loved the lingerie look. He trotted several fitted pastel slips out of the underwear closet. They usually had lace-edged tops with spaghetti straps, plus black lace gussets in the flared skirts. They would be perfect under a suit if you got tired of wearing them out to the disco. Another young Tarlazzi theme was done with eyelet: The cutest in this vein, with shorts or minis, had red scalloped edges on the shorts and fichu wrap tops. His shirred, clinging print micro dresses with their lacy edges looked as if he took very seriously the bathing-suit evening-dress idea started by Emanuel Ungaro a couple of seasons ago. For his second collection shown in Paris, English designer John Galliano went in for some off-the-wall models that outdid the Japanese of yore. His silhouettes were often quirky and asymmetrical, even including a paper-doll paper dress with cutouts. Galliano had a tendency to show a lot of skin, with some curious results, since the outfits were obviously not beachwear.

DOC.HEAD: Hollywood Builds New Calcutta Slum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: As if Calcutta didn't have enough slums, Hollywood built another one. The collection of patchwork shacks is so authentic that filmmakers had to erect a fence to keep out people hoping to move in. The 600-foot-long street of 52 houses is the location for the movie based on Dominique Lapierre's best-selling novel, ``City of Joy,'' a story about a rickshaw puller and a Polish priest in the slums of Calcutta. But it is more than just a movie set. The dilapidated homes are careful replicas of slum shacks made of tin, mud, stone, wood and tiles. They were based on dozens of photographs from slum quarters in Calcutta, Bombay and New Delhi, said Philip Kohler, the production manager. And they are so authentic ``we had to build a 10-foot fence around the lot to keep out people who wanted to move in,'' Kohler said. The homes were built on a lot owned by the national oil company near Calcutta's docks in the heart of the industrial zone. They will be demolished when filming is completed. The film for Warner Bros. is to be directed by Roland Joffe, of ``The Killing Fields'' and ``The Mission.'' The 12-week shooting schedule begins in February. Calcutta has 300 slum neighborhoods, known as bustees, housing an estimated 43 percent of the city's 12 million residents. Some estimates say up to 300,000 people are homeless street-dwellers. ``City of Joy'' is about one of them, Hasari Pal, an impoverished villager who brought his family to the city when he could no longer meet debts from his small landholding. After working as a rickshaw puller - a human horse in the last major city of the world where men still pull rickshaws - Pal can afford to move into the slum of Ananda Nagar, which is Bengali for City of Joy. From the beginning, the movie project ran into political problems. Last year the state government of West Bengal objected to putting Calcutta's poverty under the filmmakers' kleig lights. The film company argued that the movie would highlight the city's ``indomitable spirit,'' according to news reports at the time. ``We feel there is no need to show only slum-dwellers to show the indomitable spirit of Calcutta,'' retorted Parvatheneni Upendra, the information and broadcast minister of the federal government in New Delhi. The information minister for the Communist-led state government at the time, Budhadev Bhattacharya, also objected to the film. He complained that the book was written ``from an imperialist point of view.'' Details of the negotiations that cleared the way for the film have not been disclosed. The estimated $5 million the company is likely to spend in Calcutta may have helped persuade the authorities to reconsider. Kohler also said there was a contribution to an undisclosed charity of an unknown amount. The Polish priest has been written out of the preliminary script. He is replaced as the main character by an American doctor who comes to Calcutta to help the lepers and the poor. The doctor is a secondary character in Lapierre's 1985 book. The rewrite could reflect the sensitivity in this predominantly Hindu nation about Christian missionaries, or the filmmakers' belief that the doctor would have wider audience appeal than the priest.

DOC.HEAD: Operation Desert Shield Holding Off Iraqi Soldiers And Sheep
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1, DHA2 sent Oct. 18.
DOC.TEXT: Operation Desert Shield, along with holding off Iraqi soldiers, is also shielding the desert from another force that each year devastates Saudi rangeland: millions of Iraqi sheep. An inadvertent side effect of impending war, conservationists say, is that Iraqi herders have ceased their traditional migration across the border to find pasture for sheep, goats and camels. That, they say, is no small windfall to Saudi Arabia, where a loss of plant cover threatens to convert arable range into wasteland across much of the country. ``Tanks and jeeps running around up there are nothing compared to what happens from overgrazing,'' said Graham Child, senior consultant to the National Commission for Wildlife Conservation and Development. Crisis or not, the commission is pressing ahead with a 10-year plan to protect endangered habitats and restock them with disease-free gazelle, ostrich and native birds. The measures have already brought the Arabian oryx back from extinction in the wild. Two species of gazelle are being bred by the hundreds. There are also some new houbara bustards, large birds beloved by Saudis who hunt them with falcons. Arabian rangelands, slowly degrading for a thousand years, now suffer badly from Saudi Bedouin now able to use water trucks to graze their animals on fragile land they could not reach before. Under historic accords, Iraqi and Jordanian nomads have crossed regularly into northern Saudi Arabia to find fresh range. They have benefited from the same generous subsidies allowed the Saudis. At the same time, swift rural development in Saudi Arabia brought new roads, irrigated farming and other incursions on natural habitats. Saudi leaders realized they faced a crisis in the mid-1980s when hunters consistently camehome empty-handed. In 1986, the commission was set up to do something about it. Within four years, 57,692 square miles were designated protected areas. Specialists came in to shape a wildlife research center from a neglected private zoo on the late King Khalid's farm north of here. At a second center, scientists experimented with ways to breed enough houbara bustard chicks to save the threatened wild population. ``They've achieved an enormous amount in three years,'' said Doug Williamson, an English-based biologist who runs the King Khalid Wildlife Research Center. ``Things are far from perfect, but there is goodwill and money is being committed,'' he said. Abdul Aziz abu Zinada, the commision's secretary-general, said his priorities were protecting habitats, seeking environmental legislation, restocking wildlife and building public awareness. Conflict with Iraq has stalled plans for regional cooperation, he said, but international organizations have continued to help with data and advice. ``Now in the north you can see idmi (sand gazelle) where they had almost disappeared,'' Abu Zinada said. ``It is thrilling.'' At the King Khalid Center, scientists have all but eliminated the tuberculosis which, traced back to a gift deer from Spain, had crippled herds left for years in a single enclosure. Soon the 600 to 700 gazelles now thriving as a result of the program will be breeding hundreds of kids a year to be released into the wild, Williamson said. The center has two pairs of afri, or Saudi dorcas gazelles, among the last 27 believed left in the world. Altogether, there are 20 species from five continents. The animals thrive in separate pens and paddocks and include a mix of indigenous species and gifts from visitors. There are idmi, rheem (mountain gazelle), other rare gazelles, Arabian oryx, zebras, ostriches and assorted extras, including a mad half-goat, half-ibex that thinks it's a deer. Williamson, an antelope specialist who worked in Botswana's Kalahari Desert, is also conducting research on how gazelle cope with roasting desert temperatures. ``We haven't been affected much by the Iraq crisis,'' he said, echoing remarks by scientists conducting other commission projects. ``There is a lot to do still, but we're doing it.''

DOC.HEAD: Drugmaker Fined $1 Million In Generic Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: A generic drug manufacturer was fined $1 million Thursday for bribing and lying to Food and Drug Administration officials in applying for approval of drugs, the Justice Department said. American Therapeutics Inc., of Bohemia, N.Y., was fined after pleading guilty to five charges in U.S. District Court in Baltimore. ATI pleaded guilty to interstate travel in aid of racketeering, making false statements to a government agency, failing to follow required drug manufacturing practices, obstruction of an agency investigation and making unlawful payments to FDA officials. Judge John Hargrove fined ATI $1 million on the first four counts and $500,000 on the bribery charge. The $500,000 fine was a concurrent fine, meaning ATI must pay a total of $1 million. ``(The case) reveals a depressing and sinister picture of the generic drug industry,'' U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox said in a statement. ``Unfortunately, the picture will get even darker. As heinous as the conduct of American Therapeutics and its former chief executive is ... the conduct of ATI was altogether commonplace,'' he said. As part of a plea bargain agreement, the company agreed to assist prosecutors in a continuing investigation of possible misconduct by former ATI employees. The company admitted to substituting newer pills of the anti-hypertension drug clorazopate dipotassium for older ones in reserve samples, which are required by the FDA for testing purposes. The FDA investigated the drug after hearing complaints that it crumbled in storage, prosecutors said. The company also admitted that it submitted false data and prepared false records for two other generic drugs it had submitted for approval, prosecutors said. Clorazopate dipotassium made it to the market, but the other two did not, Justice Department spokesman Michael Robinson said. Whether the drug posed a health risk to consumers was not known, he said. The company engaged in the actions at the direction of its former chief executive officer and president, Raju Vegesna, prosecutors said. Vegesna was convicted in April of giving $60,000 in bribes to employees of the FDA's generic drug division in exchange for favorable treatment of drug applications. The division where the employees worked is responsible for reviewing applications from pharmaceutical manufacturers who want to produce and market generic equivalents of brand name drugs. ``We are grateful that the Vegesna chapter in ATI's history finally has been concluded,'' said Dr. John Meloy, a director of ATI. ``ATI has been committed from the outset to fully cooperate with the government and to ensure that there are not safety and effectiveness concerns about any ATI product.'' The pleas Thursday were part of an ongoing investigation of fraud in the generic drug industry being conducted by the Justice Department, the U.S. Attorney's office, the FDA and the Department of Health and Human Services Inspector General. The investigation already has led to the felony convictions of four former FDA employees, five generic drug company executives, three drug companies and one industry consultant.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Stamp Unveiled In Evergreen
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Postal Service unveiled one of two 1990 Christmas stamps Thursday and offered a ``first issue'' postmark for stamp collectors. The stamp, which shows a white Christmas tree against a red background with the words ``Season's Greetings'' printed across it, was issued at a ceremony near Hiwan Homestead Museum in Evergreen. Evergreen was chosen because of its obvious connection to the evergreen tree depicted on the stamp. The other stamp was issued Thursday in Washington, D.C., officials said. Each year, the Postal Service releases Christmas stamps in a town whose name has a holiday ring. Past sites include Santa Claus, Ariz., and Bethlehem, Penn. The Evergreen post office held an open house to celebrate the stamp unveiling and collectors lined up to obtain ``first-issue'' postmarks. The rest of the world had to wait until Friday to buy the stamp.

DOC.HEAD: Ted and Jane in Moscow: She Runs, He Plays `Gone With the Wind'
LaserPhoto MOSB4 of Oct. 18
DOC.TEXT: In yet another threat against the old Soviet way of life, Jane Fonda and her workout show have muscled into Red Square. Ms. Fonda ran circles around the Kremlin Thursday in a promotion for her exercise tapes, which will be broadcast on Soviet TV starting next week. Soviet citizens are not particularly health conscious or fit, but the several hundred Soviet women who jogged with Jane showed that not all Russians are couch potatoes, or standing in line to buy them. ``This is something we do in the United States very frequently and I wanted to bring it to Moscow and share it with you,'' Ms. Fonda said before setting out. Wearing a white track suit, snug black and purple midriff-length shirt and sunglasses, she led the joggers in a 1{-mile run. The joggers went down the cobblestone road from St. Basil's Cathedral, along the Moscow River embankment, up a hill past the outer Kremlin wall and then back to Red Square past the Lenin Mausoleum. Twenty minutes later, surrounded by star-struck youths and dozens of cameras, Ms. Fonda arrived at the finish line, where the crowd was entertained by the Red Army band and a small circus bear. Burly security guards helped push through the crowd to get Ms. Fonda into her car. Her companion, broadcast mogul Ted Turner, had to follow later in a separate car. Turner was here for Friday night's Soviet premier of the U.S. classic movie ``Gone With the Wind.'' His company owns MGM Entertainment and the movie is part of its library. Turner was making his eighth visit to the Soviet Union since 1984. ``I'm a great believer in the Soviet Union and I think they'll get their economy solved,'' he said. ``Then there'll be tremendous opportunities, pent up demand for all sorts of products.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Shutdown Would Keep Yeutter From Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: If the federal government shuts down because Congress and President Bush can't agree on spending cuts, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter will be among those essential employees to remain on the job. With a few restrictions, that is. For example, if no budget agreement is reached, Bush has said he will shut down the government Saturday morning, when federal spending authority is due to expire. The goal is for Congress and Bush to agree on a $500 billion deficit-reduction plan to guide government spending over the next five years. The Agriculture Department's share, as approved this week by House and Senate farm bill negotiators, is $13.6 billion. Yeutter, meanwhile, is to leave Sunday for meetings next week in Argentina, Brazil and Chile on the current Uruguay Round of talks in Geneva under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Kelly Shipp, Yeutter's press secretary and director of the USDA's office of public affairs, said that ``if on Sunday, the government's not up, then he will not go'' on the South American trip. That is one example of what a shutdown will mean at the department. Yeutter and selected aides would still be considered essential, would work and collect their pay. But most of USDA's 100,000 full-time employees would not. ``No one can tell you today, precisely, all the people who would be essential in the event of a shutdown,'' Shipp said Thursday in a telephone interview. ``I can give you broad categories ... that's why they have to leave it up to the discretion of the various managers.'' In other words, there is no central board or office that designates ``essential'' employees. Each USDA agency, from the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service to the Rural Electrification Administration, handles its own designations. Shipp said a ``very, very rough'' estimate is that 20,000 to 30,000 USDA employees would be considered essential in a government-wide shutdown of services. Those would include about 7,500 federal meat and poultry inspectors, who would remain on the job. There are several general guidelines used to help determine essential duties and employees, the spokeswoman said. Those include: -Functions that affect the health and safety of the general public. Meat and poultry inspection is an example. -Employees who are needed to conduct an orderly shutdown of the government. -Those whose jobs involve the safety and security of government facilities. Forest rangers and others needed to protect federal property would be in this category. Some other jobs that could be considered essential include workers needed to maintain feed and water for animals at USDA farms and laboratories. Those would include quarantine stations operated by the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. Workers and technical people involved in campaigns against intruding pests, such as the Mediterranean fruit fly, could be kept on if their duties are essential to the program. Shipp said the campaign this week against Africanized honeybees in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas would be another example of essential work. As for Yeutter's staff, no determination would be made until an actual shutdown began, she said. But receptionists and some other office people probably would be furloughed. Essential people would ``not necessarily'' include Yeutter's senior aides, Shipp said. It would depend on what kind of activities they were overseeing. Would Shipp remain at work in a shutdown? ``I don't know, because it depends on what's going on,'' she said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department says China has bought an additional 299,740 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price subsidy program. Officials said the subsidies for wheat sold to China have about doubled from what they averaged only a few months ago. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Thursday that three private exporting companies made the deals under the Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for the first three months of 1991, he said. It was the first wheat sale to China under EEP since Aug. 1. The sales were part of 2 million tons authorized China under EEP on May 2. Dickerson said China has about 460,000 tons remaining in its current allocation. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 11 million bushels. At current prices estimated by USDA at around $2.42 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $27 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $41.38 per ton, or about $1.13 per bushel. That was double the bonuses paid on China's previous wheat purchase on Aug. 1, which averaged $20.40 per ton, or 56 cents per bushel. A glut of wheat from bumper harvests in key producing countries has pressured world prices, thus requiring larger subsidies to keep U.S. grain competitive. The subsidized sales were handled by Bunge Corp., 150,000 tons; Louis Dreyfs Corp., 100,000 tons; and Tradigrain Inc., 49,750 tons. With the latest sales, China has bought nearly 2.8 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1990-91 wheat marketing year that began June 1, compared with 5.6 million tons in 1989-90.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Keating Released Once Federal Judge Reduces Bail to $300,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with Keating's release from jail. Pick up 8th graf, `One of ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Senators-Keating, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge lowered Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bail Thursday from $5 million to $300,000, allowing the former savings and loan chief to walk out of jail after a month behind bars. Relatives whisked away a smiling Keating after his release. U.S. District Judge John G. Davies reduced Keating's bail, saying Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner arbitrarily set it as much as 50 times higher than that of his co-defendants, who already had made bail. ``I can see no rational reason whatsoever ... for this disparate treatment among defendants,'' Davies said. Keating, 66, an Arizona developer, was jailed on charges of fraudulently selling junk bonds issued by his American Continental Corp., which owned the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. A federal bailout of Lincoln Savings is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion, which would make it the nation's costliest thrift bailout. The bail decision came as the Senate Ethics Committee investigated whether five senators who received campaign contributions from Keating improperly intervened with banking regulators on Keating's behalf. Keating's family posted the reduced bail. One of Keating's attorneys, Jeffrey Powell, said Keating would return to his home in an exclusive Phoenix suburb and begin preparing his defense. ``I'm extremely pleased,'' Powell said. ``But I think it's unfortunate it took us 33 days to get to this point.'' Deputy District Attorney Paul Turley said prosecutors would not appeal Davies' bail ruling but contended Klausner ruled carefully in considering bail. ``I believe Judge Klausner viewed all the evidence in front of him and that evidence supported the bail amount without any arbitrariness,'' Turley said. When Klausner initially set Keating's bail at $5 million, Klausner described it as 2 percent of the alleged $250 million in losses to people who invested in worthless bonds through Irvine-based Lincoln Savings. Davies called that proof of arbitrary bail and said the Constitution allowed bail to be set only high enough to ensure a defendant would appear to answer charges. The 42-count state grand jury indictment accused Keating and three of his former officials of misleading investors about the security of American Continental junk bonds sold at Lincoln branches. At the end of a two-day hearing last month, Klausner let stand the $5 million bail he set earlier. He said the potential 10-year prison term in the fraud case might make flight likely for Keating, who also faces a federal criminal investigation and civil lawsuits including a $1 billion racketeering case. Keating appealed his $5 million bail to the federal court aftr exhausting appeals through state courts, going all the way to the California Supreme Court without success. In federal court, Keating appealed the bail on constitutional grounds. ``The bottom line is there was a violation of Mr. Keating's 8th Amendment rights'' against excessive bail, Davies said. Keating was not in court, although several family members were. Davies' ruling followed an impassioned plea by a character witness, former Keating attorney John ``Jack'' Quinn of Los Angeles. In Washington, the Senate Ethics Committee adjourned Thursday without announcing a decision on whether to intensify its investigation of three senators: Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. Committee documents obtained by The Associated Press show the three had more extensive dealings with Keating than previously acknowledged. Quinn described Keating as obsessed with clearing his name and described him as a devoted, God-fearing family man. Keating is ``probably the most vilified man since Richard Nixon'' and must be free to defend himself, Quinn said. To qualify for bail, Keating agreed to surrender his passport, restrict his travel to the 48 contiguous states, report to Los Angeles County authorities by phone every week and provide authorities with a detailed itinerary of any trips planned.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Interior Department Fails to Protect Endangered Plants, Animals
DOC.TEXT: The Anastasia Island cotton mouse is gone forever. So is the insular long-tongued bat of Puerto Rico and the Texas Henslow's sparrow. All are victims of mismanagement and a shortage of money that has kept the Interior Department from adequately enforcing the federal law that is supposed to protect endangered species, according to government auditors. A report by the department's inspector general's office said Thursday that hundreds of other rare animals and plants may become extinct without any federal effort to save them because of shortcomings in the federal endangered species program. During the past decade, 34 species have disappeared because of inadequate protection under the Endangered Species Act, the internal report said. It cited underfunding and personnel shortages and blamed the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for not adequately managing the program. Craig Rieben, a spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service, acknowledged a huge backlog of endangered species cases, but he maintained the problem largely involves a lack of money. ``Working with the (budget) constraints that we are, we feel that we're doing the best job possible. That's not to say that more couldn't be done,'' he said. The internal report said it could cost as much as $4.6 billion to protect all of the presently known endangered species, while the Fish and Wildlife Service is provided about $33 million a year to administer the program. The cost of merely listing the current leading candidates for protection was estimated at $36 million. The agency's listing budget is $3.5 million. The Fish and Wildlife Service has put about 50 plants or animals on the threatened or endangered list yearly, but has a backlog of 601 applications where the species probably deserve immediate protection, the investigators said. An additional 3,000 species are suspected of being endangered, but ``are receiving little or no protection'' while they await the federal review, the report added. It estimated that at the current pace it would take the agency almost 50 years to bring those species under the protection of federal law. The Endangered Species Act, enacted in 1969 to protect species in danger of extinction, has been under attack in recent months, largely because of a bitter controversy over how to protect the Northwest's spotted owl. The Fish and Wildlife Service last summer declared the owl threatened, and the Bush administration has been trying to come up with a way to protect the bird while limiting the loss of 20,000 jobs in the timber industry. The owls are rapidly dying off because of intense cutting in the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. Any owl protection plan is likely to include restrictions in cutting. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan caused an uproar last summer among environmentalists when he suggested the endangered species law be made more flexible to take economic considerations into account in some circumstances. In its report on the enforcement of the law, the department's investigators concluded the Fish and Wildlife Service ``has neither developed nor implemented a basic management system for effective administration of the (endangered species) program.'' It said investigators also found that in addition to the huge backlog of petitions to list species for protection, the agency has failed to develop recovery plans for many plants and animals already under the law's protection.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby would rather switch than fight. The star of NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' made good on a promise Thursday as the program dumped a disputed opening credit sequence and replaced it with the title scene from last year's show. The rejected sequence featured Cosby's television family dancing in front of a colorful mural. Last year's showed them dancing in front of the Apollo Theater marquee. The dropped sequence drew complaints from a Harlem art teacher who said students at the Creative Arts Workshop for Homeless Children got no credit for inspiring the mural. Cosby had accused workshop director Brookie Maxwell of ``trying to hold us up,'' and said his order to drop the sequence was a matter of principle. Maxwell had said the children deserved credit and should be paid if the idea was marketed. Workshop lawyer Vivian Pollack said no specific financial demands were ever made. The original mural, ``Street of Dreams,'' was painted by workshop students on a Harlem building and shows children playing and laughing. A similar mural was used in ``The Cosby Show'' title sequence. Negotiations to end the dispute, including a financial settlement offer from the show's producer, Carsey-Werner Co., failed to resolve the conflict. --- OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - Actor and peace activist Ed Asner told Oklahoma teachers they can help humanity better itself, but warned that idealism means taking risks. ``It's our responsibility and our duty to point out the wrongs we see around us,'' Asner said Thursday in a speech to the Oklahoma Education Association. Asner, best known for his portrayal of Lou Grant on two television series and a school principal on ``Bronx Zoo,'' said personal involvement is a must for teachers to convey high ideals to students. The former president of the Screen Actors Guild and backer of many humanitarian and political organizations warned educators their job is made more difficult by mass media distractions. ``I get to the kids' minds before you do,'' Asner said, quoting statistics that show children typically have viewed 5,000 hours of television by the time they start school. --- LAS VEGAS (AP) - Veteran entertainer Art Linkletter says older people can still get a kick out of life. ``I'm 78 and still alive and doing what I want to stay alive and be fulfilled,'' Linkletter told a seminar for seniors Wednesday. He encouraged them to ``save your self-esteem and your identity'' by staying young emotionally. Linkletter is author of 23 books, including his latest, ``Old Age is Not For Sissies.'' He says everyone needs ``something to hope for and something to love.'' Linkletter, the host of long-running TV shows ``House Party'' and ``People Are Funny,'' also said taking things easy shouldn't wait until old age. ``Live your life so you don't destroy yourself en route,'' he said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - ``Mod Squad'' regular Clarence Williams III, who played the ultra-hip undercover police officer Linc Hayes, returns to TV on the other side of the law in an upcoming episode of ABC's ``Gabriel's Fire.'' Williams, known on ``Mod Squad'' for his huge Afro hairstyle and delivery of late 1960s slang lines like ``Solid, man'' and ``Keep the faith, baby,'' will play a street gang leader on the Nov. 1 episode of ``Gabriel's Fire.'' Williams has appeared in few acting roles since ``The Mod Squad'' was canceled in 1973. He reprised his role in the 1979 TV movie ``The Return of the Mod Squad'' and in 1984 played the father of rock star Prince in the movie, ``Purple Rain.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Connie Chung says women in TV make tongues wag more than their male counterparts, especially when there's a hint of conflict. Speaking about NBC newswoman Jane Pauley's sudden departure from the ``Today'' show earlier this year and her replacement by the younger Deborah Norville, Chung said the change got more attention because the central figures were women. ``When Chris Wallace and Bryant Gumbel and Jane Pauley were on `Today' together and it didn't work out and Chris left - OK, that was a one-day story,'' Chung said in the Oct. 21 edition of Parade magazine. ``When it's a woman, like Jane ... wow!'' --- SANTA MONICA, Calif. (AP) - An obsessed fan who harassed ``Rocky'' and ``Rambo'' star Sylvester Stallone for years was ordered to stay away from the actor's home and office. Elsie Wade of Santa Monica was ordered Thursday to stay at least 200 yards away from Stallone's Malibu beach house and the offices of his White Eagle Enterprises. The order lasts three years. Stallone had sought the injunction because the woman delivered more than 200 cards and letters to his home over a two-year period, placing up to 10 letters a day in his mailbox. Stallone and Ms. Wade didn't attend the brief court session. Many Hollywood celebrities have been plagued by obsessive fans, including Johnny Carson, David Letterman, Michael J. Fox, Olivia Newton-John and Sharon Gless.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Adds Another Reversal to Series of Budget Flip-Flops
With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's apparent decision to sign yet another stopgap spending bill represents his latest reversal in a budget debate that has seen more than a few presidential flip-flops. Earlier this week, the president declared in political appearances in Texas and Iowa that he would not sign another short-term bill when the current one expires at midnight tonight. ``Lest there be any doubt, let me make clear to Congress just how serious I am about meeting that Friday deadline,'' he told a Republican audience in Dallas on Monday. ``This Friday, time's up. The American people deserve more than this stopgap government.'' But his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Thursday that Bush had decided to sign such a measure after all, so long as ``satisfactory progress'' is made by tonight toward a final budget compromise. ``We'll decide at the time (midnight tonight) what satisfactory progress is,'' Fitzwater added. The White House, sent scrambling several times over the past days to explain, interpret or deny a Bush budget turnabout, found itself in the same position once again Thursday. Asked why the president had changed his mind on whether to sign another stopgap bill, Fitzwater insisted that he really hadn't. ``The point is, we want to get a budget agreement, we want a budget. And if we've got two bills, we've been in conference, we've worked out something that's reasonable, we're willing to sign a CR to get it,'' Fitzwater said. A CR is a ``continung resolution,'' legislative jargon for a stopgap spending bill. A House-Senate conference committee must reconcile vast differences between the House-passed budget, which Bush opposes, and the Senate version, which he supports. ``The president wants to get a budget and he feels this is the best way to get one,'' Fitzwater said. So far in the deliberations on a budget for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, Bush: -Abandoned his 1988 ``read my lips: no new taxes'' campaign pledge and endorsed a package proposing $134 billion in new taxes over five years, including levies on cigarettes, alcohol, gasoline and luxury items like yachts and furs. The plan was rejected by the House. -Appeared to contradict White House chief of staff John Sununu's declaration in a television interview that the administration would not support any increase in income taxes. Bush, at a news conference early last week, said he was open to a compromise that would include higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans in exchange for a cut in capital gains taxes. -Backed away from this formula under pressure from Republican leaders, according to participants at a White House meeting at which Bush renewed his opposition to any increase in income taxes. -Added to the confusion and mixed signals as he jogged in St. Petersburg, Fla. He responded ``read my hips'' and pointed to his buttocks when asked by a reporter if he was dropping his support for a lower capital gains tax. -Suggested late last week that he could support a package to raise the top tax bracket from the current 28 percent to 31 percent if it were accompanied by a decrease in capital gains taxes to 15 percent. But then he said he wouldn't push such a plan because he didn't think it could muster enough votes to pass Congress. Bush said in political speeches this week in Dallas, Omaha, Neb., and Des Moines, Iowa, that he was ready to close down the government again, if necessary, as he did over the Columbus Day weekend. ``There have been 37 of these emergency measures since 1981 - seven in one year alone - just to keep the government's door open,'' he told the Omaha audience. ``I am sickened by such mortgaging of our children's future.'' But, Fitzwater said Thursday, ``Closing down the government is only something you do if you absolutely have to.''

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Thatcher, Neil Kinnock Exchange Gibes
DOC.TEXT: Even for the acrimonious standards of Britain's parliamentary debates, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and opposition leader Neil Kinnock exchanged some pretty tough language. Debating education policy Thursday, the Conservative prime minister called the liberal Labor Party leader a ``crypto-communist'' and he labeled her a ``crank.'' The government plans to give vouchers for parents to send children to schools of their choice and apparently to encourage schools to opt out of control by left-wing local authorities. Labor says the move is elitist. ``Of course you hate choice, of course you hate higher standards, of course you hate opportunity, you are a socialist - you are a crypto-communist!'' she shouted at Kinnock. ``It is a long time since we had quite such a tantrum from you,'' Kinnock replied. Earlier, Kinnock told Mrs. Thatcher: ``You are a crank.'' The prime minister's question time - a twice-weekly, 15-minute session - has become increasingloy rowdy and ill-tempered in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Hate Group Leader Pleads Innocent to Flag Burning
DOC.TEXT: Two white supremacists pleaded innocent Thursday to burning an Israeli flag on a sidewalk last month. A Nov. 29 trial was scheduled for Matt Hale, 19, and Steven Thornhill, 17, both from East Peoria. Each man faces a possible fine of $40 to $300 if convicted of violating a city ordinance on public burning. They are free on $50 bond. The flag was burned Sept. 23 as the two demonstrated on a street corner. Hale, leader of the American White Supremacist Party, didn't deny burning the flag and said he wants to use the case to test the ordinance banning burning. ``If someone has the right to burn the American flag, they have the right to burn the Israeli flag. I know if I had burned the American flag, I'd have the ACLU defending me,'' Hale said.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Try to Break GOP Stranglehold
DOC.TEXT: Democrats are the ones boasting about the Republican candidate seeking to replace GOP Rep. Lynn Martin in the U.S. House. Republican John Hallock is ``probably the worst candidate in the country this year,'' says Howard Schloss, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in Washington. Hallock was clocked driving 107 mph by a state trooper and has been embarrassed by public disclosure of a child support dispute with his ex-wife. ``He's gotten a lot of press for his inability to obey the law,'' Schloss said. ``He's doing everything possible to lose the race.'' Democrat John Cox hopes Hallock's problems will help him break a GOP stranglehold on the northern Illinois district. Martin is giving up her House seat to challenge Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. Rockford, where Hallock lives, anchors an eight-county GOP stronghold bordering Iowa and Wisconsin. The city has been represented in Congress by Republicans for all but two of the past 135 years. But the 1989 election of a black Democrat as Rockford mayor signaled a potential shift in voter loyalties. Cox, a lawyer, has a history of taking on entrenched Republicans. He won the first of two consecutive terms as JoDaviess County state's attorney in 1976, becoming the first Democrat elected to that post since 1933. Hallock has raised $500,000, Cox $250,000. National committees for both parties are contributing manpower and money in what is likely to be the only competitive race in the region. Republicans are counting on a boost from the Martin-Simon race. Although she trails Simon substantially in published polls, Republicans hope the Rockford-area congresswoman will draw well in her home district and pull extra votes for Hallock. Hallock, a state representative since 1979, has soft-pedaled his personal troubles and tried to shift attention to his differences with Cox on taxes. Hallock pleaded guilty last summer to a May 11 speeding ticket. A state trooper said Hallock was driving 107 mph on Interstate 55. After missing his court date, Hallock pleaded guilty to going 95 mph and paid a fine and court costs of $400. In September, Hallock was stopped for speeding in a 30 mph zone, but was released with an oral warning, state police said. ``Let's not make more of it than it is,'' Hallock said. ``I got a speeding ticket. We all make mistakes. ``It's the credentials of a candidate that's important, not his driving record.'' Hallock also has come under attack for his position on abortion. He supports the right to abortion through the first trimester of pregnancy, but not after. He has voted in the state legislature for parental notification and consent for underage girls seeking abortions. He is against federal funding of abortions. Cox staked out a pro-choice position early and has the support of abortion rights groups. Hallock has attacked Cox as a proponent of higher taxes. ``My options don't include any tax increase,'' Hallock said. ``My options are cutting the budget, collecting back taxes and a balanced budget amendment.'' Cox said he has not supported five tax increases, as Hallock says, but suggested five areas where revenue could be raised if necessary. He said he favors increasing the income tax rate for people making more than $150,000 a year from 28 percent to 35 percent, to pay for the thrift bailout ``and perhaps budget reduction.'' He criticized Hallock as a career politician who embodies the problems in Washington and the lack of public respect for government. ``The first thing we have to do is get credibility back to our leaders in Washington,'' Cox said. ``It's experienced legislators in Washington that have gotten us into the budget deficit mess.''

DOC.HEAD: Rivals Tap Washington Ties in Battle For Open House Seat
DOC.TEXT: It is 8 a.m. at La Colline, a fashionable Capitol Hill restaurant, and Connecticut Democrat Toby Moffett is trolling for campaign dollars. Suddenly, who should step around the bend - doing the same thing - but Gary Franks, Moffett's Republican opponent in the race for Connecticut's 5th District House seat. ``It was incredible,'' Moffett said. ``We just shook hands and said `hi.''' By coincidence, Moffett and Franks rented separate rooms for fund-raising breakfasts at the same time on the same day. Both candidates are tapping their Washington connections as they battle for a congressional seat that has been controlled by Republicans for 12 of the last 18 years. The seat is being vacated by Republican Rep. John Rowland, who is running for governor. ``This race will probably be in the top 20 in terms of national interest,'' said Doug Sosnick, political director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Franks, 37, is hoping to become the first black in Connecticut history to serve in Congress, his campaign says. And he would be the first black Republican in the House since 1935. The alderman from Waterbury, Conn., is one of three black Republicans running for the House this year. Moffett, 46, is a liberal-leaning Democrat seeking to return to Congress, where he served four terms from another district. He moved so he could seek the open House seat. Moffett ``wandered into the wrong district,'' says Franks. During the campaign, Franks has hobnobbed at the White House with President Bush. Both are Yale University graduates and were campus athletes. Bush is committed to a campaign swing through Connecticut before Election Day. The Republican Party also promised to provide Franks' campaign the maximum $63,000 in cash and in-kind contributions. In the current political climate, insider status can be a disadvantage. So Moffett is trying to exploit Franks' ties to Washington. ``We just can't match that,'' he said of Franks' ability to draw attention and campaign visits from GOP bigwigs. ``They just drop in on you like paratroopers; a Cabinet member a day, the president.'' But Moffett has ties of his own. The Democrat has tapped into alliances formed during his years on Capitol Hill to pick up $120,565 from political action committees. Moffett also has used his status as an ex-congressman to lobby on the House floor against decreases in Medicaid benefits. Franks calls Moffett ``a tax-and-spend career politician.'' Trying not to seem too much the insider, Franks notes that he disagrees with the president on the deficit-reducing budget plan because it calls for tax increases. He also claims underdog status in the race. Moffett ``has higher name ID than a little alderman from Waterbury,'' he says. Moffett frequently refers to Franks as ``a creature of the Republican National Committee'' and brands his opponent as too conservative for Connecticut. ``The Republican Party is controlled by conservatives and the conservatives think Franks will be another Jesse Helms,'' Moffett said. ``He forgot where he came from and I didn't.'' Sosnick says the Republicans desperately want a black to win. But Mark Nuttle, executive director of the Republican National Congressional Committee, said, ``It makes no difference whether you're black or white.'' The goal, he said, is holding onto the seat now held by Rowland, a Republican, and defeating Moffett, a well-known Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Candidate Cautioned By Medical Board, Alleges GOP `Dirty Trick'
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky's medical licensure board chided Dr. Harvey Sloane, the Democratic nominee for U.S. Senate, for writing prescriptions with an expired federal drug registration. But the board said Thursday no formal sanction was warranted. Sloane said the inquiry into his writing prescription refills for himself was ``a carefully orchestrated ... Republican dirty trick.'' A spokesman for Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell accused Sloane of ``outrageous lies.'' It was the second inquiry by the state Board of Medical Licensure into Sloane's prescriptions. Last fall, the board advised Sloane to stop prescribing sleeping pills for himself. Sloane, who no longer has an active medical practice, said he wrote refills of the pills because of arthritis pain in his hip and back pain from a degenerative disk disease. He did not write the original prescriptions. The inquiry was prompted by the disclosure that Sloane's Drug Enforcement Administration permit to write prescriptions had expired in February 1987.
DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Ready to Unleash $1.6 Million
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Jay Rockefeller has $1.6 million on hand for the remainder of his campaign against Republican challenger John Yoder. The West Virginia Democrat already has outspent Yoder by a rate of 47 to 1. Rockefeller has spent $917,293 compared with Yoder's $19,338, according to financial records filed in connection with the campaign. Rockefeller spent $11.7 million in 1980 to be re-elected governor and $12.1 million in 1984 to be elected to the Senate, both records for the state.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Smith $300,000 For Election Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A judge denied an heir to the du Pont fortune the $300,000 he requested from a trust to finance his independent campaign for Congress. Thursday's denial by Anthony R. Appel, a Lancaster County judge assigned to the case by the state Supreme Court, marks the second such failure this week for Lewis du Pont Smith. Smith, 33, a follower of political extremist Lyndon LaRouche, is running against Republican Rep. Richard Schulze, aneight-term incumbent, and Democrat Sam Stretton, a West Chester attorney.
DOC.HEAD: Rinfret Going Greyhound To Debate
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret says he will be going by Greyhound bus to the first full-scale debate of the campaign. Rinfret, a millionaire Manhattan economist, says he is demonstrating how strapped for money his campaign is. He will take the bus from New York City to Syracuse for the Friday night debate.
DOC.HEAD: Exon's Wife Says Drinking Allegations Have Hurt Family
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jim Exon's wife says allegations that her husband has a drinking problem have caused her family considerable pain. ``It's hard on our children to hear things about their father that they know aren't true,'' Pat Exon said at a fund-raising event here for her husband, a two-term Democratic senator who is seeking a third term against Republican Hal Daub. Mrs. Exon was referring to allegations former Sen. John Tower made that Exon had a reputation as one of the heaviest drinkers in the Senate. Tower made the comments during a campaign stop for Daub in Nebraska last week.
DOC.HEAD: Wilson Criticized For Campaign Contributions
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists called Republican gubernatorial candidate Pete Wilson ``Pesticide Pete'' for accepting $80,909 in campaign money from the pesticide industry. Wilson's campaign said the environmentalists were engaging in smear tactics. The National Toxics Campaign said Wilson ranked third in the U.S. Senate among recipients of pesticide industry contributions between 1983 and 1988. The organization said Wilson ranked behind Sen. Steve Simms, R-Idaho, and Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. ``We had been wondering why Pete Wilson decided to oppose `Big Green' (environmental initiative Proposition 128), and now we've finally got an answer that makes sense,'' said Sierra Club member Bob Hattoy. Wilson spokesman Otto Bos accused the National Toxics Campaign of a ``big lie.'' He said Wilson was ranked ``third-best Republican in the entire U.S. Senate on the environment by the national League of Conservation Voters.... The voters are much smarter than to fall for the `big lie,''' Bos said. He did not dispute, however, that Wilson received the contributions.

DOC.HEAD: Capitol Springs Leak, Adding to Lawmakers' Woes
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: As if Congress didn't have enough trouble, now the roof is leaking. Already besieged by a storm of criticism for its handling of the budget crisis, Congress experienced a rainstorm Thursday that caused a massive leak in the Capitol Dome and shredded flags flying over congressional office buildings. Crews quickly threw plastic sheets over statues and leather upholstered benches in the Rotunda as puddles formed on the floor. ``This is symbolic of what is happening to our government,'' Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., said while rain dripped down a marble likeness of Abraham Lincoln. Fatigue is taking its toll on lawmakers as debate, droning on practically around the clock, moves Congress painfully toward the end of its 101st session. The Republican side of the House burst into angry shouting late Wednesday when Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., was awakened from a nap in time to break a 206-206 tie on a vote that would change U.S. policy toward Angola. ``You already said time had expired,'' screamed Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn. But the speaker overruled the protest. ``Tempers are pretty short around here,'' Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said Thursday. Even in the Senate, where time has never been an object and long-winded pontification is high art, enough was getting to be enough. ``The speeches have been persuasive, the speeches have been powerful, the speeches have been emotional, most of all the speeches have been plentiful,'' Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said during debate on deficit-reduction. ``If we could have charged fees for the speeches made in this chamber on the need to reduce the deficit, we could have reduced the deficit just by that fee. We could have a balanced budget by now. In fact we would have a surplus,'' Mitchell said. ``People look puffy,'' said news photographer Wally McNamee. Three other photographers sitting at lunch with him nodded, commenting on which members of Congress looked the most tired. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., acting as president pro tempore Thursday, announced a Senate vote as 45-57 and reporters dutifully wrote it down. Minutes passed before anyone noticed it totaled 102, two more than the full membership of the Senate. Weary elevator operators, working 15-hour days, slumped in the corners of their lifts. ``You get tired and you miss your kids and your family misses you,'' said a cashier in the House restaurant, which stays open as long as members are debating on the floor. The eight months pregnant wife of a top Democratic staffer said that if the lawmakers didn't finish their work soon, ``they're going to have divorce lawyers walking around the halls of Congress.'' Still, there was some room for humor. In the lounge area off the House chamber, a photographer was taking pictures of the members for their voting identification cards next year, even though they're all facing election next month. ``That's the overconfidence booth over there,'' said Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass. ``That's the `What, me worry?' booth.'' Sitting for his official photo, Rep. Bob Wise, W.Va., quipped: ``With the anti-incumbent thing out there, it makes you feel good for a little while.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Seek Man Who Parachuted From St. Paul's Cathedral
DOC.TEXT: Police today sought a man who parachuted 100 feet from a balcony to the floor of St. Paul's Cathedral. Dozens of tourists and clerics visiting the Whispering Gallery in the London landmark saw the stunt Thursday, which police and church officials condemned as dangerous and irresponsible. After landing, the man shed his small oblong-shaped parachute and ran into the street, disappearing in the afternoon crowds. The casually dressed man appeared to be in his early 20s.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Researchers Killed Birds in Oil Spill Study
DOC.TEXT: Alaska oil spill researchers killed as many as 350 birds this summer as part of a study commissioned by the federal government, a newspaper reported. The researchers fitted the dead birds with radio transmitters and smeared some with oil, then tossed the bodies into the sea to track their progress, The Sacramento Bee reported Thursday. The federal government commissioned the $600,000 study to help its case against Exxon Corp., owner of the tanker that ran aground and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound in March 1989, the newspaper said. By tracking the dead birds, researchers hope to develop a formula to estimate the number of birds killed in the spill. During a highly publicized program after the spill, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said 797 birds had been rescued, cleaned and released, the newspaper said. Thousands more birds were believed to have died then. The birds killed this summer were shot on islands, most in national wildlife refuges, outside the spill zone, the newspaper said without providing specifics. The birds included murres, scoters, common eiders, cormorants, ancient murrelets and auklets. The research was conducted by a Portland, Ore., company, Ecological Consulting Inc., under a contract with the U.S. Department of Justice and the Fish and Wildlife Service, the Bee said. The study is among a series of research projects upon which the federal government will rely to try to prove natural resources damages. Jack Hession, Alaska representative of the Sierra Club, said the study is important. ``On the other hand, it's unfortunate they had to collect live birds for the study,'' he said. ``Why didn't they use dead birds they collected last year?'' Bruce Batten, a spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service in Anchorage, said the government knew the study would be controversial. ``The Justice Department felt strongly that this study needed to be done to make its case,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Congress Challenges the President - Again
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Blame the Founding Fathers if you like, but there is still disagreement in America's third century over who decides whether to go to war - the president, Congress or both. The undeclared war in Vietnam almost tore the country apart. Today, the possibility that President Bush might send American troops into action against Iraq is driving a wedge between Congress and the executive branch. At this point, emotions are under control. There are few anti-war protests. But if Americans fight and die in the Persian Gulf the country could be torn apart again. The problem basically is a constitutional one, but don't look to the Supreme Court to settle it. Even the Warren Court, which did not shrink from controversy over segregation, gerrymandered legislatures and heavy-handed police interrogations, avoided judging the legality of the Vietnam war. The justices hoped that somehow the White House and Congress would work it out, but they never came to an agreement. The root of the problem is that the Constitution gives Congress the right to declare war while designating the president as commander-in-chief. At first blush, that may seem a workable arrangement. But the White House and Congress have been wrestling over powers of war and peace ever since. Toward the end of the Indochina war, after thousands of Americans had died in combat, Congress' decision to enact the War Powers Act in 1973 reflected widespread public disapproval of the powers assumed by the White House. Passed over President Nixon's veto, the law attempted to make sure Congress would serve as a rein on the White House in future conflicts. The law requires the president to withdraw American troops from combat or from situations of ``imminent involvement of hostilities'' within 60 days unless Congress gives its approval. The deadline can be extended by 30 days at the president's request. Some members of Congress are trying to apply the resolution to today's situation in the Persian Gulf. They are particularly anxious because Congress may adjourn late next week until mid-January. The concern is that Bush will send Americans to war while Congress is away. Secretary of State James A. Baker III assured the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday that the administration would consult with congressional leaders during the adjournment period. But Sen. Paul S. Sarbanes, D-Md., told Baker that ``consultation is not authorization.'' Sarbanes, one of several senators who challenged the administration's approach, lectured Baker: ``The notion that the president alone would be able to commit American forces in a military assault - in effect without receiving a shared decision by the Congress - is contrary to the Constitution.'' And Sen. Nancy L. Kassebaum, R-Kan., while describing herself as not a supporter of the War Powers Act, still advised Baker that ``it is the law of the land, and as long as it is the law of the land I think we have to adhere to it.'' Actually, in the 17 years of the law's existence, Congress has never required that troops be brought home. Congress tried to force the president to carry out the law only once, when Marines landed in Lebanon in 1983. But it extended the deadline for 18 months and the Marines were withdrawn in the meantime. The current debate is over who decides to go to war. Some of the members of Congress who are challenging the executive branch seem inclined to support force against Iraq. Others are skeptical of the wisdom of such a move. Among them is Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., who told Baker: ``I feel very strongly, absent some severe provocation, that it would be a tragic mistake of lasting proportions if we started the shooting.'' Ultimately, Bush may have to face the War Powers issue, although Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., drawing on his experience as a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, suggested another approach Thursday in a brief interview. Moynihan took the position the president has the authority to send U.S. troops into action under Article 25 of the U.N. Charter, which binds nations to abide by U.N. resolutions. As Moynihan explained it, the president could arrange with the Security Council to make American troops available for combat under a council resolution. But even then, the senator said, Congress would have to approve the agreement. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered the Supreme Court and the State Department for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Memo Tells How Senator Should Approach Donors
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: A document written by Sen. Alan Cranston's fund-raiser provides a textbook lesson in approaching political donors and shows that the California Democrat never did so unprepared. Ironically, Cranston, D-Calif., was told in the 1988 memo to be aware of one couple's desire ``to keep Trent Lott out of the Senate.'' Lott, R-Miss., not only won, he's now one of the six Ethics Committee members deciding how to proceed in an investigation of Cranston and four other senators involved in helping Charles H. Keating Jr., the former owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif. The committee met Thursday without taking action and was resuming deliberations today in the case of the ``Keating five'' senators. The panel is deciding whether to follow its special counsel's advice to advance its investigation of Cranston, Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich. The counsel advised dropping investigations against Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. The 1988 memo from fund-raiser Joy Jacobson provided advice on how Cranston should approach potential donors for a Democratic-run voter registration project. Keating gave $850,000 to the project, the bulk of the $1.3 million he and associates contributed to the five senators' campaigns and causes. Jacobson advised Cranston to approach a California couple ``about giving $250,000 and giving directly to the efforts in four states.'' One was Mississippi because ``it will be a priority with them to keep Lott out of the Senate.'' The memo said the couple knew Democratic Sen. Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio ``is going to have a very tough race,'' and so would Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. The memo went on: ``North Carolina: you will need to explain how this effort is building toward defeating (Republican Sen. Jesse) Helms in 1990.'' Jacobson also advised Cranston to approach Ann Cox Chambers, a daughter of Cox Communications founder James Cox, and her daughter. ``Anne is an avid Democrat who was one of Jimmy Carter's biggest supporters,'' the memo said. ``Before asking her for money, you should determine what her main political interest currently is. Rebuilding the Democratic Party in the South? (Sen. Albert) Gore (D-Tenn.) for president? Southern Senate races? etc.'' Cranston should approach Florida corporate chief executive officers, the memo said, because ``these are all companies that gave large amounts to Graham's races for governor.'' Bob Graham, a Democrat, was governor of Florida and now is one of the state's senators. The memo asked that Cranston meet with A. Dano Davis, saying: ``CEO of Winn-Dixie, we asked Graham to arrange this meeting because Winn-Dixie is one of the companies that has given to VoteAmerica, our Republican counterpart.'' Winn-Dixie is a Florida-based supermarket chain.

DOC.HEAD: Government Upgrades Probe of Taurus, Sable
DOC.TEXT: The government and Ford Motor Co. are investigating reports of brake disc corrosion in all Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models, a problem that could cause brakes to fail. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Thursday it had upgraded the probe from a preliminary evaluation - an examination of paperwork - to an engineering analysis, in which engineers will study the possibly defective parts. The investigation could result in a recall. Ford said it was conducting its own investigation of all its models that have the same brake rotor and hub assembly as the Taurus and Sable. They include the Lincoln Continental, Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar. Agency spokesman Tim Hurd said there had been six complaints of front disc brake corrosion in the Taurus and Sable. An estimated 1.8 million of the vehicles are on the road. The complaints allege that the discs deteriorate and fail. The problem has been blamed for one accident and a minor injury. The problem appears to be centered in Northern climes where roads are heavily salted in the winter, Hurd said.
DOC.HEAD: United Way Charities Face Greater Competition
DOC.TEXT: Charities not connected with the United Way are getting a larger chunk of the contributions raised through campaigns at the workplace, a report says. The report was issued Thursday by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, which has campaigned for giving workers access to newer and smaller charities that are not usually part of United Way campaigns. The committee, representing more than 300 fund-raising organizations, was established in 1976 to monitor developments in philanthropy. Alternative organizations are getting 10.1 percent of the money raised in workplace campaigns, the report said. Ten years ago, it said, alternative groups got 3.5 percent of the total. Among the alternative organizations are some health agencies such as the Muscular Dystrophy Association; international agencies such as CARE and Oxfam America; arts funds; the United Negro College Fund; and agencies that raise money for social action causes and women's and environmental groups. All told, United Way campaigns are expected to raise $3.2 billion in contributions this year, two-thirds of it through payroll deductions and other employee contribution programs. Organizations not under the United Way umbrella are expected to raise $205 million from employee contribution programs.
DOC.HEAD: Surgeon General Expresses Concern About Fortified Wine Product
DOC.TEXT: Young people may be drinking a fortified wine product - containing 20 percent alcohol - unaware it is far more potent than wine coolers, the surgeon general says. Surgeon General Antonia Novello said Thursday ``it scares me to death'' that people, particularly young people, may buy Cisco without realizing its high alcohol content. She said she is especially concerned that in some states the product can be sold in convenience stores, and is often placed in stores next to wine coolers, which have about 4 percent alcohol. Ordinary table wines have about 12 percent alcohol content. Others, including the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, also have expressed concern about the product, made by Canandaigua Wine Co. in Canandaigua, N.Y. ``This poses a serious safety and health risk,'' said Christine Lubinski, a spokeswoman for the council's Washington office. A 100-pound person who drinks two 375 milliliter bottles of Cisco within an hour could die from acute alcohol poisoning, she said. A 150-pound person who drinks one bottle within an hour would have a blood-alcohol content level of 0.11, which is more than the legal limit for driving in all states but Georgia, she said.

Member is CQ, it does look closer to 4 percent. But the $53,400 appears on a Social Security fact sheet the author used. However, it should be a 5.4 percent increase. We'll have to wait until tmw to see if Soc Sec made mistake. WX gbd

DOC.HEAD: Three Supremacists Convicted of Plotting To Bomb Gay Disco
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury Thursday convicted three white supremacists of plotting to firebomb a gay Seattle disco. The jury convicted Stephen Nelson, 35, of Hayden Lake, Robert Winslow, 29, of Laclede, and Procter James Baker, 58, of Coeur d'Alene, after deliberating three hours Wednesday night and all day Thursday, said Jim Martin of U.S. District Judge Harold Ryan's office. During 10 days of testimony from about 50 witnesses, defense attorneys charged FBI informant Rico Renaldo Valentino encouraged the three to take action and even bankrolled them. Assistant U.S. Attorney Ron Howen rejected that allegation. He played about 100 hours of secret recordings and videotapes of the defendants as they said the back alley of the nightclub would resemble a ``meat grinder'' when the homemade bombs exploded. The recorded conversations also included profanity-laced talk of blowing up a Jewish synagogue and killing and maiming minorities in the Puget Sound region. ``This is not just some fantasy,'' Howen said Wednesday in his closing argument. ``This is real.'' ``We were here because of what they did, not what they talked about,'' Howen said after the ruling. ``They were constructing a device for the purpose of killing, wounding and maiming people.'' The trio is tied to the white separatist Aryan Nations (Church of Jesus Christ, Christian) at Hayden Lake. Rev. Richard Butler, founder of the white-separatist group, testified Valentino displayed lots of money and bravado around the defendants. Butler earlier beat charges he intended to overthrow the government. He declined to comment after Thursday's verdict. Nelson and Winslow face up to 25 years in prison. They were convicted of conspiracy to bomb; knowingly making, receiving or possessing bombs or grenades; carrying firearms in relation to a crime of violence; and crossing state lines to commit a crime. The two were arrested May 12 near Seattle as they accompanied Valentino in his van containing hidden FBI microphones. Inside the van, FBI agents found the makings of a firebomb: a one-pound can of smokeless explosive powder, a portion of steel pipe and screw-on end caps, fuse and a propane tank. Also discovered were a loaded shotgun and revolver belonging to Nelson. Baker was arrested the same night at his Coeur d'Alene home. A search of his Kendrick cabin yielded a partially assembled pipe bomb. He was found guilty of conspiracy and bomb-possession counts, which carries imprisonment of up to 15 years. Sentencing was set for Jan. 11. Valentino, a 53-year-old former professional wrestler who once performed as the ``Masked Avenger,'' posed as a tax protester fleeing the Internal Revenue Service to infiltrate the Aryan Nations for 3{ years.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Gives Budget OK, to Seek Compromise With House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, should stand for AMs; roll call planned
DOC.TEXT: The Senate passed a bipartisan budget early Friday aiming the sting of deficit-reduction at virtually all Americans, raising taxes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco while paring Medicare and other programs. Lawmakers adopted the measure 54-46, paving the way for bargaining with the House and President Bush over a compromise bill that could end the year-long budget stalemate. Negotiations were set to begin later Friday. ``This is the first step we must take to reduce the staggering deficits that are essentially bleeding us dry,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The House has approved legislation relying heavily on tax hikes on the wealthy to close the federal deficit. It contains no change in the current 9 cents a gallon gasoline tax, which the Senate would boost to 18{ cents. Both versions slash spending on programs ranging from agriculture to veterans' benefits. The Senate approved the bill shortly before 1:30 a.m., ending a long day that saw lawmakers dump an attempt to scale back the gas tax increase and substitute a series of tax increases on the wealthy. ``Let's go and get it from those who've got it,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., but her plea was rejected, 55-45. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president was prepared to sign separate legislation keeping the government in funds through next Wednesday. The House approved the measure 379-37, and its expected quick approval by the Senate would avert the threat of a second government shutdown in two weeks. With the immediate crisis of a closed-down government solved, a new non-fiscal problem emerged. The famous Capitol dome sprung a leak during a rainstorm, forcing workers to cover statues with plastic sheets and prompting metaphorical comparisons between Congress' home and its budget process. Lawmakers' eyes were on the calendar, with Election Day less than three weeks off. To diffuse possible blame, Senate leaders crafted a broadly based collection of $250 billion worth of new taxes and spending reductions. Leading Democrats promised to try to change the bill during negotiations with the House, though Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, acknowledged, ``We can't guarantee the result.'' The president had said as recently as Monday that he would not sign another emergency spending-authorization extension, but press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said late Thursday that Bush would sign a bill keeping the government going through next Wednesday if ``satisfactory progress'' was being made. Without such an extension, the government's authority to spend money would expire Friday night. But the president also took the offensive, trying to turn the tables on House Democrats who have spent the last few weeks accusing him of protecting the rich. He said most Americans would be hurt by a House provision delaying annual inflation adjustments in income-tax brackets and personal exemptions. ``The opposition is trying to say `favor the rich,''' Bush said. ``I'm saying I'm favoring incentives, investment, and ... protecting the working men and women of this country.'' As senators neared the end of debate, they voted 69-31 for items sought by airlines.
