Many local noise restrictions would be superseded by federal rules to be written later, and limits on flights into and out of airports in New York and Chicago would be slightly relaxed. The tax increases and spending cuts were to be the lion's share of $500 billion worth of deficit cuts over the next five years, including $40 billion this year. Most of the rest of the savings would come from defense cuts in separate legislation. Although that Senate-House bargaining was not expected to begin formally until Thursday evening, some lawmakers were already beginning to glimpse the shape of a final package. House Democrats meeting privately early in the day were told by leaders that some gasoline tax increase was virtually inevitable, said one lawmaker who demanded anonymity. But they said they would demand some form of higher taxes on the rich in return. The House approved no gasoline tax increase in its budget. But Democrats at the meeting seemed to agree that if the 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax was boosted by 6 cents, ``most of us wouldn't go crazy,'' the lawmaker said. ``The major issue with us in the House is hanging onto some notion of progressivity,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. House Budget Committee Chirman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said he believed the House would also drop its provision halting, for one year, the annual inflation adjustment made in income-tax brackets and the personal exemption. Several Senate Republicans said they were not immovably opposed to boosting the tax rate on the richest Americans to 31 percent from its current 28 percent - depending on what trade-off they received. ``The real question is whether 31 percent is OK with the president,'' said Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis. ``We've just been told 31 percent is not OK, but we've also seen the president change his mind before.'' Just a week ago, Bush repeatedly shifted his position on whether he would accept higher taxes on the rich. The president also had earlier said he would close the government unless a deficit-reduction deal was completed by Friday night - a deadline Congress seems all but certain to miss. But the White House softened that Wednesday, saying the requirement was for substantial progress in the right direction. The Senate measure limits deductions for people earning more than $100,000, imposes the 1.45 percent Medicare tax on the paychecks of many upper-middle class people for the first time, and boosts levies on yachts and furs. It also raises the 9-cent-a-gallon federal gasoline tax to 18{ cents by 1992, increases levies on alcohol and tobacco products, and makes Medicare benefits a bit less generous for 33 million elderly and handicapped people. In contrast, majority Democrats pushed their own bill through the House Tuesday that leans much more heavily on the country's wealthy - a theme they hope will improve the party's election prospects. The House bill raises the income-tax rate on the richest Americans from 28 percent to 33 percent and adds a 10 percent tax on people earning $1 million annually. It guarantees that no matter how many deductions are claimed, a wealthy person would pay income taxes of no less than 25 percent, an increase from the current 21 percent. The House measure reduces Medicare benefits by less than the Senate would, and contains similar tax increases on alcohol, tobacco and luxury items. But it gives a modest tax break to middle-class people who sell property.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged After Tape of Child Abuse Found
DOC.TEXT: A former maintenance man in this Washington suburb is being held in a Texas jail on a morals charge after police said a videotape showing him sexually abusing a 6-year-old girl was found in his abandoned car. William Boyd McIntyre, 29, was arrested in New Boston, Texas, on Tuesday and charged with indecency with a child by sexual contact, a felony, police said. He was lodged in a Texarkana, Texas, jail in lieu of $50,000 bail. Police said McIntyre's car, found abandoned in Interstate 95, was about to be demolished last month at a wrecking yard when a workman found the tape. He took it home, played it and then turned it over to police after seeing scenes of a man molesting a young girl. New Boston Police Chief Kerry Pinkham told The Washington Post that Fairfax police traced McIntyre to the Texas community, where the young girl and McIntyre both resided. Authorities said the tape was made in December 1987 and that the girl, now 9, apparently has no memory of the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Learning the Blues: Musicians Prepare for Their `Bar Exam'
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: All you need to know to get into the Chicago Blues Ensemble is how to pluck out a couple of chords and sing in the shower. By the end of an eight-week course, students are transformed into toe-tapping, hard-playing blues performers with dark glasses and a new attitude. They're ready for their final exam - in a local bar. ``Blues is the people's music,'' said Jon Spiegel, one of the ensemble's directors. ``If you can plant the seed of obsession, then it's really great. After that, you just stand back and steer.'' The training is open to all instruments and some students bring in violins or dulcimers, but most favor guitars, pianos, basses and harmonicas. Everybody has to sing a solo before they're through, and the lessons teach more than music, Spiegel said. ``You can see the change in the students,'' he said. ``They first come in wearing oxford shirts, and by the end of the eight weeks they're wearing sharkskin suits and wide ties.'' The program is offered by the Old Town School of Folk Music. Typically, about 45 students of varying experience levels separate to work in small groups. Most take music lessons during the week and meet each Wednesday to apply the theories they've learned. ``You get a lot out of playing with other people of all levels and from all walks of life,'' said George Minkel of Bridgeview. ``I've been a closet player for years. So this is wonderful.'' Directors help students develop the best group sound, while focusing on the emotional extremes that are the root of the blues, Spiegel said. ``Play an angry note,'' Spiegel told a bass player during one of the Wednesday night sessions. The student answered with a screeching sound that bounced off the walls and echoed through the room. ``Now, play one that's real sublime,'' Spiegel said. The responding tone wafted mellowly around the room. The group then played a rendition of the blues standard ``Crossroads,'' with Rich Yeater, a mild-mannered computer consultant, pounding the piano keys and belting out the lyrics. ``It's the first time I've done this,'' he said after his solo singing debut. ``It's exciting, very different and a lot of fun. Playing with a group forces you to be more disciplined.'' Final exams take place in a local bar where the groups take the stage during an open microphone night. ``The best thing about this class is that, while they probably won't be the best group up there, they definitely won't be the worse,'' Spiegel said. Some of the ensemble groups go on to perform regularly, but few are willing to quit their day jobs for life in Chicago's smoky blues clubs. ``Well, the option's always open,'' said Kevin Hauser, a 35-year-old train conductor and guitar player from suburban Elmhurst. ``I'll wait to see if the audience wants an encore after our first session.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Child Care Plan
With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A $15 billion child care bill, including grants to states and a tax credit for poor families, was approved by the Senate today as part of a deficit-reducing tax package. Senate leaders reached agreement with the Bush administration earlier in the week on a scaled-down version of a bill providing assistance to working families with children. They put the package into the budget bill and sent it back to the House in an effort to break a year-long stalemate and bypass a conference committee that has been unable to resolve differences. Rep. Gus Hawkins, D-Calif., chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, called the Senate version disappointing and said he would seek changes. The central element of the bill, $13 billion over five years, is an expansion of the earned-income tax credit for low-income working families with children. The cost would be offset by a continuation of the 3 percent telephone excise tax, which otherwise would expire at year-end. The other major element is a new program of grants to the states for child care assistance. States could pass along the money directly to families to offset part of their child care costs, or the money could go as a subsidy to day care centers. The Senate bill would provide $2.5 billion over three years for those grants, with money in the final two years to be negotiated later. That is less than what House sponsors sought. Church-run child care centers would be eligible for the money. To reach agreement with the White House, Senate Democrats accepted reduced federal safety and quality standards for child care providers from previous versions of the bill, and removed provisions expanding money for the Head Start child-development program. Also eliminated is a provision passed by the House to provide money for local governments to establish after-school child care programs based in the public schools. Another key difference is in the structure of the grant program. House sponsors wanted the program established under the Social Security Act, which would make it an entitlement program that is automatically in the budget. The Senate's version would require the program to compete for appropriations each year. Federal child care assistance was backed by both presidential candidates in 1988, but the issue has been stuck in conference committee since clearing the House and Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Hold Carbon Dioxide Emissions Down to Present Levels
DOC.TEXT: Japan is planning a sweeping program to keep carbon dioxide emissions from rising beyond 1990 levels in order to help stop global warming, the governing Liberal Democratic Party said. The plan will be presented to the Cabinet for approval on Tuesday, a party official said Thursday. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the plan calls for more solar energy, nuclear power, hydraulic power and rail transportation. It also includes using heat from trash incinerators to generate electricity and developing low-pollution automobiles. The Environment Agency said Japan discharges 2.5 tons of carbon dioxide per person each year, twice the world average but about half that of the United States. Carbon dioxide from the burning of oil and coal are blamed for the ``greenhouse effect,'' which raises world atmospheric temperatures and could cause harmful changes in the weather.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Missile Frigate Rescues 50 Vietnamese Boat People
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy guided-missile frigate rescued 50 Vietnamese refugees aboard a disabled wooden boat floating in the South China Sea, a Navy spokesman said. The refugees had been at sea for about 10 days when the USS Curts found their 25-foot boat on Tuesday, Lt. Lee Saunders, spokesman for the Navy's 7th Fleet, said Thursday. He said the boat was crowded and found not to be seaworthy, and the Vietnamese were allowed to board the frigate. The boat was found about 350 miles off the coast of the Philippines. Saunders said the refugees would be taken to the Philippines and turned over to authorities. The Navy frigate is based in Yokuska, Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Reaction And Fear Of Clashes Prevent Non-Smoking Flights
DOC.TEXT: Fear of in-flight clashes between militant smokers and non-smokers has prompted Lufthansa to drop plans to ban smoking on domestic flights, the airline says. The national German carrier had planned to ban smoking on the flights with the start of its winter schedule on Oct. 28. But Lufthansa said Thursday that passenger reaction to its plans had been ``extremely divided,'' although a majority of smokers had indicated their willingness to accept the ban. But since federal lawmakers had decided not to pass no-smoking legislation, barring smoking on flights could lead to ``polarization and confrontations among passengers,'' the airline said. It said it could not allow passengers and cabin crews to be involved in such situations. Smoking is banned on U.S. domestic flights.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Resigns Over Differences With Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Safa Giray has resigned, becoming the second minister in a week to leave the government, according to news reports. In a letter to Prime Minister Yildirim Akbulut, Giray said he was stepping down because he was ``convinced that the relationship of trust between us has been damaged,'' the semiofficial Anatolia news agency reported Thursday. The report did not elaborate, and further information was not immediately available. Giray, 59, a civil engineer, had been defense minister since March 1989 and served in all Cabinets since 1983. Foreign Minister Ali Bozer resigned last Friday after Turkish media reports that President Turgut Ozal had taken over foreign policy matters.

DOC.HEAD: Libya to Halt Transport, Communications on `Day of Mourning'
DOC.TEXT: Libya will halt all international air and sea traffic in its territory next Friday and bar international telephone calls to commemorate suffering under Italian colonial rule, Libya's official news agency said. The government will halt airline flights and sea traffic at its ports from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m., according to a dispatch Thursday from the news agency JANA, monitored in Rome. All international postal, telephone and telegram service also will be stopped during those hours, it said. Libya marks Oct. 26 as the ``Day of Mourning,'' commemorating the deportation of 4,000 Libyans to remote Italian islands during colonial rule between 1911 and World War II. In recent years, Libya has renewed claims for reparations from the colonial period. The Italian government says it met its obligations with payment of $6.7 million under a 1956 agreement with the Libyan monarchy. Gadhafi deposed the monarch in a 1969 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Four Cubans Refugees Rescued by Puerto Rico Cargo Ship
DOC.TEXT: A Puerto Rican cargo ship rescued four Cuban lifeguards who spent five days in the Atlantic in a rubber dinghy after fleeing their homeland, U.S. immigration officials said. The men set sail Saturday and were rescued Wednesday 25 miles north of Cuba, said Monserrate Diaz, a spokesman for the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. ``They're in good shape because they're all lifeguards,'' Diaz said. All four are in their 20s, he said. He said the Cubans fired flare guns when they sighted the cargo ship, the Sea Land Consumer. Diaz said the Cubans told authorities they fled their country because they wanted freedom and were ``living like prisoners.'' He did not elaborate. Officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Cubans had hoped to reach Key West, Fla., and were seeking political asylum in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Obscurities Mixed With Well-Known Classics
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Of course you film fans are familiar with the classic ``Killers of Sheep.'' Or the unforgettable ``Primary.'' How about the evergreen ``Meshes of the Afternoon''? OK, so maybe not. Those three head-scratchers were among 25 films selected to join the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress. The Registry's second list, announced Thursday in Washington, tilted heavily toward the often neglected documentary, which comprised 20 percent of the selections. Included were the admirable ``Harlan County, U.S.A.,'' Barbara Kopple's 1977 Oscar-winning study of a Kentucky coal miners' strike, and ``The River,'' Pare Lorentz's lyrical plea for soil reclamation, made for the government in 1937. The other three documentaries selected may be worthy of ``treasure'' status also, but are they more deserving than ``City Lights,'' ``Stagecoach'' or ``Rear Window,'' which didn't make the list in 1989 or this year? James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, explained that films on the list were chosen because they ``impressively display the depth and variety of the American creative spirit'' in filmmaking. ``This is not Academy Awards night,'' Billington said. ``These are not annual lists of the `best' American films.'' The new list shows a healthy regard for the comedy: Howard Hawks' wacky ``Bringing Up Baby'' from 1938; Harold Lloyd's best silent, ``The Freshman,'' from 1925; Greta Garbo's only comedy, ``Ninotchka,'' a 1939 film directed by Ernst Lubitsch; and the madcap 1933 Marx Brothers' feature, ``Duck Soup.'' The musical was recognized with the best of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, ``Top Hat,'' from 1935; the Maurice Chevalier romance, ``Love Me Tonight,'' produced and directed by Rouben Mamoulian in 1932; and Walt Disney's ``Fantasia,'' from 1940. Coincidentally, ``Fantasia'' is in re-release and winning far more praise and patronage ($11 million in 10 days) than when it was first shown. Some choices were unassailable: ``All About Eve,'' ``All Quiet on the Western Front,'' ``Dodsworth,'' ``The Godfather,'' ``Raging Bull,'' ``Red River,'' ``Rebel without a Cause,'' ``Sullivan's Travels,'' ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre.'' John Cassavetes' 1974 ``A Woman Under the Influence'' was a more idiosyncratic selection. Cassavetes was a pace-setter of the new realism, but his films, including this one, were often overlong and self-indulgent. Last year's list produced only one head-scratcher: ``The Learning Tree,'' Gordon Parks' 1969 reminiscence of his Kansas childhood, admirable but hardly a classic. Charles Burnett made ``Killers of Sheep'' in 1977, ``Meshes of the Afternoon'' is an 18-minute film directed by Maya Deren in 1943 and ``Primary'' is a Time Inc. film made in 1960. ``All About Eve'' was made in 1950 by director Joseph L. Mankiewicz. ``All Quiet on the Western Front'' was directed by Lewis Milestone in 1930. ``Dodsworth'' was a 1936 film directed by William Wyler. Francis Ford Coppola made ``The Godfather'' in 1972. Martin Scorsese directed ``Raging Bull'' in 1980. Nicholas Ray directed James Dean in ``Rebel Without a Cause'' in 1955. Hawks made ``Red River'' in 1948. ``Sullivan's Travels'' is a Preston Sturges film made in 1941. John Huston directed ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'' in 1948. Also named to the 1990 list were Edwin S. Porter's ``The Great Train Robbery,'' a 12-minute classic made in 1903; John Ford's ``How Green Was My Valley'' from 1941; and Frank Capra's ``It's a Wonderful Life'' from 1946. The 1988 law that established the National Film Registry called for 25 registry listings each year for three successive years. It requires companies to label videocassettes of films on the list that have been colorized or otherwise tampered with. This year's list was based on 1,500 nominations from the public. It was narrowed by a 14-member National Film Preservation Board representing the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the American Film Institute, movie and television producers, directors, broadcasters, screen writers, the Screen Actors Guild of America, film critics and scholars. The final choices were made by Billington, a cultural historian and movie buff, based on consultations with advisers including the staff of the library's division of motion picture, broadcasting and recorded sound. Films are eligible for the registry 10 years after their first theatrical release. They need not necessarily be American films, the library said, but the first 50 movies in the registry all were made in the United States. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Associated Press Hollywood correspondent Bob Thomas has been covering the film industry since 1944.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Support Use of Force in Gulf, Poll Finds
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A new poll indicates 70 percent of the people in Britain, Germany, France, Italy and Spain support the use of military force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. The survey, commissioned by British Kuwaitis, also says 69 percent approve of President Bush's decision to send armed forces to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. Britons are the most ``hawkish'' of the Europeans: 86 percent percent back military action to free Kuwait and 80 percent support Bush's action, according to the poll released Thursday by Gallup, a leading British poll company. In a corresponding U.S. poll, 70 percent of Americans said they supported Bush's decision to move troops into the gulf. ``It seems George Bush would do better in this country than his own,'' Gordon Heald, Gallup managing director, told a news conference. Heald said British public opinion had hardened since a Gallup poll in September, when only 75 percent supported the use of force to free Kuwait. An average of 67 percent across the five countries said they support the use of military action to protect the West's oil supplies, the survey found. Sixty-one percent overall favor military action to defend Saudi Arabia and the gulf states. Fifty-eight percent overall support the use of military force to topple Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, researchers found. Youssef al-Youssef, a spokesman for Britain's Kuwaiti community, said: ``We have always viewed Britain and the United States as being the world leaders in the gulf crisis. It is very pleasing to see this is reflected in public opinion.'' Britain, France, Italy and Spain have contributed to the U.S.-led international force which has been deployed in the Persian Gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Germany's Constitution prevents it from doing the same. Gallup questioned 500 people in each of the five countries for the poll, commissioned by the London-based Association for Free Kuwait. The margin of error is 5 percent. Heald said 86 percent of Britons support military action to free Westerners prevented from leaving Kuwait and Iraq. Sixty-three percent support military action even if it means putting hostages' lives at risk, he said. ``I find this staggering, because Britain has by far the most hostages,'' Heald said. The Foreign Office says 1,400 Britons are still trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. In France, the survey found, 75 percent support military action to free Kuwait, and 82 percent back military action to free the hostages. But only 49 percent support military action if it means putting hostages at risk. Seventy-three percent are firmly behind Bush's response to the Iraqi invasion. In Germany, 63 percent favor the use of force to free Kuwait, 70 percent back military action to free the hostages and 75 percent support Bush's decision. Heald said Spain and Italy were the least supportive: only 59 percent of Italians and 66 percent of Spaniards back military action to free Kuwait. Only 59 percent of Italians and 53 percent of Spaniards approve of Bush's decision to move troops into the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvian Guerrillas Dozen Targets, Including German Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas bombed the German Embassy, power lines and about 10 other targets, blacking out half of the capital, police said. Police had no immediate details on casualties or damage from the attacks Thursday night, but early reports indicated a private guard was killed in an attack that set a steel foundry afire. The Shining Path guerrillas also lit fires in the shape of the communist hammer and sickle on hills above Lima, typical of their night attacks. Police said they detained 400 suspects. The guerrillas carried out at least a dozen attacks simultaneously Thursday evening, said police. Targets included a shopping center, a police station, state mining company offices and a hydroelectrical station. The rebels bombed high tension towers on the outskirts of the capital, blacking out half of Lima, police said. Television reports showed extensive damage to the arage of the German Embassy, and witnesses said they saw a woman place an explosive at the garage door. The embassy had no immediate comment. The Maoist Shining Path have often attacked embassies in the past, calling them ``representatives of imperialism.'' The attacks broke a lull in violence in the capital. Human rights groups say more than 500 people were killed in September, the highest toll of the year, but few attacks occurred in Lima.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Version of Orwell's `1984' to Premiere in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union soon will be watching Big Brother. The movie version of George Orwell's bleak classic ``1984,'' depicting the terrifying world of an omnipresent government, will have its Soviet premiere in the next few months, its executive producer said. Marvin J. Rosenblum, a Chicago lawyer who bought the rights for the movie in 1980 from Orwell's widow, said the film will be shown in Moscow in conjunction with a conference sponsored by the Cinemacentre on ``Art, Politics and Freedom of Expression.'' ``It's like breaking down the Berlin Wall,'' Rosenblum said Thursday night. Orwell wrote his fictional account of total conformity, thought control and constant surveillance in 1948 and published it in 1949. The Soviet government didn't even acknowledge its existence until 1984, when it published a review. Excerpts from the novel, including the omnipresent warning of Orwell's imaginary regime that ``Big Brother is Watching You,'' first were published in Soviet newspapers in 1988 as tight restrictions on information eased under Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. But Soviet people had read copies smuggled into the country, Rosenblum said. ``I've talked to a lot of Russians, and there's always been a lot of interest in it. All the intellectuals are aware of it.'' While a date for the showing has not been set, Rosenblum said he expects it will come in early December or January. He is about to begin negotiations with Soviet distributors for nationwide showings of the film, made in 1984 and starring John Hurt and Richard Burton in his last movie before his death that year. No political problems exist in negotiating a distribution contract, Rosenblum said. Previously only one agency had permission to import films, but that has changed. ``Now just about anybody can do it,'' Rosenblum said, adding that a person must be sure whom he's dealing with to make sure he gets paid. ``I'm willing to take payment in rubles,'' he said. ``I'm just going to look for a reputable distributor who's going to do a good job getting it out to the Russian people.'' The film has been shown in at least 20 countries, but not in most of the Soviet bloc. Rosenblum bought the rights to distribute the film in the Soviet Union for an undisclosed amount from the British company Virgin Vision, whose parent company had put up the $8 million to film the story. Orwell wrote ``1984'' in 1948 as the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union was turning into a deep freeze. Orwell said the novel was meant to depict any totalitarian government, left or right, and not the Soviet Union in particular. But the book was often read as an indictment of the Soviet system and became required reading in many American high schools. A generation of students learned of the world of doublespeak where war means peace, the Ministry of Truth disburses lies and the Thought Police can set straight anyone who doesn't love Big Brother. An earlier movie version of ``1984'' came out in 1955 and was received so poorly Orwell's widow vowed never to let it be filmed again.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves 23 Diplomatic Nominees
DOC.TEXT: The Senate early today approved 23 of President Bush's nominees for diplomatic posts, but only after Republican leaders threatened to hold GOP opponents of the nominations on duty for an all-night session. Among the nominees approved on a block vote, after the Senate completed action on a deficit-reduction bill, was George Fleming Jones as ambassador to the tiny South American state of Guyana. Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and a frequent thorn in the side of State Department officials, had vehemently opposed Jones' nomination. However, ``holds'' that any single senator can put on a nominee to block or delay Senate confirmation were removed from the 23 nominees Thursday after Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas suggested keeping the Senate in session through the night to act on them. ``These people have families and have made plans,'' Dole said. ``It's unfair to keep them twisting in the wind.'' Under the Senate's complex parliamentary rues, continuing to block their confirmation would have required opponents - but hardly anyone else - to remain on the Senate floor. Helms, according to sources who asked not to be identified, has suspected Jones, a career foreign service officer, of being involved in the 1986 leak of a secret Chilean report about the death of an American during a violent protest in Santiago. The senator was infuriated when his own office was blamed for the leak. Among the other nominations of career foreign service officers confirmed to ambassadorial posts today were Eugene Scassa for Belize, Richard C. Brown for Uruguay, Michael Martin Skol for Venezuela, Stephen Rogers for Swaziland and Gordon L. Streeb for Zambia.

DOC.HEAD: British Judge Says George Washington Innocent Of Treason
LaserPhoto LON4 of Oct. 18
DOC.TEXT: George Washington has been found innocent of treason against the British crown in a mock trial which featured real British and American judges and lawyers and actors playing historical figures. The participants playing Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin and Lord North, the British prime minister during the American Revolution, testified at the trial set in 1779, which was filmed Thursday for television. The American statesmen, in 18th century dress, were played by members of the Philadelphia-based Royal Pickwickians, a troupe which combines acting with historical research. North was played by Prof. Bruce Collins also in period costume. Washington, speaking through Bill Sommerfield, who played him, said he was elated by the unanimous ruling of the three judges. ``Justice has been done,'' he said. ``We've been vindicated and now I must go back and pursue the war with vigor and bring it to a just conclusion.'' The armistice ending the Revolutionary War was not announced until 1783. The team of American defense attorneys argued that Washington acted in self-defense since the British had declared war in effect with their litany of abuses, hurting the colonists economically and depriving them of liberties. ``We have a right to defend ourselves to resist those acts of tyranny,'' James Figliulo, another Chicago lawyer told the court. ``We ask only to be free, we ask only to govern ourselves. We tried time and time again to address our grievances and make our point. Those petitions, remonstrances and requests were repeatedly rejected by the Parliament and the King.'' The defense argued that Lord North and King George III had treated the colonists like slaves. Prosecuting Washington under the Treason Act of 1351 was Sydney Kentridge, the human rights lawyer who defended Steven Biko in South Africa. He argued that the conditions in the colonies could not have been so bad since 221,000 people had migrated to America between 1760-75. ``The moral pretensions of this case are ill-founded,'' Kentridge said. ``What is this slavery that the Colonies say they have, which thousands of people cross the Atlantic to be part of.'' In his summing up, Kentridge called on the three judges hearing the case not to find Washington guilty of treason which is punishable by hanging, but to ``make a declaration that Washington was guilty of treason,'' and allow him to return to America. The three judges - Lord Bridge of Harwich, a senior Law Lord; Sir Patrick Neill, a British appellate judge; and U.S. Federal Judge A. Sherman Christensen from Utah - ruled that the way Britain governed the colonies forced the Americans to react. The colonists ``only as a last resort, were driven to the Declaration of Independence,'' Lord Bridge said. The defense attorneys' wives and other Americans, in the audience of 280 which paid $34 to watch the trial, waved tiny colonial American flags as the verdict was announced. The International Scholarships for Young Lawyers will receive the proceeds from the trial, which will be shown at a later date on British and U.S. television. The trial came about after Lord Goff, a member of the House of Lords made the treason charge at a June meeting of the American Inns of Court Foundation. Lawyers from Chicago and New Jersey took up the gauntlet and traveled to the history-laden Lincoln's Inn for the trial. The Inn, an oasis of Georgian office buildings and tidy gardens in central London, was founded in the 14th century. It is the oldest of four Inns of Court which train and admit barristers, lawyers who argue cases in Britain's senior courts. Barristers-in-training must spend 18 months following senior barristers through the courts and the Inns, so-called because many barristers used to work and live there.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly, Stock Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar firmed against the yen Friday in Tokyo for the first time in two weeks, while this week's bullishness on the stock market continued. Although it opened at a 22-month low of 124.75 yen, the dollar regained lost ground to finish at 125.25, up .85 yen from Thursday's close of 124.40 yen. The currency ranged between 124.05 yen and 125.45 yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,481.49, up 114.41 points, or .47 percent, from Thursday's close of 24,367.08 points. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds fell slightly to 84.53 points at 2 a.m. EDT from their previous close of 84.73. Their yield rose to 7.795 percent from 7.750 percent. Currency dealers said caution among buyers about the weekend, typical on Fridays, prevailed. ``Market players are wary about the speed of the dollar's fall yesterday. So the dollar will not fall radically today, unless for some reason it drops below 123 yen,'' said Katsunobu Motohashi of Yasuda Trust and Banking. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said Friday he was not considering any measures to support the dollar. The dollar's decline is not ``abnormal'' or ``too fast,'' he said. Buyers were also cautious on the stock exchange, traders said. Many were stalling their purchases for next week, said Nobunao Nakamura of Nomura Securities co. Stocks that had fallen in the past, including shipbuilding, finance and non-life insurance shares, rose. Foreign buyers also boosted prices, Nakamura said.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani Politicians Striking At United States To Hit Ms. Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: Benazir Bhutto's political opponents have found a potent response to growing sympathy for the ousted prime minister: America-bashing. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan ousted Ms. Bhutto, accusing her of corruption and mismanagement, on Aug. 6. She is running in next week's general election despite facing a court battle. Khan's hand-picked caretaker government is pressing an aggressive campaign against her. It has filed charge after charge against her, her father-in-law and a half-dozen former Cabinet ministers alleging they used their power to get rich fast. It jailed her husband on charges of kidnapping and extortion. The government also branded Ms. Bhutto an unbeliever, an enemy of Islam and a traitor. But the initial onslaught only damaged the credibility of the president and the caretaker government, making both appear vindictive and generating sympathy for Ms. Bhutto and her populist, center-left Pakistan People's Party. It seemed nothing could stop her unexpected rebound. Then U.S. Ambassador Robert Oakley, in a speech in Washington, noted that Ms. Bhutto's opponents are not above reproach. Pakistanis have voiced similar views, but many were outraged by Oakley's comments. Newspapers wrote numerous editorials accusing Washington of blatant interference and suggested U.S. influence over this country of 110 million people should be greatly curtailed. Some caretaker ministers called Oakley's statements undiplomatic; one demanded that Washington replace him. Pakistan is the third-largest recipient of American aid after Egypt and Israel. It also has been conduit for an estimated $300 million in assistance to the Moslem resistance during the 12-year-old war in Afghanistan. The Oakley fire subsided briefly. Then 53 U.S. senators reportedly wrote a letter to President Bush warning that economic and military aid would be cut off if Ms. Bhutto were disqualified from the election. Forty-four Pakistani senators wrote a blistering response, saying that was a matter for the court - not the U.S. Congress - to decide. In the rhetoric of the People's Party, Ms. Bhutto ``became the American puppet, someone willing to give away her country's sovereignty,'' said one Western diplomat, insisting on anonymity. ``It played nicely into her opponents' hands,'' the diplomat said. ``They parlayed it nicely into an election issue and dampened the PPP. Now the momentum may be swinging the other way.'' Ms. Bhutto, who was educated in the United States, is considered by many in the West, especially the United States, as a symbol of democracy in South Asia. She has capitalized on that image and cemented strong ties to Washington. An undercurrent of anti-Americanism always runs through Pakistan, which tends to blame the United States for all its problems during times of crises. It surfaced again on Oct. 1 when Washington suspended a $573 million aid package demanding greater assurances that Pakistan neither possesses nor wants to possess nuclear weapons. The caretaker government blamed Ms. Bhutto for the aid suspension, a charge she dismissed. ``Ms. Bhutto, her mother and the PPP have been lobbying in the United States to get our aid stopped,'' caretaker Prime Minister Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi charged Thursday, referring to the Pakistan People's Party. ``They have been working against the national interest for the sake of their petty benefit to pressure the government of Pakistan and to win in the election,'' he said. Even though he mentioned no one by name, Pakistan's most powerful soldier, Army Chief-of-Staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, issued his own warning - to the Americans and to Pakistan's next prime minister. Military sources said it was the first time he has made such comments. In an hourlong speech to his troops earlier this week, Beg vowed Pakistan would not compromise its principles. He warned leaders not to look for ``outside direction or guidance. ``And those looking for such political guidance and support for promoting their political ambitions are certain to be frustrated,'' he said. ``There's a lot of nationalism now in Pakistan,'' said one Commonwealth diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There's a growing feeling that Pakistan needs to be more aligned with the Islamic world and less with the Western world.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Vows To Fight Dismissal From EPA Smoking Panel
DOC.TEXT: A scientist dismissed from an Environmental Protection Agency panel on second-hand cigarette smoke after vigorous tobacco industry lobbying says he will fight to be reinstated. The industry charged that the scientist's ``long and intense involvement with the antismoking movement'' makes him biased, but colleagues said his credentials are impeccable. Dr. David Burns of the University of California, San Diego, learned Thursday he had been removed from the EPA's Scientific Advisory Board studying the dangers of second-hand cigarette smoke. The dismissal ``damages my credibility and the credibility of the panel, and as a matter of public policy I feel compelled to try to reverse the decision,'' he said. ``It is a substantial insult to my professional status, and I can't let that go unanswered.'' Stephen Bayard, manager of the EPA project to assess passive smoking's health risks, said ``I've never seen anything like this'' in 12 years at the agency. ``I'm disturbed about this,'' he said. ``I think it was lousy. I think it shows undue pressure, personally, from the tobacco companies and the Congress.'' Burns said he had been told in an Aug. 10 letter he was on the EPA panel. The same day, the Tobacco Institute, an industry group, wrote EPA Administrator William Reilly protesting Burns' selection. ``Frankly, we are mystified how an individual with Dr. Burns's long and intense involvement with the antismoking movement can be expected to contribute to a reasonable, objective examination'' of the EPA reports, the letter said. Burns has worked on the surgeon general's smoking reports since the 1970s. He was editor of the 1986 report that said passive smoking can cause disease including lung cancer in healthy non-smokers. Brennan Dawson, a Tobacco Institute spokeswoman, said, ``We want a fair panel that will look at it objectively. Our concern is that Mr. Burns is unable to do that.'' On Sept. 18, Rep. Thomas Bliley, R-Va., wrote the EPA without mentioning Burns by name but urging the panel ``consist of qualified individuals who have not already prejudged this issue in any manner.'' Bliley is a strong tobacco industry ally. Philip Morris is the largest private employer in his congressional district. Bayard said Bliley's letter was factor was a factor in Burns' dismissal. Burns said: ``I am surprised that an EPA review would be swayed by pressure from the tobacco industry on an issue of science, when the tobacco industry is on record as disputing even the scientific evidence that cigarette smoking is related to lung cancer with active smokers.'' Robert Flaak of the advisory panel, who told Burns he had been removed, said he could not comment on the decision. Donald Shopland, coordinator of the National Cancer Institute's smoking control program, defended Burns, his long-time colleague. ``I don't know of anyone else you could point to that would have the degree of expertise he would possess on smoking in general and the whole issue of passive smoking in particular,'' Shopland said. Bayard said Burns was among 16 or 17 researchers who already had submitted a preliminary review of the EPA's report on passive smoking's health risks, and Burns' comments ``were by far the best comments that I received.'' Bayard said he was concerned Burns' exclusion would compromise the final report's quality. ``If I feel there's tampering with the committee, am I going to get a good review out of it? I have my concerns,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Carrier Convicted of Exposing Boy to Killer Virus
DOC.TEXT:
An AIDS carrier was convicted of exposing an 8-year-old boy to the killer virus in a sexual assault case that was the first test of the state's novel AIDS exposure law. Randall Lee Dempsey, 34, was found guilty Thursday of criminal transmission of HIV, the organism that causes AIDS, and aggravated sexual assault. Jurors deliberated more than 11 hours before convicting Dempsey of forcing the boy to perform oral sex. The boy had testified against Dempsey. Dempsey could face up to 30 years in prison on the assault count and a maximum seven-year term on the AIDS exposure count. The Illinois AIDS exposure law, which took effect in September 1989, requires only that offenders know they are infected when they engage in activities that could transmit the virus to others. Conviction does not require that the victim develop AIDS. One of the main ways the disease is spread is through sexual contact. Dempsey, of rural Marion in south-central Illinois, twice tested positive for HIV, the AIDS virus. The boy, now 9, has not been tested to see if he carries the virus. He was attacked in May and his mother said ultimately he will be tested. The man, who moved back to Illinois from California after learning he carried the AIDS virus, denied the charges and claimed the boy fabricated the tale with his mother's help. The boy reported the sexual encounter the following morning after Dempsey tried to silence him with promises of a pet turtle, Williamson County prosecutor Charles Garnati said.
Defense lawyer Larry Broeking told jurors during closing arguments, ``The defendant uncategorically denies that it happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Gov't And UNITA Rebels Approve UN Relief Convoys
DOC.TEXT: Angola's Marxist government and U.S.-backed rebels locked in a 15-year-old war have agreed to a U.N. plan to ship food to 1.9 million Angolans threatened by famine, U.N. officials said. ``United Nations relief convoys will begin to move urgently needed humanitarian supplies to drought and war-induced famine areas in Angola effective Nov. 1,'' U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said Tuesday. The operation involving 130 million tons of food and other relief supplies will cover nine of Angola's 18 provinces, officials said. The Angolan relief plan is based on the methods used by Operation Lifeline Sudan, which established ``corridors of tranquility'' in Sudan so food could be shipped to the rebel-held south, and garrison towns there controlled by the government. Operation Lifeline Sudan is believed to have saved 100,000 Sudanese lives in 1989-90. In Angola, ``The question of the safety of relief workers and the security of relief convoys ontinues to be of prime concern top the United Nations, considering that a cease-fire has yet to be declared,'' said a U.N. announcement. Peace talks between the UNITA rebels and the government of President Eduardo dos Santos have failed to produce an agreement. ``Firm assurances have been sought and received from the government of Angola and UNITA that they will facilitate the safe passage of convoys, ensure the safety of relief personnel and fully support'' the relief program, it said. Officials from the World Food Program and the U.N. Children's Fund have made safe-passage arrangements with the government for the areas it controls, and will meet shortly with UNITA representatives to make similar plans for rebel-held territory. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar will launch an international fund appeal for the program in November. The first phase of the program, from October 1990 through the end of March 1991, is expected to cost about $75 million, mostly for food and logistics, but with about $22.5 earmarked for non-food supplies and services. Angola, once one of southern Africa's more prosperous nations, has been reduced to abject poverty by civil war since 1975 with Jonas Savimbi's rebels, who take their name, UNITA, from the Portuguese acronym for the National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola. Perez de Cuellar said he hoped that the relief operation will ``help to promote the peace process that is already under way.'' Savimbi and dos Santos met for peace talks in June, 1989, in Gbadolite, Zaire, to sign peace accords, but the process broke down over misunderstandings over Savimbi's future political role and the war resumed. Cuban troops are withdrawing from Angola, however, under the southern Africa accords that led to Namibia's independence, and the Soviet Union and United States are trying to help their proxies resolve the conflict.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Companies Will Delete Offending Symbols From Games
DOC.TEXT: Swastikas and a Star of David will be deleted from two companies' computer games after the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith complained, the games' makers said. A spokeswoman for the New York-based ADL said the league contacted NEC Technologies and Nintendo of America earlier this year asking that the symbols be removed from two computer games and an instruction booklet. ``In letters to ADL, both companies informed the league that they had taken action to have the offensive symbols removed,'' spokeswoman Barbara Walden said Thursday. Walden said NEC's ``Syber Corp'' game uses swastikas as weapons in action scenes. The object of its ``Neutopia'' game is to destroy ``bosses,'' one of whom wears the six-pointed Star of David on his chest. She said Nintendo's ``Legend of Zelda'' has a swastika in its instruction booklet. Grant Schneider, a spokesman for Wood Dale, Ill.-based NEC, said the company was surprised by the ADL request. ``We have third-party software developers who develop the games,'' Schneider said. ``Somehow, whoever programmed these things apparently put these in.'' ``We notified the game developers ... and said they had to remove these from the games,'' he said. He said if any consumer who purchased one of the games is offended, NEC will replace the game with another of the consumer's choosing. Schneider also said NEC would beef up the screening process to make sure offensive images don't appear in games in the future. Richard Lindner, a spokesman for the Redmond, Wash.-based Nintendo, said the symbol in the ``Legend of Zelda'' instruction booklet is not, technically, a swastika. ``It's something called a manji,'' Lindner said. ``It's a reversed swastika symbol that has significance in the Hindu religions and other Asian religions.'' But Lindner said Nintendo will remove the symbol and, further, has invited the ADL to conduct a sensitivity training session for its game developers. ``Nintendo has a pretty stringent software development standard,'' Lindner said. ``Things that are offensive to any particular religious group are not supposed to be in games.''

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Quake Replay On TV Panics Philippine City
DOC.TEXT: A TV replay of last year's San Francisco earthquake caused panic among many residents of a northern Philippine city that was ravaged by an earthquake in July. The tension Thursday in the mountain resort city of Baguio died down only after authorities at the U.S.-run Camp John Hay explained that footage shown by the Far East Network were from the San Francisco earthquake, which occurred Oct. 18 last year. Local reporters in Baguio, about 130 miles north of Manila, said he old TV reports caused hundreds of residents to leave their homes and stay outdoors, causing heavy pedestrian and vehicular traffic. Schools and offices shut down. FEN is the U.S. military's television in the Philippines and is widely viewed by Filipinos living near the six U.S.-run military bases in the country. Camp John Hay is a U.S. rest and recreational facility in Baguio. In July, an earthquake which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale hit a wide area in the northern Philippines, leaving nearly 1,700 people dead and widespread damage. In Baguio, at least 400 people died in the temblor. More than 1,070 aftershocks of that earthquake have been recorded. The last one which was strong enough to be felt occurred last Sunday. The FEN aired old footage of the San Francisco earthquake which included ``bulletin notices.'' Many residents mistook the messages as new bulletins, causing the panic, reporters added. The earthquake that hit the San Francisco-Oakland area measured 7.1 on the Richter scale and killed 67 people.

DOC.HEAD: Carbon Monoxide Reaches `Potential Hazard' Levels In 2 Tractor Pulls
DOC.TEXT: Tractor pulls can produce not only noise and skidmarks but potentially hazardous levels of carbon monoxide, federal health officials say. Tractor pulls typically feature a dozen or so truck rigs outfitted with super-powerful engines competing in pulling 50-ton sleds across a dirt floor. Carbon monoxide levels during two tractor pulls in a Winnipeg, Manitoba, hockey arena ``represented a potential health hazard to both participants and observers,'' the U.S. Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. Carbon monoxide, a colorless, odorless gas in all exhaust and smoke, can cause headache, dizziness, cardiac problems and even death. The problems may not occur at other tractor pulls. U.S. health officials aren't sure whether the problem was peculiar to Winnipeg Arena, where attempts to decrease carbon monoxide levels didn't work. ``I wish I knew,'' said Dr. Ruth Etzel, a researcher with the Center for Environmental Health at the Atlanta-based CDC. ``We would certainly like to see some data so we would know if this is a problem. `We were quite surprised at the levels of carbon monoxide that can build up in these things.'' The findings from the 1988 events at Winnipeg Arena prompted the cancellation of a February 1989 tractor pull in the building, constructed in the early 1950s. Health officials didn't report any incidents of carbon monoxide poisoning during either Winnipeg event, although some members of the ambulance crew did report severe headaches, Etzel said. But the officials urged arena officials not to allow future tractor pulls, and the arena management agreed, said Rod Thiessen, director of operations for Winnipeg Arena. ``They've never come back and made them safe enough,'' he said. At the start of a February 1988 pull at Winnipeg, health inspectors measured airborne carbon monoxide levels averaging 62 parts per million - nearly twice the Winnipeg Health Department's recommended indoor one-hour guideline of 33 parts per million. By the event's end, the level had increased to 262 parts per million. For a November 1988 event there, roof louvers were opened, the time of the event was extended and one fewer pull was run. Still, according to the CDC, carbon monoxide levels then went from 78 parts per million to 436. Adverse health effects have been reported in people breathing a constant 15 parts per million, the CDC said. Mike Weber, a spokesman for TNT, one of the largest tractor-pull promoters, said his group has ``never had any problems'' like those at the Winnipeg arena. ``We present motor sports events in all the major arenas across the country, and we take every precaution. We do constantly monitor our emitted fumes ... it's worked very well for us,'' said Weber, director of public relations for the United States Hot Rod Association, sanctioning body for TNT events. TNT was not involved in the Winnipeg pulls, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Beverly Sills Condemns Sexually Explicit Lyrics
With PM-2 Live Crew
DOC.TEXT: Opera star Beverly Sills, at a Catholic fund-raiser, denounced violence and explicit sex in the arts. But she added that ``you can't criminalize imagination.'' ``We have laws today that tell us we can't smoke on airplanes, but you can freely sing - if you'll pardon the expression - about the joys of violating a woman's body in monstrous detail on commercial recordings because it's a constitutional right,'' Sills said. She addressed about 1,000 politicians and pundits Thursday night at the 45th annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner. The $500-a-plate affair dinner, run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, benefits health care causes. ``We do not need self-appointed vigilantes to insist upon legislating artistic work, because you can't legislate taste,'' Ms. Sills said. ``You can't criminalize imagination. You shouldn't throw artists in jail.'' Instead, she said, higher moral standards are needed. ``Now I'm all for artistic freedom - I used to be a performing artist myself - but we as a society are growing dangerously out of touch with our conscience,'' she said. ``We don't need more laws to be enacted; we need to be outraged and worried about our kids. We will not accept the lowest common form of human behavior as the price for free expression.'' Ms. Sills spoke at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel at what has been called the city's most important non-political political event. Among prominent guests were Mayor David Dinkins, former Mayor Edward Koch and syndicated columnist William F. Buckley. Last year first lady Barbara Bush gave the keynote. In 1988, George Bush and Michael Dukakis, then rival presidential candidates, traded barbs. Other past speakers include John F. Kennedy, Richard M. Nixon, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Lyndon B. Johnson and Winston Churchill. Smith was governor of New York from 1923 to 1928, the year he became the first Catholic to be nominated for president. Ms. Sills, 61, is a soprano who directed the New York City Opera from 1979 to 1989 after retiring from the stage. Gov. Mario Cuomo did not attend the dinner. Cuomo is Catholic and favors abortion rights, and he has been criticized by church officials who say Catholic politicians should support the church's anti-abortion stance. Cuomo's aide, Karen Polk, said he had made a prior commitment to speak at a state school boards conference in Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of U.S. Middle East Policy Plan Wave of Protest
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East are resurrecting 1960s-style peace activism for nationwide protests Saturday. Among the demonstrators will be labor unions and veterans' groups. Rallies scheduled for at least 15 major U.S. cities will cap a week of smaller protests and the debut of a televised peace message starring Ron Kovic, the hero crippled in the Vietnam War who became a staunch anti-war activist and wrote his story in ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' A wide-ranging coalition of groups is sponsoring the weekend protests. Demonstrators staged a '60s-style teach-in rally at Harvard University on Thursday and other protests elsewhere earlier in the week. Organizers hope the mass protests will sap support for the Persian Gulf military buildup arising after Iraq's conquest of Kuwait in early August. ``Once people see thousands out in the street, we can build on that,'' said Charles Twist, spokesman for the New York Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. The 30-second TV spot starring Kovic debuted Thursday and was set for broadcast in 50 U.S. cities. In it, Kovic says American troops are risking their lives ``not to defend democracy, but to protect the big oil companies.'' Money for the TV message was raised from veterans and peace groups. Kovic also is scheduled to address a rally in Los Angeles on Saturday titled ``Stop the U.S. War for Oil - Bring Back Our Sons and Daughters.'' ``The government's doing a good job at a media blitz for the war in the Middle East, but very little information is getting out about how this crisis was created or what the underlying motives are,'' said Eric Larsen, a Marine reserve noncommissioned officer who says he will refuse to go to Saudi Arabia if called there. ``Once they have the facts, people will turn against this policy,'' he said. At least one counter-demonstration was planned for Saturday by Atlanta-area families of soldiers stationed in the Middle East. The cost of the U.S. troop deployment will figure prominently in protesters' rhetoric, organizers said. ``The front pages are full of the budget crisis,'' Twist said. ``It doesn't take much to make the connection that we're spending billions to keep our troops there at the same time we're cutting Social Security.'' That has helped draw labor unions to the movement. ``You've got inflation, budget cuts, joblessness and now the war,'' said Nan Genger, a United Auto Workers official helping stage a rally Saturday in Boston. ``Right now, working people are under attack.'' Veterans' groups also have joined the coalition. ``The days of U.S. veterans blindly supporting their government are over since Vietnam,'' said Winston Warfield, president of the 400-member Smedley D. Butler Brigade of Veterans for Peace. Besides Los Angeles and Boston, rallies were planned in Albuquerque, N.M., Birmingham, Ala., Chicago, Cleveland, Honolulu, Houston, Minneapolis, New York, Olympia, Wash., Portland, Ore., San Diego, San Francisco and Seattle. Demonstrations also are scheduled Saturday for cities in Canada, Europe and Australia. Rallies were held on Tuesday in Honolulu, Washington, Houston, Seattle and San Francisco in support of Jeffrey Paterson, a 22-year-old Marine corporal who refused to go to the Middle East with his unit.

DOC.HEAD: Police Official Says Secret Services Covered Up Jet Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: Italy's No. 1 police official says secret service agents covered up evidence that would show a domestic airliner that blew up over the Mediterranean ten years ago was shot down, news reports said. The DC-9 jetliner, of now defunct Itavia airlines, was flying from Bologna to Palermo, Sicily, on June 27, 1980, when it blew apart. All 81 people aboard were killed. Italy at the time was wracked by terrorist attacks from both the left and the right, and a bomb was first suspected. But investigation over the years - especially after the retrieval of the undersea wreckage seven years later - pointed to the possibility of a missile. Vincenzo Parisi, chief of the national police force, told a parliamentary committee Wednesday that he believes a missile shot down the plane, newspapers reported. He was also quoted as saying that while elements in the Italian secret services acted to cover up the downing, they weren't involved in the missile-firing. He did not elaborate on the alleged cover-up. Investigators have complained that the secret services were not fully cooperating in the probe and that key radar tapes were missing. The head of the military branch of the secret services at the time of the plane crash was a general who was later identified as a member of Propanganda Due (P-2), a Masonic lodge that sought to destabilize the Italian government. Parisi, who became assistant director of the civilian secret service a few weeks after the plane went down, didn't identify the nationality of the missile. However, he ruled out U.S. involvement, the reports said. None of the past investigating commissions has identified the nationality of the missile, if there were one, although Italy, France, the United States and Libya have been named in media reports as the chief possibilities. A Libyan connection was raised with the discovery, reported in July 1980, of a Libyan MiG jetfighter which had crashed in southern Italy. Some reports contended that U.S. fighter planes were chasing a Libyan jet over the Mediterranean and fired a heat-seeking missile that mistakenly hit the passenger aircraft. France was implicated in some reports because of the presence of an aircraft carrier in the Mediterranean the evening of the tragedy. French, U.S. and NATO officials have denied there was any military activity in the skies that night. Parisi, in his testimony before the commission, discounted the theory that the aircraft was accidentally hit by a missile. ``The case must be inserted in the national and international terroristic panorama of the last 20 years,'' La Stampa, a national daily, quoted him as saying. Parisi's testimony was the first by a high government official to link the missile-firing theory to terrorism. The plane tragedy, known as the ``Ustica case'' from the name of the tiny island near where the craft went down, has been one of the more sensational unsolved cases among several Italian tragedies. Parisi's account seemed to raise more questions than provide answers. ``I can't give the origin nor the nationality'' of the missile, another account, by Il Messaggero, quoted Parisi as saying. ``I accuse no one because I haven't the elements to do so.''

DOC.HEAD: Church Nightingale Silenced By Court
DOC.TEXT: Elojia Macias may hear the beat of a different drummer, but a judge says she must get in tune with the rest of her church's flock. In a lawsuit, Father Alexander Wangler of Our Lady of Sorrows Catholic Church accused Ms. Macias of disrupting church services by singing her own songs, causing ``confusion and disruption.'' At first she sang from her pew, the lawsuit said, but then she got up and started singing through the sound system. Because of her actions, the church suffered a ``loss of good will, spiritual tranquility and membership,'' the lawsuit said. State District Judge John Specia issued an injunction Thursday ordering Ms. Macias to cooperate or risk being held in contempt of court. Father Wangler said the first test should occur at Sunday's 9 a.m. Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Machinery Keeps Blood Flowing After Cardiac Arrest
LaserPhoto PG3 of Oct. 18
DOC.TEXT: A device that takes over the function of the heart - pumping oxygenated blood throughout the body - could more than double the number of people who survive sudden cardiac arrest, researchers say. In its first human test, the pump kept blood flowing through one woman for 15 hours until doctors got her heart working properly again. ``Had they not gotten approval ... to use this machine, I can question whether I'd be alive,'' said Sharon Wilczynski, 29, who survived her heart attack although she was clinically dead several times during the ordeal. ``What else could they have done?'' she asked. About 10 percent of people who suffer sudden heart attacks survive. The pumping device could save an additional 10 percent to 15 percent, Dr. Samuel Tisherman of the University of Pittsburgh Medical School said Thursday. ``This is just the beginning in new vistas in resuscitation,'' Tisherman said. The device adds oxygen and heats the blood outside the body before pumping it back inside. It is called an emergency closed-chest cardiopulmonary bypass. It is designed for use after the failure of manual resuscitation methods, commonly known as CPR. ``If CPR doesn't work within a few minutes, we normally are dealing with a hopeless situation,'' said Dr. Peter Safar, who developed CPR and directs the university's International Resuscitation Research Center. The equipment assembled by Pitt researchers is a smaller version of heart-lung machines that sustain patients during open heart surgery, Safar said. It consists of an oxygenator, oxygen tank, pump, heat exchanger, battery pack and several feet of tubing. Two plastic tubes are inserted into a patient's femoral artery and vein at the groin area. Blood flow is maintained so the brain and other vital organs are not damaged while attempts are made to restart and stabilize the heart. Although paramedics reached Miss Wilczynski within five minutes of her attack on July 26 and administered CPR, her heart beat only intermittently and stopped before she reached Presbyterian University Hospital's emergency room. She was hooked to the bypass machine within 50 minutes. After two hours, her heart was beating but unstable, so doctors let her sleep while the machine maintained blood flow. The next day her rested heart stabilized. Tests indicate she suffered no brain damage. ``We went to my sister's recently and passed a funeral procession,'' Miss Wilczynski said from her home in Coraopolis. ``It was an odd feeling, like `there but for the grace of God go I.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Sam Kinison's Bodyguard Testifies In Rape Trial
DOC.TEXT: A man hired to protect comedian Sam Kinison testified he had sex with the comic's girlfriend as Kinison slept, but said it wasn't rape. Unway Carter, 22, took the witness stand Thursday at his rape trial. He said Kinison's girlfriend consented to have sexual intercourse with him. The 6-foot-4, 300-pound Carter testified that Kinison's 22-year-old girlfriend told him afterward: ``We can't let Sam know anything happened.'' The woman testified Tuesday that Carter burst into her bedroom and raped her repeatedly. The incident occurred June 21 after Carter, who said he had been paid $100 to act as Kinison's bodyguard, helped the comic into bed. Carter said Kinison was intoxicated. He said he heard the woman yelling at Kinison soon afterward about alcohol and infidelity. Carter said he and the woman had sex when he went to comfort her after the alleged fight. Carter faces five felony charges: three counts of rape and two counts of sexual assault. Kinison, the former preacher known for his raunchy, loud comedy diatribes, may not testify because he apparently was asleep and did not realize what happened until authorities arrived.

DOC.BYLINE: Court Upholds Former Premier Benazir Bhutto's Dismissal
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Pakistan-US-Bashing
DOC.TEXT: A court has confirmed the ouster of Benazir Bhutto's government, handing the former prime minister her second legal setback in less than a week. Acting Chief Justice Saeeduzzaman Sadiqqi on Thursday also upheld the dismissal of the Sindh provincial legislature controlled by Ms. Bhutto's populist Pakistan People's Party. Ms. Bhutto is not expected to challenge either ruling, fearing an appeal could delay the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections, a party spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The Sindh High Court's decisions mirrored a ruling by the Lahore High Court last week in Pakistan's prosperous Punjab Province, a stronghold of Ms. Bhutto's political opponents. The Lahore court upheld her dismissal, ruling corruption and mismanagement had paralyzed her government. Both rulings are expected to help Ms. Bhutto's political opponents stem the momentum her party has gained in recent weeks. Three lawyers, all members of Ms. Bhutto's party, filed lawsuits asking the court to rule her dismissal unconstitutional and to restore her government and the provincial government. But Sadiqqi told the packed courtroom it was too late to put the brakes on the election with less than a week to go. ``It is difficult to reverse the election process,'' the judge said. Ms. Bhutto joined with two smaller liberal parties to form the People's Democratic Alliance. Her key opponent is a coalition of nine parties espousing ideologies ranging from right-wing to religious fundamentalism. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed her government Aug. 6 and, in a scathing critique of her 20 months in power, accused her of corruption and power abuse that crippled the National Assembly, the lawmaking lower house of Parliament. Kahn also criticized the 37-year-old former prime minister's inability to stem the growing tide of violence in Sindh, her home province, where at least 500 people had been killed since last May. Sadiqqi said the president was justified in his decision. Ms. Bhutto's party and a small Indian immigrant party have been blamed for much of the violence. The Mohajir Qami Movement, or Refugee People's Party, representing Indians who immigrated to Pakistan after partition of the subcontinent, are bitter opponents of Sindhi nationalists, who want greater autonomy or independence from Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Climbs To 21 In Mine Blast
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in a mine explosion in northern Moravia has climbed to 21, the state news agency CTK reported today. Eight miners were reported still missing after rescue workers recovered the bodies of 21 miners killed in an accident that CTK said was probably caused by a leakage of methane. Ten miners were injured, and four of them remained hospitalized, the agency said. CTK said the explosion occurred about 2,400 feet underground Thursday. It was the second-worst mine accident in Czechoslovakia in the last 10 years, CTK said. The worst accident occurred in September 1981 in Northern Bohemia, killing 65 people.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower in Europe, Except Against Yen; Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar recovered from overnight lows but was still down against all major currencies except the yen in European trading late this morning. Gold prices were higher, capping a technical rally that started on Thursday, dealers said. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar's recovery was spurred by remarks from an anonymous Bank of Japan official that a dollar plunge should be avoided and that monetary officials must watch the situation carefully. Dealers said the Japanese statement had put at least a temporary floor under the dollar at 1.500 German marks and 126.00 yen. However, they said the room for increases above those levels was also limited. The dollar has been declining on expectations of a cut in the U.S. federal funds interest rate, the protracted and unsuccessful attempts to cut the U.S. budget and a belief by some traders that the United States is on the verge of recession, dealers said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose against the yen for the first time in 44 trading days. It finished at 125.25 yen, up 0.85 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 126.85 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5065 German marks, down from 1.5115 -1.2710 Swiss francs, down from 1.2735 -5.0473 French francs, down from 5.0630 -1.6880 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7035 -1,129.00 Italian lire, down from 1,132.75 -1.1650 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1750 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9570, up from $1.9540 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $371.75 per ounce at midmorning, up from $367.75 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $371.75, up from $366.50 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $6 to close at a bid $375.58. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.24 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Lie Detector Results Buoy Embattled Grunseth Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Jon Grunseth said a lie detector test shows he is innocent of allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls. Grunseth, an Independent-Republican, used the test results to get a critical boost from his party Thursday. After his campaign manager, Leon Oistad, discussed the results with party leaders, the 14-member IR executive committee gave Grunseth a vote of confidence at its meeting in Bloomington. ``Jon was our candidate, and the lie detector test proved beyond a doubt that the allegations were false and there was no reason he should not be moving ahead with his campaign,'' IR Party Chairman Bob Weinholzer said. Less than three weeks before the election, Grunseth wanted to rebut allegations by two young women that he swam nude with four teen-age girls at a 1981 party, tried to touch the breast of one and served beer to minors. The Grunseth campaign refused to release details of the test procedures, the questions asked and the identity of the test administrator before a news conference today. Grunseth took the test Wednesday night, campaign officials said. Oistad acknowledged that lie detector tests are not 100 percent reliable, but he asked, ``How else does Jon prove a negative?'' The women's attorney, Robert Tennessen of Minneapolis, did not return a reporter's telephone call for comment. The women's allegations have been corroborated by several other people at the party, while Grunseth has obtained sworn statements from 16 people who support his version. Grunseth faces Gov. Rudy Perpich, the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party nominee.

DOC.HEAD: Clear Skies Across East, South; Rain Expected in Parts of West
DOC.TEXT: The Eastern Seaboard was drying out early today from a night of heavy rain. The rest of the country also had clear skies. Rain was expected to drench parts of the West and upper Midwest while sunny skies and warm weather were forecast for the South and Southwest today. Sunshine was predicted for most of the East Coast, except for Maine and some other areas along the Canadian border. Several Eastern states were struck by high winds and heavy rains late Thursday when a fast-moving storm system raced through the area. Rain was expected to move across Nevada, Arizona, Colorado and into the Dakotas today. Temperatures in the 80s were forecast for the South and Southwest, with highs in the 70s expected in the East and along the West Coast. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 97 degrees at Phoenix and Coolidge, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Adults Missing Too Many Immunizations, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: The federal government wants more Americans to get their vaccinations - not just kids, but grown-ups too. ``Despite the continuing occurrence of vaccine-preventable diseases among adults in the United States, safe and effective vaccines recommended for adults are not optimally used,'' the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. Examples cited by the CDC in its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report: -While influenza vaccine is about 75 percent effective in reducing deaths in high-risk older people, a 1987 survey found just 32 percent of adults over 65 had taken flu shots. -Five states had large college-based measles outbreaks in 1989; only one had a pre-enrollment immunization requirement for students. -Health care workers get between 6,000 and 8,000 new hepatitis B infections each year. But in 1988, only 19 percent of U.S. and Canadian medical schools required hepatitis B vaccinations. -Pneumococcal vaccine is more than 60 percent effective in preventing invasive pneumococcal infections, which cause as much as one-fourth of all pneumonia cases and 40,000 deaths a year. But a 1985 study concluded only 10 percent of high-risk people got the shots. Between 1985-89, adults made up 92 percent of the nation's tetanus patients, 87 percent of hepatitis B patients and 45 percent of rubella patients; all are vaccine-preventable diseases, the CDC said. The National Coalition for Adult Immunization, a coalition including the American Medical Association, the American Lung Association, CDC and other medical groups and drug companies, has established a series of standards for adult immunizations. The group recommends ``all health providers routinely determine the immunization status of their adult patients'' and offer them the shots they may need. If the standards are implemented, it ``could markedly improve delivery of vaccines to adults'' by the year 2000, the CDC said.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Owners Fear Anti-Semitism Behind Holocaust Art Theft
DOC.TEXT: The owners of a Houston gallery fear anti-Semitism may be behind the theft of three drawings depicting scenes from the Holocaust and three other works by the same artist. Officials of Hooks-Epstein Galleries said Thursday more costly works were ignored as six sketches by respected artist Jerome Witkin, valued at $5,850, were removed early Wednesday. ``Was it just plain art theft, or was it anti-something art theft?'' gallery owner Charles Hooks said. ``It's a puzzlement. It's just maddening.'' Hooks said the thief singled out renderings of the crematorium floor at Auschwitz and the women's barracks and a latrine area in the Birkenau concentration camp, then removed a nude and two drawings of women from another wall. ``We think it was an anti-Semitic act,'' said Hooks' wife, Geri. ``This is the first show we have had here in 20 years that has any religious significance.'' ``Maybe they were trying to throw us off by taking the women,'' Mrs. Hooks said. Police report no progress in the burglary, which Hooks said occurred about 4 a.m. when the glass front door was shattered. Police responded to an alarm within minutes, but the burglar or burglars had disappeared. The owners said they do not believe the thief felt rushed. The slender brass rods that held the pictures were still in place and nothing else in the gallery was disturbed. The three Holocaust sketches, hanging on a wall facing the entrance, were carefully lifted from their places in a row of four pictures. Hooks said the thief had to brazenly walk by a wall-size window facing the street to remove the three other pictures.

DOC.HEAD: Schools Distributing Condoms Beginning With Sixth Grade
DOC.TEXT: With little apparent controversy, the city health department has begun dispensing birth control pills and condoms at seven middle and high schools. The clinics began distributing the contraceptives last month to reduce the risk of pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases, said Elias Dorsey, acting city health commissioner. Health clinics at selected schools have counseled sexually active city students and prescribed contraceptives since 1985 as part of a broad range of medical care offered to youngsters who might not otherwise get it. Middle school begins with sixth grade. ``With kids 14 or 15 years old, you have to do it right now,'' Dorsey said.
