The distribution of condoms has become the subject of a major policy debate this fall for school boards in Talbot County, Md., and New York, but the Baltimore school board did not consider the issue because it was a health department matter, board president Joseph L. Smith said. A survey of parents this spring found overwhelming support for dispensing contraceptives at the clinics, said Dr. John Santelli, the health department official who runs the program. Both he and school officials said the policy change had not been controversial. Abstinence from sex is an option discussed with students at the clinics and in health classes, Santelli said. About 5,000 students, around two-thirds of the total at the seven selected schools, are enrolled in the clinics, Santelli said. Baltimore led the nation's big cities in the percentage of babies born to teen-agers in 1988, the most recent year for which figures are available, and teen-agers accounted for 30 percent of the city's gonorrhea cases last year, according to the city's health department. Parents must sign a consent form before their children are enrolled in the clinics for most types of medical care, except treatment for sexually transmitted diseases, pregnancy, alcoholism, drug abuse, and dispersal of contraceptives.

DOC.HEAD: High School Teacher Spins Tales of Steamy Romance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT dateline, add detail on location of high school. Picks up 3rd graf, `The 54-year-old...'.
DOC.TEXT: Here's one teacher who doesn't spend all her time poring over textbooks. Martha Krieger, a Huron High School teacher of family living and home economics at Huron High School in this Detroit suburb, writes steamy romances novel by night. The 54-year-old Taylor has written four historical romance novels in the past five years, all under the pen name Allison Knight. Her latest, published by Zebra Books, is ``Sea-Spun Ecstasy,'' set against the 1831 hurricane that devastated Barbados. Explains Krieger: ``I'm telling love stories in the way I think others want to experience love. ``I'm writing what every woman, and man, would like to have in their lives but nine out of 10 don't. It's a means of escape.'' Krieger, who said she receives modest royalties, believes her status as a novelist helps her communicate with students. It shows them ``I'm not a stuffy old schoolteacher. I know what the world is about.''

DOC.HEAD: Robert Tessier, a Villain in Numerous Movies and Shows, Dies At 56
DOC.TEXT: Actor Robert Tessier, whose baleful looks helped him portray tough guys and villains in such movies as ``The Deep'' and ``The Longest Yard,'' has died. He was 56. Tessier died of cancer in Lowell, Mass., on Oct. 11, said a longtime friend, Diane Haggert. He had returned to his hometown after learning his illness was fatal, she said. Known for his trademark shaved head, Tessier's first prominent role came in 1970 with ``Cry Blood, Apache.'' Other film credits included ``Hooper'' and ``Hard Times.'' His last picture was ``Night-wish,'' released this year. He also worked in television, playing Rude Water in the acclaimed miniseries ``Centennial.'' Other TV appearances included ``Charlie's Angels,'' ``Vegas'' and ``The Fall Guy.'' Tessier earned the Silver Star and two Purple Hearts while serving in the Korean War. He came to Los Angeles in the 1960s to find work as an actor and was befriended by Lindsay Crosby, Dennis Hopper and Dan Haggerty. His first roles were in low-budget motorcycle pictures. Tessier is survived by two sons, three daughters, his mother and two sisters. A memorial celebration was scheduled for Sunday at the Outlaws, a club in the Los Angeles suburb of Playa del Rey.

DOC.HEAD: Collective Presidency Accepts Croatian, Defers Debate on Nation's Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with parliamentary debate postponed, comment from Jovic, Mesic. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's Parliament today moved to defuse mounting ethnic and political tension and warnings of impending civil war by naming a Croatian reformer to the country's collective presidency. A crucial parliamentary debate on whether Yugoslavia remains a federation or becomes a looser alliance was then postponed until at least November. The two moves indicated that the country's quarrelling political leaders had decided to put off at least for now a showdown in their power struggle over Yugoslavia's future. Deputies loudly applauded a conciliatory speech by outgoing President Borisav Jovic, a Serb who holds the annually rotating chairmanship of the collective ruling body. ``All bridges have not been burned. There are still possibilities for the crisis to be overcome,'' Jovic said after the Croatian Stjepan Mesic was named to the presidency. ``We are obliged not only to offer hope to the upset and frightened citizens but, I believe strongly, we can justify the trust they laid in us in these hard times,'' Jovic added. Communist-ruled Serbia staunchly opposes the confederacy plan pushed by Slovenia and Croatia. Under it, Yugoslavia would become a loose alliance of sovereign states. There would be no central rule or national capital, and each state would decide how it would deal with each other on an individual basis. Serbia calls for a ``modern federation'' that would keep central rule in Belgrade, the capital of the country and Serbia. Deputies from Serbia - the largest republic and Croatia's traditional rival - had earlier blocked the election of Stjepan Mesic, charging he was a Croatian nationalist who seeks independence for his republic. But those objections apparently were dropped following moves within the eight-member presidency to ease tension. The presidency contains representatives from each of Yugoslavia's six republics and two provinces. Croatia had officially been without a representative in a dispute over Mesic's nomination. He was proclaimed a member to the applause of hundreds of deputies. In the growing split between the country's Communist and non-Communist republics, Croatia on Thursday ordered its militia reserves to mobilize. The order was reported by the republic's television on Thursday and rebroadcast by Serbian television in Belgrade. It said only that Croatia was conducting a ``routine check'' of reserve units. The national news agency Tanjug said it had learned that arms had been distributed to some reserve forces. Leading Yugoslav politicians warned hours before the mobilization that ethnic and political struggles could lead to civil war. Croatian President Franjo Tudjman said ``if necessary, the entire Croatian people at home and abroad will fight to protect the democracy it won.'' Croatia would not tolerate any ``solutions that have proved fatal for the economic and democratic development,'' he said. Croatia and Slovenia elected center-right governments this year and are seeking greater independence. Belgrade is in Serbia, which is still controlled by Communists. In recent months, members of the Serbian minority in Croatia have staged demonstrations and seized arms from police, and Serbia has talked of absorbing areas of Croatia where there are large numbers of Serbs. Slovenia's delegate in the collective presidency, Janez Drnovsek, said that Serbia's Communist leaders were ``forcing the federal concept that could only lead to the breakup of the country.'' But, he added: ``At this moment it would be extremely risky to stop a dialogue between republics that would lead to the final breakup.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Suffers Stunning Defeat in Election For Seat of Slain Legislator
DOC.TEXT: In a stunning defeat for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the centrist Liberal Democratic Party today won this Conservative Party stronghold in a special parliamentary election. The Liberal Democrats took Eastbourne, a prosperous south England coastal town, in a huge 20.5 percent swing against the government. Balloting was to replace a legislator slain by the IRA. The Tory trouncing was among the worst electoral setbacks suffered by Mrs. Thatcher since she came to power in 1979. It prompted speculation she might feel forced to shelve any plan to call a general election next year, a year before her third five-year term expires. Still, the result had scant impact on Mrs. Thatcher's control of the 650-member House of Commons, where the Conservatives have 373 seats, Labor 226 and the Liberal Democrats now have 20. The rest are split among minority regional parties. The victory by Liberal Democrat David Bellotti, 47, appeared in part a backlash to the Tory campaign theme that a vote for the opposition would be ``a moral victory for terrorism.'' It marked a revolt against government economic policies of trying to squeeze 10.9 percent inflation with nearly two years of high interest rates and an unpopular new local tax imposed in the spring. Critics also pointed to what they have said is under-funding of the health, education and welfare services. ``It is a very poor result for us; there are no bones about it,'' Conservative Party chairman Kenneth Baker acknowledged when the result of Thursday's ballot was declared early today. Bellotti, scooping 51 percent of the vote, overturned a near 17,000-vote Conservative majority in Eastbourne to in by a comfortable 4,550-vote margin. The Conservatives' Richard Hickmet went down with 18,865 votes. The vote for the socialist Labor Party, with a yearlong lead in national opinion polls but no hope in Eastbourne, collapsed to just 2,308, or 5 percent. Eastbourne had been Tory territory for more than 70 years and ranked among the dozen safest Conservative Party seats in the country. ``This is a fine result for us and a disastrous one for the Conservative Party,'' said Bellotti, 47, a local authority counselor and director of the Young Men's Christian Association. Ian Gow, the previous legislator and a close aide to Mrs. Thatcher, was killed July 30 when the outlawed Irish Republican Army blew up his car. He was an outspoken opponent of the IRA's violent campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. The slaying of Gow, among the most audacious attacks in IRA violence this year, stunned this sedate, 18th-century resort community. Liberal Democratic leaders hailed the victory as restoring the party's fortunes after internal feuds slashed the centrists' support to single figures in poll ratings, compared with a one-fifth share in the 1987 general election. Labor leader Neil Kinnock said Eastbourne ``shows that people will vote against the Tories any time, any where.'' But observers said a modest revival of the centrists, who helped Mrs. Thatcher to victory in the past two elections by splitting the left-of-center vote, could benefit her again. Eastbourne epitomizes south England Tory territory - negligible unemployment, a high proportion of retirees and an abundance of small businessmen, and voters strong on law and order.

DOC.HEAD: Burning Mine To Be Sealed In Effort To Suffocate Flames
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with decision to seal mine. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The fire...'.
DOC.TEXT: A coal mine that has been burning for more than two days, driving about 50 people from their homes, will be sealed in an attempt to extinguish the smoky blaze, a spokesman said this morning. The decision to seal the mine's seven openings was made after engineers drilled tubes 100 yards into the earth and concluded the fire had spread farther than they thought and had grown in intensity, said Robert Toothman, spokesman for National Steel Corp. The steel company owns the Mathies Coal Co. mine near this western Pennsylvania town. The fire spewed thick smoke and invisible carbon monoxide. Fifteen to 20 families living within a mile of the mine's northernmost portal were ordered out of their homes Wednesday evening because of the fumes, said Washington County emergency services spokesman Philip Garrow. Most of them went to stay with relatives or friends. It could take several days before the mine is sealed and the evacuation order is lifted, and then several months before the fire is completely smothered, Toothman said. ``We're going to try to cut off all the air,'' he said. The fire began early Wednesday at the mine southwest of Pittsburgh near the juncture of two interstate highways. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette quoted unidentified Mathies miners as saying the main fire was sparked by a high-voltage line that collapsed in a primary tunnel. Toothman said he was unable to confirm those reports. Dark smoke filled the valley near the portal, but authorities were more worried about the amount of invisible, odorless, toxic carbon monoxide in the atmosphere, Garrow said. ``As long as the fire is burning, you'll get carbon monoxide,'' he said. A separate fire in the mine's maintenance shop was contained by cutting off air to the area, Toothman said. The blast that started that fire Wednesday slightly injured 11 firefighters.

DOC.HEAD: Bernstein's Philharmonic Lets His Music Speak for Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Fixes typo in Philharmonic in 1st graf
DOC.TEXT: For the New York Philharmonic, it was supposed to be a night of Beethoven and Shostakovich. The fates made it a night of Leonard Bernstein. The official catalog of his works says Bernstein led 74 orchestras. But this was HIS orchestra, and the musicians came to pay tribute to THEIR laureate conductor, who led them through 1,244 concerts during his 47-year association with the Philharmonic. They let his music do the talking. ``Tonight's concert is not an evening in which we want to dwell on the passing of a giant, but rather what he has left us,'' guest conductor Leonard Slatkin told the audience at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night. So four nights after Bernstein's death at age 72, Beethoven's ``Violin Concerto'' became Bernstein's ``Serenade for Solo Violin, String Orchestra, Harp and Percussion'' (1954); Shostakovich's ``Symphony No. 4'' became Bernstein's ``Symphony No. 1 (Jeremiah),'' written in 1942. Also added were his ``Chichester Psalms'' (1965) and his overture to ``Candide'' (1956). The substitute Bernstein program was being repeated Friday night, Saturday and Tuesday. It was an extraordinary concert. There weren't many smiling faces among the audience or musicians. Slatkin's brief introductory comments, followed by the whimsical ``Candide,'' broke some of the tension. Then came the eclectic ``Serenade,'' which Bernstein's program notes says is supposed to be based on Plato's ``Symposium.'' It begins with a lyrical praise of the Eros, the god of love. The piece is sometimes jocular, sometimes melancholy, sometimes assaulting and sometimes hedonistic. It ends in drunken revelry, an intrusion of jazz - as if Bernstein was looking down from heaven and telling the audience, ``It's O.K. to smile tonight.'' The soloist - concertmaster Glenn Dicterow - played with much agility, especially through the difficult double stops and especially considering the lack of preparation time. The mourning returned after intermission, but not without optimism. ``Jeremiah'' begins with suspenseful strings, followed by a cantorial French horn, a melodic return to the strings and then a prophetic blaring of brass. The second movement continues the point-counterpoint of brass versus strings (Jeremiah versus the corrupt priests, with Nebuchadnezzar looming on the horizon). In the third movement, Jerusalem has fallen to the Babylonian king. Judea is exiled. Jeremiah weeps. ``How she sits desolate - ``The city once so full of people - ``She is become as a widow.'' During her chanting of the prophet's ``Lamentations,'' mezzo-soprano Wendy White had to wipe a tear from her eye. S did members of the audience. Last on the program was another Hebraic elegy, ``Chichester Psalms.'' The New York Choral Artists and a boy soloist joined the orchestra. Two harpists dominated the center of the crowded stage. ``Awake, psaltery and harp!'' the choir begins in Hebrew. ``I will rouse the dawn.'' In the second movement an angelic 8th-grader, Evan Weber, sings King David's 23rd Psalm, ``The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want.'' After he finishes, the men's chorus bellows: ``Why do the nations rage?'' The piece, however, ends in a Mahlerian motif and chorus declaring a message Bernstein had sought for society: ``Behold how good, ``And how pleasant it is, ``For brethren to dwell ``Together in unity.'' To emphasize the point after the final note, Slatkin suspended his hands for several long moments of silence. Then came the cascade of applause. For Leonard Bernstein.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Economy at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here are the four stages of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform plan, followed by an outline of the effects it will have on various sectors of the Soviet economy. The plan was given preliminary approval by the Supreme Soviet legislature on Friday.

Stage 1: Calls for reduction of the national budget deficit, controls on the money supply, higher bank interest rates on savings accounts, increased production of consumer goods and land reform. Stage 2: Provides for freeing the prices of 70 percent to 80 percent of goods from state control, encouraging small private businesses and a social welfare net for workers who lose their jobs. Stage 3: Establishes a minimum wage and the lifting of restrictions on the size of earnings, as well as a free market for housing and a modern banking system. Stage 4: Ends the government monopoly of many industries and makes the ruble a convertible currecy.

BUDGET AND DEFICIT: ``Improving the state of finances and money circulation by slashing the deficit of the state budget,'' reducing the supply of bank notes and increasing bank interest rates on savings.
BANKING: Creating a central bank, similar to the U.S. Federal Reserve, to regulate credit rates and monetary supply ``no later than November of this year.''
CURRENCY: Establishing ``an internally convertible ruble'' to ``open up broad opportunities for the influx of foreign investments ... which the country badly needs.''
THE UNION VERSUS THE REPUBLICS: Laying ``the foundations for a voluntary unification of sovereign republics within the framework of a rejuvenated and strong union.''
STATE MONOPOLIES: ``Energetic measures ... for denationalizing and demonopolizing the economy, for promoting entrepreneurship and elements of competition.'
PRIVATE PROPERTY: Allowing privately owned property, land reform and stabilization of foreign economic ties.
AGRICULTURE: Allowing each of the 15 republics to decide whether to decollectivize farmland or maintain the system of collective and state ownership dating from 1929-32.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., British Hostages Reported Moved to Eastern Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: American and British hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists have been moved from Beirut's southern slums to eastern Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, Lebanese military intelligence sources said today. The hostages were moved last week, before Saturday's attack by government troops and the Syrian army that crushed Gen. Michel Aoun's rebellion in the Christian heartland northeast of Beirut, the sources said. ``We have accurate information the captors whisked the captives out from south Beirut a few days before the attack,'' one source said. ``The Syrians are certainly aware of the transer. They control all roads from Beirut to the Bekaa. But we do not know whether they had any role in it,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Another army intelligence source, who also spoke on condition he not be named, confirmed that the hostages were moved to the Bekaa. ``But we don't know whether they were tipped off about the attack and asked to make the transfer, or they took the move for other considerations that we are not aware of,'' he said. The tank-led attack on Aoun was mounted from three directions, one of which was the densely populated Shiite Moslem southern slums, a major power base of the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah. Hezbollah, or Party of God, is believed to be the umbrella of Shiite extremists holding most of the Western hostages in Lebanon. The Western hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. The longest held is Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Both intelligence sources said the hostages spirited to the Bekaa were the six Americans and two of the Britons: Anglican church envoy Terry Waite and journalist John McCarthy. ``We believe they are now held in Sheik Abdulla barracks in Baalbek and in the nearby village of Nabi Sheet,'' one source said. ``But we do not know who, or how many, are held in either place.'' Sheik Abdulla barracks, a former Lebanese army garrison, is the command post of about 3,000 Iranian Revolutionary Guards who were stationed in the Bekaa after Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Nabi Sheet is a Hezbollah base 12 miles southeast of Baalbek, which is about 40 miles east of the Lebanese capital. The Syrians, who maintain 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate, have often skirmished with Hezbollah militiamen in Beirut and the Bekaa but have carefully avoided confrontation with the Iranian guards. Syria was the only active Arab ally of Iran during its eight-year war with Iraq. Syria and Iraq are governed by rival wings of the Arab Socialist Baath Party. The Syrians were instrumental in arranging the release of two American hostages and two Swiss captives of the Red Cross this year.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Moving Storm System Smashes Eastern Seabord; 1 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs, `Some homes...', to add quote. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `In Virginia...'; SUBS 10th graf pvs, `Another 80,000 ...' to UPDATE with school closings; ADDS graf at end with storm destroying motel in Rhode Island.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX27, CH1
DOC.TEXT: Intense storms that sped across the Eastern Seaboard spun off tornadoes that killed one person in Virginia and destroyed homes and injured at least 50 people in Baltimore suburbs. Thursday's storms poured rain into the halls of Congress in Washington, D.C., and left tens of thousands of people without electricity from Virginia to the New York City area. The storm system, although strong, passed quickly through most areas, and today's forecast called for generally fair weather and reduced winds. Some homes in Baltimore's suburbs were condemned early today after a tornado ripped through the area, tearing off roofs and tossing uprooted trees through the air. ``I didn't hear nothing until the roof was on top of me. All of a sudden, the whole roof caved in,'' said Alverta Payne, 80. She escaped her home in Reisterstown, Md., by crawling through the wreckage of her third floor. In Virginia, the storm system produced two tornadoes, the weather service said. One took the life of a farmer and left a trail of damage across the state. Russell Martin, 73, was crushed to death when the old wooden barn in which he took cover was shattered by a tornado early Thursday night, King William County Sheriff W. Wayne Healy said. The storm front dropped six inches of rain in Albemarle County before it headed to sea. Storms hit Washington, D.C., with 60 mph winds that knocked down trees. Heavy rain poured through the west side of the Capitol dome and into the Rotunda, forcing workers to cover a half-dozen statues with plastic sheeting. Utility companies said as many as 80,000 customers lost power in the District of Columbia and neighboring Virginia. Another 80,000 homes in Baltimore lost power as winds of 75 mph or more blew down utility lines, and power was also out in 2,000 homes in parts of Delaware. Four schools were closed in northern Delaware and four elementary schools were closed in Baltimore County this morning. Fifty to 70 people were believed hurt in Baltimore, authorities said, but most of the injuries appeared to be minor. In Reston, Va., residents of the Southgate condominium complex said winds toppled trees and ripped holes in the roofs of several homes. ``We've got trees uprooted, trees down, limbs all over the place. Parts of roofs are missing,'' said Tish Hidebrand, who works at the condominium complex. Strong winds from a severe thunderstorm buffeted Newark International Airport in New Jersey and damaged some homes in the state. Air traffic was not disrupted and the only reported injuries were five people hurt when winds overturned a storage trailer near a taxi area, the officer said. In Montgomery Township, N.J., high winds damaged seven homes and sent eight people to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. Montgomery police Lt. Kenneth Chrusz said one home was ``reduced to kindling'' and another was ``virtually torn in half'' by the high winds. In counties surrounding New York City, more than 90,000 customers temporarily lost electricity, utility officials said. In Rhode Island, thunderstorm winds flattened a hotel in a resort area, but no injuries were reported. The 10-room Paddy's Motel along Westerly's Misquamicut Beach was closed for the off-season when the storm hit. A few weeks earlier and the motel would have been crowded, a fire official said. Utility officials said about 1,700 customers, most in the southwest part of the state, were without power early today.

DOC.HEAD: Minimal Hurricane Heading Northwest Toward Bermuda
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd-4th grafs, bgng `At 6...' to UPDATE with 9 a.m. position, speed. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `It appears...'.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Nana moved northwest over the open Atlantic toward Bermuda early today, with top winds of 75 mph, forecasters said. A hurricane warning for the island was expected to be posted later today, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 9 a.m. EDT, Nana was centered about 275 miles south southwest of Bermuda. The eighth hurricane of the Atlantic hurricane season was headed northwest at near 10 mph and a turn to the north was expected later today, according to Robert Case, a hurricane specialist at the center. ``It appears as though the center (of the hurricane) is going to come pretty close to the island in the next 24 to 36 hours,'' Case said. ``But because it's such a small hurricane, it could pass by the island entirely.'' Hurricane force winds extended only 25 miles to the east of Nana's center, Case said. He said early today that there was only a 30 percent chance Nana's center would pass within 65 miles of Bermuda when it reaches the area early Saturday. The system formed Tuesday off Puerto Rico as a tropical depression, and achieved hurricane strength Thursday. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: A Capitol Dilemma: How to Cut Spending and Still Bring Home the Bacon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf pvs `Hours later ...' to ADD details of projects. SUBS 8th graf pvs `Just this ...' to CORRECT figure to 2,800 sted 28,000
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alfonse D'Amato took to the Senate floor this week, scolding his colleagues for spending beyond their means. ``What about some fiscal discipline? What about a freeze?'' the New York Republican demanded. ``What about maybe a cut? What about eliminating some programs?'' Hours later, D'Amato's press secretary was on the phone giving reporters what has become the senator's nightly pork report - i.e., a list of millions of dollars for New York projects won by D'Amato's legendary tenacity on the Appropriations Committee. D'Amato had taken credit for a $17 million appropriation to help build a road bypassing the town of Corning; $100 million over six years to help clean up two polluted lakes and the Long Island Sound; $11 million to build a second railroad track between the tip of Manhattan and Penn Station; and $1.45 million to buy land for a veterans' cemetery somewhere around Albany. Is Congress trying to cut spending or bring home the bacon? The answer is, both. On the floors of the House and Senate, Congress has been debating proposals to reduce thebudget deficit by $500 billion over the next five years. Meanwhile, conference committees have been meeting to craft appropriations bills that will spend the government's money. The timing could hardly look worse. Just this week, one of the 13 Senate appropriations subcommittees received a wish list of 2,800 special projects from various senators, said Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark. ``Those same senators then come in here with unctuous, pontificating statements about how, if we could just freeze this or that, we could get the deficit under control,'' Bumpers said on the Senate floor Wednesday. And with elections less than a month away, members need to look fiscally tough at the same time as they're taking credit for this bridge or that veterans' hospital. Take Rep. Doug Barnard Jr., a Georgia Democrat locked in a tense re-election race. On Tuesday, Barnard issued a press release saying he had voted against the House budget package because it would have increased taxes by $149 billion over five years. ``If the rest of the Congress had followed my lead and voted for across-the-board cuts and freezes to spending bills all year, we wouldn't be faced with trying to find massive cuts here at the 11th hour,'' he said. The next day, Barnard issued another release bragging that Fort Gordon - in his district - will get $10.6 million from federal coffers for a ``soldier support center'' that would consolidate all administrative offices. The Army originally requested the money for fiscal 1992, Barnard noted, but he petitioned the House Appropriations Committee to fund the center a year sooner. ``Everybody wants to reduce the deficit but nobody wants to contribute to the reduction,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole said earlier this week. Yet, the Kansas Republican recently took credit for helping win $28 million for military projects back home, as well as $1 million to relocate a soup kitchen. Of course, only the politically naive would expect a senator or congressman to give up money for a pet project, right? Well, maybe not. Last week, Rep. Carl Pursell, R-Mich., walked into the energy and water development appropriations conference and asked that $3 million to clean up the Rouge River near Detroit be stricken from the bill, the money returned to the Treasury. ``As far as I know, it was an unprecedented move - removing a project from a bill,'' Purcell said afterward on the House floor. ``If each member of this body followed suit, and would give up any of their projects, the numbers would begin to become significant.''

DOC.HEAD: Party Postpones Mission After Softening of U.S. Measure on Racial Comments
DOC.TEXT: Governing party officials postponed a planned mission to Washington today after a U.S. congressional committee decided not to demand the resignation of a Japanese Cabinet minister for his remarks about American blacks. The U.S. House Foreign Affairs Committee voted Thursday to condemn Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama's remarks, but amended its resolution at the last minute to remove a call for his resignation. Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party immediately postponed the trip by a delegation of lawmakers, who had planned to try to soothe the anger of members of Congress over the remarks. On Sept. 21, after a police roundup of foreign prostitutes in a red-light district in Tokyo, Kajiyama compared the arrival of the prostitutes to blacks moving into neighborhoods in the United States and forcing whites out. His remarks were immediately condemned in the United States, and Kajiyama retracted the comments four days later and apologized. ``Now that the resolution has been modified, it may be better to find a more appropriate time to consult with (members of Congress) rather than go there hastily,'' Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the governing party, told reporters today. Kyodo News Service reported that Kajiyama expressed relief when he learned that the resolution did not include a call for his resignation. ``I am aware of the passage of the bill, but I can't comment on it because I have not heard about the details,'' Kyodo quoted him as saying. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said it was ``regrettable'' that the resolution was approved. When asked to assess the affect the remarks had on bilateral relations, he acknowledged that ``it is a serious incident.'' Watanabe urged Americans not to conclude that Japanese are racists. ``It is wrong to assume that all the Japanese are sharing that view represented in the statement made by Mr. Kajiyama,'' he said. Meanwhile, opposition party leaders attacked Kajiyama and demanded that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu dismiss him, but Kaifu said he had no intention of doing so. Kaifu has repeatedly called the remarks ``inappropriate'' and rebuked Kajiyama, but protests continued to grow both inside and outside of Japan. In the United States, the Congressional Black Caucus prepared a resolution demanding Kajiyama's resignation, and some black groups called for a boycott of Japanese products. In hopes of stopping the passage of the resolution, the justice minister sent a letter of apology Wednesday to Rep. Ronald Dellums, who chairs the 24-member caucus, but the group refused to withdraw the resolution. Kajiyama is the latest of a series of Japanese politicians who offended minorities with public racial remarks. In 1986, then Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said Americans have a lower intelligence level than Japanese because the population includes a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans. In 1988, former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said American blacks have few qualms about going bankrupt and implied that they walk away from debts.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Goes Home After `Miraculous' Recovery from Heart Defects
LaserPhoto SB01 of Oct. 18.
DOC.TEXT: A nearly 3-month-old baby was released from the hospital after recovering from serious heart defects that once made him a transplant candidate. Weston Kilpatrick left Loma Linda University Medical Center in good condition Wednesday, but still faces the prospect of future surgery to repair remaining defects, hospital spokesman Dick Schaefer said. ``We're very excited and cautiously optimistic as we take Weston home,'' said his father, Layne Kilpatrick, a 31-year-old pharmacist. ``He's doing well. Although the future is uncertain for Weston, he has amazed us.'' ``Everyone's really excited that Weston can get home in this sort of shape without a transplant,'' said Dr. Steven Gundry, who performed surgery to repair some of the defects that didn't heal. Weston was born July 27. He suffered several congenital cardiac defects, including underdevelopment of the left side of his heart, underdeveloped heart valves, an open duct between two arteries and a narrowed aorta, which is the main artery carrying blood from the heart to the rest of the body. Layne and Janet Kilpatrick and their 4-year-old daughter, Danielle, moved from the central California community of Lompoc to Redlands in order to be near their son while he waited for a donor heart. Gundry repaired the duct and artery problem Oct. 7 after the usually fatal underdevelopment of the heart's left pumping chamber got better on its own. The valves also showed some improvement. That recovery, which doctors called virtually miraculous, eliminated the need for a heart transplant to save Weston's life. ``Weston has continued to improve,'' Gundry said Wednesday. ``He still has problems with one of the valves in his heart and a few small holes in his heart. But right now he's really amazed all of us.'' Schaefer said the holes allow a small amount of blood to flow between chambers of the heart in an unwanted manner and may require corrective surgery later. Loma Linda has become a leading center for newborn human heart transplants since 1984, when Dr. Leonard Bailey implanted a baboon's heart in the infant known as Baby Fae in an attempt to save her life. She suffered a more severe underdevelopment of the left side of her heart.

DOC.HEAD: Gambino Sons, Others Arrested on Extortion Charges
DOC.TEXT: Two sons of the late crime boss Carlo Gambino were arrested on charges of monopolizing trucking in the city's garment district with threats, extortion and violence. State indictments accuse Thomas and Joseph Gambino, along with five other trucking executives, of dividing the district into zones, each run by a specific mob-controlled trucking company that agreed not to compete in another's territory. With competition eliminated, mob truckers could charge extortionate rates and extract millions of dollars more in profits than a legitimate trucking concern would have earned, District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said Thursday. That caused ``a `mob tax' on every garment shipped in New York City, which is ultimately passed along to the consumer,'' Morgenthau said. If a garment shipper used an independent trucker, Morgenthau said, the mob truckers would make the shipper pay them anyway. The suspects used their reputations as gangland figures to scare dozens of manufacturers and contractors into cooperating, he said. During the two-year investigation, undercover police ran a dress shop, Morgenthau said. The officers also ran a small trucking company. One indictment charges Thomas Gambino, 61; brother Joseph, 54; and their employees John DiSalvo, 39, and Raymond Buccafusco, 61, with enterprise corruption and 52 other counts of larceny by extortion, coercion and restraint of trade. Thomas Gambino was the head of the criminal enterprise while his brother and DiSalvo were his principal operating officers, Morgenthau said. The millionaire Gambino brothers are sons of the late ``boss of all bosses,'' Carlo Gambino, who ran the gang that bears his name and is now allegedly controlled by John Gotti. If convicted, they face up to 25 years in prison and loss of their trucking companies. The companies, also charged in the indictment, are Consolidated Carriers, Clothing Carriers, Greenberg's Express, and GRG Delivery Corp. Named in a second indictment on charges similar to those in the first are Michael Vuolo, 55; David Stuart, 49, of Hollywood, Fla.; Stuart's son, Mark, 27; and six companies they own. At arraignment in Manhattan's state Supreme Court, the city's trial-level court, Acting Justice Herbert Altman set bond ranging from $50,000 for Buccafusco and Mark Stuart to $1 million for Thomas Gambino. The defendants later posted bond and were released.

DOC.HEAD: Giant Plumes on Neptune's Moon May Be Dust Devils Instead of Geysers
DOC.NOTE: Eds; SUBS 12th graf, `Ingersoll said..', to CORRECT to `dust-devil theory sted' `geyser theory.'
DOC.TEXT: Black plumes rising five miles above Neptune's moon Triton may be swirling funnels called ``dust devils'' instead of volcano-like geysers as many researchers believe, a study published today says. ``The majority theory is still that they're geysers. But we're having a lively debate,'' said planetary scientist Andrew Ingersoll of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. At least four plumes were discovered in photographs taken by the Voyager 2 space probe when it zoomed past Neptune and Triton in August 1989. The plumes of nitrogen ice, nitrogen gas and carbon dust rise five miles high, then flatten into clouds that drift 90 miles downwind. Because they are so tall, ``a lay person would call them volcanoes. But the proper technical term is geysers - if that's what they are,'' said Edward Stone, Voyager's chief scientist and director-designate of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena. In a study published today in the journal Science, Ingersoll and Caltech graduate student Kimberly Tryka argue the plumes are five-mile-tall dust devils, similar to those on Mars and on Earth's windy deserts. ``A dust devil forms when the floor of the desert gets much hotter than the air right above it,'' Ingersoll said Thursday. ``The air near the ground is very buoyant and just rises. If there's a little breeze blowing, it can get spinning. You get this narrow column that extends up to 2,000 feet. On Mars, they extend up 3{ miles.'' Ingersoll said he thinks the plumes are dust devils because they remain narrow as they rise off bare spots on Triton's icy surface. Volcanoes and geysers usually form umbrella-shaped plumes, he said. A study by Laurence Soderblom and Randolph Kirk of the U.S. Geological Survey in Flagstaff, Ariz., and Robert H. Brown of Jet Propulsion Laboratory says nitrogen and methane ices that cover much of Triton's surface act like a greenhouse, trapping heat from the sun. They say the heat vaporizes underground ice, which then erupts through overlying ice to form geysers. The debate is important for ``understanding the solar system in which we live,'' said Roger Yelle, a planetary scientist and geyser advocate at the University of Arizona, Tucson. Ingersoll said the main problem with the dust-devil theory is that Triton's atmosphere is so thin wind shouldn't be able to whip up dust and nitrogen ice. For dust devils to form, Triton's dust and ice would have to be 1,000 to 10,000 times less ``sticky'' than similar materials on Earth, Ingersoll said. The flight past Neptune and Triton capped an $865 million exploration of four planets and more than 50 moons by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Voyager 1 and 2 space probes. The twin craft were launched in 1977. Both visited Jupiter and Saturn. Voyager 2 went on to Uranus and Neptune. The Voyagers now are zipping toward the edge of the solar system. Neptune is usually the eighth planet from the sun. But because of Pluto's elongated orbit, Neptune now is temporarily the ninth and outermost planet.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Operator, Seven Men Acquitted of Manslaughter in Zeebrugge Disaster
DOC.TEXT: A judge today cleared a company and seven of its former employees of manslaughter charges in the sinking of a ferry off Belgium three years ago that left 193 people dead. The justice, Sir Michael John Turner, told the jury on the 27th day of the trial to find P and O European Ferries (Dover) Ltd., three former directors and two seamen not guilty. He said the prosecution had failed to legally prove manslaughter. Turner also ordered the jury to acquit two other seamen when the prosecution said it would drop its case against them. Relatives of the victims fought for more than three years to bring what is believed only the second charge of corporate manslaughter against a company. In the first case, a construction company was acquitted in 1965. The judge told the jury that ``evidence already called is such that you, properly directed, could not properly convict the company and the five most senior defendants.'' All defendants had denied a single charge of manslaughter. Only one person who died in the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise ferry was named in a test case to simplify the charges. They were the ferry company, chief marine superintendent Jeffrey Develin, deputy chief marine superintendent John Alcindor, technical director Wallace Ayres, senior master John Kirby, master of the Herald David Lewry, chief officer Leslie Sabel, and assistant boatswain Mark Stanley. The prosecution dropped its case against Sael and Stanley. They had been accused of unlawfully killing Alison Gaillard, 27, a passenger aboard the Herald of Free Enterprise when it capsized outside Belgium's Zeebrugge harbor on March 6, 1987. The ferry set sail with her bow doors open. The man responsible for closing them, Stanley, had been asleep in his cabin, and Sabel, the officer responsible for ensuring they were closed, admitted he had not fulfilled his duty. The charges alleged there was an obvious and serious risk that because of the failure by the defendants to do their duties the Herald would sail with open doors, capsize and cause death. The defendents allegedly either gave no thought to the risk, or if they recognized it, still took it. But the judge said there was no direct evidence that a reasonably prudent person occupying the position of any of the five senior defendents would have perceived that the risk was obvious or serious. Victims' families were ``very disappointed and saddened'' by the outcome, said Maurice de Rohan, chairman of the Herald Families Association and the father of Mrs. Gaillard, the one victim named in the manslaughter charge. The company, which was covered by insurers, has settled piecemeal most claims by survivors and relatives.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Attorney Drops Request for Retrial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Barry dropping request for retrial. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry today withdrew his request for a new trial on a misdemeanor cocaine possession. ``I have spoken with my client, and he has decided to withdraw that motion for a mistrial,'' defense lawyer L. Kenneth Mundy told U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson during a pre-sentencing hearing. Barry, scheduled to be sentenced Oct. 26, faces up to a year in prison and a maximum fine of $100,000. He did not attend today's court session. Law enforcement officials had said U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens might consider retrying the mayor on a dozen charges the jury could not resolve if Barry pushed ahead with his request for another trial. Stephens had said earlier that he would not conduct another trial. Mundy said today that the decision to withdraw the request was reached before the government filed papers opposing the motion. On Thursday, Mundy had asked that the sentencing be delayed because he hadn't had enough time to respond to a pre-sentencing report prepared by the mayor's parole officer. ``We disagree wholeheartedly with the pre-sentencing report,'' Mundy said. The report was not released in open court, but Mundy said his chief objection was its apparent conclusion that Barry has neither shown remorse nor taken responsibility for his actions by admitting to prior drug use. ``There is an ongoing probe of Mr. Barry, and some of the questions being asked (of witnesses) involve drug use by Mr. Barry,'' Mundy said. ``It would have been very perilous for him to make any pre-sentencing statement to the parole officer until we know that there will be no other trial.'' The judge denied the request to delay sentencing. According to Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts, the report said Barry ``affirmatively denied'' using drugs. If a defendant admits guilt in a pre-sentencing report, he often is given a lighter sentence than if he denies culpability. In his motion for retrial, Mundy had argued that Barry should receive a new trial because some of the jurors witnessed a drug sting at the hotel where they were sequestered. A jury convicted Barry on Aug. 10 of one misdemeanor cocaine possession count, acquitted him of another and deadlocked on a dozen other counts, including a charge resulting from his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at a downtown Washington hotel. Barry chose not to seek a fourth mayoral term next month, but is running for the city council.

DOC.HEAD: Featured on TV Show, Escaped Prisoner and Guard Are Caught
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The department...', with 3 grafs to add background on other fugitive arrested this week in Canada, Lawrencia Bembenek. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Kerns, 29...'. ADDS 2 grafs on end with further on Bembenek.
DOC.TEXT: A female jail guard and an escaped male inmate were arrested at a motel in Canada a day after their disappearance was featured on a television show, authorities said. Edgar Eugene Kerns, who escaped from the Allegany County Jail on Aug. 29, and guard Sandra Kay Beeman were arrested Thursday after a viewer of NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries'' contacted authorities, the Allegany County Sheriff's Department said. Royal Canadian Mounted Police also arrested another high-profile prison escapee this week as a result of a television show. Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek was captured Wednesday in the tourist city of Thunder Bay, Ontario, after a tip came from someone who had seen her case described on ``America's Most Wanted.'' The one-time police officer and former model fled to Canada with her fiance after escaping from a Wisconsin prison three months ago. In the Maryland case, the sheriff's department alleges that Beeman let Kerns and another inmate escape. The other inmate, James Vernon Barnes, 35, of Romney, W.Va., was captured in Hampshire County, W.Va., four days after the jail break. Kerns, 29, and Beeman, 46, of Frostburg, spent several weeks at a motel in Hamilton, Ontario. They moved several miles away to another motel Wednesday night and were arrested there early the next day, the sheriff's office said. They were held by authorities in Hamilton, about 30 miles south of Toronto. Kerns faced charges of grand larceny, assault and passing a bad check. Barnes was serving 50 years on kidnap and rape charges in Virginia when he was transferred to Allegany County to be tried for kidnapping, rape and possession of a deadly weapon. For three days after the escape, authorities believed Beeman was a hostage. One of the escapees allegedly had his arm around Beeman's neck when the three left the jail. Beeman, a guard at the jail for 10 years, was dubbed a fugitive after she called her 21-year-old daughter in Frostburg and told her, ``I'm fine. I'm with him,'' authorities said. Beeman has been charged with aiding an escape, a felony with a maximum penalty of 10 years in jail. Ms. Bembenek and Dominick Gugliatto were arrested after authorities were contacted by an ``America's Most Wanted'' viewer who recognized Ms. Bembenek in a Thunder Bay restaurant. Ms. Bembenek was serving a life sentence for the 1981 killing of Christine Schultz, the previous wife of Ms. Bembenek's then-husband. Authorities allege Ms. Bembenek, 32, killed Mrs. Schultz out of resentment for the $700-a-month alimony payments she was receiving.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Symphony Announces Soviet Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Georg is cq
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra will make its first tour of the Soviet Union next month, says its conductor, Georg Solti. The tour will mark the last overseas trip with the orchestra for Solti, whois in his final season with the musicians. The tour ``solidifies the idea of cultural exchange ... since while we go to Russia, the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra visits Chicago for five concerts,'' said Henry Fogel, executive director of the orchestra, on Thursday. ``We must show the spiritual side of our life,'' Solti said. ``What could be a better ambassador for that than the Chicago Symphony?'' The tour starts in Leningrad Nov. 21 and moves to Moscow on Nov. 24. The orchestra also will visit Vienna and Budapest during the tour, which ends Dec. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Senate to Debate Anti-Obscenity Curbs on Arts Endowment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-6, beginning `At issue ...' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with floor action on bill delayed; ADD non-obscenity pledge. Picks up 7th graf pvs `Current law ...
DOC.TEXT: Weary from a bruising battle over the federal budget, the Senate is wading into another fight over whether to renew strict anti-obscenity restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts. The debate pits Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and his conservative allies against supporters of a bipartisan compromise proposal, which would have the courts decide whether federally supported arts projects are obscene. At issue before the Senate was an $11.7 billion appropriations bill for the Interior Department and several other federal agencies in the 1991 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. The Senate measure contains $170 million for the NEA and the same anti-obscenity curbs that Congress imposed a year ago. Acton on the bill was delayed until late tonight or Saturday so the Senate can tackle more pressing end-of-session legislation, including a stopgap resolution extending government spending authority through Wednesday. The Senate bill ignores a House-approved compromise that would omit any explicit obscenity ban. The House bill would require the NEA to recoup its money from grant recipients who later are convicted of violating obscenity laws. A similar judicial approach to the ``obscene art'' issue had been approved on a bipartisan 15-1 vote by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, but Helms effectively blocked floor action on that measure. In a move apparently aimed at placating Helms, the Senate Appropriations Committee voted to keep the NEA alive for one more year, trim its proposed $175 million budget and reinstate the strict, Helms-inspired obscenity ban for another year. The bill also would allow NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer to continue to require grant recipients to sign a non-obscenity pledge before they can receive federal funds. The pledge, which the House voted to scrap, has caused widespread protests in the arts community and is the target of three federal lawsuits. Current law forbids the endowment to finance any works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homosexual and sadomasochistic activities, the sexual exploitation of children and ``individuals engaged in sex acts.'' The House voted to scrap the obscenity restrictions and extend the NEA's statutory authority for three years, with a first-year budget of $180 million compared with $171 million last year. The House bill said only that obscenity lacks artistic merit, is not protected speech and ``shall not be funded'' by the endowment. Last year the NEA awarded $153 million in grant money to nearly 4,500 artists and arts institutions, from opera and ballet companies to painters and poets. Most of the grants required matching funds from private sources. Whatever the outcome of the Senate debate, it will remain for negotiators to reconcile differences between House and Senate versions before a final bill is ready for enactment. The Senate compromise bottled up by Helms was drafted by liberals Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and conservatives Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Nancy L. Kassebaum, R-Kan.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf under US-Egyptian Aid to CORRECT that opponents say legislation would set bad precedent, sted because it amount to giving aid to a foreign country without congressional approval
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of the major legislation and issues yet to be resolved as Congress heads toward adjournment of the 101st session, possibly by the end of next week:
DOC.HEAD: BUDGET AND TAXES
DOC.TEXT: -The House and Senate are searching for a compromise budget reduction package. The government is scheduled to run out of money at midnight tonight, but White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president was prepared to sign legislation to keep the government in business for another five days until final budget details are worked out. The House-passed bill would hit hard at higher-income Americans, chiefly by raising the maximum 28 percent tax rate on top earners to 33 percent and imposing a 10 percent surtax on those with incomes over $1 million. The Senate bill would not change tax rates but would limit itemized deductions of those with incomes over $100,000. Final passage is needed on 13 appropriations bills financing government agencies in the new budget year, which started Oct. 1.
DOC.HEAD: ARTS-OBSCENITY
DOC.TEXT: -An $11.7 billion appropriations bill that would reinstate strict anti-obscenity restrictions on the National Endowment for the Arts is pending in the Senate. The bill would trim the agency's $175 million budget request by $5 million. Opponents favor a House-approved proposal to let the courts decide whether federally subsidized art works are obscene.
DOC.HEAD: CLEAN AIR
DOC.TEXT: -Members of a House-Senate conference committee are laboring to formally approve compromise clean air legislation, which would be the first major rewrite of this law in 13 years. The conferees have tentatively approved provisions requiring tougher emission controls on automobiles, and any compromise package would have to be approved subsequently in both the House and Senate.
DOC.HEAD: CHILD CARE
DOC.TEXT: -Senate leaders and the Bush administration have reached agreement on the broad outlines of legislation providing assistance for low-income families. But major differences with the House remain an obstacle to passage. The latest Senate version is a five-year, $15 billion package. Most of the money would go for an expansion of earned income tax credits for low-income working families with children.
DOC.HEAD: ASSAULT WEAPONS
DOC.TEXT: -The Senate has approved an omnibus anti-crime bill that would ban the sale of nine semiautomatic assault weapons. But the House version contains no such provision. Instead, the House may vote on a bill to outlaw ownership or sale of semiautomatics the Treasury Department deemed not suitable for sporting purposes. The politically influential National Rifle Association opposes both bills and House sponsors are clearly nervous over whether their measure could survive on the floor at this stage.
DOC.HEAD: FARM BILL
DOC.TEXT: -A compromise $40.8 billion farm bill covering government agriculture programs for the next five years awaits final passage by both the House and Senate. A version of the bill approved by House and Senate conferees would, among other things, slash farm spending by $13.5 billion over the next five years, as part of a larger deficit-reduction package.
DOC.HEAD: CABLE TV
DOC.TEXT: -Supporters of legislation reimposing some government regulation hope a compromise accord reached in recent days will ease the way toward final passage in both the House and Senate. Under terms of the compromise, the industry would be required to sell network programs to about 3 million mostly rural owners of backyard satellite dishes, according to Senate sponsors.
DOC.HEAD: US-EGYPTIAN AID
DOC.TEXT: -Included in a Senate version of a foreign aid bill yet to be approved is a provision aimed at forgiving $6.7 billion in debts that Egypt owes to the United States. Supporters say the measure is needed to show that Middle Eastern nation appreciation for its backing of the U.S. military deployment to the Persian Gulf in the wake of the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait. Opponents complain that it would set a bad and expensive precedent and that other nations would seek the same type of relief.
DOC.HEAD: KEATING INVESTIGATION
DOC.TEXT: -The Senate Ethics Committee is pressing ahead with its investigation of senators who assisted Charles H. Keating Jr. as his Lincoln Savings and Loan was sinking toward collapse.
DOC.HEAD: CIVIL RIGHTS
DOC.TEXT: -The House and Senate have passed and sent to President Bush the Civil Rights Act of 1990 aimed at overturning the effects of recent Supreme Court decisions reversing some affirmative action programs. Bush promised in advance of final passage that he would veto the bill, and a veto override attempt could take place in Congress once Bush has acted.

DOC.HEAD: New York State Acts Against Major Barge Company
DOC.TEXT: A family-run shipping business with a history of accidents and illegal operations was ordered to pull its barges out of the spill-plagued New York harbor. The action by the state Department of Environmental Conservation was the first time it has exercised its authority to ground an entire fleet of barges since the department was created in 1970. Commissioner Thomas C. Jorling said the companies and individuals named in his order have a record so bad that, ``their continued operation presents an imminent danger to public health and irreparable damage to the environment.'' One of the company's barges, operating illegally, sank Sept. 27 at the First Marine Shipyard on Staten Island, spilling 50,000 gallons of oil into a waterway known as the Kill Van Kull. That was only the latest in a series of unrelated spills that have dumped more than 1 million gallons of petroleum products into the harbor during the past year. The three companies named in the order are among the 45 or so owned by the family of former city Ports and Terminals Commissioner Susan Frank, as well as her mother, brother and sister. They control at least 19 barges - about 10 percent of all commercial barges operating in the harbor, Jorling said. The companies are Berman Enterprises Inc. of New York City, and General Marine Transport Corp. and Standard Marine Services Inc., both of Bayonne, N.J. Also named were 72-year-old Evelyn Berman Frank, who heads General Marine; Peter Frank, president of General Marine; and Jane Frank Kresch, secretary of Berman Enterprises. Telephoe messages left at their offices were not immediately returned. The barges are to remain docked at least until a hearing Oct. 30, at which time the company will be allowed to present its case. After that, the environmental conservation department will determine whether to lift the shutdown order or allow the companies to operate under restrictions. The companies are also the subject of an ongoing criminal investigation, Jorling said. In addition to the sinking of the Sarah Frank last month, the companies have been responsible since 1983 for nine known oil spills, three groundings, two collisions and 21 other cases in which the Coast Guard assessed penalties, Jorling's order said. They have also been involved in fires and explosions that have resulted in the deaths of two people and serious injuries to others, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Third Death Confirmed in Florida Encephalitis Outbreak
DOC.TEXT: A third death was confirmed in an outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis, a mosquito-carried disease that has spread to 18 Florida counties, health officials said. A 69-year-old Orange County man who died Oct. 13 was a victim of encephalitis, bringing to three the total deaths in the outbreak, said Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services spokesman Ernie Durfee on Thursday. His identity wasn't immediately released. Tests also were performed Thursday to determine whether a 91-year-old man who died Monday in Martin County was a victim of the disease, but Durfee said they were incomplete. Local health officials said he had suffered flu-like symptoms that closely matched those of encephalitis. Three cases were confirmed Thursday in central Florida, bringing to 46 confirmed cases statewide. An additional 23 people have passed the first of two confirmation tests. ``We're still classifying it as an outbreak, not an epidemic,'' Durfee said. So far, the outbreak was confined to central and southern Florida. In 1977, the last major outbreak, 110 cases were reported and eight people died. Because encephalitis is carried by mosquitos that prefer to bite after dark, health officials have urged people to wear long clothing when going outside at night. Municipalities have stepped up spraying of insecticide, and outdoor activities such as prep football games have been moved to daytime.

DOC.HEAD: Police Raid Offices of Former Communist Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th grf pvs, `The former...' to CORRECT that elections in March; Pickup 13th, `Former functionaries...'
DOC.TEXT: Scores of armed policemen raided the offices of the renamed East German Communist Party to seek clues in an alleged $65 million fraud case. A Berlin prosecutor said, however, that the raid shortly before midnight on Thursday at the offices of the Party of Democratic Socialism turned up no such information. The prosecutor spoke on condition of anonymity. The raid was the latest action by the united German government against vestiges of the old, often corrupt regime that ruled former East Germany for 40 years. It came on the first anniversary of Communist Party boss Erich Honecker's ouster as leader of the former hard-line government. German law enforcment officials said they raided the offices to check on suspicions that the former Communists may have illegally transferred $65 million to the Soviet Union. Party chief Gregor Gysi and other top party officials today protested the action at the Berlin offices, saying it violated their rights and would only radicalize former Communists trying to fit into the new society. ``I'm exhausted with this daily struggle to destroy us,'' he said. Gysi said an unspecified sum had been transferred to the Soviet Union to cover living expenses for German students the party had sponsored there. He said such payments were an ``old financial burden'' inherited from the former Communist Party. Gysi's office was among those searched by 150 police officers wearing bullet-proof vests. The party headquarters is near Alexanderplatz, the central square of former East Berlin. Also searched was the office of Hans Modrow, former premier of the Communist caretaker government that ran East Germany after the old regime was ousted following mass demonstrations last year. Gysi, Modrow and 23 other members of the former Communist Party are members of the united German Parliament. East German lawmakers were added to the West German legislature when the two nations united on Oct 3. The former Communists finished third in East Germany's state elections in March. Former functionaries in the old party are believed holding millions of marks in property and cash because of their position of privilege during the old regime. A police spokesman said the offices were raided ``because of the danger of delay.'' Germany has been struggling with how to deal with the remains of the old Stalinist order that ruled the nation with an iron fist. Lawmakers are debating whether to grant amnesty to the thousands who worked for eastern Germany's secret police and government. More than 60 former East German spies have been arrested in western Germany in recent months. Authorities also are trying to decide whether to prosecute members of the old power elite for corruption, abuse of power and other charges. Prosecutors are investigating whether to charge Honecker, 78, who is suffering from kidney cancer in a Soviet military hospital oustside Berlin. But they have been unable to make sufficient progress in their criminal probe to arrest the deposed East German leader, officials said today. Berlin Justice Department chief Jutta Limbach said various factors, including a lack of a sufficient number of prosecutors, has slowed the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Witness Saw Richards Use Cocaine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for SANTA FE, N.M.-dated story cited on PM-News Digest
DOC.TEXT: A tour operator has told an investigator that he witnessed Texas' Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards using cocane 13 years ago, a newspaper reported today. The Richards campaign denied the allegation. The Albuquerque Journal said tour operator J.D. Arnold of Santa Fe, N.M., told a Bexar County, Texas, sheriff's investigator that he saw Richards use cocaine in a foyer outside a restroom at the Stoneleigh P. bar in Dallas. He said the incident occurred during the early morning hours of Dec. 7, 1977, after a fund-raising banquet for then-congressman Jim Mattox. Richards' staff said Arnold is a former aide to Mattox, whom Richards defeated in a bitter Democratic primary runoff this spring. After Richards refused to say yes or no when asked during a debate whether she had ever abused illegal drugs, Mattox sought to make that question a primary campaign issue. The Richards campaign said Arnold is an unreliable source because of his past run-ins with the law and that Arnold's charge is a tactic by Richards' opponent, Republican Clayton Williams. Judy Powers of Los Alamos, N.M., said she was at the gathering that night and said Richards never was there. ``I don't know why he'd want to help Clayton Williams,'' Ms. Powers said. ``He's been a lifelong Democrat. But I do know that Ann Richards was not there.'' Jim DeLesdernier, chief of the criminal investigation division for the Bexar County sheriff's office, said he flew to Santa Fe on Monday to talk to Arnold as part of an investigation into drug trafficking in the San Antonio area. He said the trip was not politically motivated and refused to say whether there had been an allegation of cocaine use by Richards. DeLesdernier said Sheriff Harlan Copeland authorized the trip to interview Arnold. He said that although Arnold's charges involve events past Texas' five-year statute of limitations, he believes they could lead to more recent incidents. ``Don't you think that on the surface it stinks?'' Monte Williams, a spokesman for Richards, told the newspaper. After the story was published today, the Richards campaign scheduled an afternoon news conference. Williams called it ``laughable'' that the Bexar County sheriff would spend tax money to research an allegation of an incident from 1977, adding that it was ``a sign of how desperate the Clayton Williams campaign has become.'' Reggie Bashur, a spokesman for Williams, said today that the GOP campaign had nothing to do with Arnold or his charges.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges Help for Hungarian Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 9 grafs new with Antall comment, etc.; pickup 6th graf pvs: ``In his, etc.
DOC.TEXT: The first democratically elected Hungarian leader to visit the White House in four decades is taking home a packet of Bush administration pledges to help his ailing economy. ``Our visit here has opened a new era in U.S.-Hungarian relations,'' Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said at a farewell news conference. Among Antall's worries as he tries to steer the Central European country toward political democracy and a free market system is spillover from a faltering Soviet economy. Bush said Thursday the United States would provide $47.5 million in agricultural credits and loan guarantees to help Hungary recover from a drought-inflicted grain shortage. Bush also announced he would push for international lending concessions for Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland, and that U.S. travel restrictions on Hungary's diplomats would be lifted. In addition, Hungary will establish a consulate in Los Angeles. Antall stressed Bush's promise to encourage American firms to do business in Hungary. ``It is very important to us to see American investments in Hungary and we would like to see them strengthened in the future,'' he said, speaking through an interpreter. Antall said his delegation had discussed with U.S. officials how to insulate Hungary from economic chaos should the already faltering Soviet economic go into a deeper tailspin. Despite Hungary's break from communism its ties to Moscow are still strong. Besides his meeting with Bush, the Hungarian leader visited Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, before being honored at a White House state dinner Thursday night. In his welcoming remarks to Antall, Bush answered Hungary's request for what one administration official referred to as a ``strong signal'' to foreign investors. ``I encourage more American businesses to find out what Hungary has to offer,'' the president said. ``Hungary is no longer an emerging democracy. Hungary is a democracy,'' he said. To help Hungary stabilize its economy as it moves from communism to a free-market system, Bush called on the International Monetary Fund to make lending concessions to it and other Eastern European countries. He said the lending organization should make $5 billion available to compensate the new democracies for the burden they are suffering by supporting United Nations sanctions against Iraq. ``We understand that the loss of export markets and rising energy costs complicate your historic effort to transform a centrally planned economic system to a free-market economy,'' Bush told Antall. Hungary plans to send a military medical unit to Saudi Arabia, where the bulk of the U.S. troops are stationed in opposition to Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, said Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Curtis Kamman. Bush told the Hungarian he was pleased with Antall's support for the U.S.-led opposition to Iraq. He also said he would seek acceleration by the Wold Bank of aid in the energy field, drawing on $9 billion already committed to Central and Eastern Europe. Antall said the president had ``granted us everything that we could have enumerated as our request or as our complaints.'' In fact, he said in a toast at the state dinner that Bush is so popular in Hungary that he probably could find a good political job there when he is through being president of the United States. ``I'm sure the Hungarian nation would surely elect you as president,'' Antall told Bush.

DOC.HEAD: National Festival Cancelled Because of Royal Family Death
DOC.TEXT: Monaco's annual national festival has been canceled because of the death of Princess Caroline's husband, Stefano Casiraghi, in a boating accident Oct. 3. The royal palace said Friday that the Nov. 19 festivities - including a soccer game between AS Monaco and England's Tottenham Hotspurs - would be canceled. Instead, a special service will be held at the Cathedral of Monaco, the palace said.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Family Asks Court to Let Woman Die
DOC.TEXT: The family of a woman who has suffered two strokes is asking a County Court to remove the feeding tubes that keep her alive. Joseph M. Ragona filed suit Thursday, the day after Orphan's Court Judge Frank P. Eagen declared Ragona's wife, Ruth, incompetent and appointed him as her guardian. The couple's four children filed affidavits supporting their father's request. Named as defendants are the hospital and state Attorney General Ernest D. Preate Jr., whose responsibilities include representing ``the state's interest in the preservation of life, prevention of suicide and maintenance of the ethical integrity of the health care profession,'' according to the suit filed in Lackawanna County Court. The petition said that Mrs. Ragona ``stated in unequivocal terms to her family member that she did not want her life to be prolonged by artificial means or other mechanical life-sustaining procedures.'' Mrs. Ragona, 63, suffered a stroke in 1984 and has remained hospitalized at Moses Taylor Hospital since a second stroke Feb. 8. The woman's physician, Dr. Vithalbhai D. Dhaduk, said in a letter that Mrs. Ragona does not understand or react to questions, and that there is ``no chance that she will improve.'' The petition argues that Mrs. Ragona has the right to be removed from the tubes because of ``Pennsylvania's doctrine of informed consent prohibiting a physician from instituting any medical procedures without a patient's express consent.'' Hospital spokeswoman Tricia Pahoski said the hospital would not comment on the case. The attorney general's office also said there would be no immediate response. Last June, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in a Missouri case that under that state's laws, the state could keep a patient on life support in the absence of ``clear and convincing proof'' that the person would want to die.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed, 73 Injured in Massive Autobahn Pileup
DOC.TEXT: A massive pileup in dense fog involving more than 200 cars killed 11 people and injured 73 others Friday, police said. Some cars caught fire and rescuers needed several hours to clear the wreckage and pull out all the victims, police said. The crash near this southern German town stopped traffic on the busy highway linking Nuremberg with Berlin for most of the day. Police arrested the driver of a truck that rammed into four cars, killing eight people. There are no speed limits on most highways in western Germany and there are frequent crashes withthe arrival of the autumn fog.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Pelt Government Building With Vegetables, Manure
DOC.TEXT: About 50 farmers angered by government agriculture policies bombarded a government building with vegetables, paint and liquid manure during a late-night raid, police said Friday. Seven people were arrested after a highway chase, police said. The attack apparently was part of a nationwide protest campaign by farmers upset over agriculture policies and low-priced meat imports. Police said the farmers arrived at an administrative center in Dijon about 11 p.m. Thursday in 12 vehicles, then hurled eggs, tomatoes, black paint and bottles full of liquid manure at the facade of the building. The farmers fled after about two minutes, but police gave chase and arrested seven suspects near Sombernon, 18 miles away. Dijon is 195 miles southeast of Paris.

DOC.HEAD: 51 Die in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: A crowded bus plunged into a 500-foot ravine in the Hamalayan foothills Friday, killing at least 51 people and injuring 11, police said. Six children were among the victims, according to police officials quoted by local news agencies. Rescuers pulled 51 bodies from the gorge, but the death toll could be higher, they said. The accident occurred near the town of Pithoragarh close to the border of Nepal, about 180 miles east of New Delhi.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa's Governing Party Opens Itself to All Races
DOC.TEXT: The governing National Party agreed to open its membership to all races Friday when the last of four provincial congresses voted to support the proposal of President F.W. de Klerk. ``Our goals are beyond reproach and we can say with elation that the National Party is on course,'' de Klerk told 1,000 congress delegates meeting in Pretoria. All four provincial congresses easily passed the measure, which called for eliminating racial qualification for membership. Approval by the congresses permits the party hierarchy to make the change. The move represented a sharp reversal for the National Party, which implemented the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance after gaining power in 1948. The party has traditionally been the political domain of Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended whites who domiate the government. Despite the move, it was not clear if many blacks would join the National Party. African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela has said any prominent black would be commiting political suicide if he joined the governing party. Even if blacks were to join the National Party, South Africa's constitution prohibits them from voting in national elections. De Klerk has pledged to end apartheid and negotiate power-sharing with the black majority. He also has sought the lifting of international economic sanctions imposed against South Africa to protest apartheid. Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha told the congress South Africa had emerged from international isolation since de Klerk became president just over a year ago. He noted that world leaders who previously rejected South African leaders now receive them.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dissidents Sentenced to Jail Terms; Monks Warned
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers have sentenced two dissidents jail terms, a government spokesman said Friday. It was the latest crackdown on the party that won free elections but has been barred from taking office. Also, Buddhist monks have been warned to stop refusing to perform religious ceremonies for soldiers and their families. The dissidents were members of the National League for Democracy, the pro-democracy force that easily won elections held on May 27. But the military has refused to relinquish control, and most of the party's leaders have since been arrested. The military government took power in 1988 by brutally crushing a nationwide pro-democracy movement. Human rights groups including the London-based Amnesty International say troops killed several thousand people that year. A government spokesman told a news conference Friday that the seven-year jail terms for the two dissidents were handed down Thursday by a military tribunal. The two - Ohn Kyaing and Thein Tan - were arrested on Sept. 6 and accused of inciting unrest in the central city of Mandalay. Ohn Kyaing was a central committee member for the league in Mandalay and Thein Tan a party organizer. At a meeting in Rangoon Thursday, Prime Minister Gen.
