DOC.HEAD: Hard Times for Soviet Soldiers in United Germany
DOC.TEXT: The once-mighty Red army has fallen on hard times in the new Germany. Its military mission is over, its presence is resented by many Germans, and its soldiers are deserting in droves to avoid going home. Once they were crack front-line troops in the Cold War. Now the Soviet soldiers stationed in what was East Germany find themselves a relic of a bygone era. Final withdrawal of the 600,000 troops and dependents is not scheduled until 1994. Already, the strain is showing. The Soviet forces are a heavy financial burden for newly unified Germany, now saddled with enormous costs of the merger. The Bonn government agreed to pay upwards of $800 million this year to maintain the Soviets. Germany will also pay billions to retrain and build new housing for the troops. ``A nightmare'' is how Heinrich Vogel, head of the Federal Institute for Soviet and International Studies, describes the problems associated with the presence of the Soviet troops. The soldiers face uncertain futures in the Soviet Union, where jobs, housing, and food are scarce. The temptation is great to stay in newly reunited Germany, where life is easier and consumer goods abundant. Some Soviet soldiers are resigned to going home, but want to buy as much as possible to take with them. The entry to the Soviet base at Wuensdorf, south of Berlin, is a cross between a used-car lot and a central Asian bazaar. Soldiers are snapping up everything from leather coats to used BMWs. Others are deserting to try to stay in Germany. The Interior Ministry said Friday that 53 Soviet soldiers had registered for asylum in the last two months. The figure is almost certainly higher, as it takes weeks to register the cases. Authorities in Berlin said 10 Soviet soldiers a day were seeking asylum before unity on Oct. 3. The number fell when the Soviet military introduced harsher punishment for deserters - the maximum penalty is death. A German Foreign Ministry spokesman acknowledges the problem is ``delicate.'' The Bonn government, he said, is trying to work with the Soviet government on the desertion problem. German government officials do not know how many Soviet troops will try to avoid returning home, but they agree that unity and Germany's liberal asylum laws make it easier to consider staying. Desertion was almost impossible while the Berlin Wall stood. East German police were required by treaty to turn deserters over to the Soviet military. Once the wall fell, a Soviet soldier could cross into West Germany and apply for asylum. Police in unified Germany are not required to return deserters to Soviets military authorities, who have now stepped up patrols to curb desertions. Although there is resentment of the Soviet presence, there is sympathy for the plight of individual soldiers. A week ago, Soviet military authorities were unnerved by an outpouring of civic support in Weimar for Oleg Luchak, a young Soviet deserter on trial. A group of young Germans sheltered the family and lawyer of the young soldier, who said he left his unit because of ``extreme necessity.'' Townspeople lit candles on a fence in front of the courtroom. A week later, the Soviets reversed a longstanding policy of no fraternizing between the soldiers and local residents. They invited the town to visit the base. A similar invitation has been extended to the residents of Franfkurt an der Oder, a town on the Polish border. Even before the new ``open door'' policy, the barrier between Germans and Soviet soldiers had begun to collapse. Soviet soldiers began receiving German currency on July 1. But they found themselves second-class citizens in a land of plenty. A private's monthly wage is only $16. Violence, theft and corruption are on the rise among troops desperate for money. Police report that hard-pressed Soviet soldiers are selling weapons including machine guns and grenades as well as uniforms. One officer reportedly rented out the men from his unit to help on a local collective farm.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Blockade, Imported Food Plentiful In Baghdad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An array of imported food can be seen in Baghdad grocery stores these days, despite the United Nations trade embargo imposed on Iraq in retaliation for its invasion of Kuwait. But many of the items on store shelves are from what Iraqis call their 19th province - Kuwait, which was stripped of consumer goods after Iraq took over on Aug. 2. Buyers in Baghdad can find mackerel from China, sardines, tuna and pineapples from Asia, olives from Morocco, butter cookies from Denmark and grape juice from Austria. They can even get American hot sauce. But whether they can afford the items is another question. Prices are rising beyond the reach of the common man in this city of 4.5 million. At Baghdad's popular riverside fish restaurants almost all the tables are full, and diners have a choice of roast chicken, baked fish or beef. But a chicken lunch in an average restaurant costs $15. Motorists at Baghdad's open market pack their cars with whatever food is available. ``Before, I used to buy food for the whole month; now I buy all the food I can get,'' a taxi driver said. The basics - wheat, milk, sugar and tea - are not available and ``this is hurting many average Iraqis,'' said a European diplomat, who like the others spoke on condition of anonymity. The government has rationed these items along with cooking oil, soap, detergent and rice. ``The milk situation is pretty grim,'' said an Iraqi official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. He would not give any figures, but said: ``I would say that pretty soon, we will be in a serious crisis.'' ``Our assessment is that without any external help, Iraqis can last four to five months,'' said an Asian diplomat. ``And by that time, their winter wheat crops will be ready.'' He noted that Iraqi farmland is very fertile and abundantly irrigated by rivers. ``Like any other developing society, farming had been neglected in Iraq, but now it appears that the government is serious,'' he said. Before the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait brought on the U.N. embargo, Iraq had imported most of its food. Now, in an effort to fight the blockade, the government has asked farmers to triple wheat cultivation by devoting all farmland into the crop. Financial incentives have been offered and orders issued that no land should go to waste. ``We expect big response and big success,'' said Deputy Prime Minister Sadoun Hamadi. ``These objectives center on the main issue of self-sufficiency in grains, at least at a minimum level, although some say that we are able to go beyond that,'' Hamadi said. State television runs programs on how to raise poultry, an Iraqi staple, and cultivate the ubiquitous date palm. ``There is tremendous enthusiasm,'' said Jihada Samran Abedhi, a 50-year-old mother of seven children, who heads a collective farm at Sholei, 16 miles west of Baghdad. About 200 men and women work on the farm. ``We are planting wheat on 80 percent of our land this season,'' she told a group of reporters. ``We are also planting barley, beans and potatoes.'' ``We know about efforts by imperialist America to starve us, but this is not going to work,'' Mrs. Abedhi said as she drove off to instruct a group of farmers. Availability of fertilizers is uncertain, and spare parts and lubricants for agricultural equipment, as well as imported seed, may run out because of the trade embargo, diplomats said. ``If the government succeeds in promoting agriculture the way it is doing now, it will suddenly be a big plus point in fighting the blockade,'' said the European diplomat. ``But then you just cannot survive on wheat,'' he said. ``They need cooking oil, sugar and beans.'' While there appear to be no critical food shortages yet, the U.N. blockade is reportedly hitting Iraqi industry hard. ``At least 60 percent of the industry is either closed or about to close down,'' the Asian diplomat said. ``Many are running below 25 percent capacity. ``Time will come when Iraqis will need cement, steel or plastic. Where are they going to get it from?''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Iraq Will Not Be Rewarded With Compromise
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised Friday that Iraq's aggression will ``not be rewarded by some compromise'' and said that American forces in the Persian Gulf are ready for military action if necessary. Bush met for more than an hour with senior Soviet official Yevgeny M. Primakov, who was sent to Iraq two weeks ago by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in search of a political settlement. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush emphasized that ``the international community is prepared to consider alternative options'' if sanctions and diplomacy fail to drive Iraq's army out of Kuwait. Fitzwater said, ``The president's resolve was firm and firmly expressed.'' The United States has provided the bulk of troops - more than 200,000 - and naval units to defend Saudi Arabia and the gulf. The Soviet Union, while solidly backing economic pressures against Iraq, has made only a minimal contribution to the multinational force in the gulf. Emerging from the meeting, Primakov expressed hopes for a peaceful outcome but said the Soviet Union strongly supports United Nations resolutions and sanctions against Iraq. ``I believe we should not rule out the possibilities of a peaceful solution until we have exhausted all options,'' the Soviet official told reporters in the White House driveway. At the same time, he said Iraq's aggression was unacceptable. ``One cannot allow a situation where actions which are incompatible with the civilized society would be applauded,'' he said. Primakov said he was not carrying any message from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``because I am not a messenger.'' Similarly, White House officials said there were no new proposals. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, asked if there were any signs that Iraq was willing to compromise, said, ``Not that I'm aware of.'' Even before Primakov arrived at the White House, Bush emphasized U.S. unwillingness to make any concessions to Saddam. ``I'm determined as I was the day that the first troop left that Saddam Hussein's aggression not be rewarded by some compromise,'' the president said. ``Not be rewarded by our failing to get him totally out of Kuwait or restore the legitimate rulers.'' In remarks to Italian-American leaders, Bush said, ``the bottom line is, he can't prevail.'' In his private talks with Primakov, Bush said U.S.-Soviet cooperation has been an important factor in isolating Saddam. Fitzwater said Bush told Primakov ``there is no interest, either on the part of the United States or the international community, for any partial solution to the blatant aggression that Iraq has perpetrated against Kuwait.'' Fitzwater said Bush had told Gorbachev, at their September summit in Helsinki, that U.S. forces in the gulf ``are available should their use be necessary, and that point was made again today.'' Primakov outlined his personal impressions of Iraqi leaders, whom he knows well, and discussed the situation in the gulf and the prospects for a diplomatic solution. Fitzwater did not characterize Primakov's remarks. The Soviet official replied guardedly when reporters asked if he were optimistic about chances for a peaceful settlement. ``I cannot say that I have become less moderately optimistic than I used to be before,'' Primakov said. Meanwhile, Fitzwater said there was an urgent need for steps to be taken at the U.N. to help the handful of American officials who are keeping the U.S. embassy in Kuwait open in defiance of Iraqi occupying forces. ``Clearly some kind of action will need to be taken in the not too distant future to either resupply the embassy or to remove or otherwise ensure the safety of our citizens there,'' he said. ``So it is an imminent question that we need to deal with, and we think the U.N. is the appropriate forum to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Gubernatorial Candidates Threatened During Debate
DOC.TEXT: An anonymous caller made a threat against gubernatorial candidate Jim Edgar and someone fired a shot into a building where his opponent, Neil Hartigan, has his office. State police were investigating the incidents, which occurred while Democrat Hartigan and Republican Edgar participated in a televised debate at the state Capitol Thursday night. A shot was fired into a glass-fronted building housing the office of Hartigan, who is Illinois attorney general. State police were summoned. An hour or so later, an anonymous caller phoned Gov. James R. Thompson's mansion and told executive security personnel, ``You can tell Jim Edgar that he'll get trouble from us too.'' Edgar is the secretary of state.
DOC.HEAD: Richards Ad Attacks Williams' Remarks
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ann Richards is using Republican Clayton Williams' own words in a new attack ad aimed at her opponent in the Texas governor's race. The ad repeats Williams' controversial joke about rape, plus a more recent comment that he hoped Richards, a recovering alcoholic, ``didn't go back to drinking again.'' The commercial ends with an announcer asking, ``Governor Williams?'' The commercial is ``evil and malicious,'' said Gordon Hensley, a spokesman for the GOP candidate. ``The more the people see of him, the better for us,'' said Richards consultant Glenn Smith. The most controversial of Williams' remarks was a joke about rape, made last March, when he likened bad weather to rape and said if it were inevitable ``relax and enjoy it.'' Williams quickly apologized, saying he didn't mean to offend anyone.
DOC.HEAD: Lie Detector Results Buoy Embattled Grunseth Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Jon Grunseth told about 100 cheering supporters Friday that he's staying in the governor's race. He says a lie detector test has shown him innocent of allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls. ``I'm in until November sixth,'' Grunseth, an Independent-Republican, told a news conference on the state Capitol steps. The lie detector test, Grunseth said, ``exonerates me on every charge leveled at me. But I know the media and I know you will have doubts. That's your job,'' he said. Grunseth has accused Gov. Rudy Perpich and his supporters of being behind the allegations. The governor, his aides and family members also should take lie detector tests, said Grunseth. Two young women alleged that he swam nude with four teen-age girls at a 1981 party, tried to touch the breast of one of them and served beer to minors.
DOC.HEAD: Martinez Charges Chiles-MacKay Will Raise Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez said Friday that Democratic foes Lawton Chiles and Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay are liberal ``Washington insiders'' out to raise taxes. Chiles has indicated he might revive the state tax on services next year. Martinez focused on that point before the Florida Association of Realtors convention. Martinez promoted the service tax, then repealed it, three years ago. Real estate commissions were exempt from the services tax for sales of homestead properties. Chiles said he wouldn't rule out raising taxes and would take a look on how to make a services tax fairer than the repealed version. Martinez has signed the biggest tax increases in Florida history. His popularity plummeted after the services tax controversy. Chiles told the convention that Martinez was hardly a tax-cutter. ``I want to find out what the hell we've done with the $3.8 billion that we've raised over the last four years,'' Chiles said. The two have a debate scheduled for Oct. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Operator, Seven Men Acquitted of Manslaughter in Ferry Disaster
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday acquitted a company and seven of its former employees of manslaughter charges in the sinking of a ferry off the coast of Belgium three years ago. The disaster on the Herald of Free Enterprise left 193 people dead. The justice, Sir Michael John Turner, told the jury to find P and O European Ferries (Dover) Ltd., three former directors and two former seamen not guilty on the trial's 27th day. He said the preosecution had failed to prove manslaughter. He also ordered the jury to acquit two other former seamen when prosecutors said they would drop their case against them. If convicted, the company would have faced an unlimited fine and the seven men could have received a maximum sentence of life imprisonment. Relatives of the victims fought for more than three years to bring what was believed to be only the second charge of corporate manslaughter against a company. In the first case, a construction company was acquitted in 1965. In explaining the acquittal, the judge told jurors the ``evidence already called is such that you, properly directed, could not properly convict the company and the five most senior defendants.'' The Herald of Free Enterprise, a car and passenger ferry, overturned off the Belgian port of Zeebrugge carrying 454 passengers and 80 crew members on March 6, 1987. Headed for the southern English port of Dover, it had set sail just six minutes earlier with its bow doors open. All the defendants had denied the manslaughter charge. Only one person who died in the sinking of the ferry was named in the test case to simplify the charges. The defendants were accused of unlawfully killing Alison Gaillard, 27, a passenger who was on a day trip aboard the ferry. Besides the company, the defendants were the chief marine superintendent Jeffrey Develin, deputy chief marine superintendent John Alcindor, technical director Wallace Ayres, senior master John Kirby, and master of the Herald David Lewry. Chief officer Leslie Sabel and assistant boatswain Mark Stanley were the two defendants whose cases were dropped by prosecutors. They said it was not in the public interest to proceed. Stanley, the man responsible for closing the bow doors, was asleep in his cabin, and Sabel, the officer responsible for ensuring they were closed, has admitted he did not fulfill his duty. Turner said there was no direct evidence that a reasonable person occupying the position of any of the five senior defendants would have perceived the risk as obvious or serious. Families of the victims were ``very disappointed and saddened'' by the outcome, said Maurice de Rohan, chairman of the Herald Families Association and the father of Mrs. Gaillard. But he said, ``the fact that it came to court and that corporate responsibility was accepted as a possible verdict was important. Society progresses in steps. We believe that we have progressed.'' The company has settled piecemeal most of the claims by survivors and relatives. Another judge who headed a 1987 inquiry into the disaster blamed the tragedy on sloppy management at the company, formerly called Townsend Thoresen, but he ruled that no statutory offense had been committed by the ferry operator. An inquest earlier had returned a verdict of unlawful killing.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev and Yeltsin Can't Agree on Soviet Union's Future
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with fresh Gorbachev quotes. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The government...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his main political rival, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, are deadlocked over the economic and political future of the Soviet Union. After Yeltsin quit the Communist Party last July, Gorbachev sought to compromise with him over how to shift the country from a centrally planned to a market-driven economy. Those efforts broke down a month ago, and the dispute intensified on Tuesday after Gorbachev disclosed his latest reform package. Gorbachev's plan, overwhelming approved Friday by the legislature, stops far short of the more radical one adopted last month by the Russian Federation parliament, which Yeltsin heads as president of the republic. Thus Gorbachev is trying to carry out moderate reform against opposition from the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Russia has more than half the Soviet Union's population and the lion's share of its natural resources, including oil, coal, gas, timber, gold and diamonds. Gorbachev took Yeltsin to task on Friday in a speech to lawmakers. ``Comrade Yeltsin's assertions are strange, to say the least,'' he said. ``I'm under the impression that the Russian leadership is afraid of difficulties and wants to pass on responsibility for possible difficulties and consequences .... onto central organs of power.'' Yeltsin, for his part, derided Gorbachev's program hours after it was disclosed on Tuesday, calling it ``another endeavor ... to perpetuate the system hated by the people. Yeltsin predicted ``it will take less than six months to realize that the chosen road is another blunder,'' adding: ``If we procrastinate and put off further, there will be nothing to reform because the economy will simply fall to pieces.'' The government seems already in pieces, and that will hamper any reforms Gorbachev puts forward, says Ed Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. ``What is important is confidence in the government, and that is falling,'' he said. ``Even if you produced a very detailed plan that was very radical, but gave it to a government that has a reputation of doing nothing, little could happen.'' Beyond the question of confidence and rivalry, the heart of the dispute between Gorbachev and Yeltsin concerns the political structure of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev seeks in his program to preserve ``the integrity of the union as a federation.'' Yeltsin says the republics should take control of their own economies, then negotiate new forms of cooperation among themselves, not unlike the East European nations that broke from Moscow last year. Besides a rebellious Russia, Gorbachev faces a growing separatist movement in the second-most populist republic, the Ukraine. Nearly all of the Soviet republics have declared some form of economic and political sovereignty, including the three Baltic republics, which have declared outright independence. Whether or not Gorbachev the reformer believes in Yeltsin's radical prescription, Gorbachev the politician is chained to a top-heavy government bureaucracy that perpetuates central rule. The normally tame state news agency Tass on Thursday endorsed the plan supported by Yeltsin. It is named after its principal author, economist Stanislav Shatalin. ``Gorbachev is unwilling to consider radically breaking the managerial structures amid increasing political instability,'' an inevitable result of Yeltsin's plan, the news agency said. But, Tass said, the plan ``is possibly the only form of surgery that can help the ailing Soviet economy recover.'' Gorbachev's defenders - who include many reformist economists - said his program represented the speediest possible path to doing away with the heavily centralized system, which has produced consumer shortages and a technologically moribund society. Abel Aganbegyan, a pioneer of Soviet reform, told lawmakers Wednesday that Yeltsin was motivated by ambition and not economics. ``He made a political speech and would have spoken this way regardless of what we had proposed,'' Aganbegyan said. The Communist Party daily Pravda, one of the most traditionalist publications, defended Gorbachev, saying the nation has inherited ``a pitiful legacy'' from the central planning system. Pravda praised a number of Gorbachev's proposed steps that would have seemed politically impossible a year ago, but are now being criticized by Yeltsin and others as half-way measures. They include: -Laying ``the foundations for a voluntary unification of sovereign republics within the framework of a federative and strong union.'' -Establishing ``an internally convertible ruble'' to ``open up broad opportunities for the influx of foreign investments ... which the country badly needs.'' A convertible currency is one that can be exchanged for other monies on the open market. -Creating a central bank, similar to the U.S. Federal Reserve, to regulate credit rates and monetary supply - bold new steps in a Soviet economy where credit has been all but unavailable and the government has printed rubles to meet its spending needs. -``Energetic measures ... for denationalizing and demonopolizing the economy, for promoting entrepreneurship and elements of competition.'' But those proposals don't meet the demands of Russia and other republics. If trends continue, the central government could lose authority, and it would fall to the republics to reconstitute the nation.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley, The Associated Press Chief of Bureau in Moscow, has covered Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Won't Seek Retrial In Drug Possession Conviction
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's attorney on Friday withdrew his request for a retrial on the mayor's misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction. ``I have spoken with my client, and he has decided to withdraw that motion for a mistrial,'' defense lawyer L. Kenneth Mundy told U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson during a pre-sentencing hearing. Barry, scheduled to be sentenced Oct. 26, faces up to a year in prison and a maximum fine of $100,000. He did not attend Friday's court session. Law enforcement officials had said U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens might consider retrying the mayor on a dozen charges the jury could not resolve if Barry pushed ahead with his request for another trial. Stephens had said earlier that he would not conduct another trial. Mundy said the decision to withdraw the request was reached before the government filed papers opposing the motion. In the 10-minute hearing Friday, Mundy asked that the sentencing be delayed because he hadn't had enough time to respond to a pre-sentencing report prepared by the mayor's parole officer. ``We disagree wholeheartedly with the pre-sentencing report,'' Mundy said. The report was not released in open court, but Mundy said his chief objection was its apparent conclusion that Barry has neither shown remorse nor taken responsibility for his actions by admitting to prior drug use. ``There is an ongoing probe of Mr. Barry, and some of the questions being asked (of witnesses) involve drug use by Mr. Barry,'' Mundy said. ``It would have been very perilous for him to make any pre-sentencing statement to the parole officer until we know that there will be no other trial.'' The judge denied the request to delay sentencing. Mundy originally asked for a retrial because he said some of the jurors were compromised when they witnessed a drug sting operation at the hotel where they were sequestered. A jury convicted Barry on Aug. 10 of one misdemeanor cocaine possession count, acquitted him of another and deadlocked on a dozen other counts, including a charge resulting from his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at a downtown Washington hotel. Barry, said in advance of his trial that he would not seek re-election, but announced his candidacy for the city council after the conclusion of his trial.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Crisis, Oil Crunch, Signal Harder Times For Farmers
DOC.TEXT: The Mideast crisis and the oil crunch are helping set the stage for some rougher times ahead for farmers, an Agriculture Department report said Friday. Net cash income of farmers - the difference between grosscash income and cash expenses - is still expected to be at a record level in 1990, probably in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion. That is unchanged from previous forecasts by the department's Economic Research Service. ``However, abundant crops, lackluster commodity prices, the oil shock and a weaker global economic outlook are putting downward pressure on farmers' receipts and boosting expenses for this quarter and into next year,'' the report said. Farmers have ``undergone a major financial restructuring'' since the previous oil shock and recession in the early 1980s, it said. Total farm debt has dropped about one-third from the 1983 peak of $193 billion. ``With a lighter debt burden and record income this year, U.S. farmers are in a stronger position to withstand a drop in income,'' the report said. The agency did not make a prediction of 1991 farm income, however. That forecast is expected to be announced during the department's annual outlook conference here Nov. 27-29.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Calls for Inquiry into Lebanon Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Friday called on the Lebanese government to launch an independent investigation into reports Syrian forces executed at least 30 supporters of Gen. Michel Aoun. The Lebanese government has denied that scores of soldiers loyal to Aoun were massacred after surrendering to Syrian and Lebanese forces who crushed his 11-month rebellion. President Elias Hrawi said Aoun ordered his troops to keep fighting even after he had broadcast a surrender message and taken refuge in the French embassy in Beirut on Oct. 13. Amnesty also called on Syrian authorities to investigate the role of their troops in the incidents, which it alleged took place during Aoun's defeat on Oct. 13-14. ``Although the full circumstances are not clear, the killings of prisoners are said to have been carried out by Syrian troops in retaliation for shootings of their soldiers by Aoun supporters,'' Amnesty said in an urgent appeal. Earlier this week, journalists in Beirut reported seeing a number of corpses in the mortuary at Baabda Hospital in Beirut. Amnesty said it did not have any names of the victims, ``but they are mostly reported to have been young men who were partially stripped and had their hands tied behind their backs before being shot in the head at close range.'' The London-based human rights organization said it was concerned about the safety of prisoners reportedly held by the Lebanese and Syrian armies. Amnesty said some of the prisoners had reportedly been taken from Lebanon to undisclosed places of imprisonment in Syria. ``Amnesty International has previously received reports of extrajudicial executions and torture of prisoners by Syrian forces in Lebanon. Torture of prisoners is widespread in Syria,'' the rights organization said.

DOC.HEAD: Protesting Federal Workers Arrested in Front of White House
with AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Twenty federal workers were arrested in front of the White House Friday as they chanted ``Furlough Bush, tax the rich,'' in a protest over the budget stalemate. The 20 members of the National Treasury Employees Union arrested for demonstrating without a permit were among about 200 unionized workers who rallied to protest the possibility of another government shutdown. Over the last several weeks, the nation's 2.4 million federal workers have faced furloughs and a government shutdown due to Congress' and the Bush administration's inability to agree on a deficit-reduction plan. The government did shut down over the three-day Columbus Day weekend, but the impact was limited. House and Senate negotiators worked Friday to find a compromise so another shutdown could be avoided, although the White House has indicated it would back an emergency spending bill to keep the government operating. ``It's come to this,'' Robert Tobias, the president of the 140,000-member union and the first to be arrested. ``This president and his predecessor have bashed the government work force for more than 12 years and demeaned the valuable public service it provides,'' Tobias said. Nearby, the American Federation of Government Employees held a separate rally. A few dozen workers marched in front of the White House chanting ``Read my lips, tax the rich.''

DOC.HEAD: UPI, Reuters, Settle Photo Dispute
DOC.TEXT: United Press International and Reuters settled a courtroom battle over photo services Friday, agreeing that Reuters will continue to supply the American wire service with foreign news photos but will cover the United States for itself. The legal settlement arose out of a 1984 agreement calling for UPI to supply Reuters with photographs from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. The agreement was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. Reuters later sued to void the agreement. UPI filed a counterclaim saying Reuters had negotiated in bad faith. The news organization said the settlement does not call for any compensation or monetary damages. UPI will have the option of ending the exchange agreement by giving Reuters 30 days notice, it said. Otherwise, the London-based agency will supply UPI with foreign news photos withut charge until September 1992. After that, UPI will have the option of subscribing to the Reuter service. Reuters will cover the United States with its own resources and will not use UPI pictures, the announcement said. It said UPI will sell its news photo service outside the United States without involvement by Reuters. In a separate statement, UPI announced the establishment of the Helen Thomas Unipresser Award, a $1,500 prize to be given annually to a UPI journalist for ``achievements in gathering and reporting the news with accuracy and fairness.'' Winners of 12 new monthly Unipresser awards will compete for the annual prize. Ms. Thomas, 70, joined UPI's Washington bureau in 1943 and has covered the White House since 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Battle For Provincial Afghan Capital Enters Sixth Day
DOC.TEXT: Moslem guerrillas and government troops battled a sixth day Friday for control of the provincial capital of Zabul in southern Afghanistan, diplomatic and rebel sources said. No casualty figures were known for either side. The guerrillas, known as mujahedeen or Islamic holy warriors, have fired a steady barrage of mortars into the besieged garrison overlooking Zabul's capital city of Qalat, about 220 miles southwest of Kabul, the Afghan capital, the sources said. About 500 soldiers barricaded in the fort were blasting resistance positions around Qalat with heavy aerial and artillery attacks, according to the sources, who insisted on anonymity. Afghan warplanes airlifted arms, ammunition and food to the troops, they said. Hundreds of government soldiers surrendered to the mujahedeen earlier this week, they said. On Oct. 4, the guerrillas captured Tarin Kot, the capital of Uruzgan province which shares a border with Zabul. It was the guerrillas' biggest success since Soviet troops withdrew from Afghanistan in February 1989. Qalat is considered strategically more important because its highway links eight Afghan provinces with Kabul. Diplomatic sources said Qalat's fall would not dramatically alter the military balance between the guerrillas and forces loyal to President Najibullah. But they said it would step up pressure on Najibullah and his Soviet backers to reach a settlement to the 12-year-old war, the bloodiest and costliest conflict of the decade. After the last of the 115,000 Soviet Red Army troops left Afghanistan, Washington and Moscow intensified discussions on how to end the war. The two superpowers have agreed that elections should be held to decide the political future of the country, but they still disagree on what role Najibullah would play in an interim government. Washington insists he must relinquish control over the military and intelligence agencies, a demand that Najibullah and Moscow reject. Moscow continues to send an estimated $500 million in weapons and supplies to Kabul every month. The United States provides about $300 million to the resistance annually.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Orders Foreigners to Report to Authorities; Rations Gas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf with Canada suspending operations at embassy in Kuwait, minor editing throughout.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA2, WX15
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Friday ordered all foreigners in occupied Kuwait to report to authorities or face punishment, and announced it would ration gasoline to save imported chemicals used in refining fuel. The gasoline rationing was the latest indication that international trade sanctions against Iraq are having an impact. The U.N. embargo was imposed two months ago to force Iraq out of Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. In New York, there was good news about oil. Prices were down $2.00 a barrel in early afternoon trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $34.70. Traders said prices eased after conciliatory remarks by an Iraqi official. Iraq's deputy prime minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said Thursday in Amman, Jordan, that he thought both sides in the crisis were reassessing their positions and that peace talks could be in the offing. But in Washington, President Bush said he saw no chance for compromise in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I am as determined as I was the day the first troop left, that Saddam Hussein's aggression not be rewarded by some compromise,'' Bush said in a meeting with Italian-American leaders. Bush met later with a Soviet envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, who said he agreed that the world should not relax its insistence on an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. ``One cannot allow a situation where actions that are incompatible with a civilized society would be in order,'' Primakov said after the meeting. A report published in Iraqi newspapers Friday said all foreigners in Kuwait must register with local authorities before Nov. 5. Those who fail to do so ``will be responsible before the law, and their residency cards will be canceled,'' the report said. Under Iraqi law, foreigners found without residency cards are punished with fines and imprisonment. The exceptions are citizens from Arab Cooperation Council nations - Egypt, Jordan and Yemen. About 400,000 foreigners are believed in Kuwait, including 2,000 Westerners that the U.S. State Department says are hiding from Iraqi soldiers. Hundreds more are held in Iraq, many at strategic sites to deter attack by the multinational force. About 200,000 U.S. soldiers and thousands from other nations are facing an estimated 430,000 Iraqi troops in the region. Saddam's forces overran his southern neighbor in a dispute over oil, land and money. With Kuwaiti oilfields, his share of world reserves increased to 20 percent, second only to Saudi Arabia. Despite Iraq's vast reserves, the Oil Ministry announced Friday gasoline rationing would begin next week. The U.N. embargo on Iraq has squeezed Baghdad's supply of imported chemicals used in refining oil. ``There is nothing to get worried about. ... The rationing is just a precaution,'' said oil minister Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi.``There is a lot of waste and by introducing the rationing we are going to cut that waste.'' Iraq is already rationing food staples such as milk, meat and bread. Baghdad says there are shortages of all such products - and many more. Car owners were ordered to pick up ration coupons at special centers, although the minister did not say how much gasoline would be allocated to each person or how long the rationing would last. Iraqis rushed to gasoline stations to stock up on gasoline Friday and long lines formed outside gas stations. In Moscow, U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney praised Soviet cooperation in bringing diplomatic and economic pressure to bear on Iraq and said ``we have not given up on that policy.'' ``I have also made it clear ... that we have not ruled out other options,'' said Cheney. He declined to speculate on possible U.S. military steps. Cheney later traveled to Paris for three days of talks with the French government on cooperation in the gulf crisis. France has deployed 13,000 troops in the gulf, the second-largest Western contingent after the United States. At the United Nations, the Security Council was considering a resolution that would allow nations hurt by Iraq's invasion to seek reparations from Baghdad's frozen assets abroad or against its future oil earnings, diplomats said. The resolution also threatens Baghdad with unspecified ``further enforcement measures,'' condemns Iraq's human rights violations in Kuwait, and demands that Iraq release all Western hostages, the diplomats said. No vote has yet been scheduled on the new resolution, they said. It would be the 10th U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Iraq. In other developments: -U.S. military officials in Saudi Arabia said there had been 2,500 interceptions, 240 boardings and 11 ``diversions'' of commercial ships since the embargo against Baghdad was imposed. -Iraqi troops have placed explosives at oil fields, gas and gasoline storage tanks as well as on bridges and viaducts in Kuwait, according to Sheik Mishal Mohammed al-Sabah, a member of the emirate's exiled ruling family. He was quoted as telling the Amsterdam newspaper De Telegraaf that Iraq plans to blow up the facilities if its soldiers are forced to withdraw. -Canada suspended operations at its embassy in Kuwait, Ottawa said Friday. Saddam ordered embassies in Kuwait closed after he annexed the emirate, and although only the British, French and U.S. embassies now remain open, most nations still recognize Kuwait as a separate nation.

DOC.HEAD: Everybody Makes a Motion in this Judge's Court
DOC.TEXT: Everybody made a motion in Judge Milton Wharton's courtroom. To the pop jazz beat of Sade's ``Smooth Operator,'' the judge, jurors, attorneys and spectators stretched and swayed under the guidance of an aerobics instructor in St. Clair County Circuit Court Thursday. Wharton said he thinks the four-minute session, held during a break in the trial of a personal injury lawsuit, helps keep people alert. ``I think it's probably very valuable for the jurors,'' said defense attorney Ann Hamilton, who participated in the aerobics. ``I think it helps keep them alert and attentive.'' The aerobics break was intended to let jurors exercise more than their civic duty. ``Sitting and listening can be very fatiguing,'' Wharton said. ``I saw no reason why exercise couldn't be beneficial to jurors who are forced to be inactive for long periods of time.'' The session Thursday was the third aerobics break during the trial. ``OK you guys, spread out,'' aerobics instructor Jan Voellinger said as the jury stood and stretched the length of one wall in the small courtroom. They began with simple inhaling and exhaling, followed by neck movements, looking to the right, center and left. The jurors then rolled their shoulders, punched the air and bobbed their hips. ``It does help relieve a little tension,'' Hamilton told the instructor. ``Can I do it during the closing arguments?''

DOC.HEAD: Janitor Accused of Trying To Electrocute Boss
DOC.TEXT: A school janitor on Friday denied he tried to electrocute his boss because of a poor work evaluation. Richard Dale Langston pleaded innocent to a charge of attempted murder and was returned to jail under $150,000 bond. A pre-trial hearing was scheduled for Nov. 5. Langston, 26, of Lynwood, was arrested Oct. 12 after boarding a jet at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport with a one-way ticket to Hawaii. Prosecutors allege that Langston wired a chain link fence at Kellogg Middle School in Seattle in an attempt to electrocute his supervisor, Jeffrey Minnix. When Minnix touched the fence the morning of Oct. 9, showers of sparks and smoke went off, said Dan Donohoe, a King County prosecutor's office spokesman. Minnix was saved from serious injury because he still wore his insulated motorcycle gloves, said Donohoe. A bare wire had been connected to the fence and plugged into a portable school building, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Proposes New Pathways Of Superpower Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday proposed new cooperation with the Soviet Union to punish nations that spread nuclear technology and to prevent regional conflicts like the one that now threatens the Persian Gulf. ``Our search for points of mutual advantage has been productive,'' Baker said in a major foreign policy speech. ``And the search must continue - in new, ambitious ways. We now need to pursue our hopes for the post-Cold War future.'' Specifically, Baker called for cooperation ``in a regular, almost day-by-day fashion,'' over a wide range of world problems, including threats to the environment and uncertain access to vital resources. ``These paths should cross at all levels - among persons, groups, firms, institutions, cities and states,'' Baker said. Baker sounded a note of caution in an otherwise optimistic assessment of the chances of moving beyond an easing of Cold War tensions to cooperation on several levels. While hailing the growth of political democracy and the decentralization of economic power in the Soviet Union, Baker said the process was marked unfortunately by ``a deterioration in Soviet life.'' Standards of living are falling shortages are spreading and this fall's harvest is rotting, Baker noted. Moreover, he said, ``freedom has unleashed age-old ethnic animosities that often shout down the voices of tolerance.'' Calling for understanding of the hardships ``a great people is now enduring,'' Baker said ``this other, darker side of the Soviet revolution concerns all of us.'' However, he said he stands ``on the side of hope, hope for a new Soviet Union built on democratic values.'' Baker delivered the speech to The American Committee on U.S.-Soviet Relations, a predominantly liberal private group that urged cooperation with Moscow long before it became U.S. policy in the last years of the Reagan administration. The Committee presented Baker with its George F. Kennan award, named for the American diplomat who helped originate the post-World War II policy of containing the Soviet Union and who later advocated superpower cooperation. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet foreign minister, is the co-recipient. He received his award earlier in the month in New York. Baker's proposal for joint management of problems by Washington and Moscow began on the military level since a central concern of cooperation up to now has been how to cope with huge arsenals of nuclear and conventional weapons. With new treaties to reduce arms nearing completion, Baker called for exchanges with Moscow that would enable the United States ``to learn more about the doctrine and strategy Soviet leaders follow for use of those weapons.'' In this vein, he said he would propose to Shevardnadze the establishment of a U.S.-Soviet working group on ways the two sides could deter attack and on the conversion of weapons to peaceful uses. Turning to other topics, Baker said Iraq's ``brutal subjugation of Kuwait leaves no doubt that even though the danger of U.S.-Soviet confrontation has eased the world remains a dangerous place.'' Therefore, he said, the United States and the Soviet Union should collaborate to try to anticipate regional conflicts and try to resolve them before they lead to war. Also, Baker said, the incipient nuclear programs of Iraq and North Korea ``are the best argument that our non-proliferation effort needs a new impetus to cope with a new danger.'' Consequently, he proposed the United States and the Soviet Union agree that stopping the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and missiles ``must be a central part of our agenda.'' Baker said the Bush administration, therefore, would work with the Soviet Union ``to explore sanctions'' imposed by the two superpowers on nations that amass weapons of mass destruction.

DOC.HEAD: Rap Star M.C. Hammer Pays $5 Million for Fremont Mansion
DOC.TEXT: Rapper M.C. Hammer, whose hit ``U Can't Touch This'' is the theme song of the Oakland Athletics and the Cincinnati Reds, is buying a $5 million mansion in the Fremont hills. Hammer's new 12.5-acre spread includes a V-shaped, one-story, 11,000-square-foot house with three master bedrooms, four dishwashers, a media room, exercise room, recording studio and a rehearsal hall for his chorus line. Two swimming pools, a reflecting pool and a nine-car garage round out the new digs, which Fremont developer John Dyer described as a ``Beverly Hills type of house.'' Hammer, 27, is a former batboy for the A's. He hit the big time with ``Please Hammer Don't Hurt 'Em,'' which sold 7 million copies. Hammer was raised in an East Oakland housing project and has lived in Fremont for five years. Real estate agents tried to interest Hammer in mansions in the exclusive suburbs of Atherton, Woodside and Blackhawk, but Hammer considers Fremont home. ``We're not competing to have the biggest house in Fremont,'' said Hammer's older brother and manager, Louis Burrell. ``We just count our blessings that we can build the house we dreamed of having. This is not an egotistical statement or anything.'' Hammer moved to Fremont after a stint in the Navy. Burrell, 30, followed a year later, and their mother and two older brothers also have moved here. Hammer has a recording studio and a practice studio in Fremont for himself and his dancers, Burrell said Wednesday. The new house, described as a modern, Mediterranean style, will replace Hammer's current 4,700-square-foot, four-bedroom home valued at $750,000.

DOC.HEAD: 88-Year-Old Nominated For Fiction Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lowercase `them' in 10th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: An 88-year-old Spanish immigrant who waited more than four decades to have his novel published is among nominees for fiction in the 1990 National Book Awards. Felipe Alfau was one of five novelists nominated in the fiction category. Others included two first-time novelists, Elena Castedo and Jessica Hagedorn, and writers Charles Johnson and Joyce Carol Oates. The nominations were announced Thursday by the National Book Foundation, the non-profit organization that sponsors the annual awards. In the non-fiction category, authors were nominated for works about the Morgan banking family, former President Nixon, American artist Jackson Pollock and Harold Ickes, a member of Franklin Roosevelt's cabinet. Alfau wrote ``Chromos,'' published by Dalkey Archive Press, in the 1940s. The book is about the experiences of a group of Spaniards who move to Manhattan in the 1930s. A translator for a New York bank before retiring, Alfau also wrote the 1936 novel ``Locos: A Comedy of Gestures'' and is the author of a children's book. Castedo, who grew up in Chile and worked at odd jobs while traveling around the world, was nominated for ``Paradise,'' published by Grove Weidenfeld. The book is about a Latin American ghetto family. Hagedorn, a poet, playwright and commentator for public radio, wrote ``Dogeaters,'' published by Pantheon Books. Her first novel explores native tradition and popular American culture colliding in the Philippines, Hagedorn's homeland. Johnson, a professor of English at the University of Washington, was nominated for ``Middle Passage,'' published by Atheneum Publishers, about a newly freed slave's voyage on a slave ship bound for Africa in 1830. Oates, who won the National Book Award for fiction in 1970 for her novel ``them,'' is nominated for ``Because It Is Bitter, and Because It Is My Heart,'' published by E.P. Dutton-William Abrahams Books. Her 20th novel is about a young white woman and a black classmate brought together by a murderous street fight. Finalists in the non-fiction category include: -Ron Chernow for ``The House of Morgan: An American Banking Dynasty and the Rise of Modern Finance,'' publisher Morgan Entrekin Books-Atlantic Monthly Press. -Samuel G. Freedman for ``Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students and Their High School,'' publisher HarperCollins. -Roger Morris for ``Richard Milhous Nixon: The Rise of an American Politician,'' publisher Henry Holt. -Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith for ``Jackson Pollock: An American Saga,'' publisher Clarkson N. Potter. -T.H. Watkins for ``Righteous Pilgrim: The Life and Times of Harold L. Ickes, 1874-1952,'' publisher Henry Holt. The two winners will be announced Nov. 27. Each winner receives a $10,000 check.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Clash With Palestinians in Gaza, At Least 10 Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shot and wounded at least 10 Palestinians in the occupied Gaza Strip Friday during a violent protest of the killings on Jerusalem's Temple Mount earlier this month. The clash was sparked by hundreds of worshipers in the Khan Yunis refugee camp who marched out of mosques and paraded with outlawed Palestinian flags chanting, ``Our blood for Al Aqsa, for Saddam,'' Arab witnesses said. They were referring to the Al Aqsa mosque, on the Temple Mount, where at least 19 Palestinians were killed on Oct. 8. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is viewed by most Palestinians as a hero because he has tried to link the Israeli-Arab conflict to the Gulf crisis. Arab reports said soldiers fired live ammunition, tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the Gaza demonstraters. Hospital officials said 10 people were admitted with live bullet wounds and over 50 were treated for injuries from rubber bullets. The army said its troops opened fire after coming under a hail of stones and that 13 Palestinians were ``slightly'' wounded from live ammunition and rubber bullets. In Jerusalem, meanwhile, police used water cannons to disperse hundreds of Moslem youths who were protesting at being barred from prayer services at Al Aqsa mosque for a second consecutive week. Police blocked all residents of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip from attending the services, as well as all men from Jerusalem under age 45. As a result, fewer than 2,000 Moslems were at the service. Before the 34-month Palestinian uprising, on a normal Friday, the Moslem Sabbath, more than 10,000 Moslems would pray at Al Aqsa and the Dome of the Rock mosques on the Temple Mount. Moslem religious leaders charged Friday that Israel was interfering with their freedom of religion and demanded that all Moslems be admitted to the Mount for worship. In a sermon at Al Aqsa, Moslem preacher Mohammed Hussein said the police step was ``an action of hate.'' ``I say to the occupation authorities that you are preventing worshipers from getting into the house of God. This is not in the religion of Moses or Jesus,'' Hussein said. The Temple Mount, known as Haram es-Sharif in Arabic, is one of the holiest sites in both Islam and Judaism. The Oct. 8 clash, in which 140 Palestinians were also wounded, was prompted when Palestinians threw stones at Jews worshiping at the Western Wall below. Jews revere the wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, as the last remnant of their ancient temple. Palestinians said the stoning began when rumors spread that Jewish zealots planned to march on the Temple Mount. In the occupied territories, Moslems were blocked from attending Friday prayers by army curfews in scattered areas. Curfews kept 145,000 people in their homes in Nablus, the West Bank's largest city, and in nearby refugee camps. Also Friday, a Jerusalem magistrate's court ordered two prominent Palestinians kept in jail while police continue an investigation into whether they incited the Oct. 8 violence. Faisal Husseini, the leading PLO activist in the occupied territories, was ordered held seven more days, and Sheik Mohammed Jamal, deputy Moslem leader of Jerusalem, was remanded for five additional days. Both deny the allegations. In his remand ruling, Judge David Cheshin said there was ``more than sufficient grounds to support suspicions that the two incited worshipers on the Temple Mount to throw stones,'' the Itim news agency said. The Temple Mount killings were condemned in a resolution passed unanimously by the U.N. Security Council last week. Israel has refused to cooperate with a U.N. probe into the incident, but has launched its own investigation into the deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Three More Bodies Found In Mine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with three missing in another mine. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers on Friday found three more bodies in a mine where a small earthquake triggered a rock slide, bringing the death toll to nine, officials said. One person was still missing following the rock fall Thursday at the Anglo American Corp. mine near Carletonville, about 40 miles west of Johannesburg. A quake measuring 3.7 on the Richter scale shook the area Thursday morning, causing a slide about 1.5 miles underground at the Western Deep Levels' West mine. The bodies of six mine workers were found Thursday, and three more were recovered Friday, a spokesman said. Six people were injured, he said. Dogs trained to search by smell were being used to try to find the last missing miner, officials said. The tremor was the second to affect the mine in two days. A small quake Wednesday caused a slide that killed three miners. The company also said that earth tremors Thursday caused collapses at another mine, and three employees were missing. It said rescue teams were searching for the men, who had been working about a mile below the surface at the Vaal Reefs South Mine near Orkney, about 120 miles southwest of Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Former Securitate Chief Suspended
DOC.TEXT: A Bucharest military court decided Friday to suspend the trial of former Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police chief because of insufficient evidence. Gen. Iulian Vlad, the former head of the feared Securitate, or secret police, was charged with ``complicity to genocide'' in the deaths of more than 1,000 Romanians during the revolution against Ceausescu last December. He would face a maximum sentence of life in prison if convicted. But a statement by the court, carcial news agency Rompres, said ``the prosecution has not succeeded in convincing anyone that Vried on the offilad was guilty of mass murder.'' The prosecution can appeal the court's ruling within 10 days, and Vlad, 59, will remain in police custody until then. The case was withdrawn and will be transferred to the prosecutor's office for ``completion of investigation,'' the court said. If the prosecution decides Vlad could be guilty of another offense, then a new trial could be held. If the prosecution does not appeal the court's decision or loses the appeal, Vlad will be freed. About 40 witnesses have testified so far. Most maintained that Vlad did not give any orders to fire on demonstrators during the revolution that ended with the execution of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, on Dec. 25. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Defense Sec't Cites Soviet Help in Gulf in Ending Skepticism
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Friday cited Soviet cooperation in the Persian Gulf as helping end his skepticism toward the Kremlin and fostering a belief that Moscow is no longer an adversary. ``I think that while I did in fact begin as a skeptic, based on past experience, I have been persuaded by the events of the last 18 months that indeed we have entered a new era of U.S.-Soviet relations,'' Cheney said at a joint news conference with Soviet Defense Minister Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov. During his four-day Soviet trip, which ended Friday, Cheney met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Yazov and other leaders, visited an elite Soviet airborne unit and toured an underground air-defense post and a MiG-29 factory. He departed for Paris after the news conference. ``President Gorbachev, in his conversations with me, reiterated the strong support of the Soviet government for the international effort that has been mounted through the United Nations and the support of the Soviet people for the position of forcing Saddam Hussein to halt his aggression and to withdraw from Kuwait,'' Cheney said. ``The United States is undertaking a fundamental revision of its military strategy as a result of the significant improvements we have seen in U.S. Soviet relations,'' he said he had told Soviet officials. ``I am very positive about the changes we have seen to date. I think that the evidence is overwhelming that there is indeed change underway in Soviet foreign and military policy,'' Cheney said. He cited proposed treaties to slash conventional and strategic forces, along with ``Soviet withdrawal from Eastern Europe, reunification of Germany, (and) cooperation in the U.N. Security Council in opposing Saddam Hussein's aggression in the gulf.'' Cheney, while praising Soviet help in bringing economic and diplomatic pressure to persuade Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, said, ``I have also made it clear, as have other officials of our government, that we have not ruled out other options.'' The Soviet defense minister emphasized that, ``We should look for political options to revolve the problem of the gulf.'' ``I believe that if we succeed in resolving this conflict by political means, it would be a ... good warning to those who people who try to disrupt peace in the future,'' Yazov said. Yazov hailed the superpower military talks, saying, ``We have never had such frank talks about deep cuts in our forces.'' He also said that with completion of a proposed treaty to slash superpower strategic nuclear arsenals by up to half, the Soviet Union might reduce its production of rockets by 50 percent as well. But until such weapons are eliminated altogether, he said the Soviet Union would continue to replace about 10 percent of its strategic rocket force every year, to assure that they were in a state of readiness. Cheney, in remarks Wednesday to the Soviet lawmakers, said he was worried because the Soviet Union was conducting tests on four new ballistic missiles to replace the latest generation of weapons. Responding to questions about the turbulent Soviet political situation, Yazov repeated his denials of rumors of a possible military coup at the Kremlin to restore a hard-line stance toward ethnic and regional unrest. ``The Armed Forces of the Soviet Union are part and parcel of our people of this country and they will never raise arms against their people,'' Yazov said. Yazov declined to clarify conflicting reports about whether nuclear weapons had been removed from some areas such as the Baltic and Caucasian republics. But he did say that long-range nuclear forces were stationed only in Russia, Byelorussia and the Ukraine. His remark did not appear to cover shorter-range nuclear weapons that might be stationed, or might have been removed, from other republics. Yazov also said the military would hold its customary parade on Red Square this Nov. 7, the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. But he said similar parades might be restricted to military bases in cities where local authorities chose not to celebrate the holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Drops Prayer, But Says He Will Appeal Ruling
DOC.TEXT: A county judge skipped his usual opening prayer for the court Friday after a federal judge ruled the blessing unconstitutional. U.S. District Judge James McMillan ruled Thursday that Judge Bill Constangy's prayer was tantamount to government establishing religion. The ruling decided a lawsuit against the Mecklenburg district judge by the American Civil Liberties Union and five Charlotte lawyers who objected to Constangy's morning invocation. ``With all due respect for Judge Constangy's sincerity, I must conclude that his prayer in the courtroom is contrary to the law of the land,'' McMillan wrote. ``Judge Constangy's prayer, uttered in good faith to an audience that may include people of different faiths (or no admitted faith at all) is an obvious violation of the First Amendment,'' he wrote. Constangy said he will appeal the ruling. ``I do not want anybody to be disappointed,'' said Constangy, who was appointed to the bench in 1989. ``This is just the first round.'' Each day since taking office Constangy has recited a 67-word prayer he composed: ``Oh Lord, our God, our Father in Heaven, we pray this morning that you will place your divine guiding hand on this courtroom and that with your mighty, outstretched arm you will protect the innocent, give justice to those who have been harmed and mercy to us all. Let truth be heard and wisdom be reflected in the light of your presence here with us today. Amen.'' Constangy, a Roman Catholic, said he intended the prayer to be ``very nonsectarian, nonproselytizing.'' ``There are three reasons why I open with prayer,'' Constangy said. ``They are to express a reverence for God, to set proper tone for the court and to continue the American tradition of opening deliberative bodies with prayer.'' Constangy said that before the lawsuit he heard complaints from only two attorneys. One of them joined the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Only Operational Aspect of Desert Shield Goes Uncovered by Media
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While troops conduct maneuvers in the desert and pilots fly training missions, naval interceptions to enforce the embargo against Iraq are the only truly operational element of Desert Shield. U.S. military officials said Friday there have been about 2,500 interceptions and 240 boardings the past two months. U.S. warships had a role in 191 of the boardings, the officials said. The British, Australian and Spanish navies have participated jointly in some. In 11 cases, commercial ships were diverted to ports other than their destination after being suspected of carrying cargo bound to or from Iraq, the officials said in a report. The embargo was imposed on Iraq following its Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Navies from about a dozen nations are taking part in the gulf efforts. The U.N. Security Council imposed a trade embargo on Iraq following its takeover of Kuwait. Later the same month, the Council voted to back the sanctions with military might. Navies from about a dozen nations are taking part in the gulf efforts. On a handful of visits to vessels in the Persian Gulf region, reporters have heard radio traffic exchanges between naval ships and commercial vessels and have seen demonstrations of how the boarding teams operate. But none of the journalists covering Operation Desert Shield have been present in instances in which warships fired warning shots to force merchant ships to stop. Nor have they seen any boarding by inspection teams. After questioning ships as to their cargo and destination, the warships may send boarding teams to determine whether the cargo is bound to or from Iraq in violation of the U.N. restrictions. Ships whose cargo or documents are suspect are then directed to ports other than their intended destination. U.S. officials have offered little to explain why the media have not been allowed to visit American warships performing embargo duty, or why details have been provided by the navy in only a handful of cases. Navy Cmdr. Mike Doubleday, a spokesman for the U.S. Command in Riyadh, blamed logistical problems, especially transportation for journalists.

DOC.HEAD: Two Sections of Line to be Inspected For Alleged Corrosion Flaws
DOC.TEXT: Two sections of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline will be dug up to check claims that corrosion flaws were covered up earlier this year. Alyeska Pipeline Service Co. will begin the work next week if the company can quickly find a contractor agreeable to the state and to federal agencies, said Marnie Isaacs, a company spokeswoman. The decision to dig comes a week after Ed Thompson, a former employee of Thorpe Technical Services Inc. claimed his employer - an Alyeska contractor - falsified corrosion detection tests and tolerated widespread drug use among employees while working on the pipeline. David Vickery of the U.S. Bureau of Land Management said his agency, the Interior Department and other federal agencies agreed Thursday to dig at two sites Thompson mentioned in his letter after interviews with others involved in the original inspections. The two small sections of line to be dug up are at Atigun pass, 171 miles south of Prudhoe Bay, and near Delta Junction. From 80 to 160 feet of line will be dug up for the inspections. Vickery said the agencies will meet again next week to decide about more digs in other areas. Doug Mertz, a state assistant attorney general working on the investigation, said it is clear that ``a substantial number'' of pipe sections will have to be dug up and reinspected. He said he does not know exactly how many or where. Isaacs said the company agreed to reinspect the two sections at the informal request of the federal agencies, and would not favor more digging until results are known from the first digs and after an investigation and audit of the original inspection project is complete. She said the digs and reinspections will cost less than $100,000 for both, but did not have a precise figure. The inspections will not impact the flow of oil through the pipeline, Alyeska said. The Persian Gulf crisis has prompted increased oil production on Alaska's North Slope. Since last summer, Alyeska has increased flow by about 300,000 barrels a day to its current level of 1.95 million barrels daily, Isaacs said. State and federal officials say they won't agree to increase the pressure of oil in the pipeline - a factor in increasing the flow - until the inspection issues are settled. Officials are concerned that increased pressure on a weakened section of the line could cause a leak. By using chemicals that reduce the friction of oil flowing through the line, Alyeska could pump 2 million barrels a day ``and still honor the pressure limits we currently operate under,'' Isaacs said. Alyeska runs the trans-Alaska pipeline for the seven major oil companies that on it. The 800-mile line provides one-fourth of U.S. oil production. Isaacs said that while Alyeska has no worries about the integrity of the pipeline, it is concerned about the alleged mismanagement of the inspectors. Dale Thorpe, president of Thorpe Technical Services, said he welcomes the inspections as a chance to vindicate the quality of the company's work. ``I think it's great,'' he said. ``We know the exact results of what's going to happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Challenges Postponement of Mandela Trial
DOC.TEXT: A government prosecutor Friday challenged a local judge's decision to postpone until February the trial of Winnie Mandela and seven of her former bodyguards on charges of kidnapping and assault. Mrs. Mandela, wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, has denied any wrongdoing. She and the others are accused of abducting and beating four young men at her house in the Soweto black township. The leader of her bodyguards, Jerry Richardson, earlier was convicted of murdering one of the four and was sentenced to death. The eight defendants appeared Sept. 24 in magistrate's court in Soweto, where her attorney argued that the original Oct. 30 trial date left Mrs. Mandela insufficient time to prepare. Magistrate T.F. Veldman postponed the Supreme Court trial until Feb. 4. Transvaal Attorney General Klaus Von Lieres on Friday asked the Supreme Court to rule that a magistrate lacks the power to change the Supreme Court trial date Von Lieres set. The delay in challenging the postponement was not immediately explained. The Supreme Court reserved judgment. The charges stem from a December 1988 incident that killed 14-year-old Stompei Seipei. During Richardson's trial, the three other alleged victims testified they were abducted by members of the Mandela United Football Club - Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards - and taken to her home. They said Mrs. Mandela whipped them and that the others also assaulted them. If convicted of the charges against them, the defendants could receive punishment ranging from a suspended sentence to the death penalty. Lawyers said the death sentence has never been imposed for kidnapping in South Africa. White and black leaders fear Mrs. Mandela's trial could strain relations between the ANC and the government as they try to start talks on ending apartheid. Youths on the soccer club Mrs. Mandela formed played few matches and were accused of terrorizing the Soweto neighborhood where she lived. According to testimony at Richardson's trial, the bodyguards accused Seipei of being a police informer and the other three of having homosexual relations with the white minister at their church home. No evidence was presented that Seipei, a well-known anti-apartheid activist, was a police spy. The Methodist Church cleared the minister of any misconduct.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto: U.S. Aid to Pakistan Ended With Her Dismissal
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto spoke to a campaign rally Friday that attracted 100,000 people and predicted her party would ``wash away'' the opposition if there's no fraud in next week's elections. After arriving three hours late, Ms. Bhutto spoke to the supporters from a 10-foot high stage surrounded by barbed wire to hold back the surging, screaming crowd. Huge posters of Ms. Bhutto, kneeling with her covered head bowed in prayer, towered over the crowd in Liaqat Park, the site where Pakistan's first prime minister, Liaqat Ali Khan, was assassinated 39 years ago. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan used his constitutional power to oust Ms. Bhutto Aug. 6 and replace her with a caretaker government. He charged her administration had plundered the national treasury and engaged in corruption and nepotism. Ms. Bhutto claims the charges were a false pretext for a politically motivated action. A court Thursday upheld the legality of her dismissal. But Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan Peoples' Party (PPP) has gained momentum in recent weeks heading into Wednesday's election, presumably due to the perception that she is being persecuted. The 37-year-old Ms. Bhutto was joined on the Rawalpindi stage by her partners in a three-party coalition that faces a right-wing alliance of nine parties. She warned the candidates to be wary of rigging by the army-backed caretaker government and predicted attempts would be made to control the voting. ``If there is no rigging, a PPP flood will wash away my opponents,'' she said. She also said only her return to power would ensure a restoration of the $573 million U.S. aid package to Pakistan. ``America stopped its aid because democracy ended when my government was dismissed,'' she told the rally. The United States technically suspended aid to Pakistan on Oct. 1 after President Bush failed to guarantee to Congress that Islamabad was not developing nuclear weapons. A decision on whether to renew the aid would come some time after a new Pakistani governmient was elected, officials in Washington have said. Western diplomats said the 37-year-old former prime minister has a strong lobby in the U.S. Congress. ``There is still that image of Benazir Bhutto as the shining example of democracy in South Asia,'' said one diplomat, who insisted he not be identified further.

DOC.HEAD: International Panel To Review Hormone That Increases Cow's Milk
DOC.TEXT: An international panel said Friday it would include in a list of chemicals to be reviewed in 1992 a controversial drug that could induce cows to give more milk. The drug, bovine somatotropin or BST, is still under review by the Food and Drug Administration for possible use by U.S. dairy farmers. Tests indicate the synthetic hormone could increase a cow's milk production by 10 percent to 25 percent. The Codex Committee on Residues of Veterinary Drugs in Foods met in closed session here this week. The agenda included the setting of priorities for future reviews. The committee was established in 1985 to create standards for safety of veterinary drug residues in food-producing animals, although it has no regulatory authority. Its parent, the Codex Alimentarius Commission, was founded in 1962 by the United Nations to develop food standards and guidelines to protect consumers and defend fair trade. The committee's priority for 1991 included several groups of tranquilizers, anti-parasitic drugs and antibiotics. For its 1992 review, the committee selected several more groups, including bovine somatotropin, also known as BGH, or bovine growth hormone. The committee reported after the meeting that porcine somatotropin, or PST, which is being developed for swine, would not be scheduled for review at this time. ``One criterion for review is that the product be currently marketed in at least one country,'' the committee said in its statement. ``PST is not currently marketed.'' An important part of the committee's job is to designate reliable test methodology for detecting drug residues in food, which is essential to national residue monitoring programs. The panel said it agreed on ``validated test methods'' for albendazole and ivermectin, anti-parasitic drugs used in cattle and sheep, and carbadox, which is used to treat diarrhea diseases in swine. Thirty-four countries and seven international organizations were said to have been represented at the conference.

DOC.HEAD: Germans, American Guests Getting Along Better In Year of Unity
With AM-Germany-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador got hearty cheers instead of angry jeers when he showed up for the unification bash in Berlin. What a difference a year makes. German grumbling about the U.S. military had reached new peaks before the East bloc started crumbling, the two Germanys began marching to unity, and Washington decided to start cutting back on its troop levels. Some Germans are still dissatisfied with the disarmament plans announced so far. But anti-American sentiments have significantly quieted. The U.S. Embassy in Bonn is no longer besieged by German journalists who ask why the American military seems insensitive to Germans' wishes. U.S. Ambassador Vernon A. Walters made a lot of German friends last year when he voiced his support for unity, and Germans greeted him with cheers when they spotted him at Berlin's unity party. His predecessor, Richard Burt, was often heckled and booed because he was the symbol of the U.S. military presence at a time of growing German impatience with NATO troops. German officials have welcomed the pending U.S. troop pullouts and are eager for the military property that will become available to them. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said last month that 30,000 soldiers would be withdrawn from Germany. Across the former West Germany, officials are drawing up plans for the property, which is sorely needed in a country with a severe housing shortage. But at the same time, there is worry about thousands of civilian jobs that will be lost because of the troop reductions. There have been estimates that across Germany about 108,000 jobs are threatened by the U.S. cutbacks. American officials say Germany gets an annual infusion of about $8.75 billion because of the U.S. troop presence alone. Some experts have said a total pullout of all NATO troops from Germany could bring economic disaster. ``I think that many Germans are now starting to realize what an economic boon it is to have the Americans here,'' says Harry Spittler, owner of Harry's Gift Shop in Kaiserslautern. Like many businesses in the area, Spittler's store relies heavily on the business of American GIs. Germans may be having kinder thoughts about their American guests now that many of them are about to leave, but the upcoming cutbacks have also caused some new friction. Some state and local officials had hoped to get their hands on properties that aren't being immediately abandoned. The troop reduction plans have also caused disputes among Germans. In some areas, people have been arguing over whether military air bases should become commercial airports. Many citizens ask why the noise of military aircraft should be replaced with that of commercial planes.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Probe Moving Slowly in Germany
DOC.TEXT: While overworked prosecutors try to build a case against former East German Communist leader Erich Honecker, he is still able to travel abroad and enjoy other freedoms, the investigation team chief said Friday. ``There is no arrest warrant against Honecker,'' said Christoph Schaefgen, whose team has been poring through about 400 large spiral binders concerning Honecker.
