Toppled from power a year ago, Honecker is being investigated for corruption and ``murder and causing bodily harm'' for the shoot-to-kill orders for would-be escapees from East Germany. About 200 people were killed trying to flee East Germany. Investigators are seeking enough evidence to arrest and jail the 78-year-old deposed party boss before trial. Honecker has been quoted as saying he wants to stay in Germany, but he has previously noted his wish to visit Chile, where his daughter Erika lives with her husband and child. There is also speculation he could head to the Soviet Union, where some of his top spies reportedly have found refuge. ``As a prosecutor, I am strictly bound to the provisions of the criminal law, and I can only hinder freedom of travel when the conditions have been met,'' said Schaefgen. Honecker reportedly is suffering from cancer, but looked fit in recently shot TV news footage taken outside the Soviet military hospital where he is staying. Berlin justice officials heightened interest in the case by announcing a news conference Friday to give an interim report on the criminal probes into Honecker and others. Some people had expected the announcement of his pending arrest. Instead, Schaefgen said a heavy workload so far has hindered progress in the Honecker case. Schaefgen said under German law prosecutors must turn their attention to the cases of two members of Honecker's former regime who are already jailed - Erich Mielke, the former East German secret police chief, and former government trade union boss Harry Tisch. ``This means that we have not been able to devote ourselves to the Honecker probe with as much intensity as you would have expected,'' the prosecutor said. He said the stepped-up probe against Honecker would begin ``as soon as possible.'' Both Miekle and Tisch are charged with corruption, and Mielke is also being investigated for complicity in murders of East Germans after they had abandoned their country. Berlin justice department chief Jutta Limbach said a lack of a sufficient number of prosecutors also has slowed the probe against Honecker. ``This takes time and patience,'' said Ms. Limbach, who urged prosecutors from other parts of Germany to come to Berlin to help relieve the workload. Ms. Limbach said using former East German prosecutors would be difficult until a full review of their past.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards, Democratic Gubernatorial Candidate, Denounces Drug Story
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards on Friday denounced a New Mexico man's allegation that he saw her use cocaine 13 years ago and called it a ``smear'' by GOP candidate Clayton Williams. ``This stinks to high heaven,'' Richards told reporters. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has been dogged by drug questions since February. During a televised debate, she refused to say whether she had ever used illegal drugs. ``My political opponents cannot resist using my illness when all else is failing in their campaigns,'' Richards said. Reggie Bashur, a Williams consultant, said the Republican's campaign had nothing to do with the charge. ``We are not involved and Ann Richards knows it,'' he said. ``As far as we're concerned, this comes totally out of left field. It's unfortunate that Ms. Richards is so shrill and so panicked,'' Bashur said. The allegation was contained in a story published Friday by the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal. It was reiterated later in the day at a San Antonio news conference held by Bexar County Sheriff Harlon Copeland. ``That story and the actions of the Republican sheriff of Bexar County have taken the Clayton Williams' smear campaign to new lows,'' Richards said. The newspaper and the sheriff cited interviews with J.D. Arnold, a Santa Fe, N.M., tour operator. Arnold also was a press secretary to former Rep. Jim Mattox, now state attorney general, who lost the gubernatorial nomination to Richards in April. Copeland said Arnold gave a sworn statement that he saw Richards use cocaine at the Stoneleigh P. bar in Dallas on Dec. 7, 1977, following a Mattox fund-raiser. ``I just can't understand why anyone who is a drug user would try to get into high office,'' Copeland said. ``Ann Richards: Did you use drugs or did you not use drugs? He denied he had a political motive in making the allegation public, saying Arnold's name surfaced during a San Antonio drug trafficking investigation. ``This is a dangerous and unpardonable subversion of the police function of Bexar County by a campaign that has not only lost its momentum, it has lost its moral compass,'' Richards said. ``The actions of the Bexar County sheriff represent an abuse of power.'' Arnold told the Albuquerque newspaper he made the allegation public ``because I can't stand Ann Richards.'' ``I'm so sick of her,'' he said. ``I'm sick of everything she's done. It all goes back to the comments she made (about Mattox), like `He's like a chicken-killing dog.''' ``The affidavit described in the article of J.D. Arnold is not true,'' Richards said. Richards introduced to reporters two women who said she hadn't attended the 1977 party - her longtime friend Betty McKool of Dallas and Martha Harris of Austin. McKool said Richards was with her that night. Harris said she attended the party and Richards wasn't there. Richards accused Williams of trying to divert attention from an investigation into his ClayDesta National Bank and its practices of giving car loans to high-risk customers. Williams has denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Published to Legalize Opposition Parties in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: A bill presented to Zambia's parliament Friday would rewrite the constitution to allow opposition parties for the first time in 17 years. The bill, signed by Attorney-General Frederick Chomba, repeals Article IV of the constitution, which made President Kenneth Kaunda's United National Independence Party the only legal political party. Zambia's rubber-stamp parliament routinely passes any initiative that is passed to it by the executive. Kaunda, 66, led the British colony to independence in 1964 and imposed a one-party state in 1973. The onetime missionary teacher has often argued that democracy in Africa unleashes tribal conflicts and hinders development. But faced by dwindling popularity due to widespread corruption, mismanagement, inflation and unemployment, he promised multiparty elections next year. In June, at least 27 Zambians were killed by security forces during nationwide demonstrations against increased food prices, the bloodiest urban violence since Independence. At the height of the rioting, jeering crowds called for Kaunda's resignation, one of the first public expressions of opposition to his leadership. Kaunda's main challenge springs from the fledgling Movement for Multiparty Democracy, a congress of opposition groups planning to establish one rival political party. The movement's chairman, former Cabinet minister Arthur Wina, and its secretary, businessman Akashambatwa Mbikusita-Lewanika, have been appointed by Kaunda to a 22-member commission that is redrafting the constitution.

DOC.HEAD: US Sending Top-of-Line Tanks from Europe to Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon said Friday it is shipping several hundred of its best tanks from storage depots in Europe to Saudi Arabia to join U.S. forces arrayed against Iraq. The transfer of M1A1 main battle tanks to armored units in the Saudi desert is the latest indication of a declining U.S. emphasis on defending against a Soviet ground attack in Europe. The Pentagon also said the Bush administration is in the final stages of approving the sale of 220 older M60 tanks in Europe to Saudi Arabia, Oman and Bahrain. It said the sale would ``contribute to the security in the Persian Gulf area.'' The announcement did not say exactly how many M1A1 tanks were being transferred to U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, but it appeared the total was 300 to 400. The M1A1 is the latest model produced in the United States. It has better protection against chemical and biological weapons attack, and its German-designed 120mm gun is more capable than the 105mm gun on the older M1 tanks. The M1A1 also has better armor. The M1A1 also has better armor and it is the first American tank with a ``microclimatic cooling system'' designed to combat the effects of excessive heat on the tank's engine and weapons system. It also has a thermal sighting system that gives the tank an added capability to fight at night and in low visibility. About 600 M1 and M1A1 tanks already are deployed to Saudi Arabia with the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment and other armored units, so the addition of M1A1s from Europe would bring the total U.S. tank strength to nearly 1,000. That compares with the 3,500 Iraqi tanks that the Pentagon says are deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. In its announcement, the Pentagon said the tanks being transferred to Saudi Arabia won't be needed in Europe once the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty is completed, which could come by the end of the year. The CFE treaty requires the NATO countries to reduce their tank inventory to 20,000, meaning that about 4,000 tanks will have to be destroyed. The Pentagon said that the administration has proposed to the NATO allies that the M1A1 tanks being sent to Saudi Arabia be counted against the NATO total under CFE, meaning the M1A1s would not have to be destroyed even if returned to Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Al Barkan, Longtime Political Activist for Organized Labor, Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Alexander E. Barkan, longtime head of the AFL-CIO's political action committee, has died, the labor federation announced Friday. Barkan, who had been active in the trade union movement since 1937, died Thursday at Sibley Hospital after a long illness. He was 81. ``To know Al was to be lifted by his great vitality and single-mindedness with which he pursued trade unionism in general and election victories in particular,'' said Lane Kirkland, president of the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO. Barkan was a native of Bayonne, N.J. He studied economics and political science at the University of Chicago. The AFL-CIO said he became committed to unionism, in part, as a result of attending lectures by and discussion groups with famed civil rights attorney Clarence Darrow. In 1937, Barkan joined the staff of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee. Following the merger of the AFL and the CIO in 1955, Barkan was appointed assistant director of the federation's Committee on Political Education, or COPE. He was appointed COPE director in 1963 by then AFL-CIO President George Meany, overseeing the powerful labor federation's millions of dollars worth of political contributions and channeling its manpower into political campaigns. He retired in 1980. Barkan is survived by his wife, Helen, two daughters and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Rainstorms Scatter Across West, Snow Sprinkles New England
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over much of the West on Friday and snow sprinkled parts of the Northeast, the National Weather Service said. Snow and slush extended from parts of New York state to New England. Rainshowers and thunderstorms were scattered over New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, Colorado and Wyoming. Rain turned to snow in the higher elevations of the Rocky Mountains. Light rain fell in central California. There were no reports of measurable snowfall during the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT, the weather service said. Heavier rainfall during the same 6 hours included about one-half inch at Cedar City, Utah. The same amount was recorded in Houlton and Limestone in Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 29 degrees at Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming to 89 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla. The nation's low was 19 degrees in Hibbing, Minn. Hurricane Nana continued northward with winds of about 75 mph. Suburban Baltimore and Delaware residents cleaned up Friday after tornadoes that left nine injured, 59 homeless and cut power to thousands. The FitzPatrick nuclear power plant on the shores of Lake Ontario near Oswego, N.Y., was closed Friday after plant operators said water intake pipes were clogged with seaweed and other vegetation stirred up in the lake by Thursday night's powerful storms. The New York Power Authority, operators of the facility, said it would be out of commission until later this weekend.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: The following also ran in the PMs cycle
DOC.TEXT: Deficit-reduction bills passed by the House and Senate would cut taxes for many of the 70 million couples and individuals with incomes under $20,000 a year. Although the aim of the bills is to raise taxes, the legislation would reduce the burden on that large class of taxpayers by boosting the earned-income credit for poor working families with children. The increase is designed to offset higher consumer taxes in both bills. The Joint Committee on Taxation estimates the Senate bill would raise the tax burden on people in the $20,000-to-$50,000 income range by about 2.8 percent, three times as much as would the House bill. People making between $50,000 and $75,000 would pay 1.9 percent more under the Senate bill and 1.4 percent more under the House bill. Those between $75,000 and $100,000 would see a 2.5 percent tax increase under the Senate measure and 1.5 percent in the House bill. The Senate would boost the tax burden of people with incomes between $100,000 and $200,000 by 3.5 percent - five times as much as would the House bill. The over-$200,000 group would pay 3.7 percent more in the Senate bill and 7.4 percent more under the House version. Here is how the bills compare: GASOLINE: The Senate would raise the 9-cent gasoline tax to 18{ cents a gallon by 1992 and the 15-cent diesel tax to 24{ cents. No increase in the House bill. Neither bill affects heating oil. INDEXING: The House would forgo for one year the annual adjustments to income tax brackets and personal exemptions, which are designed to protect against inflation-caused tax increases known as bracket creep. As a result, all except the wealthiest people would pay higher taxes every year in the future. The Senate has no such provision. ALCOHOL: House: Raise the $12.50-a-gallon tax on 100-proof liquor by $1, or 20 cents a fifth; double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raise taxes on most wines, including, for example, table wine, which would go from 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 25 cents. Senate: Raise liquor $1.20; double beer; raise table wine to 21 cents. TOBACCO: Both raise the 16-cent cigarette tax by 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. Snuff, cigars and other tobacco would face 25 percent tax increases each year. AIR TRAVEL: The 8 percent tax on airline tickets, scheduled to drop to 4 percent at year-end, would rise instead to 10 percent. TELEPHONES: The Senate, but not the House, would make permanent the 3 percent tax on local and long-distance phone service, which is due to expire Dec. 31. LUXURIES: Either would impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the price of cars above $30,000; boats above $100,000; jewelry above $5,000; furs above $10,000 (House) or $5,000 (Senate), and private planes $100,000 (House) or $250,000 (Senate). TAX RATES: The House bill would raise the top rate paid by the wealthiest people, now 28 percent, to 33 percent. It would impose a 10 percent surtax on those with taxable incomes over $1 million. The Senate bill would do neither. The House, but not the Senate, would raise to 25 percent the 21 percent alternative minimum tax, paid by some high-income people with large amounts of deductions that otherwise could reduce tax liability to near zero. ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: The Senate would limit itemized deductions (except those for medical expense, casualty losses and investment interest) of people with adjusted gross income over $100,000. Only 95 percent of deductions would be allowed against the portion of income above $100,000. CAPITAL GAINS: The House would allow a person to avoid tax on half of up to $200,000 of capital gains earned in a lifetime; the gains could come from most investments other than stocks or collectibles. A person with annual income under $100,000 could avoid tax on another $1,000 a year of gains, including those from the sale of stock. No capital gain would be taxed at a rate above 28 percent. The Senate bill has no capital gains provisions. LOW-INCOME: Both bills would increase the earned-income tax credit, which benefits low-income working families with children, as a way of offsetting some of the increased excise taxes. The Senate plan expands child care benefits. MEDICARE TAXES: The House would increase to $100,000 and the Senate to $89,000 the $51,300 maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. The tax is withheld as part of the Social Security tax. The Senate would require all state and local government workers and their employers to pay the tax; the House would continue exempting workers hired before April 1, 1986. MEDICARE PREMIUMS: House would raise the $28.60 monthly premium for Medicare Part B insurance to $46.20 by 1995. Senate: $47. MEDICARE DEDUCTIBLE: House would raise to $100 through 1995 the present $75 deductible, which beneficiaries must pay before Medicare starts paying for doctor bills. Senate: $150. SOCIAL SECURITY: Both would require all state and local government workers not covered by a public pension to pay Social Security taxes. ENERGY INITIATIVES: The Senate bill earmarks $3.5 billion worth of incentives for increasing U.S. oil and gas exploration and production. The House does not. EXPIRING PROVISIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would extend through 1991 at a five-year cost of $5.5 billion 11 targeted tax breaks that are expiring. Principal beneficiaries include workers who receive tuition aid or group legal services from employers; businesses that hire the poor; investors in low-income rental housing; self-employed who buy their own health insurance; businesses that increase spending for research; and low-income people buying a first home. CONTRIBUTIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would permit upper-income people subject to the alternative minimum tax to deduct the current value of artwork donated to a museum. Present law allows them to write off only the purchase price. BUSINESS: Both bills would raise taxes on life insurance companies by $8 billion. They would extend for five years an expiring 0.2 percent surtax that employers pay for unemployment insurance. Senate, but not House, would prohibit corporations from deducting interest paid on overdue taxes. MEDICAL DEDUCTIONS: The Senate, but not the House, would deny a medical expense deduction for cosmetic surgery unless prescribed to repair damage from an accident or a birth defect.

DOC.HEAD: Police Chief Maintains Innocence In Embezzlement Case
DOC.TEXT: The city's suspended police chief maintained his innocence Friday on charges of siphoning $58,000 in special investigation funds. ``Our day in court will come, and we'll have a chance to prove our innocence,'' Gordon Urlacher said after a brief federal court hearing. Urlacher, 47, was arrested Thursday in the mayor's office and charged with embezzlement and misapplying public funds. He was released on $50,000 bail. The chief and four other police department employees were suspended with pay. The others were not arrested. Urlacher posted the deed to his parents' home in Penfield, a Rochester suburb, as bail security. His mother, Marion Urlacher, signed the document and kissed her son before U.S. Magistrate Kenneth Fisher. Fisher scheduled a Nov. 6 preliminary hearing. The criminal complaint accuses the police chief of stealing at least $58,000 from department special investigation funds since 1989. The FBI was contacted earlier this month by an informant who worked in Urlacher's office and claimed to have helped Urlacher take the money, some of it set aside to buy drugs in undercover investigations. The arrest and suspensions stunned department employees. ``We're all real devastated by it,'' said police union President Ronald Evangelista. ``If I had to pick four or five more honest cops, I probably couldn't. We're going to support these people until they're proven to hav done something wrong.'' Deputy Chief Terrence Rickard, one of those suspended, said he worried about the department's reputation. He also denied any personal wrongdoing. ``I hurt for every one of these guys I've got out there with a badge,'' Rickard said. In a news conference Friday, Mayor Thomas Ryan called the arrest of Urlacher ``by far'' his most difficult day in office. ``The events of the past 24 hours have had a profound effect on the residents of this city, the employees of the city, the members of the Rochester Police Department, and on myself personally,'' Ryan said.

DOC.HEAD: City Council Gets Legal Definition of Breasts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A City Council committee seeking to ensure that Houston laws governing sexually-oriented businesses are legal brought in an expert to talk about the difference between male and female breasts. The panel held a hearing Thursday on a proposal to toughen the ordinance governing adult entertainment and related businesses. ``I tell you, it was difficult to keep a straight face,'' said Councilwoman Christin Hartung, who chairs the committee addressed by Gayle Beck, a University of Houston professor and sex therapist. ``She did not give us any anatomy lessons, nor did we ask for them,'' Assistant City Attorney Paul Bibler said. Councilman Dale Gorczynski summarized what the committee learned: ``Exposed male breasts are not arousing to women in our culture, but exposed female breasts are arousing to men.'' The proposed ordinance would regulate such businesses as strip clubs and adult-video stores. City officials want the law to withstand potential sex discrimination claims from people who may question why women must cover their breasts and men don't. They look to the experience of Fort Worth, where it is illegal for women to publically expose their breasts. A Fort Worth topless club called Sinbad's won a challenge to the city ordinance last year, complaining that police harassed the business and bothered customers. Last week the Texas Supreme Court decided not to review the case, letting the earlier decision stand. Houston restricts the location of strip clubs, modeling studios and massage parlors. The council wants to further restrict them. The proposed ordinance will get a council hearing next month.

DOC.HEAD: Stanford Scientists Find `Off Switch' To Halt Growth of DNA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lowercase `k' in 33-kDA in 8th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Stanford University scientists have found a chemical ``off switch'' that stops the replication of DNA, a discovery they believe could improve understanding of cancer, AIDS and other diseases. The researchers said in the October issue of Cell they identified a protein that inhibits replication of DNA in E. coli, a common bacterium. Stopping the DNA keeps the cell from dividing. While the bacterium is a relatively simple organism, DNA works essentially the same way in bacteria as in plants, animals and humans, researchers said. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the genetic code found in all cells. ``There's a universal use of basic biochemical patterns throughout nature that warrants our confidence that regulation of these processes, when understood in one system, will become easier to understand in all systems,'' said Arthur Kornberg, a biochemistry professor at Stanford. Kornberg, who won the 1959 Nobel Prize in medicine for earlier research in DNA replication, was co-author of the report written after nine years of experiments. ``We now believe we have most of the molecules that operate the switch of replication in pure form,'' Kornberg said. ``If you know the anatomy of the switch, if you have the hood off ad can see how the motor works, you can then determine what factors provoke it to get started replicating or keep it in check,'' he said. Kornberg's team, also led by Deog Su Hwang, a Stanford postdoctoral fellow, found that the ``off switch'' for DNA replication is a protein called 33-kDA. The protein prevents the twin spiraled strands of DNA molecules from replicating. The team found the ``on switch,'' a tiny segment on each chromosome activated by enzymes, in 1981. Chromosomes are formed of DNA. Kornberg emphasized that the new discovery was only a tool for further research into the code that tells cells when and how to start and stop duplicating. John Minna, a researcher at the National Cancer Institute, called the Stanford finding ``very exciting.'' ``Clearly, this is a major new finding about the biochemistry of DNA replication by Dr. Kornberg, the founding father of the whole field,'' he said. There are many diseases in which the cell's ability to control DNA replication is impaired, Minna said. ``It could have profound implications for cancer and AIDS,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Human Error Blamed On Beam That Caused Damage to Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Human error caused a 9-foot-long aluminum beam to be left inside the engine compartment of the space shuttle Atlantis, damaging the craft, investigators concluded Friday. The beam was discovered Oct. 3 when the shuttle was lifted into an upright position in an assembly room, said J.B. Kump, a spokesma for Lockheed Space Operations Co. of Titusville. The company is NASA's primary shuttle contractor. The beam, part of a work platform, banged around inside the compartment and caused about 25 dents and dings. The damage was not expected to delay a secret military flight by Atlantis, set for around Nov. 10. A nine-member Lockheed team blamed human error and not worker fatigue, experience or scheduling, Kump said. The team based its finding on employee interviews. The beam has since been removed. Kump said ``appropriate disciplinary actions'' would be taken against the employees involved. He refused to elaborate. Hugh Harris, a National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman, described the mistake as serious. The incident would be taken into account in the agency's next evaluation of Lockheed's performance, Harris said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Budget Writers Fence Over Taxes on Rich, Medicare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; DELETES 14th graf a0746 1st Ld: ``The threat,'' and SUBS 15th graf 1st Ld: ``Although that,'' with one graf, now 16th graf bgng: ``Although the,'' to delete references to unsigned temporary spending bill
DOC.TEXT: Democrats pushed President Bush to accept higher taxes on the richest Americans Friday as Congress began a final drive to craft a compromise deficit-reduction bill. Republicans warned that pressing Bush too hard would merely invite a veto. Bush, meanwhile, signed a stopgap spending bill to keep the government functioning through next Wednesday to give Congress more time to work on a final budget compromise. He signed the legislation shortly before leaving the White House for a weekend at the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md. GOP lawmakers mustered around a bipartisan budget the Senate adopted early Friday imposing only modest tax increases on the wealthy and doubling the gasoline levy. Democrats preferred a House-passed version leaning heavily on the rich, leaving the gasoline tax alone and easing cost increases on Medicare recipients. ``We believe in tax fairness and progressivity, and that's what we're going to fight for,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``You can bet your life if a package is going to pass in this House it's going to include the rich,'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. But as House and Senate budget-writers began bargaining over a $250 billion, five-year package of taxes and spending cuts, Republicans warned that Democrats could not go too far without risking a veto by Bush. ``I don't know why we have to go through a process of producing a bill that will not be signed,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee. Bush reiterated his preference for the Senate version and said, ``I, for the first time, feel optimistic that we can get this job done for the American people.'' The president visited the Capitol for about an hour, urging lawmakers to quickly fashion a compromise plan. ``He said nobody is going to get all he wants,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said afterward. But with Election Day barely two weeks off, senators who just hours earlier were united behind their compromise budget exhibited some of the same partisan strains that have divided House Democrats and Republicans for weeks. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said he did not feel obliged to fight for his chamber's deficit-cutting package. ``I much prefer the House package with regard to revenues. It puts a heavier burden on the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share.'' Responded Domenici: ``I don't think any good purpose is served by Chairman Sasser choosing sides. Frankly, the House bill isn't that great.'' Although the pressure of another threatened governmental closure was lifted, budget writers planned to work through the weekend in hopes of allowing Congress to adjourn for the year by midweek. Lawmakers and staffs met throughout the Capitol, tackling a task whose complexity was symbolized by the legislation itself: a half-foot stack of paper weighing 13 pounds. The legislation is the major part of a plan to cut the deficit by $500 billion over the next five years, including $40 billion this year. The rest of the savings would come from cuts in the defense budget, and savings on interest payments on the debt. House Speaker Thomas Foley said Democrats would insist that the Senate moderate its doubling of the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax and its steeper increases in out-of-pocket Medicare costs for beneficiaries. He also noted that Democrats remain behind the House plan's higher taxes on the rich. That package increases the income-tax rate the richest people pay from its current 28 percent to 33 percent and puts a 10 percent surtax on people earning $1 million annually. ``Obviously, compromises are required,'' Foley, D-Wash., told reporters after a party caucus. ``The insistence of the president in having no income tax changes (affecting the rich) seems to be inexplicable and inflexible.'' Lawmakers have talked for days about a possible compromise boosting the top tax rate to 31 percent. Bush has said he would accept that increase only in return for deep cuts in the capital gains tax, a trade Democrats are unwilling to make. But Republicans would not flatly rule out that higher tax rates on the rich would emerge. ``I can't support an increase in the tax rates,'' said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. But he added, ``I may get rolled'' during House-Senate negotiations. Bush strongly opposes a House provision that would, in effect, cause slight income-tax increases on most Americans. It would delay for one year the inflation adjustment made in tax brackets and the personal exemption. Democrats have said that provision is likely to be altered or eliminated. Both the House and Senate bills would increase taxes on tobacco, alcohol, airline tickets and luxury items such as private planes. Both would enlarge tax credits for low-income people.

DOC.HEAD: University of Arkansas Researchers Receive Superconductor Patent
DOC.TEXT: The patent on what is billed as the world's most advanced superconductor has been snared for the University of Arkansas by two researchers. Zhengzhi Sheng, a physics researcher at the university, and Allen Hermann, then a professor, developed a thalium-based superconductor in 1988 that produced temperatures above 120 degrees Kelvin, or minus 234 degrees Farenheit. The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office granted the school the patent last week, a university spokesman said. It will protect the rights to a material that holds the world record as the highest-temperature superconductor. The patent was featured in the Oct. 15 cover story of Superconductor Week, published in Washington. The article said ``the award gives the university the dominant patent in the field.'' Sheng and Hermann have been among leaders in a worldwide race to develop superconductors that can operate at temperatures high enough to make their use practical. A superconductors generates electricity without resistance when cooled. Scientists say a practical superconductor would significantly reduce the energy required to power manufacturing operations, transportation networks and households. The inventors and the university will split the first $200,000 of profits the patent generates. Sheng and Hermann will receive 35 percent of all other proceeds. The university will get the rest. Sheng heads the university's superconductivity team. Last month, he was among five recipients of the Awards of Excellence issued by the World Congress on Superconductivity in Houston. Herman left the University of Arkansas last year and is now at the University of Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: Ecuador's Congress in Uproar over Rejection of No-Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: The president of Ecuador's Congress rejected a vote of no-confidence directed against him on Friday, throwing the legislature of this small Andean nation into crisis. ``They'll have to take me out in a coffin,'' said Averroes Bucaram, a populist politician elected to head the Congress two months ago. The crisis arose after three congressmen who supported Bucaram switched votes this week to a group backing President Rodrigo Borja. That gave Borja's coalition a 38-to-34 seat edge in the single house of Congress. Borja's coalition voted late Thursday to remove Bucaram. Social Democrat Edelberto Bonillo was then elected in his place. But Bucaram refused to leave. He said in a radio interview Friday he slept in his office Thursday night and still tends to ``congressional business.'' Bucaram said the no-confidence vote was linked to his attacks on Borja's Cabinet. In the two months Bucaram has presided over Congress, legislators have censured and forced two Borja ministers to resign. This country of 10.5 million people returned to civilian government in 1979. Congress has been a political battlefield since then. Coalitions formed by the 16 political parties shift constantly and many congressmen have little party or ideological loyalty. Congressional officials said Friday they replaced heavy crystal ashtrays on the floor of Congress with smaller ones made of aluminum, after a congressman was severely cut above the eye by an ashtray hurled by an opponent last week.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Researcher Reportedly Detained in Albanian Region
DOC.TEXT: A prominent Norwegian activist investigating alleged human rights abuses against ethnic Albanians was detained by police for about five hours Friday, a colleague said. Bjorn Cato Funnemark, leader of the Norwegian Helsinki Committee, was detained near Pristina, capital of Kosovo province, said Tanja Petovar, Yugoslav spokeswoman for the Helsinki Committee. Ms. Petovar said Funnemark was held five hours by Serbian police, who kept Funnemark's passport and personal papers. It was not clear if the documents were returned. A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Funnemark was stopped while driving in a car with three ethnic Albanians, who were not detained. Serbian and Yugoslav authorities could not immediately be reached for comment. Serbs have taken control of the ethnic Albanian-dominated province struggling to regain autonomy. Albanian-language newspapers have been closed and radio and television stations were seized. More than 60 ethnic Albanians have died in clashes with Serb-dominated security forces the past 18 months. The International Helsinki Federation and other organizations have recently issued critical reports on the rights situation in Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians comprise about 90 percent of the 1.9 million people. ``This represents another serious violation,'' Ms. Petovar said. She said Funnemark, who has investigated rights abuses in Romania, Ireland, Bulgaria and Turkey, ``is one of the most prominent human rights experts in Western Europe.'' In September, Serbian police detained a group from the Vienna, Austria-based International Helsinki Federation. They were expelled from Yugoslavia and barred from returning to the country for three years. Authorities later lifted the ban.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Water, Transportation Money Bills
DOC.TEXT: The voted Friday to spend more than $41 billion on dams, highways, airports and various military and university projects as other lawmakers began struggling to reach a final accord on reducing the federal deficit. In a rush to finish its work next week and avoid having to return after the November elections, House members voted overwhelmingly in favor of a transportation spending bill and another energy and water spending bill together amounting to $33 billion. Also passed by voice vote was an $8.4 billion appropriations bill for military construction projects, including $3.3 billion to build new housing for families of servicemen and women and nearly $1 billion as the second installment in closing more than 80 military bases over the next few years. The bills were produced by House-Senate conference committees that reconciled separate versions passed earlier by each chamber. House members hope their votes on the so-called conference bills reflecting compromises with the Senate will be the last they have to cast. However, if senators balk later at the deals their negotiators struck, the House could be required to consider them again. Rep. Robert Walker, R-Pa., a member of the House Science and Technology Committee, griped that members of Senate and House appropriations committees had included some $90 million in projects paid for by the Energy Department for home-state universities. ``Eight of those 10 projects happen to be in states or districts of people who happen to be on the conference committee,'' he complained. ``We're allocating money not based on anything other than who's in the room divvying up the money.'' But his motion to eliminate the projects was defeated 308-108 as the chairman and top Republican on the House Appropriations Committee's energy and water subcommittee said all the projects are justified. ``There's nothing unusual about this,'' said the panel's chairman, Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala. ``We need more labs; we need more scientists; we need more emphasis put on these programs.'' Rep. John Myers of Indiana, the top Republican on the panel, said all of the projects had been examined in either House or Senate hearings before appropriations subcommittees. Among the 10 recipients of the funds are research centers at the University of Alabama and the University of Indiana. Among the projects hurt in the deficit-cutting effort was one of President Bush's favorites - the proposed $8 billion super collider atom smasher in Texas. Bush's request of $318 million to begin actual construction of the giant particle accelerator had been approved earlier by both the House and Senate. But it was slashed to $243 billion by their negotiators last week. The House-Senate negotiators also dropped provisions from the Senate's transportation money bill that would have required testing of a mass transit workers for illegal drug use and prohibited truck bus drivers from using radar detectors. But they retained a measure in the House bill that would require states to suspend the drivers licenses of convicted drug offenders. ``This is going to send a message to our young people that if they want that all-important symbol of adulthood, the drivers license, they'd better say no to drugs,'' said the measure's sponsor, Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ready to Decide on Vetoing Minority-Hiring Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-6: ``However, another,'' with further word on possible compromise; picks up 4th graf, now 7th graf: ``Meanwhile, Sen. James,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was confronted by a last-minute appeal and demonstration by civil rights leaders Friday as he weighed whether to carry through on his threat to veto the civil rights minority-hiring bill. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there was a long-shot possibility that a compromise could be reached, but he also indicated Bush might simply veto the bill. ``We will staple our new bill to the veto message and send it right back up,'' Fitzwater suggested. However, another admininistration official said Friday that the administration was preparing new proposals for Congress to consider that offers a compromise on the sticky question of whether the bill would result in hiring quotas for minorities. This official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the White House could have a draft ready this weekend to send to Capitol Hill, where Congress members will be meeting on the federal budget. The civil rights bill had not been sent to the White House from Congress by the time Bush left to spend the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. Meanwhile, Sen. James M. Jeffords, R-Vt., one of five Republicans who met Thursday with Bush to discuss the bill, said he remained optimistic that Congress could draft follow-up legislation that would satisfy the president's objections. ``I talked to the president again this afternoon,'' Jeffords said. ``We are optimistic, there has been movement on both sides.'' He said Bush set no deadline. The measure, passed earlier this week, would make it easier for women and minority workers to bring discrimination suits against their employers. The White House contends the bill would force employers to establish hiring quotas - something that sponsors dispute. The bill, which is the top legislative goal of national civil rights groups, would reverse a series of Supreme Court rulings that sponsors of the measure say have weakened anti-discrimination protections in the workplace. Fitzwater said the only hope of heading off a veto was congressional action on separate legislation that would, in effect, modify the civil rights bill to meet the administration's objections. Meanwhile, civil rights leaders demonstrated in front of the White House and sought a meeting with Bush in a last-ditch effort to persuade him to sign the bill. ``We are asking that, before he makes a decision to veto it, that he would meet with the civil rights leadership,'' said Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP. He said that Bush had told him in a telephone conversation Thursday that he was exploring possible ways to avoid a veto, including passage of follow-up legislation to soften his objections to the main bill. Hooks suggested that civil rights leaders were not willing to endorse any compromise that would water down the legislation. But, he said ``there is room for hope'' that Bush might reverse himself and sign the bill. Fitzwater said, ``The president certainly wants a strong civil rights bill. He is committed to it. Let's erase this legal question and make it a true civil rights bill.'' He hinted that Democratic sponsors of the civil rights bill that passed Congress were more interested in playing politics with the issue than in ironing out differences with the administration. ``There's been nothing to change our belief that it's a quota bill. The only issue is, is there any way to get it changed at this late date in a way that will be satisfactory,'' Fitzwater said. Hooks was among several hundred chanting demonstrators who gathered outside the White House. White House congressional liaison Frederick McClure greeted them at the gate, then escorted a small delegation onto the grounds, where he accepted the demonstrators' written request for a meeting with Bush. Demonstrators held aloft a large banner that said: ``Mr. President, Sign the Civil Rights Bill.'' Hooks said the demonstrators represented ``civil rights organizations from all over the nation, women's groups, Hispanic groups, from the Jewish community, from the black community and from the liberal Republican groups.'' ``The consequences of a veto is that President Bush will not be living up to his promise of representing all the people, and that gentler, kinder nation that we were looking for will not come to pass,'' Hooks said.

DOC.HEAD: Activist, Anti-War Berkeley Class of 1970 Comes Back to Graduate
DOC.TEXT: The University of California at Berkeley class of 1970 carried signs and burned flags to protest the Vietnam War. Saturday, they'll return to formally graduate 20 years late. ``I've always felt that I was denied some right of passage because we didn't have a graduation ceremony,'' Ken Sherman, a Beverly Hills literary agent, said Friday. ``They were afraid we would use it as a forum for protest and agitation. And I'm sure we would have.'' In May 1970, tensions were high on the campus as students stepped up their anti-war protests when President Nixon sent troops into Cambodia. Earlier that month, on May 4, four students were killed by National Guardsmen during a war protest at Kent State University in Ohio. California Gov. Ronald Reagan reacted to the Ohio killings by ordering the Berkeley campus shut down for two days. With graduation only weeks away, students and faculty began to plan protests they intended to stage at graduation to protest violence against activists. ``There was a very tense and unusual atmosphere on the campus at that time. It was like it was under siege,'' said Ray Colvig, a spokesman for the university now and then. ``There was a threat that commencement might be boycotted or that there would be a large demonstration.'' Hoping to avert trouble, Chancellor Roger Heyns canceled commencement exercises at Berkeley's Memorial Stadium, where 3,300 students were to graduate. Instead, the school's academic departments held their own small ceremonies, a tradition that continues today. ``I didn't know about the small ceremonies we were supposed to have, so I missed out,'' said Sherman, who will speak at Saturday's ceremony. ``I have always felt that I had unfinished business. Taking part in commencement will be a closure of sorts, an ending of part of my life.'' The ceremony was the idea of Class of '70 member Carol Orsborn, who suggested it to the alumni association last year. The association organized the event. More than 200 people from the class are expected to attend. ``Our generation went to sleep for a while,'' said Orsborn, who once gave up her Phi Beta Kappa key in a protest. ``But I don't think idealism is dead, but maybe it's been dormant in a lot of us,'' she said. ``Somehow, I think that this graduation ceremony will give us back some of that feeling.'' Orsborn has a San Francisco public relations company and a family. Her two children will attend commencement with her. Orsborn is author of ``Enough is Enough: Exploding the Myth of Having it All.'' The 1985 book shot down the notion that women with careers and families needed to be superwomen, working at the top of their fields while performing as perfect mother and wife.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Compromise Reached
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators approved a compromise bill Friday protecting additional acres from timber cutting in the massive Tongass National Forest in Alaska. But the agreement, which is expected to be approved by the two chambers, didn't go as far as environmentalists had wanted. The Tongass, stretching across nearly 17 million acres of the Alaska panhandle, is the world's only remaining temperate zone rain forest and home to a rich array of wildlife including grizzly bears and bald eagles. It also is a major source of timber. ``Half a rain forest is better than no rain forest at all,'' said George Frampton Jr., president of the Wilderness Society, adding that he would have preferred a bill much more restrictive to timber interests. ``With the Congress about to adjourn we were forced to take it or leave it,'' said Frampton. The legislation declares about 1 million acres off-limits to timber harvesting and creates off-limits buffers 100 feet wide along rivers and streams important to fishing. The House legislation would have protected nearly twice as many acres from timber cutting. The legislation made a number of changes in the management of the forest and timber sales by the U.S. Forest Service. Environmental groups for years have criticized practices required by 1980 legislation, and have argued that in some years the Forest Service netted only 2 cents from timber sales for every $1 of expenditures. The bill requires the Forest Service to prepare only enough timber for sale to meet ``market demand'' instead of the automatic 450 million board feet annually specified in existing law. It also eliminates the automatic appropriation of $40 million for timber management, requiring that the forest compete with others federal forests each year for funds in the normal budget process. In Juneau, meanwhile, Alaska Gov. Steve Cowper welcomed the agreement, calling it a ``compromise (so that) Alaska's timber industry can remain healthy while the environment and other uses of the forest can be protected.'' He said under the forest management program and modifications in timber contracts ``abuses of the past will be minimized and management of the forest will be improved.'' ``Southeast Alaskans who are directly affected can finally breathe a sigh of relief that this issue is behind us after so many years,'' said Cowper in a statement. Mike Francis, a forestry expert for the Wilderness Society, said that while the changes are welcome they will not necessarily reduce the amount of timber cut in the Tongass.

DOC.HEAD: Salvador Rebels Press Peace Talks Advantage With Military Action
With AM-Foreign Aid
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran guerrillas have begun a diplomatic offensive and increased their military activity, hoping the mixture will bring progress in stalemated peace talks with the government. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, began meetings Thursday with Latin American and European governments. The night before, rebels attacked the base of El Salvador's air force on the eastern edge of the capital, damaging several helicopters. Rebel spokesmen said the actions were intended to bring movement in peace talks with the government of President Alfredo Cristiani. Monthly talks began last spring but have not progressed significantly toward ending the decade-old civil war that has claimed about 72,000 lives. Salvador Samayoa, a member of the FMLN's diplomatic policy commission, said in Germany on Thursday that the military activity is part of a strategy ``to push along the negotiations process.'' The next round is to begin Nov. 4 in Mexico City. Each side accuses the other of inflexibility and negotiating in bad faith. A key sticking point is a rebel demand that the army be reduced and that officers responsible for human rights abuses be purged. The army has agreed in principle to clean its ranks but says it will do it itself without outside participation. At the U.N. General Assembly this month Cristiani offered a unilateral cease-fire if the FMLN would do the same. The rebels said they would not lay down their arms without resolving the causes of the war - social injustice and military impunity. The rebel Radio Venceremos, commenting Friday on the air force attack, said ``the operations of the last hours also are a clear signal to the American government and to some congressmen who want to referee the conflict using the blackmail of military aid.'' The Senate voted Friday to halve El Salvador's expected $85 million military aid, but stipulated the aid would be restored if the rebels walk away from the peace talks. ``If the Salvadoran and U.S. governments really want to end the war, then we say it's up to them at the negotiating table,'' the rebels said. ``Let's talk about the causes of the war and arrive at agreements. Then we can achieve not only a cease-fire, but a definitive peace.'' The government hopes the FMLN will be weakened politically by the collapse of patron governments in Eastern Europe. The left holds out hope that the end of the Cold War will allow anti-Communist governments to see that El Salvador's often brutal armed forces are to blame for the country's woes. Defense Minister Col. Rene Emilio Ponce attributed the increase in activity to internal divisions within the FMLN, which incorporates five rebel armies. ``Within the FMLN there are people who agree to solving the conflict through dialogue and negotiations, but there is another group, possible the largest, that is for a military solution,'' he said. The guerrillas deny they are divided over strategy.

DOC.HEAD: Eye-in-the-Sky to Spy on Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A Defense Department satellite to be carried into orbit next month on the space shuttle Atlantis will provide strategic and tactical reconnaissance information from the Persian Gulf region, says a report to be published Monday. The satellite will orbit at 460 miles altitude, far lower than the usual military spacecraft which are placed in a path 22,300 miles above Earth, Aviation Week and Space Technology magazine says in the Oct. 22 edition. A satellite orbiting at 22,300 miles will remain over one spot on the earth's surface, making such an orbit ideal for communications satellites. Atlantis' mission, like all Defense Department shuttle flight, is secret. The date for liftoff has not been set, pending a test for fuel leaks scheduled for Wednesday. Aviation Week said the satellite weighs 22,000 pounds, making it one of the heaviest military payloads to be put in space. It will have digital cameras and other sensors which will focus on the Persian Gulf region, the magazine said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Call For New MacDonald Trial, Based on New Evidence
DOC.TEXT: Jeffrey MacDonald, the Green Beret doctor convicted more than 20 years ago of killing his wife and two daughters, deserves a new trial because of suppressed government evidence, his attorneys said Friday. Lawyer Harvey Silverglate said in court papers that private investigators turned up forensic notes and testimony about an alleged confession by a one-time suspect that could clear MacDonald. ``This evidence was in the government files and not disclosed to the judge, nor to the jury, nor to MacDonald,'' Silverglate said. Silverglate, from Boston, said the evidence was found in Army records. Notes by forensic investigators refer to long, blond hairs found in a hair brush and black wool fibers found in the mouth and hand of MacDonald's wife, he said. It was at least the third time this year Silverglate announced that suppressed government evidence had been found, but it was the first time a motion was filed in federal court. MacDonald, a Princeton-educated Army doctor, was convicted in 1979 of the bludgeoning and stabbing deaths of his pregnant wife, Colette, and two small daughters, Kimberly and Kristen, at their Fort Bragg, N.C., apartment in February 1970. MacDonald has maintained he and his family were attacked by three men accompanied by a woman with a floppy hat, blond hair and boots. He said the woman chanted, ``Acid is groovy, kill the pigs.'' MacDonald, 47, is serving three consecutive life sentences at the Terminal Island federal penitentiary in San Pedro, Calif. He was transferred there from a Phoenix prison three years ago to be near his mother, who is in poor health. The trial drew widespread attention. Author Joe McGinniss wrote a best-selling book, ``Fatal Vision,'' about the case in 1983. The book was made into a television movie. McGinniss concluded MacDonald was guilty. The case has taken many twists through the legal system. The U.S. Supreme Court turned down several motions for retrials. Silverglate said that after filing Freedom of Information Act requests, private investigators were allowed to examine the Army's records and found notes written by forensic investigators who examined the MacDonald home shortly after the murders. The notes referred to the blond hairs from the hair brush and fibers found in the mouth and hand of Colette MacDonald, MacDonald's wife, Silverglate said. Silverglate is one of the attorneys who won an acquittal for Claus von Bulow, who had been convicted of killing his wife in 1982. A one-time suspect in the case, Helena Stoeckley, a chronic drug abuser, allegedly confessed to the crimes to various people on several occasions. The testimony of those people to whom Ms. Stoeckley allegedly confessed was not allowed during the trial. Ms. Stoeckley testified during MacDonald's trial that she often wore blond wigs and black clothing. She died in 1983. James Blackburn, the former U.S. attorney who prosecuted MacDonald, said officials did not suppress evidence. ``I'm not aware of any evidence that was ever suppressed by the government or any evidence that was kept from the defense to which they were lawfully entitled,'' Blackburn said. MacDonald was convicted on the basis of a fiber-and-blood reconstruction of the crime because there were no witnesses and no definite motive could be established.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Suspends Operations at Its Kuwait Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with arrival in Baghdad, specifies number. Picks up 5th graf, `The Canadian. . .'
DOC.TEXT: Canada has suspended operations at its besieged embassy in Kuwait and the five Canadians who kept things going there arrived in Baghdad on Friday night, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said. He said the three diplomats and two wives were tired but well, and commended them for their work under trying circumstances for nearly two months. Clark said the embassy is not officially closed and that this did not mean Canada recognized Iraq's claim to Kuwait. Iraqi forces cut off electricity and water to foreign compounds in Kuwait, which President Saddam Hussein claims as Iraq's 19th province. The five Canadians, led by charge d'affaires William Bowden, left Kuwait City with an escort Friday morning in three cars. The trip took 10 hours. The diplomats planned to stay with staff from the embassy in Baghdad. The Canadian action occurred the same day a report was published in Iraqi newspapers saying all foreigners in Kuwait must register with local authorities before Nov. 5 or face a fine and punishment. Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2 and four days later said it had annexed the oil-rich nation. Saddam ordered embassies in Kuwait closed. The Belgian and German embassies in Kuwait closed Oct. 12, and the Dutch, Italian and Polish embassies withdrew their last diplomats from Kuwait City in the week before that. Although only the British, French and U.S. embassies now remain open, most nations still recognize Kuwait as a separate nation. The U.S. Embassy maintains about 10 diplomats led by Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell. An unknown number of American private citizens also have taken refuge there. About 600 Americans are stuck in Kuwait, some in hiding and several reported to be desperately ill. The American diplomats have been surviving mainly on canned food and the occasional loaf of bread carried in by local staff. At the U.S. embassy, power and water are cut. The Americans must forgo baths and boil water form the swimming pool to drink. They use outdoor latrines and sometimes sleep outdoors to keep cool, despite the swarms of mosquitoes.

DOC.HEAD: Von Bulow Children Denounce Movie Portraying Mother As A Drunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th graf, `The lawsuit ...' to UPDATE with explanation of why von Bulow divorce not yet final. Pick up 10th graf, `He also ...'
DOC.TEXT: Martha ``Sunny'' von Bulow's children say they are outraged by ``Reversal of Fortune,'' the movie that portrays their mother as a sloppy drunk obsessed with drugs before she slipped into a coma. ``Our mother ... is unable to respond to an assault on her character and reputation,'' Ala Isham and Alexander Auersperg said in a statement. Isham and Auersperg haven't seen the movie, but read an early copy of the screenplay, their spokeswoman, Maureen Connelly, said Friday from New York. The heiress has been in an irreversible coma in New York since 1980. Her husband, Claus von Bulow, was convicted, then retried and acquitted of twice trying to murder his wife at their Newport mansion. The movie, starring Glenn Close as Mrs. von Bulow, focuses on von Bulow's successful appeal after the first trial. It is based on a book of the same name by Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz, who masterminded the appeal. The film portrays Mrs. von Bulow, who serves as the narrator, as a heavy drinker and a drug user who would resort to hiding her drugs so those around her couldn't destroy them. Isham and Auersperg said their mother was shown ``as pathetic and self destructive.'' ``We reject this injurious and erroneous portrayal and ask the public to do the same in the knowledge that our now defenseless mother was warm and caring and devoted to her family,'' they said. Isham and Auersperg, who believed in their stepfather's guilt, filed a $56 million civil lawsuit against von Bulow after his acquittal, claiming he tried to kill their mother to inherit her money. The lawsuit was settled out-of-court in 1987 with von Bulow agreeing to divorce his wife and renounce all claims to her vast fortune. His share of her estate was estimated at $25 million. The divorce has not been finalized, Connelly said, because Von Bulow has not filed, as he agreed he would in 1987. Connelly said it would require a series of complex legal maneuvers for Sunny's guardians to dissolve the marriage on her behalf. Von Bulow also agreed to give up any rights to book or movie deals about the family infighting. Von Bulow could not be reached for comment Friday at his London apartment. As part of the settlement, Cosima von Bulow, the only child the couple had together, agreed to drop two countersuits. She received an equal share, $35 million, of her maternal grandmother's estate in return. Jeremy Irons plays von Bulow in the movie. Ron Silver plays Dershowitz. ``Reversal of Fortune'' opened in New York on Wednesday and will open elsewhere in November.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Asks Venezuela to Extradite Noriega's Defense Forces Chief
DOC.TEXT: Panama on Friday asked Venezuela to extradite a former military commander charged in the murder of a critic of former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Dr. Hugo Spadafora, a popular supporter of various Central American causes and a critic of Noriega's government, was found slain near Panama's border with Costa Rica in 1985. His body showed signs of torture and had been decapitated. The Panamanian Foreign Ministry is seeking the extradition of Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera for trial as an ``accomplice in homicide, criminal association, crimes, abuse of authority and cover ups,'' lawyer Julio Berrio said. Diaz Herrera was the chief of staff of the Panama Defense Forces, which Noriega headed. The PDF was disbanded by the United States after it invaded Panama in December and ousted Noriega, now jailed in Miami awaiting trial on drug charges. Diaz was detained for unrelated reasons in 1987 - after accusing Noriega of murder and corruption - and since 1988 has been living in Venezuela. Meanwhile, the U.S. Southern Command in Panama announced Friday it was investigating a break-in at an ammunitions bunker at Rodman Naval base. The Southern Command said the break-in was discovered Wednesday, the day before Panamanian authorities announced they had smashed a military coup plot. It wasn't known if the two events were related. ``A thorough investigation of contents is currently under way to determine whether anything has been stolen,'' the Southern Command said. News reports said weapons and mines were taken. Attorney General Rogelio Cruz on Thursday accused retired Col. Eduardo Herrera and his brother, Capt. Francisco Herrera, of planning to take over military installations in a coup attempt. Eduardo Herrera was the first head of the Public Forces, the national police force set up to replace the PDF after the U.S. invasion. His brother is retired and lives in Miami. Neither has been arrested. The Herrera brothers are not related to Col. Diaz Herrera.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Drives Into Cafe, Two Men Hurt
DOC.TEXT: Two men were injured Friday when a truck hurtled into the cafe where they were having breakfast, knocking them from their seats in a shower of glass. ``I just heard the crash and watched the bumper,'' said Robert Rasmusson of Minot. Rasmusson, 31, and Thomas Krebsbach, 38, of Max were in a booth in Barb's Cafe when the accident happened. Walter St. Croix was driving his truck through a nearby intersection when he swerved to avoid another driver, police say. The driver, Jennifer Crooks, 18, of Minot was ticketed for allegedly running a red light. St. Croix's truck went over the curb and into the cafe, crashing through the front window. The truck stopped when it hit a supporting pillar inside the restaurant, police officer Jason Olson said. ``We kind of went underneath (the truck) and were pushed along,'' Rasmusson said. St. Croix, 54, Minot was not hurt. Rasmusson and Krebsbach suffered minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Tass Says First Nine Months of 1990 Looked Bad
With AM-Soviet-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet gross national product dropped 1.5 percent in the first nine months of 1990 while consumer prices rose 5.6 percent, signs of what the official news agency called a ``deepening crisis.'' Tass reported the statistics Friday, the same day the national legislature approved a plan to move to a more market-oriented economy over the next few years. ``The (statistics) statement says the situation results from looser control of the economy, disruption of economic links and the worsening of discipline,'' Tass reported. The statement said total industrial output declined .9 percent. The jobless rate stood at 2 million people, although Tass did not report a percentage change or give a comparison with 1989. The statement said inflation stood at 9 percent for the nine-month period, but incomes grew an average of 14.4 percent. The statement said food production was up 1.4 percent over the same period last year. But it added that ``the production and procurement of certain kinds of farm produce dropped. The grain harvest has not been fully collected in a number of regions.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in String of Bank Heists Ordered Held During Probe
DOC.TEXT: The suspected ``Bikerbank'' bandit accused of at least 22 bank robberies was ordered jailed for 15 days while police continue their investigation, Israel army radio said Friday. The robber, who reportedly fled heists on a red-and-black motorcycle, has become a folk hero among some Israelis for his ability to elude police for nearly two years. The suspect, arrested earlier Friday in the Tel Aviv suburb of Ramat Gan, was ordered held by the Tel Aviv Magistrates Court, according to radio reports. Under Israeli law, suspects are remanded into custody until police complete their investigation and decide if charges will be brought. The court ordered a ban on publication of the suspect's name and picture until police finish their questioning. But before the ban was issued, media reports said the suspect was 37 years old, married and came from a ``very wealthy'' family in Ramat Gan. Some reports said the man fell into debt after he built a $1 million home. During the past few months, the motorcycle bank robber has been the subject of prime-time television reports and series of articles in daily papers. News reports say his loot totaled about $150,000. Israel army radio said police searched his home and found two pistols, an air rifle and letters to his family apologizing for his crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Reported Moved to Bekaa Valley
DOC.TEXT: Lebanese military intelligence sources said Friday that Moslem extremists last week transferred the American and British hostages they are holding from Beirut's southern slums to east Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. The switch was made before government troops and the Syrian army launched a joint attack Saturday that ended the 11-month rebellion by Gen. Michel Aoun in the Christian heartland northeast of the capital, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. A source reported, ``We believe they are now held in Sheik Abdulla barracks in Baalbek and in the nearby village of Nabi Sheet, but we do not know who, or how many, are held in either place.'' One source said the Syrians had to know of the move, since they control the roads from Beirut to the Bekaa, ``but we do not know whether they had any role in it.'' The sources said those transferred included the six Americans held and Britons Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy, and journalist John McCarthy. Two other Britons, two West Germans and an Italian also are held. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, is the longest held. He was abducted on March 16, 1985. The Saturday attack came from three directions. One was the Shiite Moslem southern slums, a power base of the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella of Shiite zealots holding most of the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Gilt-Edged Givenchy, Leggy Lagerfeld
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Hubert de Givenchy's summer ready-to-wear show Friday burst out with lovely and wearable styles. This past master of couture made the luxury clothes look very expensive, which they are. It was a gilded collection, featuring gold threads in the first knit items right through gilt nailheads all over, plus gold lame shining through the colorful silk print dinner dresses at the end. On a new youth kick, the man who invented Audrey Hepburn's best ``gamine'' styles for her films more than 30 years ago gives his latest styles modern updates. Among the youngest: a strapless cable-knit top with a shortie black tulip-wrap skirt rimmed in gold button details. His ballooning silky harem pants looked refreshing this week. Everybody else is showing pants that look as though they'd been molded on the model. Givenchy showed many well-cut straight trousers with good cardigan and cable-knit tops, or jackets cut long and straight or rather full. The fine poplins, linens and plenty of gold buttons should please the rich set of a certain age. Younger fans will like his airy organza dresses and off-the-shoulder minis in harlequin or bold fruit and flower prints. The serpent theme gliding through a few collections here looks gaily-colored on bright leather belts, narrow skirts, sleeve details. Karl Lagerfeld also aims for younger looks, continuing his leggy themes with good jackets and loose tops he started last year. Some of the best of this slim-leg look topped by flowing jackets or cape effects came out in silky jersey fabrics in colors ranging from subtle linden green or beige to salmon. Lagerfeld's pants are cigarette-slim, or simply cotton tights. The young, but not very flattering, favorite style is to cut off the dark tights at various lengths along the leg, showing bootees below. Lots of ideas popped up from little apron outfits with shirred waists right through to plaid jackets of all lengths and cuts worn over the tights with matching plaid small boots. Bright piping on asymmetrical little dresses or sleeveless white jackets had a certain young charm, along with the buttoned plastron effects over short linen dresses in bright red or sky blue. Lagerfeld also went in for some graphic and check effects, using checked sheer wraps over maillot bathing suits, and sequined checkerboard decor for the evening wear in trapeze topped minis or slinky sheaths. Bernard Perris also went all-out for graphic prints and sequined late-day wear, in minis, long pants, and easy toppers. This designer has a raft of summer ideas, ranging from lace-up safari styles to neon-striped graphics and body-molding leather outfits in hot shades of vermilion, bright blue and cyclamen. His luscious sheer white embroidered blouses with tight sequined black pants and gold belts evoked a brassy pirate set to swing at the disco. Thierry Mugler put on a show worthy of a striptease nightclub, but not all went smoothly. Danielle Mitterrand, wife of the French president, and Culture Minister Jack Lang were among those who waited nearly two hours in sauna-type heat waiting for the show to begin. Before Mugler wound up with a nearly nude Diana Ross (with chunky glass just decently covering the strategic points and a fuchsia tulle cape), he'd brought out several other Imam and other famous models, clothed in outrageous costumes. It was mainly lycra and skin, plus a few little bunnies in bloomer-playsuits, and even a Chinese-lantern outfit in acid shades of pink and green. The rare true dress or suit was applauded, in one case a pleasantly draped white sheath as worn by famed model of the 1970s, Lauren Htton. Another audience came back later to see Madonna swan down the catwalk. But most observers agreed: Mugler should either make clothes and show them as such or take up showbiz as his real profession.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Sailors Missing after Sea Collision
DOC.TEXT: Twenty crewmen of a Portuguese fishing trawler were missing on Friday after their boat and a Greek freighter collided off southern Morocco, a Spanish navy spokesman said. He said the Greek vessel, the Ionian Wind, rescued 10 of the Ihla de Sao Vicente's crew from the sea after the collision late Thursday 240 miles south of Grand Canary Island. The trawler was badly damaged, he reported, adding that low visibility was one apparent factor in the ship crash. The Ionian Wind searched for the missing sailors, joined by eight nearby ships and by Spanish airplanes on Friday, the spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The fishing boat was headed home to northern Portugal when the accident occurred in northwestern African waters.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Awarded Indonesian Star of Merit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: President Suharto is cq
DOC.TEXT: President Suharto on Friday presented a medal of honor to South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. Mandela arrived in Jakarta earlier Friday to begin a four-day visit to Indonesia. Suharto stressed Indonesia's support of economic embargoes against South Africa to force an end to the segregationist policies. ``Indonesia will consistently and unwavering support the struggle waged by the black majority of South Africa to free themselves from the shackles of racialism,'' Suharto said. On Saturday, the African National Congress leader will hold talks with Suharto and speak at an international affairs forum organized by the foreign office. Mandela is on a three-week trip to Australia and five Asian countries.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Opens Airspace After 24 Years
DOC.TEXT: Albania opened its airspace to international flights on Friday for the first time in 24 years, said the Flight Assistance Agency, an Italian air traffic controllers' organization. It said the move by the isolationist Communist state will add another air corridor for north-south routes in the Adriatic and between Yugoslavia and Greece. An agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it is too soon to tell how much traffic Albanian flight controllers can handle. He also said he didn't know if any flights had flown along the corridor on its inaugural day, nor could he say which airlines might be using the corridor.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Plan to Freeze Hindu-Moslem Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The government, trying to defuse a Hindu-Moslem dispute that has claimed scores of lives, proposed Friday to allow Hindus to build a temple at a sacred site without destroying a mosque already there. But Hindu traditionalists rejected the plan, which was unveiled at the end of a frantic day of meetings and two sessions of Prime Minister V.P. Singh's Cabinet. Singh's government is under threat of collapse if no solution to the conflict is found by the end of the month. The dispute concerns a 16th century mosque in the holy town of Ayodhya. Hindus say it was built on the foundations of a temple over the traditional birthplace of the Hindu god Rama. A fundamentalist group, the Hindu World Council, has vowed to begin rebuilding the temple on Oct. 30. Moslems have said they won't let that happen. Officials fear a bloodbath unless a settlement is found. Riots between the two religious communities have claimed thousands of lives over the decades, and violence over Ayodhya left more than 80 people dead earlier in the month. The secretary of the Hindu group, Ashok Singhal, said the government plan was unacceptable because it left the mosque in place. The government has said it will not allow the mosque to be displaced, and has urged all sides to await the decision of the courts on dozens of petitions. Police and paramilitary forces have sealed off Ayodhya, 300 miles east of New Delhi, and about 5,000 Hindu politicians and activists have been detained. Information Minister Parvatheneni Upendra said the prime minister's plan calls for the government to acquire properties around the disputed site. Land would be made available for the construction of a temple, while cases pending before a local court could be transfered to the Supreme Court for quick handling. Meanwhile, the mosque would stay. Upendra said the Bharatiya Janata, a right-wing Hindu party that is a key government ally, had indicated it might support the prime minister's plan. But a Bharatiya Janata leader denied that. ``It seems the government is more keen to assuage the sentiments and protect the interests of the Moslem community with disregard to the sentiments of tens of millions of the overwhelming majority,'' said party secretary J.P. Mathur. Lal Krishna Advani, head of Bharatiya Janata, has been leading a 6,000-mile pilgrimage to rally public opinion for the temple. Army troops were deployed along the route of his caravan. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems make up 12 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Allow Parole for Teens Convicted in Racial Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who found two white teen-agers guilty of the racially motivated drive-by slaying of a black man recommended Friday that they go to prison for life with the possibility of parole. The jury deliberated about six hours on the fates of Matthew Faessel and Michael Stringer. The youths face formal sentencing Nov. 21. Faessel, 19, and Stringer, 18, were found guilty of first-degree murder Wednesday in the 1988 death of Tony Montgomery. Under Nevada law, the jury had to recommend a sentence to the judge. Both teen-agers must serve at least 20 years before becoming eligible for parole. Assistant District Attorney Ed Basl urged life in prison without the possibility of parole for both teen-agers. He did not seek the death penalty. The defense sought life sentences with possible parole. Basl has maintained that Faessel and Stringer were white supremacist skinheads who gunned down Montgomery, 27, in the font yard of his sister's northeast Reno home because he was black.

DOC.HEAD: International Group to Observe Pakistan Election
DOC.TEXT: Observers from 18 countries will monitor Pakistan's parliamentary election next week, U.S. organizers of the effort said Friday. Asia, Africa, Europe and North and Central America are represented on the 40-member team, which includes about 20 Americans and people from Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Poland, Namibia and the Philippines, countries that themselves had international observers at recent elections.
