Politicians, parliamentarians, regional specialists and others on the mission will ``demonstrate the international community's continued support for free and fair elections and democratization in Pakistan'' and provide the world ``with an objective assessment of the Pakistani electoral process,'' said the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, international arm of the U.S. Democratic Party. It said the delegation is scheduled to arrive in Islamabad, Pakistan's capital city, on Sunday, then separate into smaller groups to visit polling places and counting centers throughout the country on Wednesday, the day of the election. A news conference on its findings is planned next Friday in Karachi. In addition to the United States, participatants come from Bulgaria, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, the Gambia, Japan, Kenya, Namibia, New Zealand, Panama, the Philippines, Poland, Senegal, Sri Lanka, Turkey, Britain and the African National Council, a major black organization in white-ruled South Africa, the announcement said. It noted that U.S. members include both Republicans and Democrats. The institute recalled that it organized the 25-member international delegation that monitored Pakistan's 1988 federal and provincial elections, and that the team rated them as generally free and fair and conducted in a process that ``compared favorably with those used in other democratic countries.'' It was the 1988 election that brought to power Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was dismissed by Pakistani President Ghulam Ishaq Khan in August and accused of mismanagement and corruption. She and her Peoples Party have been campaigning vigorously for parliamentary seats.

DOC.HEAD: Petrobras Chief Quits After Clash with Economy Minister
DOC.TEXT: The president of Brazil's giant state oil company Petrobras resigned Friday and accused the government of keeping oil prices artificially low. Petrobras President Luis Octavio da Motta Veiga announced his resignation at an afternoon press conference in the company's headquarters in Rio. ``I turned in my resignation because ofthe bad conduct inside the government regarding the pricing system for oil products,'' Motta said. He said the government was ``squeezing'' the company to keep fuel prices low and avoid a renewed burst of inflation. ``This is a policy followed by this government and past governmanets and it has never succeeded,'' Motta said. ``The government is using Petrobras as a smokescreen to cover up for economic problems.'' Domestic fuel prices have been raised five times since the Persian Gulf crisis broke out beginning Aug. 2 with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The government last raised fuel costs by 20 percent on Oct. 9. Economists say the jump in oil prices poses a serious threat to President Fernando Collor de Mello's Mar. 15 austerity plan to curb four-digit inflation. Higher oil prices has helped push inflation up from 3.3 percent in April to 9.6 percent in June, 10.5 percent in August and nearly 13 percent in September. Motta said Petrobras needed at least a 40 percent increase in fuel prices to offset an internal deficit of $1.2 billion. He said the company's debt was rapidly mounting because Petrobras was selling oil domestically for the equivalent of $20 a barrel and paying $32 a barrel for low-grade imported oil. Brazil produces an average of 665,000 barrels of oil daily and imports about 450,000 barrels a day. On Monday, Economy Minister Cardoso de Mello told a Senate committee in Brasilia, the capital, that Petrobras was inefficient, overpaid its workers, and withheld information about its costs in order to win internal price increases. Motta was replaced early Friday evening by Eduardo Teixeira, the No. 2 official in the Economy Ministry and a close friend and aide of Cardoso de Mello, according to presidential spokesman Pedro Luiz Rodrigues.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Sentenced To 30 Years In Slaying Of Girl
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old honor student was sentenced Friday to 30 years in prison for fatally stabbing a schoolmate 97 times, but the sentence will be evaluated when he turns 17. Terrence, who was 12 when the slaying occurred, showed no emotion when the verdict was read Thursday or when the sentence was ordered. He will begin his sentence at a state youth facility. When he turns 17, a judge will decide whether to release him or order him to serve the rest of his sentence in a state prison. Terrence Sampson was convicted of murder in the December 1989 death of his next-door neighbor, Kelly Brumbelow, 13. He was tried under a law allowing youths as young as 10 to be tried as juveniles and adults. Kelly was found dead under a wood pile in the Sampson's backyard. The two were honor students in the seventh grade at C.D. Fulkes Middle School. Terrence played on the football team and Kelly was a cheerleader. The boy's attorney, Chris Gunter, said he will appeal the conviction. `Like I said in my closing arguments, no matter what the facts are, he was just 12 years old at the time, and I really do question whether he understood the concept of death,'' Gunter said.

DOC.HEAD: Movie Version of Orwell's `1984' to Premiere in Moscow
With AM-Gone With the Wind, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the first time, the film version of George Orwell's anti-totalitarian novel ``1984'' will be shown in the Soviet Union. ``It's like breaking down the Berlin Wall,'' said Chicago lawyer Marvin J. Rosenblum, executive producer of the 1983 movie starring John Hurt and Richard Burton, who died a few months later. Orwell's bleak classic, depicting the world of Big Brother, was aimed at any totalitarian regime, left or right, but it was often read as an indictment of the Soviet system. Until last year, the book was banned in the Soviet Union. ``But people have read it under the covers,'' Rosenblum said. ``I've talked to a lot of Russians, and there's always been a lot of interest in it. All the intellectuals are aware of it.'' Rosenblum bought the rights to make the film from Orwell's widow in 1980. It was shown in a score or more countries, but was forbidden in what used to be the Eastern bloc. The movie will premiere in Moscow in early December or January in conjunction with a conference on art and freedom of expression, Rosenblum said Thursday. His next step is negotiating distribution of the film throughout the Soviet Union. Rosenblum paid an undisclosed sum for rights to distribute the film in the Soviet Union. The rights were owned by the British company Virgin Vision, whose parent company put up the $8 million to film the story. ``I took a calculated risk and decided the amount of money I was paying for this was worth the milestone - just to see the headlines, `1984 Premieres in Moscow,' '' he said. ``I'd like to make money on this. But if all that really happens is that a significant number of Russians see the film, I would not be unhappy,'' Rosenblum said. For the Moscow showing, Rosenblum said actors may read the lines to the audience during the movie. He said he didn't know if nationally distributed films would be dubbed or sub-titled. No political problems now exist in negotiating a distribution contract in the Soviet Union, Rosenblum said. In the past, only one agency had permission to import films. ``Now just about anybody can do it,'' Rosenblum said.

DOC.HEAD: Final Ruling: Former Dictator Rios Montt Barred from Presidency
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court eliminated former dictator Efrain Rios Montt from the Nov. 11 presidential election, issuing a final ruling Friday that Rios Montt's past activities disqualified him. The Court of Constitutionality said Rios Montt was ineligible under an article of the constitution that bars anyone who came to power in a coup from being elected president. Rios Montt, a retired general, lead a military junta after the March 23, 1982, coup that overthrew elected President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia. On June 9, 1982, he named himself president. In August 1983 he was ousted in another military coup. Neither Rios Montt nor his supporters could be reached for comment Friday night. The decision left a field of 12 candidates, most of them rightists, running to replace President Vinicio Cerezo, a Christian Democrat, whose term expires Jan. 14. The Constitution prohibits Cerezo from running for another 5-year term. Rios Montt's bid for the presidency was first refused when he tried to register Aug. 22, and the Supreme Electoral Tribunal upheld that decision. But he was registered provisionally under a temporary injunction issued while courts reviewed the case. The Supreme Court later ruled him ineligible, but the Court of Constitutionality was the final arbiter in the matter. Because the Constitution links an entire ticket to its presidential candidate, the decision also bars Rios Montt's running mate, Harris Whitbeck Pinol, and his three-party coalition's congressional candidates. Rios Montt is backed by the National Unity Front, the Institutional Democratic Party and the Guatemalan Republican Front. Rios Montt's law and order image at a time of increasing crime and allegations of government corruption had given him a strong position in some polls. While president, the born-again Christian general addressed the nation in televised Sunday sermons and ordered crackdowns on corruption. He also sent more than a dozen people before firing squads for alleged involvement with leftist insurgents. Some were executed during a visit by Pope John Paul II. A bloody military campaign against leftist rebels in the northwest highlands under Rios Montt's regime killed thousands of peasants, most of them Indians.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Opponent Takes a Bus to Debate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf at bottom to UPDATE with Rinfret flying home aboard private jet.
DOC.TEXT: This is not where a gubernatorial candidate should prepare for his first debate with a powerful incumbent: Gate 76, lower level, Port Authority Bus Terminal. But there stood Republican Pierre Rinfret, clutching a $39.55 one-way ticket Friday morning. Rinfret, a millionaire economist running a cash-starved campaign, glad-handed fellow passengers and the bus driver before boarding a Greyhound bound for Syracuse and a showdown with Gov. Mario Cuomo. Lack of party funds forced him to use mass transit, he said. ``Is this a publicity stunt? Yeah, in part. But we're out of money,'' said Rinfret. Three aides accompanied him on his excursion north. So exactly how much money is left in the Rinfret warchest? ``We got a big check yesterday - $1,000. Now we've got $1,100 in our account,'' Rinfret joked. Rinfret got a lot of mileage out of the stunt even before the bus left. Four local television crews and a pair of radio reporters showed up. His arrival in Syracuse several hours later and 30 minutes behind schedule was less postitive. Striking Greyhound workers greeted him with cries of ``Scab!'' and a sign reading ``Wrong Way Rinfret.'' The debate itself, to also feature Conservative Party candidate Herbert London and Right-to-Life Party candidate Louis Wein, didn't seem to excite Rinfret as much as his first bus ride since 1941. ``It's not a debate, it's a charade of a debate. I don't consider Wein or London candidates. That's another charade,'' he said. ``Cuomo is a ghost governor. He only shows up where he wants to show up under certain conditions.'' Rinfret, wearing a blue suit, appeared out of place as he awaited the bus among the police, passengers and occasional homeless person. He perked up when another rider recognized him. ``Mr. Rinfret,'' the woman said as he walked past. ``You recognize me!'' replied an exuberant Rinfret. ``I saw you on TV,'' she responded. The gubernatorial hopeful than shook hands with other passengers, many of whom didn't seem to know who he was. Yet Rinfret remained upbeat about his trip and his chances. ``I think you might see the best political overturn in this century,'' said Rinfret. ``We are neck and neck with Cuomo in some heavy Democratic areas.'' Recent polls indicate Rinfret is more neck and neck with London than Cuomo. But he glossed over those numbers. As with much of Rinfret's campaign, the Greyhound caper didn't go off all that smoothly. The candidate almost boarded the wrong bus; the right bus left 13 minutes late. But all ended well. Rinfret waved goodbye from a window seat. After the debate, Rinfret said he was being flown back to New York City by Jefferson County Republican Chairman Ronald Trickey aboard a private plane.

DOC.HEAD: Faced With Loss of Liquor, Elks Lodge Asks To Allow Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS two grafs at bottom to include comment of ordinance opponent.
DOC.TEXT: An Elks lodge faced with losing its liquor license because of an ordinance banning discrimination by private clubs is asking the all-male group's national leaders to admit women. The Annapolis Elks Lodge 622 voted 48-3 Wednesday night to ask the Elks national convention to change its bylaws to admit women. If approved by the national convention next summer, the change would mean that every Elks lodge in the country could admit women, said George Bond, Exalted Ruler of the Annapolis lodge. The issue came up at the national convention of the 2,300-lodge fraternal benevolent society two years ago and was defeated, he said. The new ordinance, effective Jan. 1, will deny liquor licenses to private clubs with bylaws that discriminate on the basis of race, gender or ethnic background. If the Annapolis lodge loses its liquor license, it might sue to overturn the law or sell its building and move out of town, Bond said. ``We like Annapolis,'' he said. ``We've been here 90 years. We need the liquor license to sustain the lodge and our charitable works.'' Another organization, the Eastport Democratic Club, changed its bylaws to admit women after the new ordinance was approved earlier this year, but later denied membership to three women who applied. That prompted a city alderman to consider tightening the law. The two clubs have no black members. To give the Elks lodge time to change its bylaws, Alderman Wayne Turner has proposed delaying implementation until August 1991 for clubs whose bylaws are set by natinnal memberships. The council's rules committee is considering Turner's measure. The ordinance was approved in February on a close vote, 5-4. Some city alderman who supported the measure don't object to extending its implementation. ``As long as they're moving forward in good faith, I have no problems with extending it,'' said Alderman Ruth Gray, who voted for the ordinance. Alderman Carl Snowden, who sponsored the anti-discrimination measure, lauded the Elks vote, but said his support of the extension hinges on how seriously the club recruits black men. ``I very much would like to see a compromise struck with the Elks lodge. If there is this good-faith effort I wouldn't have any problem whatsoever in voting to amend the law,'' he said. Alderman Wayne Turner, who voted against the ordinance, said the Eastport club is proof the law won't work. ``I don't believe anyone on the council believes in discrimination,'' he said. ``But, it's a state issue, not a city issue. Anyone who had a problem with the club should have went through the state.''

DOC.HEAD: Arson Suspected In Dorm Fire That Critically Injures Two Students
DOC.TEXT: Investigators believe someone deliberately set a fire that swept through a San Jose State University dormitory on Friday, injuring 21 people. One student, unable to breathe because of the thick smoke that filled Andrew Moulder Hall, jumped from a third-floor window and suffered a back fracture but was in stable condition, authorities said. Other students trapped by the flames that erupted shortly before 6 a.m. leaned out the windows, screaming for help as firefighters set up ladders to rescue them. Fire crews led other students, still clad in robes and slippers, down stairways to safety. ``My roommate and I heard this crackling noise and we opened our door and smoke just gushed in our faces,'' said Anita Rich, one of the 178 residents of the brick building. ``We couldn't see where we were running. We just ran.'' Fire officials said they suspect arson is to blame for the blaze started on or near a couch on the third floor. They would not discuss all the reasons for their suspicions but said one was that the couch was not in its usual place. ``There appears to be a couch that was moved from one part of the dormitory to another on the third floor. And according to arson investigators, the couch was involved,'' said campus Police Chief Ric Abeyta. The state fire marshal was investigating the fire at the state-run university with 31,000 students about 40 miles south of San Francisco. More than 30 firefighters put out the blaze in less than an hour as paramedics took 21 students to three hospitals near the downtown campus. Two male students were in critical condition with burns at Santa Clara Valley Medical Center. Bryan Young, 20, had burns over 55 percent of his body, and Thomas Byrd, 18, suffered burns over 40 percent of his body, according to a shift supervisor at the hospital. The university moved Moulder Hall students to vacant rooms at nearby dormitories, sent counselors to the hospitals and set up a hotline for families and friends to check on students. In the afternoon, they allowed Moulder Hall residents to return to their rooms to retrieve their belongings. Most fled the burning building in bathrobes, without keys, wallets or valuables. ``You just get out of there. You don't think,'' said junior Jana Garrett, who wore a blue robe and fuzzy slippers. Students, most still groggy from sleep, were further befuddled by thick smoke. ``It was pretty freaky. The hall was completely dark,'' said Karsten Adam, who grabbed a gas mask he had hung on his wall as a decoration before running down the hallway. ``I was thinking of jumping out the window because there was so much smoke out there.'' Moulder Hall was not equipped with sprinklers because it was built in 1958, before they were required. But the dorm's fire alarm system worked perfectly, university officials said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Gubernatorial Candidates Meet for First Debate
With AM-Riding With Rinfret, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret came out firing Friday in his first debate against Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo, saying the incumbent deserves a ``double F'' in economics. Rinfret's comment set the tone of the debate, which also included Conservative candidate Herbert London and Right-to-Life candidate Louis Wein. Rinfret, a millionaire Manhattan economist and former teacher said: ``If Mario ever came into a class of economics of mine ... I'd give him a double F. His numbers are the phoniest I've ever heard.'' Cuomo, seeking a third, four-year term countered, ``If ever I came to your economics class, I shouldn't be flunked, I should be committed.'' The candidates were questioned by a panel of three reporters. The debate, which had no audience, was taped for broadcast by stations around the state over the next several days. Rinfret and London repeatedly attacked Cuomo's handling of the state economy, noting New York's credit rating is at its lowest ever and residents have just been hit with a record $1.8 billion tax increase. ``It's not a bad idea for Mario to resign before he gets thrown out in an election,'' Rinfret said. London said the state had ``a budget out of control.'' Wein said if he couldn't be elected, he would prefer to see Cuomo re-elected. He called Cuomo ``a man of decency and intelligence.'' Wein's praise drew a sharp rebuke from Rinfret, who pointed at Cuomo and said, ``This man is the enemy.'' Cuomo accused the other candidates of using inaccurate statistics when they criticized his tenure as governor. ``It's easy to answer these questions if you just make up facts,'' Cuomo said. Cuomo has agreed to participate in only two debates. The other is set for Nov. 4, two days before the election. Rinfret took a bus to get here from New York City to dramatize his campaign's lack of funds, but he was to fly back in a private plane provided by a GOP county leader. Rinfret had asked the Syracuse television station hosting Friday's debate, WTVH, to pay airplane fare for him and a half-dozen aides. The station refused. Leading up to Friday's debate, Cuomo has largely ignored his rivals and concentrated on public appearances that stress his record as governor. Cuomo said Thursday that he's never been a fan of debates. ``In a debate, it's a joke or who calls who a name,'' he complained.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Intelligence Bill
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement late Friday on an intelligence bill that would provide for a suspension of covert lethal aid to rebels in Angola if the Marxist government agrees to elections, sources said. The bill, agreed to after day-long talks between the two intelligence committees, also would phase out a covert aid program to Cambodian rebels and trim roughly $50 million from the administration's $300 million request for aid to rebels in Afghanistan. The changes reflect dwindling support on Capitol Hill for proxy wars in the Third World that were a leading feature of President Reagan's anticommunist crusade. With thawing relations between the United States and the Soviet Union and reduction of Soviet support of client groups, much of the rationale for U.S. involvement in those conflicts has evaporated. On Angola, the committees agreed to provide that military aid to the UNITA rebels - about half the total $60 million annual support - could be suspended if the president certifies that the Luanda government schedules free elections in which the rebels are free to participate. But members deleted key provisions passed by the House earlier this week that would have permitted Congress to make the decision to suspend military aid if the president did not. On Cambodia, the roughly $13 million aid program for non-communist resistance factions fighting the communist Phnom Penh government would be ended early next year and converted to an open program of humanitarian aid, the sources said. And aid to the mujaheddin rebels fighting the Soviet-supported Afghan government would be cut by about $50 million, said officials who spoke only on condition of anonymity. The cut was a compromise between a Senate-passed $100 million cut and the full $300 million the House adopted. The negotiators also left in place a House-passed provision that would disburse the Afghan rebel aid in two six-month installments, providing a point where aid could be ended at mid-year if U.S.-Soviet talks result in a withdrawal of aid by both superpowers. Also included in the compromise bill were changes that arose out of the Iran-Contra scandal, including a new requirement that presidential authorization for covert operations must be in writing. Money for various programs covered by the bill is provided in various parts, some of them secret, of the defense appropriations bill. The sum spent for intelligence activities of all kinds is believed to be about $30 billion.

DOC.BYLINE: American Takes Top Prize at Chopin Piano Competition ^By DRUSILLA MENAKER
DOC.TEXT: American Kevin Kenner won the top prize awarded Saturday in the prestigious 12th International Frederic Chopin Piano Competition. The jury awarded no first prize, apparently agreeing with the audience that the competitors performed with technical skill but no genius. Deliberations continued for three hours past the scheduled announcement. Kenner, a San Diego resident studying in Hanover, Germany, was awarded the silver medal with a prize of $2,100. ``I am happy and relieved,'' said Kenner, 27, as he was hugged by his wife and his teacher in the lobby of the National Philharmonic Hall, where the three-week competition was staged. Yukio Yokoyama, a 19-year-old Tokyo native studying in Paris, won the third-prize bronze medal, with a prize of $1,575. Fourth places went to Corrado Rollero, 21, of Italy, and Margarita Shevchenko, 23, of the Soviet Union. Fifth places were awarded to Anna Malikova, 25, of the Soviet Union and Takako Takahashi, 26, of Japan. The judges awarded no prizes for the best performance of a Chopin mazurka or for the concerto. The award for the best polonaise went to Kenner and Wojciech Switala, 23, who withdrew from the third round after being the only Pole to reach the semifinal. The competition has been staged since 1927 to honor Chopin, the composer born in 1810 near Warsaw. He studied at the Warsaw Conservatory but settled in Paris, where he gave his first concert in 1831 and went on to use his romantic compositions to establish the piano as a solo instrument. He never returned to his homeland but recalled Poland in his polonaises and mazurkas. He died of tuberculosis in 1849 and was buried in Paris. His heart, however, was interred in a Warsaw church, and Poles embrace him as a national hero. The 12th staging of the competition by the Chopin Society in Warsaw attracted nearly 140 competitors. The seven finalists performed Chopin's concertos in E minor or F minor on Thursday and Friday. The winner was to be announced by the jury at 11 p.m. Friday, but was not presented until about 2 a.m. Saturday. Meanwhile, the anxious contestants mingled with autograph-seekers and an international audience of Chopin enthusiasts. Only one American has ever won the first prize, Garrick Ohlsson in 1970, and none have placed second. Kenner, born 1963 in Coronado, Calif., studied with a Polish-American teacher before attending the Peabody Conservatory of Music in Baltimore. He called the judge's withholding of a first prize ``disappointing'' but ``very strange and very interesting.'' He noted the competition is among the most prestigious for pianists and has served to launch many careers.

DOC.HEAD: International Drug Dealer Sentenced to 25 Years, Heavy Fines
DOC.TEXT: A man described by prosecutors as the single biggest supplier of Southeast Asian marijuana to the United States was sentenced Friday to 25 years in prison and fined a maximum $6.25 million. Brian Daniels, 44, a New York native who lived in Thailand for 10 years, had pleaded guilty to smuggling tons of marijuana into the United States from Southeast Asia between 1984 to 1988. The shipments included multi-ton deliveries to Seattle, Southern California, Oregon, Nevada, Britis Columbia and Mexico, according to court documents. Among them was a shipment of 72 tons of high-grade Laotian marijuana seized in June 1988 aboard the Encounter Bay, an oil-supply vessel, off the Washington coast. ``Marijuana, regardless of what anyone feels about it, is illegal and it makes you money,'' U.S. District Judge John Coughenour said. ``You have to keep in mind there are a lot of kids in this country affected by marijuana - and for whom the first step to drugs is marijuana.'' Prosecutors contended Daniels turned drug profits into $10 million in personal assets, none of which has been recovered by the federal government. Daniels' lawyer, J. Williams Beard, said most of Daniels' assets were in Thai real estate holdings and attempts to turn them over to the U.S. government had failed. Beard said Daniels' first wife holds the deeds to the property and refuses to surrender them. Under Thai law it is illegal for a woman married to a foreign national to hold property, but the Thai government has not cooperated in securing the assets, Beard said. ``I wish to assure your honor that I have no hidden funds or assets stashed away for a rainy day,'' Daniels said during the hearing. Daniels, who has eeen held in Pierce County Jail in Tacoma, pleaded guilty last December to one count of operating a continuing criminal enterprise. In September, Daniels pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy that he earlier agreed would be part of the plea package. They involved schemes to import 17 tons of marijuana to San Diego and 42 tons of the drug to Reno. Daniels was sentenced by Coughenour to concurrent prison terms of 25 years for the Reno conviction and 15 years for the San Diego offense.

DOC.HEAD: Paint Makers Decry New Reports, Say Nearly All are Mercury-Free
DOC.TEXT: Paint companies scrambled to alleviate consumer fears Friday over reports that mercury in interior latex paint can be harmful. Several of the companies said they have not used mercury for years. The Environmental Protection Agency barred manufacturers from adding mercury to paint after Aug. 20. Paint made before then can still be sold, however. But the furor followed reports this week of a study that found relatively high levels of mercury in people whose homes were painted inside with latex paint containing mercury. The study, conducted in 1989, was published in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. Concern about mercury in paint arose last year after a 4-year-old Michigan boy suffered mercury poisoning when his home was painted. He suffered severe rashes, itching, sweating and a personality change. The EPA's 24-hour hotline for paint information - the National Pesticide Telecommunications Network at 1-800-858-7378 - reported a record 900 calls Thursday. A trade group for 550 manufacturers, including some of the nation's largest, noted that paint used in the study and to which the boy was exposed contained nearly three times as much mercury as the EPA recommended at the time. The paint was made by the Mercury Paint Co. of Detroit, Mich. ``It was almost certainly at the high end,'' said Marilyn Ludwig, spokeswoman for the National Paint & Coatings Association in Washington. ``Vague directives'' led to the EPA declaring Mercury Paint's mercury levels to be an ``unenforceable action,'' agency spokesman Al Heier said. A telephone call Friday to Charles Soberman, president and owner of Mercury Paint, was not immediately returned. Most uses of mercury were banned in the mid-1970s, except in paint. Manufacturers had convinced the EPA they didn't have a good alternative to mercury, Heier said. The element is used to preserve the paint in the can and prevent mildew after application. The EPA estimates that before the recent ban, up to 30 percent of interior latex paint contained mercury. But the industry association believes just 10 percent to 15 percent contained the element, Ms. Ludwig said. Consumers who own paint bought before the ban should call the manufacturer to determine if it contains mercury, she said. If it has more than 200 parts per million, she recommended using it only outdoors. Health officials do not recommend removing latex paint from walls. They believe the risk of mercury contamination is highest in the first weeks after application. The mercury evaporates shortly after the paint dries. Several manufacturers also criticized news reports as misleading. Sherwin-Williams and Benjamin Moore, two of the nations largest paint manufacturers, said their products haven't contained mercury since 1973 and 1969, respectively. John Oberle, technical director for Montvale-based Benjamin Moore, said alternatives to mercury that were less harmful to people and the environment were employed in the mid-1970s, even though they weren't as effective. Those alternative compounds have since been improved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Nana Downgraded to Tropical Storm
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Nana weakened late Friday to a tropical storm and forecasters expected it to slowly continue losing strength as it remained nearly stationary in the Caribbean. Nana, which had been a minimal hurricane, had top winds of 70 mph, but still posed a threat to Bermuda. ``The storm is rather close to Bermuda and could still produce tropical storm-strength winds on Bermuda,'' said Miles Lawrence at the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Nana's center was located near 29.6 north latitude and 66.2 west longitude, or about 200 miles south-southwest of Bermuda. Nana, the eighth-named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, moved north-northeast near 5 mph and was expected to turn toward the northeast Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Asks Jury to Send Message to Racists In Deciding Damages Suit
DOC.TEXT: An attorney told jurors Friday they can send a message to the racists of the world by returning a multimillion-dollar verdict in a wrongful death lawsuit against a white supremacist group and its leaders. Lawyer Morris Dees said in closing arguments that the evidence was overwhelming against White Aryan Resistance founder Tom Metzger, who is representing himself in court, as are his co-defendants. ``We want you to come back with a verdict to tell ... the Tom Metzgers of the world that this is not the way we run this country,'' said Dees, whose clients are seeking $12.5 million in damages. Metzger, 52, a television repairman from Fallbrook, Calif., is a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon. The lawsuit also names WAR and Metzger's son John, 22. The suit accuses the Metzgers of inciting the November 1988 beating death of Mulugeta Seraw, 27, an Ethiopian who planned to attend school in Portland. Seraw was attacked by three racist skinheads as he returned home from a party. His head was split open by a softball bat. Kenneth Mieske, Kyle Brewster and Steven Strasser pleaded guilty to killing Seraw. Mieske and Brewster also are defendants in the lawsuit. Seraw's family filed the lawsuit being heard in Multnomah County Circuit Court before Judge Ancer Haggerty. Seraw's young son and his father, who came from Ethiopia for the trial, sat in the front row Friday. Tom Metzger was scheduled to give a closing statement Monday, after which the case was to go to the jury. John Metzger, who heads the Aryan Youth Movement, a WAR spinoff, told jurors the trial was a conspiracy between the plaintiffs and the government. ``This whole thing is a joke,'' he said in a brief closing statement. ``They want to destroy us because we're consistent.'' ``I will continue what I'm doing because I'm right and I'm not liable like they say,'' Metzger said. He complained to jurors that much of the testimony he and his father wanted to introduce was ruled irrelevant. ``A lot of funny things went on in this courtroom that you'll never know about and it's too bad,'' Metzger said. Dees aims to bankrupt WAR. He won a $7 million jury verdict against the United Klans of America in 1987 after two Klansmen from Mobile, Ala., killed a 19-year-old black man. Dees built his case against the Metzgers around the testimony of Dave Mazzella, 21, a former leader in the Aryan Youth Movement. Mazzella said the Metzgers sent him to Portland to organize skinheads here and to teach them how to commit violence against minorities.

Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's emissary to Iraq is calling on President Bush with assurances of solid Kremlin support for tougher international sanctions aimed at forcing Iraq out of Kuwait. U.S. officials said envoy Yevgeny Primakov stressed that Moscow wants to keep working through the United Nations to reverse the Aug. 2 invasion with political and diplomatic measures. Primakov stopped in Rome and Paris this week on his way to Washington. Among the new steps under consideration are demanding reparations from Iraq for what Secretary of State James A. Baker III calls ``the rape of Kuwait'' and possibly an international trial of President Saddam Hussein as a war criminal. The U.N. Security Council has banned virtually all trade with Iraq, but after more than two months of occupying Kuwait the Iraqi leader has not bowed to the pressure. ---= BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) - There is mackerel from China, sardines, tuna and pineapples from Asia, olives from Morocco, butter cookies from Denmark and grape juice from Austria. Even American hot sauce. The array of imported food available in Baghdad belies the U.N. trade embargo imposed on Iraq in retaliation for its invasion of Kuwait. But many of the items on grocery store shelves are from what Iraqis call their 19th province - Kuwait, which was stripped of consumer goods after the invasion. No one knows for certain whether Iraqis will ever feel the full bite of the 11-week-old blockade, but it is changing how and what they eat, and what they grow. But prices are rising beyond the reach of the common man in this city of 4.5 million. A chicken lunch in an average restaurant costs $15, and it is reported that such staples as wheat, milk, sugar and tea are no longer readily available. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - After more than a month in jail, Charles H. Keating Jr. won a bail reduction and headed home to prepare his defense against the first criminal charges in one of the nation's biggest savings and loan failures. U.S. District Judge John G. Davies ruled Thursday that the $5 million bail set by a state judge for the 66-year-old former thrift operator was excessively high in the investment fraud case. Davies lowered bail to $300,000, and Keating's family posted it by pledging their houses as security. Keating was released Thursday night, smiling as he walked out of jail. Davies had heard an impassioned plea by Los Angeles lawyer John ``Jack'' Quinn, who has defended Keating against a slew of civil charges stemming from the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. ---= BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) - Colombia is trying to repair a judicial system made powerless by drug traffickers, who often kill judges and court officials they cannot bribe or coerce. President Cesar Gaviria, inaugurated Aug. 7, plans ``fortress cities'' where judges can live and work free of intimidation that presents them with a choice of ``plata o plomo'' - money or lead. ``The country's powerful crime organizations are leaving the judicial system in complete impotence,'' said Fernando Carrillo, judicial adviser to Gaviria. An elite corps of ``untouchables'' - specialized judges, policemen and lawyers - is to be created and given constant military protection.

THE AP

A judge Friday tried to jump start Manuel Noriega's drug-smuggling trial, which has stalled over disputes about legal fees, a new indictment and the fate of his co-defendants. Also complicating the case is the new Panamanian government's $5 billion lawsuit against the country's former military leader, expected to be filed here as early as next week. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler called in prosecutors and the defense Friday for a conference on the case's progress, with an eye on the planned January starting date. ``We've got to press on with this,'' Hoeveler insisted, but for the first time acknowledged the Jan. 28 trial date might have to be moved back until spring. ---= LONDON (AP) - The Liberal Democratic Party, derided by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher just last week as a ``dead parrot,'' is back in business after a stunning election upset over the Conservative Party. ``The parrot has twitched,'' Conservative Party Chairman Kenneth Baker said Friday of the Liberal Democrats' victory in a special parliamentary election in the prosperous south England town of Eastbourne. The town has been Tory territory for more than 70 years. ``Some dead parrot... It's given her a nasty nip,'' said the Liberal Democrats' leader, Paddy Ashdown. The centrist party, whose most famous member is John Cleese of ``Monty Python'' fame, posted a huge 20.5 percent swing against the government in Thursday's election to replace a Tory legislator killed by the IRA. The Conservatives were burdened by voters' unhappiness over high interest rates, health and welfare cuts and an unpopular new tax. ---= TOKYO (AP) - When the heir to Japan's throne announced more than 30 years ago that he would wed a commoner, the nation's former aristocracy lamented the end of an era. Already stripped of their titles by the Allied occupation forces following World War II, they were being confronted with the end of another birthright - supplying the throne with empresses. Michiko Shoda, the wealthy businessman's daughter who became the first commoner to marry a future Japanese monarch, has since brought a quiet revolution to an ancient and tradition-bound institution. With the support of her husband, Emperor Akihito, she has brought a secluded and often mysterious palace closer to the people. Empress Michiko, who will be 56 on Saturday, will stand beside her husband next month as he is formally coronated. ---= BERLIN (AP) - The once-mighty Red army has fallen on hard times in the new Germany. Its military mission is over, its presence is resented by many Germans, and its soldiers are deserting in droves to avoid going home. Once they were crack front-line troops in the Cold War. Now the Soviet soldiers stationed in what was East Germany find themselves a relic of a bygone era. Final withdrawal of the 600,000 troops and dependents is not scheduled until 1994. Already, the strain is showing. The Soviet forces are a heavy financial burden for newly unified Germany, now saddled with enormous costs of the merger. The Bonn government agreed to pay upwards of $800 million this year to maintain the Soviets. Germany will also pay billions to retrain and build new housing for the troops. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - What began as a small conference of academic radicals mushroomed into a weekend meeting of more than 1,000 activists and leftists - proof, organizers say, that the ethos of the 1960s is alive and well. ``It's true that many of us are a little heavier around the middle and losing hair,'' said Lauren Langman, 50, a conference leader. ``But we're still here.'' ``The radical left is still very much alive,'' agreed Carl Davidson, 47, a former member of Students for a Democratic Society and a conference organizer. ``Not all of us could marry Jane Fonda,'' he said, referring to the actress' marriage to '60s radical Tom Hayden, now active in mainstream California politics. A colorful band of political warriors - socialists, environmentalists, feminists and others - registered for the Midwest Radical Scholars and Activists Conference, which runs through Sunday. ---= MOSCOW (AP) - With popping flashbulbs, furs and limousines, Hollywood made a classic entrance in Moscow on Friday night for the Soviet premiere of ``Gone With The Wind.'' The 1939 epic began an indefinite engagement in Moscow courtesy of a British-Soviet joint venture and Ted Turner, the American media mogul already known in the Soviet Union for his Cable News Network and Goodwill Games. A Red Army band played outside the 2,500-seat Oktyabr theater while moviegoers were treated to a yellow champagne-lookalike before the opening. The VIPs got the real stuff, with caviar, behind a guarded door. Hundreds of people jammed the sidewalk in front of the theater on one of Moscow's main thoroughfares for a chance to view what Turned called the American equivalent of Tolstoy's ``War and Peace,'' another tale of lives torn asunder by a great war.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Movies: Long on Romance, Tears and Fuzzy Animals
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Japan has conquered world market after world market during its postwar economic resurgence, but its home-grown movie industry is proving no match for ``Made in America'' films. Critics say rampant commercialism, self-censorship and shrinking domestic audiences have badly damaged the Japanese industry and led to mediocrity. But the biggest threat may be the popularity of American movies in Japan, which has prompted Japanese investors to put their money in Hollywood instead of local studios. ``The world has looked up to U.S. entertainment since the end of World War II,'' says Bill Ireton, managing director of Warner Bros. (Japan) Inc. ``To the Japanese, American movies are hip and trendy and Japanese audiences would rather be dead than unfashionable.'' Japan is the largest foreign market for U.S. films. American movies accounted for 61 percent of all pictures seen here in 1989, according to Ireton. The two top box-office draws last year among Japanese movies were animated films. But even the No. 1 Japanese film, ``Kiki's Delivery Service,'' brought in less than half the 4.4 billion yen ($32 million) earned by ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.'' Akira Shimizu, a former critic who is general-secretary of the Japan Film Library Council, says mediocre films are the result of Japanese studios' emphasis on profit. Because quality movies cost more to make, he said, ``the old masters who want to depict social problems have no opportunity to make their films. ... It's a question of business.'' There is more profit to be made targeting the largest ticket-buying audience in Japan, women aged 18-25, with movies long on romance, fuzzy animals and simplistic plots. Although Japan's four big movie studios are diversified and can rely on profits from other pursuits, Shimizu believes the money available to make quality movies won't increase. ``Such a golden age of Japanese films like the 1950s will never happen again,'' he says. The film industry had its heyday in the 1950s and '60s, when a young Akira Kurosawa was making such classics as ``Rashomon'' and ``Seven Samurai'' with Japanese backing. With 1.13 billion movie tickets sold, 1958 was the height of Japan's postwar movie renaissance. But 10 years later, the popularity of television had sent ticket sales slumping to 300 million. With the influx of videocassette recorders, the domestic movie industry has been battered further, with only 143.5 million tickets sold last year. For Japanese movie studios, there may soon be no business in show business. Instead of boosting their own weak film industry, Japanese investors have more faith in the ``Made in America'' stamp of Hollywood. Japanese investors want popular American programming for TV stations, cable companies, movie theaters and videocassette ventures. Last year, SonyCorp. purchased Columbia Pictures Entertainment for $5 billion. In September, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. confirmed it was conducting negotiations with entertainment giant MCA, which owns Universal Pictures, in what reportedly would be a $7 billion buy-out. Nomura Securities, electronics-manufacturer JVC Corp. and a subsidiary of Pioneer Electronics Corp. also have invested in joint ventures or U.S. companies involved in film production. An exception to this trend is a movie production and distribution company set up earlier this year with 20 million yen ($146,000) by Suntory Ltd, which wants to create high-grade Japanese films. A few directors such as Kohei Oguri, who won the silver prize at the Cannes Film Festival this year, are making quality films with their own money from commercial projects or funding from a few large ``enlightened'' corporations such as Sony and Seibu, according to Japanese film expert Donald Richie. And Shochiku Co., Ltd., one of Japan's major studios, has decided to back Kurosawa's next film, ``Rhapsody in August,'' his first picture with Japanese financing in two decades. The movie is projected to cost about $10 million, considered too costly and risky by most Japanese studios. Kurosawa has criticized a lack of freedom of speech in Japan, suggesting self-censorship among filmmakers. ``Japan is supposed to be a place where there is freedom of speech but if you try to deal with certain problems, you will not get the money,'' he says. Filmmaker Noriko Sekiguchi got most of the funding for ``Senso Daughters,'' a new documentary about terror and starvation in Japanese-occupied Papua New Guinea during World War II, from the Australian government. ``When the film was shown in France, Fiji and Australia, Japanese diplomats told me it was interesting but that it should only be shown in Japan to the Japanese. They told me I shouldn't show the dirty side of Japan to others,'' Sekiguchi said. ``It's very difficult to really be open and speak your mind in Japan. We have lots of movie technology, but the ideas and philosophies behind good films are lacking.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-AP Arts: Japan-Movies
Kurosawa Gets Japanese Funding After 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: After 20 years, Japan is rediscovering a native son -award-winning film director Akira Kurosawa. As he talks on the set of his next film, ``Rhapsody in August,'' it is hard to imagine that this smiling, soft-spoken man once slashed his wrists in despair over the box-office failure in Japan of one of his movies. ``I realize that Japanese audiences, compared to American audiences, do not accept the kind of movies I am making, but it is not because I am purposely making films for an American audience. It is because of the level of the audience in Japan,'' Kurosawa said. Kurosawa was accepted by Japanese studios and audiences from his first film in 1941 until 1970. But since then he has been traveling the world seeking funding for his film projects, despite winning countless international awards, including two Academy Awards. ``I think when I talk about the low level of Japanese audiences, what I really mean is that it is Japanese movie studios that head the list of those incapable of appreciating good cinema,'' he said in an interview. His Oscar-winning ``Dersu Uzala'' was funded and shot in the Soviet Union, ``Ran'' was made with French money and last year's ``Dreams'' was backed by friend Steven Spielberg. Then came Kurosawa's honorary Academy Award last March in Hollywood where he was lauded on stage by directors George Lucas and Spielberg for lifetime achievement. Soon afterward, money flowed from an investment group headed by Shochiku Co. Ltd., one of Japan's major studios, for his 29th movie. ``Rhapsody in August'' is about the effect on one family of the U.S. atom bomb attack on Nagasaki. So at age 80, Kurosawa has leaped into his next project instead of spending his usual 5-year interlude combing the globe for financing. ``The Academy Award showed very clearly how much the world respects Kurosawa,'' said Toru Okuyama, co-chairman and chief executive officer of Shochiku. ``As a Japanese filmmaker, I was bothered by the fact that he has had to make his films with foreign capital,'' said Okuyama, the producer of ``Rhapsody in August.'' Although a cooling rainstorm rages outside the traditional farmhouse Kurosawa has built for his set in rural Chichibu, inside under hot lights Kurosawa's neon orange T-shirt is stained with sweat. Perspiration runs down his face. Wearing a Greek fisherman's cap and dark glasses, he won't say much about ``Rhapsody in August.'' He prefers that people see and experience it themselves. But what most appealed to him about the novel on which he based his screenplay was a heartwarming exchange between an old woman and her four grandchildren. Kurosawa has added a Japanese-American character who comes to Japan to meet his relatives. The part is played by Richard Gere. Although he tackled nuclear war in the 1955 ``I Live in Fear'' and in one of the vignettes in ``Dreams,'' Kurosawa says he wanted to talk about the atom bomb again on a human level. ``There are so many ways in which we should be closer to Americans and the issue of the atom bomb and nuclear war is one of them. After all, we are all human beings,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Old Soldiers Never Die, They Just Go to Cable
DOC.TEXT: You wouldn't consider the Discovery Channel or the Arts & Entertainment Network havens for shows about Things That Go Boom. Two of the nation's biggest cable networks, they're places for the performing arts, documentaries, science, nature and all that good stuff, yes? Yes. But guess what? They're also a military buff's paradise, offering shows that draw a large, mostly male audience, series that one Discovery official says have been ``locomotives'' for his network's schedule. The video winds of war come in three categories: - Grand old TV series about World War II, like ``Crusade in Europe,'' or NBC's classic ``Victory at Sea.'' The latter, with its memorable score by Richard Rodgers, was shown on A&E in 1988, and will return next year. A Rodgers score also is on ``Winston Churchill - The Valiant Years,'' a 26-part ABC series of the early '60s in which Richard Burton was the voice of Britain's wartime leader. It started its second A&E run this month. - Vietnam, specifically ``Vietnam - The Ten Thousand Day War,'' now on its second Discovery run, and A&E's ``The Vietnam War With Walter Cronkite,'' which starts repeats Nov. 14 as part of the network's ``Our Century Series.'' The Cronkite series, featuring CBS' Vietnam reports and footage, was made in 1985 for the CBS-Fox Video programs sold in stores and by mail. - Military things in general, typified by three series now on Discovery: ``Wings,'' largely about military aircraft, ``Firepower,'' about weaponry new and old, and ``Carriers,'' about the history of aircraft carriers. The last two are spin-offs of ``Wings,'' begun last year. Next fall, ``Choppers,'' a 13-part history of helicopters, will join the ranks, says Chuck Gingold, Discovery's senior vice president for programs. Why so much history, particularly military history, on cable? Cost, says former NBC News president Reuven Frank - whose own historical work will appear on cable Nov. 2 when A&E shows ``The Tunnel,'' his Emmy-winning 1962 NBC documentary about an escape route dug beneath the then-new Berlin Wall. ``It's cheaper to run an old one than make a new one,'' Frank says. ``Secondly, nobody in the United States is doing that kind of stuff anymore.'' Despite their supply of military history shows, neither Discovery nor A&E would qualify as The Armageddon Network. The war fare is only a portion of their daily offerings, which range from ``Pasquale's Kitchen Express'' on Discovery to A&E's cablecast next month of a video version of ``Silas Marner.'' But they ``do very well for us,'' says Brooke Johnson, A&E's programs vice president. ``For a while, they were inevitably among our highest-rated programs. ... They're still unquestionably very successful programs for us.'' ``They've been locomotives for the schedule,'' says Gingold, whose service is seen in 52.1 million homes. ``They've helped a lot. The ratings are excellent.'' And there's an odd thing he notes about the audience for ``Wings,'' a Discovery-repackaged series of documentaries from various sources. The viewers aren't just a bunch of old and middle-aged fuds who still can remember when fighter planes and even airliners had propellers. ``We're getting the young male demographics,'' Gingold says. ``It's one of our youngest-skewing shows.'' ``There's no question that there is a core group out there that loves this stuff and will find it wherever it is,'' says A&E's Johnson, whose network is seen in more than 47.5 million homes. Military programs, in fact, were very helpful in getting A&E known to viewers in its early years, she says, because the ``historical stuff tends to appeal more to men, who tend to be channel switchers.'' Will the shows' popularity diminish in time? ``I don't think so,'' says Johnson. ``They have been very popular for a number of years. ... I just don't see why they wouldn't continue to be popular through the millenium. That's our hope, anyway.'' That may happen. But Frank, although speaking partly in jest, is dour about the effect on future viewers. Networks no longer make historical series, he says, ``and all you're going to get is recycled stuff. So in the year 2511, the only history the kids will get is World War II. It'll end there.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... ROCK AND JAZZ MEET IN LONDON and L.A.: Cable's Showtime network tonight premieres a one-hour rock-and-jazz special, a two-city jam session hosted by jazzman Herbie Hancock, who doubles as a player. The special's London segment features the likes of Pete Townshend and Bob Geldof, while the L.A. crew features Van Morrison, backed by a band that includes jazz trumpeter Freddie Hubbard. The show is the brainchild of producer-director Ken Ehrlich, whose ``Soundstage,'' a pop-and-jazz PBS series in the '70s, was one of the best in the tricky art of televising music performances.

DOC.HEAD: With More Private Sector Jobs, D.C.'s Economy More Subject to Recession
DOC.TEXT: J.S. Oberai still has his architectural engineering job, and he's just bought a house in the suburbs. But he's worried about the local economy, so he's selling his Porsche. At least he's trying to. ``I've had this car on the market for four months now,'' said Oberai, who's asking nearly $11,000 for his 1984 model. ``It's becoming rather difficult to sell right now - it seems people are holding onto their money.'' In the regions that are slipping toward recession, worrying about selling a luxury car seems more whimsical than serious. But in the Washington area, one of the wealthiest in America, it is a sign of economic softness. The capital region has long been regarded as recession-proof, largely because the biggest employer, the federal government, isn't subject to the ups and downs that beset private companies. Unlike auto workers, the area's 350,000 federal workers don't have to worry about getting laid off in bad economic times. But the federal government's role in local employment is shrinking. Less than 10 years ago, almost 26 percent of area workers collected a federal paycheck; today, fewer than one in five do. The makeup began to change during the economically robust 1980s, when a number of private companies moved into the area or expanded their operations here capitalize on a glut in government contracts. ``Washington is not as recession-proof as it used to be because the mix of jobs has changed quite a bit,'' said Paul Getman, an analyst at Regional Financial Associates, a Chester, Pa. firm that monitors economic trends in different areas of the country. ``It used to be only a government town, but now you've had a boom in the construction, service and retail industries, all of which are suceptible to a downturn.'' There's plenty of evidence of problems: - Several prominent local developers declared bankruptcy over the summer, and others are on the edge of insolvency. - Garfinkel's, a venerable department store chain, went belly-up over the summer. Ditto a chain of drug stores and the National Bank of Washington, the city's second-largest. - Law firms are out recruiting bankruptcy specialists to fill sudden gaps in their firms' talent roster. - Housing sales in the region fell 14 percent earlier this year from the comparable period in 1989. Condominium sales slumped 24 percent. ``The economy clearly has slowed down, and the question of where it bottoms out is what we don't know,'' said William Harris, president-elect of the Greater Washington Board of Trade, the region's largest business group. To put things in perspective, the area still has the nation's highest median household income: $38,500. And while the national unemployment rate climbed last month to 5.4 percent, the jobless rate here has been stuck for several months at 3.2 percent. In the 1980s, development in the area took off at a breathtakng pace, fueled by retailers and builders seeking to take advantage of the steady influx of new residents. But growth eventually outstripped demand, and the first signs of trouble came early last year when developers revealed they couldn't fill their sparkling new office buildings. ``We've got an overbuilt office space market, and that filters down to residential housing, and retailers too,'' Harris said. ``What you're looking at is three or four years of glut'' that translates into about 45 million square feet of vacant office space. Retail sales also have slowed and job growth is off. Local governments are feeling the pinch, and budget squeezes mean fewer new jobs. While federal spending in the area has slowed since the 1987 - the last year of a seven-year, 170-percent spending boom - the concentration of high-technology, research and development companies located around Washington may cushion the region from the effects of a further economic downturn. ``You're going to get the same kind of recession in Washington that we are expecting elsewhere in the country, but it will come a little later and be a little milder,'' Getman said. ``That's due to the government buffer.''

DOC.HEAD: `Miami Vice' Was Nice, but `Wiseguy' Is Better
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Prime-time television has discovered another personality to this steamy city with a seedy side. It's no longer the pastels, art deco and flamingos that ``Miami Vice'' portrayed in an innovative way. It's ``la causa,'' Cuban coffee and a multi-cultural city that CBS's new version of ``Wiseguy'' hopes to bring to audiences on Nov. 17. It's the flip side of Miami, say the show's promoters. ``There's more of Miami to be seen. They (`Miami Vice') showed a large part of it, and beautifully, I miht add,'' said ``Wiseguy'' producer Alex Beaton. ``But that isn't all there is to Miami. We are showing another side of Miami because we have a great emphasis on the Cuban community, which is pretty important.'' Many of the show's stars are Cuban-Americans, and an entire episode was cast with Miami talent. Also, the show is negotiating with CBS to simulcast in Spanish, which would be a first for prime-time network television, Beaton said. Six episodes were shot in Miami and the production will shoot seven more episodes in Vancouver, British Columbia, home for the show's producer, Stephen Cannell Productions. The new episodes have some sharp differences with the original top-rated show, producers say. ``I'm not sure `Wiseguy' is an applicable name anymore. `Wiseguy' is a Mafia term,'' Beaton said. ``We're not dealing with the Mafia here. We don't intend to. It's a new direction ... a new look.'' The Mafia motif is gutted for a cocaine cartel and free-Cuba theme. Instead of Ken Wahl, the show's star is Steve Bauer, who was born in Cuba but raised in Miami. ``It feels great to come home this way. I couldn't imagine a more ideal situation really because of my family and growing up here,'' said Bauer, whose family still lives in Miami. ``They asked me to do the show and then they wrote (the role) as a Cuban-American. ... It was tailor-made.'' Bauer will play Michael Santana, an assistant U.S. attorney fired from his job and disbarred. Santana also has a fondness for rum and lives on his houseboat on the Miami River. Ken Wahl is not returning to the series. His old character, Vinnie Terranova, will make several calls to Santana prior to Terranova's disappearance. McPike (Jonathan Banks), the no-nonsense point man, will return. The story will unfold with Santana infiltrating an air cargo company owned by a good friend of his father, Rafael Santana, played by Manolo Villaverde. The younger Santana then discovers ``irregularities'' in the company, and the drug smuggling scenario begins to unfold. Bauer said his character believes in honor, justice and family, but he's been knocked down in life. ``He's a student in life, but he's got his principles and he's out there trying to do good,'' Bauer said in a recent interview. ``La causa,'' or ``the cause'' to free Cuba from Fidel Castro's grip, will be a secondary story line with the elder Santana being a Bay of Pigs veteran who takes potshots at the Cuban leader. ``I'm going to get a piece of Castro,'' Villaverde said. ``It's like a little revenge.'' Even though it's fiction, there are some streaks of reality in the show. For example, Bauer's real father, Esteban Echevarria, 59, is a pilot who flew 14 missions for the CIA in 1961, including three during the failed Bay of Pigs assault. The plight of the Haitians will be mentioned during an episode in which a boat filled with citizens of the impoverished nation washes ashore at Key Biscayne. Both the writers and actors are painstakingly trying to erase any stereotypes. ``Of course we are dealing with the problems, but there's a different way of showing the problems and solving the problems,'' said Villaverde, who graduated from the University of Havana in Cuba. ``If the writer knows what to project to the audience, than we are all right. Some of the writers are doing excellent.'' The quest to eradicate stereotypes has even reached Emmy-award winning Villaverde's underwear. ``I don't think they wear those 100 percent nylon underwear,'' said Villaverde, referring to a director's instruction that he wear nylon undershirts. ``I only wear cotton. So I said, `No, not for me. I'd rather change into cotton.' '
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, Oct. 24

DOC.HEAD: Blues in the Garden of Eden
DOC.TEXT: As far as John Lee Hooker is concerned, the blues wasn't born in the Mississippi Delta. He dates blues back farther than that - to the Garden of Eden. ``When the world was born, the blues was born,'' he says simply. ``There wasn't no problem 'til God put man and woman together. Then started love and heartache. It turned into blues.'' The 73-year-old singer, guitarist and songwriter had a hit with his first record, ``Boogie Chillen,'' in 1948. Since then, he's been up and he's been down, opened for the Rolling Stones on one tour, paid a lot of dues. His latest record, ``The Healer,'' has brought him more attention than any record he's ever had. He was recently honored at a concert in Madison Square Garden, and talked about the tribute a few days before. ``I'm glad to be here and alive,'' he said. ``I'm just proud and I'm overjoyed that the people are doing this for me. It's a long time coming but it got here. ``I paid so many dues. I've laid the path for so many other musicians to follow my footsteps. I'm proud of that.'' The concert, part of a 10-day Benson & Hedges Blues Festival, was a benefit for the 12-year-old Delta Blues Museum in Hooker's birthplace, Clarksdale, Miss. A duet by Hooker and Bonnie Raitt, ``I'm in the Mood,'' won a Grammy Award this year. A single now is out, ``Baby Lee,'' by Hooker and Robert Cray. Raitt and Cray are on Hooker's ``The Healer.'' So are Carlos Santana, Charlie Musselwhite, Los Lobos, Canned Heat and George Thorogood. ``They wanted to do it because of the respect they had for me,'' Hooker says. ``They didn't need the money. It's brought more attention to me than any album ever.'' Hooker estimates that he has made between 65 and 70 albums, and wrote or co-wrote all the songs on ``The Healer.'' About the title: ``The blues is a healer. It's got a meaning to it. You do things in your lifetime - at the time you did it you really wanted to do it. In the end sometimes you see it wasn't good for you and you say, `It served me right to suffer.' People hear that and say, `Oh, that's a true lyric,' and feel better. ``I write songs people can relate to, young or old.'' He recites his ``Think Twice Before You Go,'' a blues about getting mad, storming out, then wanting to come back but it's too late. ``People think you got to be poor and half starving to sing the blues. Rich people can sing the blues. I ain't poor and broke. I sit and sing the blues. I'm a human being. I like women. I've been brokenhearted. ``You can have a room full of money, if you're sad and lonely, that money is no good. You spend and spend and spend and it don't take away the loneliness. You love a woman and you go out there and you party and drink and come back home by yourself; you're lonely with a hangover. The woman is still gone. You got the blues. ``I know it because I experienced it myself.'' Appreciation of blues music never dies, Hooker says. ``It may reach a certain level, then it stops. It is in a big rise now. Rock 'n' roll boomed way up and boomed down.'' Hooker's stepfather taught him the guitar style he still uses. ``Nobody else plays this style,'' he says, adding that some try. ``I don't use a lot of fancy chords, just a solid driving, moving, soulful beat. You hear the sound, it gets right to you. ``I never change. I keep the musicians around me doing something different. You got to move with the times. But what they do fits into what I'm doing.'' Hooker lives in Vallejo, Calif., and tours two to four months a year. ``I love to go in small nightclubs, dirt on the floor or peanuts, people drinking at the bar, not dressed up. They're shocked, thinking I shouldn't be in the funky little place with them. They're the ones put me where I am. Rich men don't buy records. They ain't got the time. Poor people is the ones that support you. They work, buy your records, come out and see you when you got a concert.'' He has had ideas for songs while performing. ``You don't say it right then. Later on, you think about it. ``You dream some of your best songs. If you don't put it down on tape, it is gone from you.'' He can reach the button that starts his tape rolling without getting out of bed. ``If I never made another album, people won't forget me,'' Hooker says. ``Long after I'm gone, I'll still be here - my songs, my blues, in the minds of people.''

DOC.HEAD: Latest Wall Street Woe: Dwindling Dividends
DOC.TEXT: The nation's second largest banking empire, and the third biggest computer company. A major insurance conglomerate, and an airline with routes in 36 states. So goes the ``honor roll'' of publicly held businesses that have slashed or eliminated dividends in the past few weeks amid deepening recession fears on Wall Street. Chase Manhattan, Unisys, Travelers Corp. and USAir Group are by no means isolated cases. Through the first nine months of 1990, corporations announced 278 dividend omissions or reductions, according to Standard & Poor's Corp. It is shaping up as the biggest crop of adverse dividend actions since 1982, S&P says. On the other side of the coin, dividend increases are setting their slowest pace since 1971. ``These statistics will likely get worse before they get better, especially if a full-fledged recession develops,'' says Richard Evans, research director at Dow Theory Forecasts, an investment advisory firm in Hammond, Ind. All this has had a manifest impact in the stock market, which has lately traded at its lowest levels since the spring of 1989. Dividend cuts and suspensions are distinctly unpopular in the world of big-time money management. But unsettling as these developments may be, some analysts say investors should not necessarily take them as cause for despair about the future course of stock prices. In fact, maintains Mark Stumpp at the investment firm of PDI Strategies, it may even be a sign that stocks are due to take a turn for the better in the not-so-remote future. To reach that conclusion, Stumpp examined how stock prices performed since 1960 after years of varying degrees of dividend growth. The peak dividend years, averaging payout growth of 13 percent, were followed in the ensuing six-month periods by returns on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index averaging a paltry 1.8 percent. Within the three-decade sample, Stumpp found, as the dividend-growth rates diminished, the stock market's performance over the following six months steadily improved. At the other extreme, after years in which dividends eked out a meager 0.3 percent increase, stocks chalked up an average gain of 10.1 percent. ``Abandoning stocks because dividend growth is low has a certain intuitive appeal, but it's a poor investment strategy,'' Stumpp concluded. Analysts say the reasons for this seeming anomaly aren't hard to discern. For one thing, they say, corporate directors tend to resist making dividend changes, either up or down, until the underlying forces that mandate them are clearly established. If they act hastily, they risk hurting their credibility and their companies' image of stability among investors and the other constituencies, including employees and customers, with which they must deal. So by the time a dividend is either raised or lowered, the circumstances warranting the action tend to be well known among stock traders. At any given time, furthermore, those traders are usually preoccupied not with the present, but with trying to see as far into the future as they can, always bearing in mind the business cycle. ``Periods of high dividend growth tend to be followed by periods of slower growth,'' said Stumpp. ``The investment implication is that skyrocketing dividends signal that it's time to worry because growth is likely to slow in the future. ``Our interpretation? Last year was the time to have been worried about dividends.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon Oct 22

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Looks Past Recession, To Recovery
DOC.TEXT: Don't worry about whether a recession has begun in the U.S. economy. Get busy figuring out how, where and when it's going to end. That's the watchword right now among traders seeking an edge on rivals in the perennial guess-the-future competition that goes on in the stock market. With the drop of better than 20 percent that took place in stock prices from midsummer through early this month, these investors reckon that a business slump is a foregone conclusion. Whether it eventually qualifies as a recession - defined as two consecutives quarters of declines in the inflation-adjusted gross national product - is, for them at least, a question of academic interest. But the prospective starting point and timing of an economic recovery is another matter, since they stand to help determine when stocks might bottom out. ``The economy is facing a mild recession, not a collapse,'' asserts Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. ``Now is the time for portfolio managers to plan for economic recovery next year. If our forecast of lower inflation in 1991 is correct, then the bond market is poised for a major rally. ``That could create a tide that will lift all of Wall Street's boats. Remember, the name of the game is to buy low, and sell high.'' Or as Rao Chalasani, analyst at Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., puts it: ``We believe the deceleration in downward momentum of the stock market is visible. We expect the economy to be on its way up starting in the second quarter of next year.'' The big hazard now confronting the markets, many observers believe, is the chance that recovery might begin from a much lower, and later, starting point than is now generally foreseen. ``Though our numbers say mild recession, we remain wary,'' said Maureen Allyn, chief economist at the money management firm of Scudder, Stevens & Clark. ``Too much leverage has strained the financial system. The debt overhang is outside the range of past experience, so history is no guide to the troubles it might cause. ``We've little doubt that the dynamics of dealing with debt will be intimately connected with what happens next in the economy.'' Visions of recovery stirred in the stock market during the past week, helping the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials to mount a 122.77-point rally to 2,520.79. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 5.98 to 170.40; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 9.81 to 337.37, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was off .26 at 293.71. Volume on the Big Board averaged 180.28 million shares a day, up from 156.19 million the week before. What worries some analysts more than the recent woes of stocks and bonds is the ailing market for real estate. ``Falling real estate prices are driving bank balance sheets into preilous territory around the globe,'' says Robert Barbera at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. But before too much more time has passed, Barbera argues, problems in real estate and banking are likely to prompt a shift in the credit policy of the Federal Reserve toward easier credit. ``Major declines for U.S. short term interest rates will follow,'' he argues, ``and this fall will halt and then reverse the slide for asset prices.'' His conclusion: ``Recession, yes. Depression, no.''

DOC.TEXT: Surging oil prices drove imports to a new record in August and helped propel the U.S. merchandise trade deficit to its highest level in seven months, the government reported. In its first report on America's trade gap since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and disrupted international oil markets, the Commerce Department said Thursday imports rose 1.8 percent, to $42.0 billion, while exports gained 1.6 percent, to $32.6 billion. The difference meant a $ WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's 40 million Social Security recipients will receive their biggest benefit boost in 8{ years next January, a 5.4 percent increase that will give an average retiree an extra $31 a month. The annual cost-of-living increase, announced by the government Thursday, will mean that the typical benefit check will climb to $602 per month next year from $571 this year. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - A federal judge lowered Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bail to $300,000 Thursday, ruling that $5 million bail set by a state judge was unreasonably high for the former savings and loan chief. U.S. District Judge John G. Davies said Thursday Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner arbitrarily set Keating's bail. The restructuring, proposed by two Trump subsidiaries, Trump Taj Mahal Funding Inc. and Trump Taj Mahal Associated LP, would give bondholders a nearly 20 percent equity stake in the Atlantic City casino in return for changes in the terms of its $675 million in junk bonds. --- NEW YORK (AP) - AT&T said its third-quarter profit rose almost 2 percent despite the sluggish economy, but earnings continued to be dragged down by processing costs for the phone company's highly popular new credit card. For the three months ended Sept. 30, AT&T said Thursday it earned $712 million, or 65 cents a share, compared with $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Per-share earnings remained stable due to a higher number of outstanding shares in the most-recent quarter. Revenue advanced about 5 percent to $9.36 billion from $8.9 billion in the year-ago quarter. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Losses at R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. more than tripled in the company's 1990 fiscal year, a source familiar with the national retailer said. The Reston, Va.-based company, known as Freddie Mac, said Thursday it lost $81 million on apartment loans and $43 million on single-family mortgages. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The House has voted to curtail trade with China for repressing its pro-democracy movement but - anticipating a presidential veto - also approved a backup option that only threatens a future cutback. However, President Bush, a former U.S. diplomat in China, was expected to veto both, and supporters of the two measures acknowledged they lacked the votes to override vetos. ---

Stocks were higher Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 64.85 to 2,452.72, for its biggest single-day gain since it jumped 78.71 on Aug. 27. The dollar closed weaker.
