DOC.HEAD: Japanese Makers Announce New Lighter Laptop Computers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Japanese companies are promising a new generation of laptop computers made smaller and lighter by new power-saving circuits and plug-in memory cards that replace floppy disks. ``Even though laptop computers were called portable in the past, they really were a burden for people who had to carry them around all day,'' said Isao Hirano, a spokesman for Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer maker. ``We've changed that now.'' Fujitsu on Thursday introduced a thin new laptop-size personal computer, the FM R-CARD, which uses a full-size keyboard but weighs only 2.2 pounds - less than half the weight of many other laptops. It uses power-saving technology developed by Poqet Computer, a U.S. company that sells a miniature 1.1-pound computer in the United States. Fujitsu owns 58 percent of Poqet and manufactures its computer, which is about half the size of a normal laptop. Such technology, which cuts electricity to circuits that are not being used, is important for portable computers because it extends battery life and allows the use of smaller, lighter batteries. Instead of the heavy battery packs used by most portable computers, which must be recharged every few hours, Fujitsu's FM R-CARD runs for eight hours on two regular alkaline penlight batteries. The FM R-CARD, going on sale in Japan in January for 238,000 yen, or about $1,900, uses a unique Fujitsu computing standard and is not directly compatible with computers made by International Business Machines Corp. Officials said they don't plan to market the laptop overseas, but wouldn't be surprised if Poqet introduces a similar model that is IBM-compatible. Earlier this week, Japan's NEC Corp. announced a diary-size computer, the PC-98 HA, which weighs 2.4 pounds. Because of its small keyboard, NEC officials said they expect it will be used mostly for data retrieval, scheduling and light word-processing. The NEC model, which also is not IBM-compatible, goes on sale in Japan next week at 198,000 yen, or about $1,585. No plans have been made for overseas marketing, officials said. Like the Fujitsu, the NEC model uses plug-in memory cards instead of floppy disks. The cards, which look like thick credit cards, contain an array of memory chips and can be used to store both programs and data, like floppy disks. But they are smaller, use much less electricity and are 100 times faster, said Yoshihiro Satoh, general manager of Fujitsu's personal computer systems engineering division. In addition, computers using them don't need a floppy disc drive, saving weight. The cards are expected to begin appearing on many other portable computers following an agreement last spring between U.S. and Japanese industry groups that established uniform standards for them. Spreadsheet and word-processing programs already are available on memory cards, and Japanese software makers plan to produce magazine-like cards containing ``lifestyle'' data such as restaurant listings and tourist guides. But one obstacle will be price, with program cards costing a minimum of about 10,000 yen, or $80 dollars, to produce, Fujitsu officials said. By contrast, floppy disks cost less than a dollar to make. ``It will take a while, but memory cards will catch on,'' said Katsushi Shiga, an analyst for Dataquest Japan, the Japanese branch of a U.S. computer industry research company. ``Experienced computer users will be slower to adapt because they tend to feel uneasy without floppy disks, but new users are quickly accepting them.'' Also this week, Intel Corp. of the United States announced in Japan a new powerful microprocessor, the 386 SL, that will allow laptop makers to increase performance while curbing electrical consumption. Like the Fujitsu laptop, it monitors the computer's circuits and shuts off those not being used.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Outlines Debt Restructuring Proposals, Warns Bankruptcy Filing Possible
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump has unveiled a new debt restructuring proposal for bondholders of his Taj Mahal casino - and warned them that if they turn the plan down, everyone could end up in bankruptcy court. But if the developer meant to frighten bondholders Thursday with the specter of a Chapter 11 filing, it didn't work. A representative of the investors said bankruptcy court would be preferable to Trump's plan. The restructuring, proposed by two Trump subsidiaries, Trump Taj Mahal Funding Inc. and Trump Taj Mahal Associated LP, would give bondholders a nearly 20 percent equity stake in the Atlantic City casino in return for changes in the terms of its $675 million in junk bonds. The plan, outlined in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, calls for the interest rate on the bonds to be lowered to 9 percent from their current 14 percent and for a Nov. 15 interest payment on the casino's $675 million in junk bonds to be met by issuing additional bonds. Some future interest payments would also be made with new bonds, and the maturities of some issues would be extended under the plan. In the filing, Trump said the restructuring proposals ``are (the) only alternative to bankruptcy.'' ``The company and partnership believe that the terms of the amendments (to the bond terms) are more favorable'' than the treatment bondholders would receive in bankruptcy court, Trump said in the filing. But Wilbur Ross, a bondholder representative, wasn't impressed by Trump's statement. Ross said Taj Mahal investors would get a better deal through a Chapter 11 filing than the 19.9 percent stake being offered by Trump. ``It doesn't make any sense for us to make hundreds of millions of dollars in economic concessions they want and let 80 percent go to the Trump Organization,'' said Ross, who represents 10 institutions that hold about one-third of the Taj Mahal bonds. Ross noted in a telephone interview that the investors hold the first mortgage on the casino, which would place them at the front of the line of creditors in a bankruptcy court reorganization. Ross, who is senior managing director of Rothschild Inc., declined to discuss how large an equity stake the bondholders were seeking from Trump and indicated that negotiations would continue. Stephen Bollenbach, chief financial officer for the Trump Organization, did not return a reporter's phone call seeking comment on Ross' statement. Both sides have already rejected restructuring proposals put forth by one another. In the SEC filing, Trump said bankruptcy court would have a negative impact on the Taj Mahal's image. The glitzy casino opened earlier this year amid much publicity and fanfare, but like other Atlantic City casinos, it has been struggling in an uncertain economy. Trump has been forced to negotiate with bondholders because his three casinos - which also include Trump Castle and Trump Plaza - have been unable to generate enough cash to pay all their bills. The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Trump also has been forced to restructure $100 million in bank loans to Trump Castle and the Taj Mahal. And earlier this year, the developer negotiated a $65 million bank bailout that was supposed to give him breathing room to repay his loans, which together are believed to total more than $3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: UAL, Coniston Make Peace
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp., having removed its largest shareholder as a hostile takeover threat, now faces another challenge: possibly bitter negotiations with its three major unions. The employees' failed seven-month effort to buy the parent of United Airlines has left behind resentment toward managers who rejected to last-minute buyout proposals that lacked firm financing commitments. To make matters worse for employees, they've apparently lost a key supporter. Consiton Partners, UAL's largest shareholder, Thursday agreed not to take part in any attempt to take over UAL for the next 2{ years. In exchange, the investment firm got two seats on the UAL board. ``Coniston, once an ally, is now part of the establishment,'' Stephen Dexter of Kemper Financial Services Inc., said referring to Coniston's support for the employee's buyout attempt. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL common stock, had threatened to oust UAL directors unless a union-led buyout was approved. The $4.4 billion buyout bid failed last week when the unions were not able to raise financing. In November 1989, Coniston bought 2.5 million shares of UAL stock for an average disclosed price of $161 a share. Faced with paper losses of $100 million, Coniston this spring was threatening a proxy fight with the UAL board. Chicago-based UAL also agreed Thursday to repurchases of up to 2 million shares of its stock to improve shareholder value. UAL stock, which peaked at $296 last year, closed Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange at $94.75, up $5. Earlier Thursday, the three major unions at United Airlines said they would band closer together so they can fight any company attempts to gain concessions. More than 80 leaders of unions representing pilots, flight attendants and mechanics met Wednesday in Chicago. ``It was generally determined that in light of (UAL Chairman Stephen) Wolf's record of aggressive concessionary bargaining tactics, labor at United must continue to mature (their) alliance,'' the union statement said. UAL spokesman Joe Hopkins said the company had no comment on the union statement. Some observers say the company needs concessions from the unions to meet its expansion goals. Unions say they are looking for major improvements in wages and benefits, and some think the potential exists for a major national labor dispute. All of United's 47,300 union employees, comprising about two-thirds of UAL's labor force, are working under extended contracts. No dates have been set for talks. But they're not expected to begin before November.

DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Chief Gets Out of Jail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: LaserPhoto LA1

After more than a month in jail, Charles H. Keating Jr. won a bail reduction and headed home to prepare his defense against the first criminal charges in one of the nation's biggest savings and loan failures. U.S. District Judge John G. Davies ruled Thursday that the $5 million bail set by a state judge for the 66-year-old former thrift operator was excessively high in the investment fraud case. Davies lowered bail to $300,000, and Keating's family posted it by pledging their houses as security. Keating was released Thursday night, smiling as he walked out of jail. Davies had heard an impassioned plea by Los Angeles lawyer John ``Jack'' Quinn, who has defended Keating against a slew of civil charges stemming from the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Reimbursing the thrift's federally insured deposits could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion. It would be the nation's costliest thrift bailout. Quinn said Keating had wrongly become ``the most vilified man since Richard Nixon,'' but would never skip bail after his family put up their homes as security. ``I'll tell you what would have an impact on Charlie Keating - the thought of his children and grandchildren losing the places they live,'' Quinn said. Keating was not in court. Several family members were. The savings and loan chief with powerful political connections came to symbolize the excesses of the thrift industry with his investments in risky real estate ventures and junk bonds. He controlled the Irvine-based Lincoln Savings through his American Continental Corp. in Phoenix, Ariz., drawing huge salaries and maintaining a lavish personal lifestyle. He contends he is being victimized by authorities who failed to prevent the nation's S&L debacle and now seek to make him a scapegoat. Shirley Lampel, a bondholder who claims she was cheated by Keating, said, ``He belongs in prison. I hope he'll be back there soon .... He's a con man.'' His lawyers say he is broke. They said that while jailed he could never defend himself adequately against the many cases stemming from Lincoln's collapse and American Continental's filing for bankruptcy protection. Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner refused to lower Keating's bail last month. He noted that the 42-count indictment against Keating carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison, giving Keating ample reason to flee prosecution. Davies disagreed, ruling Klausner arbitrarily set Keating's bail as much as 50 times higher than that of his three co-defendants. Those three, former top officials of Keating's companies, face identical charges and already have posted bail. ``The bottom line is there was a violation of Mr. Keating's Eighth Amendment rights'' against excessive bail, Davies said. The judge ordered Keating to surrender his passport, restrict travel to the Lower 48 states, report to Los Angeles County authorities by phone every week and give them a detailed itinerary of any planned trips. Keating attorney Jeffrey Powell said Keating would return to Paradise Valley, Ariz., to prepare his defense against charges that he defrauded investors who bought now-worthless American Continental junk bonds at Lincoln branches, Powell said. ``I'm extremely pleased,'' Powell said. ``But I think it's unfortunate it took us 33 days to get to this point.'' Deputy District Attorney Paul Turley said prosecutors would not appeal the bail reduction. The criminal case is separate from charges in civil suits that contend Keating looted Lincoln. The bail decision came as the Senate Ethics Committee investigated whether five senators who received campaign contributions from Keating improperly intervened with banking regulators on his behalf. The committee adjourned Thursday without announcing a decision on whether to intensify its investigation of three senators: Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Orders Fuel Rationing, Foreigners in Kuwait to Register
DOC.TEXT: Squeezed by the U.N. embargo that apparently cut off refinery materials, the government today announced it will ration gasoline beginning next week. It also ordered all foreigners hiding in occupied Kuwait to report to authorities or face unspecified punishment. The Oil Ministry ordered car owners to go to special centers set up by the ministry to obtiin ration coupons. The order was carried today by all Iraqi government newspapers. The order did not say how much gasoline would be alloted under the restrictions that go into effect Tuesday, but long lines seen forming at gas stations in Baghdad early today. The rationing order covers cars, buses and trucks, but not kerosene and liquefied gas, which is widely used for cooking and other domestic purposes. The directive comes one day after Iraq announced it would sell its oil at $21 a barrel, the market price before its invasion of Iraq and half the current rate on world markets. Sources in Baghdad, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the decision may have been taken because Iraq lacks imported materials used in refining oil as a result of the United Nations trade embargo imposed after the invasion. During its eight-year war with Iran that ended in 1988, the Iraqi government did not impose oil rationing. The order applied to Iraq's 18 provinces, but not to Kuwait, which Iraq invaded and annexed two months ago and now calls its 19th province. The Oil Ministry's order did not explain why Kuwait was not included in the rationing. Another report published in Iraqi newspapers Friday said all foreigners in Kuwait must register with local authorities before Nov. 5. Those who fail to do so ``will be responsible before the law, and their residency cards will be canceled,'' the report said. It gave no other details. Under Iraqi law, foreigners who are found without residency cards are punished with fines and imprisonment. The exceptions are citizens from Arab Cooperation Council nations - Egypt, Jordan and Yemen. The Iraqi military has seized Western men and scattered them throughout Iraq at strategic military sites to deter attack by the U.S.-led military forces in Saudi Arabia and nearby Gulf regions. About 400,000 foreigners are believed to remain in Kuwait, including about 2,000 Westerners said by the U.S. State Department to be in hiding from Iraqi soldiers. An estimated 1 million foreigners were in Kuwait before the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: United Way Charities Face Greater Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This item was included in PM-Washington in Brief on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Charities not connected with the United Way are getting a larger chunk of the contributions raised through campaigns at the workplace, a report says. The report was issued Thursday by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, which has campaigned for giving workers access to newer and smaller charities that are not usually part of United Way campaigns. The committee, representing more than 300 fund-raising organizations, was established in 1976 to monitor developments in philanthropy. Alternative organizations are getting 10.1 percent of the money raised in workplace campaigns, the report said. Ten years ago, it said, alternative groups got 3.5 percent of the total. Among the alternative organizations are some health agencies such as the Muscular Dystrophy Association; international agencies such as CARE and Oxfam America; arts funds; the United Negro College Fund; and agencies that raise money for social action causes and women's and environmental groups. All told, United Way campaigns are expected to raise $3.2 billion in contributions this year, two-thirds of it through payroll deductions and other employee contribution programs. Organizations not under the United Way umbrella are expected to raise $205 million from employee contribution programs.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell House Account Moves in Kraft General Foods' Ad Roster Shakeup
DOC.TEXT: If the coffee tastes a little better at Ogilvy & Mather these days, it may be because Maxwell House is back on the agency's menu of U.S. advertising assignments. Kraft General Foods said Thursday it has realigned assignments for its advertising agencies and said it will pay them more for advertising that works better. The biggest shift in ad assignments gives the domestic Maxwell House coffee account, estimated at more than $70 million a year in billings, back to Ogilvy which lost it 16 months ago. The changes were part of a series of new policies and practices that the huge food marketer said are designed to strengthen its ties to its ad agencies, enabling them to develop expertise in a brand and apply it around the world. Glenview, Ill.-based Kraft General Foods is one of the nation's biggest advertisers, spending an estimated $900 million a year to promote products that include Post cereals, Jell-O desserts, Oscar Mayer meats and Birds Eye vegetables. The company declined to say how much it spends on advertising. As a major advertiser, the moves being made by Kraft General Foods could influence relations between other companies and their ad agencies. Ogilvy, a New York-based subsidiary of the British marketing company WPP Group PLC, had created Maxwell House ads for more than 30 years but lost the U.S. account in the summer of 1989 to the agency D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. Eric Strobel, senior vice president-marketing for Kraft General Foods, said the switch back to Ogilvy did not reflect dissatisfaction with D'Arcy's work. He said Ogilvy had continued to handle Maxwell House in some other countries even after losing the U.S. account. ``This takes advantage of the worldwide capabilities of Ogilvy & Mather,'' Strobel said. D'Arcy continues as one of Kraft's major agencies on brands such as Entenmann's baked goods, Cool Whip topping and Crystal Light beverages. Officials of the two ad agencies declined to discuss their reactions to the moves. But Clayton Wilhite, president of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles USA, said the loss ``will have an impact on the agency'' that was being assessed. In a pair of other major account moves, Kraft said it was giving the Chicago-based Leo Burnett agency responsibility in the United States for Kraft Real Mayonnaise advertising while J. Walter Thompson of New York gets the Miracle Whip salad dressing account. The Kraft mayonnaise account had previously been handled by Young & Rubicam in New York while Foote Cone & Belding Communications in Chicago had Miracle Whip. The trade journal Advertising Age said Kraft General Foods spent about $51 million on the two accounts last year. In addition to the account switches, Strobel said the new policy calls for agencies to be paid 16 percent of ad billings for superior work, 14 percent for ads that meet agreed-upon goals and 13 percent for ads that fall short. For years, agencies have often paid ad agencies 15 percent of billings for their work. In recent months, however, a number of advertisers and agencies have adopted compensation systems that reward work for improved sales and penalize campaigns failing to produce desired results. Julian Clopet, president of Ogilvy & Mather-North America, applauded the new policies advanced by Kraft General Foods. ``It is treating another person like a partner,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Navistar President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Neil A. Springer will retire at the end of this month as president and chief operating officer of Navistar International Corp., the company says. ``After more than 30 years with Navistar, I have accomplished many of the objectives I set for myself and for the company,'' Springer said Thursday. Springer began his career with Navistar, formerly International Harvester, in 1960, progressing through a number of manufacturing positions in Fort Wayne, Ind., Springfield, Ohio and Bridgeport, Conn. He was named head of the truck group in 1979 and appointed to his present position in 1984. Navistar manufactures and markets diesel trucks and replacement parts in North America and distributes them in selected export marekets.

DOC.HEAD: Pascual Nominated to Head Mack Trucks
DOC.TEXT: An executive with 20 years in the heavy-truck business has been nominated to head Mack Trucks Inc., the troubled Allentown subsidiary of French automaker Renault SA. Elios Pascual, general-secretary of Renault Vehicules Industriels, was nominated by the Mack board's nomination and compensation committee to replace Ralph E. Reins, Mack announced. ``His knowledge and experience will be critical to our taking all necessary steps to return Mack to profitability while maintaining and increasing Mack's market share,'' Jean-Pierre Capron, RVI chief executive officer, said in a statement Thursday. Pascual, 49, is in charge of RVI's long-term strategic planning and administration. A career RVI employee, he has been a member of Mack's board of directors and its executive and finance committee since 1983. The Mack board will vote on Pascual's nomination later this month. He would assume office at the end of the month. Renault announced Oct. 1 it had acquired control of Mack after several years of holding a 44.5 percent stake. Its intervention allowed Mack to renegotiate $498 million in bank loans, averting possible bankruptcy. Mack has said it expects 1990 to be its second consecutive year with a loss of more than $180 million. The departing Reins will become president of the automotive group at United Technologies Corp. of Hartford, Conn., effective Oct. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Denny's Inc. to Move Headquarters to South Carolina
DOC.TEXT: Denny's Inc., the family restaurant chain, said it will move its headquarters to Spartanburg, S.C. to centralize its operations with those of its parent company, TW Services. Denny's also said Thursday it had appointed Bernard Scott, 57, as chief executive. Scott replaces Sam Maw, a TW Services executive who has operated the 315-restaurant chain since 1988. Thursday's announcement of the move surprised many of the 500 headquarters executives in Irvine, said Roger Shively, vice president in charge of human resources. It was not known how many jobs, if any, would be cut in the move, which will take two to three years. ``There are certain people who we have asked to make the move. We will consider requests from anybody else,'' Shively said. Denny's, which began as a doughnut shop in 1953, underwent a face lift in 1987 after it was bought by TW Services. Menus were updated, restaurants were renovated and the work force was slashed by about 25 percent. Since then, the chain's revenues and profits have grown. In the first six months of this year, Denny's reported earnings of $58.7 million, up nearly 20 percent from the $49 million in earnings for the same period in 1989. TW Services, a $3.5 billion conglomerate, also owns Canteen Inc., El Pollo Loco, Hardee's and Quincy's Steakhouse chains.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Parliament Gives Nod to New Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with quotes, reaction, tightens. No pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Parliament today gave preliminary approval to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform plan, after he accused his key rival of shirking responsibility for the transformation to a free-market system. The Supreme Soviet voted 356 to 12 in favor of the plan, with 26 abstentions, and began debating possible amendments. President Gorbachev said his plan, a compromise forged from a series of competing proposals, was ``the only rational course of action.'' He acknowledged that the huge Russian Federation wants faster, more radical reforms, but said its leaders, including Boris N. Yeltsin, are afraid of the social and economic disruptions they would cause. In a 50-minute speech, Gorbachev also dismissed concerns that the switch from a centrally planned system was a retreat from socialism. Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, has lambasted Gorbachev's program as a ``catastrophe'' that is ``doomed to fail'' within months after touching off inflation and unemployment. He said Russia, the largest and richest of the 15 Soviet republics, may proceed with its own 500-day plan as early as Nov. 1. Gorbachev said he shared many of Yeltsin's concerns about the country's worsening economy and his fears of inflation. But he noted the Russian parliament recently raised the wholesale prices of meat, and said this touched off a wave of inflation. ``Comrade Yeltsin's assertions are strange, to say the least,'' Gorbachev said. ``I'm under the impression that the Russian leadership is afraid of difficulties and wants to pass on responsibility for possible difficulties and consequences .... onto central organs of power.'' Gorbachev appealed to the Soviet people and lawmakers at all levels of government to approve his plan, stressing ``we cannot delay any longer.'' Leaders of the republics were invited to join the 542 national lawmakers in listening to Gorbachev's speech in the Supreme Soviet's beige marble hall, but Yeltsin was not present. The speech received only five seconds of lukewarm applause. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who drafted a conservative reform plan, told the legislature that implementing tough changes ``would not bring glory'' to those who carry out the orders. He called on opponents to ``discard political and other ambitions'' and warned, ``If changes turn into chaos, violence becomes very possible.'' Gorbachev's plan would transform the moribund Soviet economy in four stages. It sets no deadline for the switch from a centrally planned economy, but says other countries have achieved similar goals in 18 months to two years. The plan begins by cutting the budget deficit and the nation's money supply, increasing production of consumer goods, raising bank interest rates for savings and introducing land reform. In the second stage, prices on roughly 70 percent of all goods and services would be freed to respond to market forces and small private businesses would be encouraged. The third stage calls for a free market for housing, a modern banking system and entrepreneurship. The final stage would end government monopolies in many industries and allow the ruble to be freely traded against other world currencies. The plan would give the ethnically and geographically diverse republics more clout in running the economy. They would have the right to control most of the resources in their territory, override price increases approved by central authorities and decide whether to break up collective farms into private plots. All but two republics have declared some form of autonomy from the Kremlin. Russia, the biggest and richest of them, threatens to implement its own reform plan as early as Nov. 1, setting up a separate currency and customs system. Gorbachev tried to merge the radical 500-day plan already adopted by the huge Russian republic with several other proposals, including a far more conservative plan drafted by Ryzhkov. The Soviet people are unlikely to endure the inflation and unemployment expected to accompany any switch to a market economy unless it has confidence in the leader carrying out the reforms. Gorbachev, facing a breakdown of the economic system, realized this in late July when he set up a committee with Yeltsin to forge a compromise. But the two leaders quickly broke ranks, and their rift is widening. Even Tass, traditionally loyal to the Kremlin, jumped on Yeltsin's bandwagon. It said Thursday in an unsigned commentary that Yeltsin's plan ``is possibly the only form of surgery that can help the ailing Soviet economy recover.'' The government now sets prices on nearly all products and subsidizes many unprofitable factories. Under a market system, most prices would be decontrolled and unprofitable businesses would close, forcing workers to seek new jobs. ``Everything will depend on who implements this program,'' Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak said in an interview. Referring to Ryzhkov, he said: ``If it is done by the current government, nothing will come of it. It could be a catastrophe.''

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Takes Options on Tennessee, Alabama Property
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. U.S.A. has bought options on about 900 acres in Tennessee and Alabama for a plant to build engines, a company executive said. The sites under consideration would be used for a new plant that also would build major components for the Japanese carmaker that builds Sentras and light pickup trucks at its Smyrna, Tenn., plant., near Nashville. Nissan is looking at Decherd, Tenn., - about 60 miles south of Smyrna - and at Athens, Ala. - about 90 miles south of Smyrna. Nissan still is examining the sites and has not made a recommendation to the company's board, according to Gail Neuman, Nissan vice president and general counsel. Details of the options were disclosed Thursday. Nissan has said it would like to have components plant in the United States and that there is no room for such expansion at its Smyrna plant. The Smyrna plant is undergoing a nearly $500 million expansion that will add 1.7 million square feet and a third car line in 1992. Ms. Neuman said Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. may not decide before year's end on whether to go ahead with plans for a U.S. components plant. Site selection must be made by next June, when the options expire.

The stock market rose sharply today, extending Thursday's rally as oil prices and interest rates receded. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 36.39 to 2,489.11 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by nearly 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 585 up, 125 down and 266 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 34.57 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Oil prices, which have turned downward of late, took a big drop in today's activity. Crude oil futures for November delivery fell almost $3 a barrel, to the neighborhood of $34 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The resulting letup in inflationary worries helped push interest rates lower in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds, which move in the opposite direction from interest rates, rose about $10 for each $1,000 in face value. Analysts said that gave stock traders the encouragement they needed to keep following through on the rally that began Thursday. Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1 at 106]; General Electric, up 1 at 55{; Ford Motor, up \ at 30~, and American Express, up | at 19. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.11 to 169.24. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 2.71 at 294.55. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64.85 to 2,452.72, for its biggest single-day gain since it climbed 78.71 on Aug. 27. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 5 to 2 on the NYSE, with 1,118 up, 441 down and 418 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 204.12 million shares, against 161.26 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil Agrees To Phase Out Use Of Deadly Acid
DOC.TEXT: The Mobil Oil Corp. settled a city lawsuit against its refinery here by promising to get rid of deadly hydrogen fluoride and submit to outside safety inspections. Under the agreement, Mobil would be allowed to develop and use a derivative of hydrogen fluoride that would not form a toxic, acid cloud. The corporation also has seven years to phase out of hydrogen fluoride use. The agreement Thursday settles an action filed by the city alleging use of the lethal cloud-forming acid threatened thousands of residents. The case was set for trial Nov. 5. A trial would have ``shown the world how dangerous (hydrogen fluoride) is and how poorly managed the plant was operated,'' said Councilman Dan Walker. The lawsuit, filed early this year, stems from a November 1987 explosion and fire sparked when hydrogen fluoride overflowed into a tank and mixed with another chemical. The blast caused $17 million damage, injuring four workers and six bystanders. Hydrogen fluoride is used to manufacture high-octane gasolines and forms a heavy cloud when exposed to air. City officials feared a refinery accident or leak could send such a cloud over residential neighborhoods. Refinery Manager Joel Maness said he expected the settlement to end several years of acrimony between Torrance and Mobil. ``We feel strongly that we have a safe operation,'' Maness said. ``But I never mind having another set of eyes take a look at our operations and our procedures.'' An inspector will advise the plant on safety considerations. The independent reviewer will be chosen by joint agreement between Mobil and the city. The bill will be paid by the company, court documents said. The inspector will report to retired Superior Court Judge Harry V. Peetris, who will act as an arbitrator on future disputes over the phase-out program. Peetris also will be paid by Mobil.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Wheel Plant Closing in Windsor
DOC.TEXT: A Kelsey-Hayes Canada Ltd. steel wheel plant in Windsor, Ontario, will be closed by the end of the month, resulting in the loss of about 450 hourly and salaried jobs, the company says. The company on Thursday blamed the closing on ``grave operational problems and mounting losses due to significant overcapacity in the steel wheels manufacturing industry.'' The plant's equipment will be sold to the Romulus, Mich.-based parent company, Kelsey-Hayes Co., for $8.5 million. Kelsey-Hayes Canada will continue making automobile brake components in Woodstock and St. Catharines, Ontario.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 337.99 up 3.96 from the previous day's close.

The stock market advanced broadly today, extending Thursday's rally as oil prices and interest rates receded. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 64.85 on Thursday, climbed 27.73 to 2,480.45 by 11 a.m. today on Wall Street. DOC.HEAD: Conran Leaves Home Furnishing Empire He Founded
DOC.TEXT: Sir Terence Conran, the British design maverick who created the Conran and Habitat home furnishing stores, has left the retailing giant he founded. The company, Storehouse PLC, said Friday that Conran has resigned as a non-executive director to pursue other commitments. Conran, 59, relinquished his duties as chairman in May, after heading the group since its formation in 1986. He has bought from Storehouse the main London store bearing his name for $6.9 million and intends to open additional stores. He also is a director of RSCG Conran Design and of the publisher Conran Octopus, and has property and restaurant interests. In July, Conran sold a 4.9 percent stake in the company to investors, reducing his holding to 2.2 percent. Storehouse, whose profits have come under pressure from increased costs and heightened competition, has embarked on a program of widespread management restructuring and disposals. Storehouse Chairman Ian Davison told shareholders that he didn't expect six-month profits, to be released in November, to match those of a year ago. In the six months ended Sept. 16, 1989, the company earned 7.3 million pounds, or $14.3 million, on revenue of 535 million pounds, or $1.05 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Export Sales Boost Wheat, Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and soybean futures prices rose slightly in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting new export demand. Corn futures were narrowly mixed. The crop markets opened mostly lower but wheat quickly rallied following an Agriculture Department announcement that China bought about 450,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Government figures showing increased export demand for soybeans provided early support in the bean market but gains were limited by harvest pressure as dry conditions returned to the Midwest, analysts said. Harvesting of corn and soybeans was expected to resume at a brisk pace today following Thursday's stormy weather. Light showers were forecast for the region during the weekend. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.65{ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.27} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $1.23\ a bushel; and soybeans were 1} cents to 2{ cents higher with November at $6.12} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .55 cent higher with October at 79.40 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent lower to .45 cent higher with October at 86.90 cents a pound; hogs were .05 cent lower to .40 cent higher with October at 57.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent to 1.40 cents higher with February at 66.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures rose on Thursday; pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for light sweet crude was $35.12 per barrel at 12 p.m. Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Agrees to Keep P-I-E Rolling
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy court judge has agreed to allow Olympia Holding Corp. of Miami to use certain funds to keep its P-I-E International trucking company operating until the next court hearing Nov. 4. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge George L. Proctor ruled Thursday that Olympia could use $24.4 million in cash from accounts receivable to fund P-I-E's operations through Nov. 4. On Tuesday, Olympia filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors while it develops a reorganization plan, listing debts of $237 million and assets of $169 million. P-I-E is Olympia's only subsidiary. ``The action of the court today was a vote of confidence in P-I-E's management and employees in their ability to reorganize,'' said Olympia attorney Steve Busey. As part of the plan to reorganize, the parent of the Jacksonville-based motor carrier said up to one-fifth of its 7,500 workers would be laid off and about 50 of P-I-E's 230 terminals would be closed. P-I-E, which had revenues of $512 million last year, plans to reduce its annual sales volume to about $350 million by cutting out inefficient, unprofitable terminals. ``As the volume goes down, employment levels will have to be lowered. The layoffs will affect everyone from terminal managers down to janitors,'' said P-I-E President Gerard W. McIntyre.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Decides To Pull Out Philadelphia Hub
DOC.TEXT: Blaming fuel prices in part, Midway Airlines anounced today it will be closing down its hub operations in Philadelphia and concentrate on its Chicago hub. The cutback includes the sale of 11 gates at the Philadelphia airport to USAir for approximately $68 million. The deal includes routes to Toronto and Montreal as well as a cargo building, vehicle maintenance building and related operations space. The sale is subject to federal government approval. Midway will still serve Philadelphia, but with connector flights to Chicago, according to David R. Hinson, chairman and chief executive officer. ``The unprecedented increases in the cost of aviation fuel since August have added more than $10 million to the company's monthly operating costs,'' Hinson said. ``These additional costs have led to substantial operating losses.'' Midway president Thomas Schick said during a news conference in Philadelphia the decision was a difficult one. ``We would have preferred to stay in Philadelphia, but the economic reality forces us to leave,'' Schick said. Midway will retain two gates. The cutbacks will be accomplished in stages, Hinson said. The final cuts will occur next April. Schick said there will be layoffs from the staff of 810 who now work in Philadelphia. He did not say how many would lose their jobs and how many would be transferred. Midway moved into Philadelphia in November of 1989 with the purchase of gates and space from the ailing Eastern Airlines. Midway currently offers 61 flights daily to 17 destinations, accounting for one-sixth of the airline's operations. As Midway moves out of its Philadelphia hub, Hinson said 14 new destinations will be added to the Chicago flight schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Northwestern's Business School Tops in Magazine Survey
DOC.TEXT: Northwestern University's business school placed first for the second consecutive year in a new survey by Business Week magazine. In its Oct. 29 issue, the magazine said Northwestern's J.L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management in Evanston, Ill., received the highest rating from the 6,000 business school graduates and 322 corporate recruiters surveyed. Following Northwestern at the top of the list were the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, Harvard University, the University of Chicago and Stanford University. The graduates were asked to rate their schools on teaching, curriculum and placement, and the recruiters rated the graduates' skills. Recruiters in the survey ranked Northwestern graduates highest in interpersonal skills and marketing, and third in general management. Stanford graduates had the highest average starting salary of $79,135. Rounding out the Business Week Top 10 were the business schools at Dartmouth University, University of Michigan, Columbia University, Carnegie Mellon University and University of California at Los Angeles. They were followed by the business schools at Massachusettes Institute of Technology, followed by University of North Carolina, Duke University, University of Virginia and Indiana University. Filling out the top 20 in the Business Week rankings were Cornell University, New York University, University of Texas, University of California at Berkeley and University of Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Cash Management Bills Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department on Friday sold $12.5 billion in 69-day cash management bills at an average discount rate of 7.37 percent. The discount rate understates the actual return to investors: 7.58 percent, with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,858.70.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Trader Says News of Boesky's Plea Deal Seemed to Unnerve Milken
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 1-15 new with more testimony today; picks up 10th graf pvs, He said. . .
DOC.TEXT: A former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond salesman today described a climate of fear at the investment bank after client Ivan Boesky began cooperating with the government, but he didn't back a bribery charge against Michael Milken. Terren Peizer, testifying with immunity, said that as Milken learned the news of Boesky's November 1986 plea agreement for securities fraud from a financial news ticker, Drexel's top junk bond financier ``lost his train of thought and concentration and started going, `Uh, uh.' '' Boesky became Milken's chief accuser in a traumatic financial scandal that eventually brought both Drexel and Milken down. Government witnesses testifying Thursday offered vivid details of possible insider trading, bribery and influence-peddling between Drexel junk-bond division employees and their customers. But as in previous testimony during Milken's pre-sentencing hearing, no direct evidence was established linking Milken to a string of crimes alleged by the government. The second of three transactions presented at the hearing by prosecutors involves allegations of bribery and misappropration for personal gain of securities in the Drexel-financed buyout of Storer Communications Inc. Peizer also said Milken ordered him to turn over a blue ledger book containing a list of trades between Drexel and David Solomon of Solomon Asset Management, who had a close relationship with Milken and has been linked by the government to wrongdoing. The witness said he handed the book over to a Drexel executive, Lorraine Spurge, in a kitchenette at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., junk bond department after turning on a water faucet in case anyone was listening. ``Everyone was running faucets'' at Drexel after Boesky's plea deal, Peizer said. But like other witnesses, Peizer did not link Milken directly to a bribery scheme involving Storer stock as alleged by prosecutors. The hearing was called by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood to gain insight into Milken's character for sentencing. The government says Milken engaged in lawbreaking far beyond crimes to which he has pleaded guilty and therefore deserves a long prison term. Milken, 44, pleaded guilty in April to six felony counts related to illegal trading and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces up to 28 years imprisonment. Prosecutors charged that Milken established a partnership known as MacPherson Partners largely to reward customers who bought hard-to-sell Storer securities with company stock warrants sold below market value. Two government witnesses testified the stock warrants were offered to induce big investors to buy certain preferred securities in Storer. But neither could link Milken to any such activity. Benalder Bayse Jr., former manager of high-yield bond funds for First Investors Management Corp., offered a picture of corrupt behavior by other Drexel employees at the Beverly Hills division. He said a Drexel salesman, Roy Johnson, sought a guarantee he would funnel Drexel First Investors' business after steering him to the job. He said Johnson claimed he had spoken with Milken about negotiating his compensation at First Investors. ``He told me they wanted total control over the account if they were going to endorse me for the job,'' Bayse testified. Bayse admitted that Johnson offered him - and he bought - a personal interest in MacPherson after he committed about $10 million in the preferred securities for First Investors. But he said he wasn't bribed to invest in Storer for First Investors and bought the preferred securities because Milken assured him the Storer deal was sound. Bayse said Johnson told him that ``because I was a good customer'' he would receive other investment tips. He said Johnson told him one of his accounts ``was accumulating the equity'' of Republic Air but that ``you didn't hear that from me.'' Republic shortly thereafter received a takeover offer from Northwest Airlines. Thomas Connors, who headed Drexel's preferred stock group, testified that the Storer stock warrants were offered to some customers to induce participation. He said one customer, Richard Grassgreen, bought a personal investment in MacPherson after purchasing the warrants on behalf of Kinder-Care Inc. A lawyer for Grassgreen told Wood on Wednesday his client was being investigated by the government in connection with the trading. Grassgreen resigned Thursday as chairman of Enstar Group Inc. In its pre-sentencing memo, prosecutors said five Milken-controlled partnerships bought 82 percent of the Storer warrants and made $172 million. They charge Milken was guilty of fraud in the sale of the warrants, controlling the market for the securities and using them as gratuities for customers. The partnership was formed shortly after the $2.5 billion buyout of Storer by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Drexel provided nearly $1.5 billion in financing for the deal.

DOC.HEAD: PPG Earnings Up Slightly in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: PPG Industries said Friday its third-quarter profits rose 0.3 percent as the company's glass and coatings operations posted gains. Vincent A. Sarni, chairman and chief executive officer, said higher sales from acquisitions, foreign currency translation gains, modest improvements in North American auto production and increased European business contributed to sales and earnings gains in the glass and coatings divisions. For the three months ended Sept. 30, profit totaled $107.1 million, or $1 a share, compared with $106.7 million, or 97 cents a share, in the same period of 1989. The latest quarterly earnings included a charge of 4 cents a share related to the restructuring of PPG's ink business. The 1989 quarterly results included a gain of 13 cents a share from business divestitures and realignments. Sales increased 8 percent to $1.47 billion in the third quarter from $1.36 billion. Sarni said PPG remains optimistic that 1990 results will exceed those of 1989 despite recent international political developments and a sluggish second half. ``Improved operating efficiencies experienced by each of our major businesses are expected to contribute significantly to the company's 1990 earnings improvement,'' he said. Profits in the first nine months of the year increased nearly 3 percent to $373.4 million, or $3.47 a share, from $363.8 million, or $3.25 a share. Sales increased nearly 5 percent in the nine-month period to $4.52 billion from $4.31 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Management Rule No. 1: Control Your Fate
DOC.TEXT: It is generally considered a principle of good management in governmental and business affairs to maintain as many options as possible and in that way to protect yourself from others. It applies equally to the President of the United States and his fiscal policies, to the management of a corporation, and to the way an individual automobile driver handles himself on the highway. Stated another way, it means you should never get into a position that allows friend, competitor or enemy to seize the initiative from you and make decisions affecting your life, liberty or future. It isn't practiced well these days, and it isn't difficult to cite the examples. You may begin with the price of oil. Its fluctuations in the past week have affected the value of the dollar, the prices of stocks, the potential level of inflation, the balance of payments and the future of the economy. All those factors involve the futures of Americans from the President to the latest infant born, but the influences on them are largely from without. Americans have lost their options. They do not control their destiny. Neither do many corporations. The fate of Robert Campeau, a successful Canadian builder, is an example. He mortgaged everything in order to become the world's biggest merchant, the head of Allied and Federated stores. Then his creditors took it from him. Donald Trump can tell you what it's like. He sat on an imaginary throne of great wealth and believed it was real. But now his creditors are disgruntled, and some of them sound determined to reclaim throne, tiara and robes. Individuals did it, too. When times were good they made good incomes, and they traveled and bought nice cars, big houses and lots of adult toys. They spent, and then they borrowed more. Then the economy turned down. All this is a vast departure - governmental, corporate, personal - from the American ideals of half a century ago, when people worked to pay off the home mortgage, government balanced the budget and businesses watched their dimes. Traces of the old still may be found, but those who hold to those ideals do so quietly, as if they possessed a treasure they cared not to share. All in all, the old methods have disappeared, replaced by ``creative'' management. As a nation, the United States owes a vast bill to other nations because it consumed so much. Japan and Europe were eager to serve this American appetite, and in doing so they accumulated billions of American dollars. Those dollars didn't just sit over there. They helped finance productive enterprises that competed with the United States. Then some of the money was returned to America, to purchase American stocks and real estate. Japanese and other foreign investments helped shove securities prices to unprecedented highs, and Americans cheered. But then the foreigners began taking their money home again, a major factor in the big stock market collapse. In the 1960s, Americans were known as the greatest managers, and their methods were studied and copied. Good business schools were rare in Europe and Japan, and so their students came to America to learn how to do things. Americans also began sending their management authorities abroad, not necessarily because they wanted to teach foreigners but because they no longer wished to listen to their home-grown experts. Soon after, domestic production quality and efficiency seemed to go into a decline as it rose abroad, and American companies soon were being beaten on their own turf by imports. They had given away their options and delivered their fate into the hands of others, one of the most basic management errors anyone can make, but one that is being made over and over again.

DOC.HEAD: Midway Shutting Down Philadelphia Hub
DOC.TEXT: Midway Airlines announced Friday it would sell off its unprofitable hub operations at the Philadelphia International Airport and end 61 daily flights by April 30 as it faces even greater losses due to fuel prices. Midway will start dropping flights in January and shift passengers to other airlines as the flights are phased out. President Thomas Schick said at a news conference that Midway would sell 11 gates, a maintenance building, baggage, cargo and ticket facilities, and Canadian routes to Toronto and Montreal to USAir for approximately $68 million. Midway, whose main hub is at Chicago's Midway Airport, had obtained the Philadelphia assets - plus 16 DC9 planes and slots in Washington and New York - a year ago from Eastern Airlines for $205.6 million. The selloff, Schick said, would cost his airline about $30 million. David Hinson, Midway chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement that the sale was necessary to stabilize the airline's financial condition and return it to profitability. ``We must close this USAir transaction to obtain the cash resources we require,'' he said. Hinson said the losses, if left unchecked, would ``threaten the company's continuing viability.'' Said Schick: ``We felt it was prudent to make this move now to make sure we could survive the fuel crunch'' caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. The higher fuel prices are costing Midway $10 million more in monthly operating costs, which Schick said is not being replaced through higher fares. He said there will be some cuts from the 810-member work force in Philadelphia. Many will be offered jobs at other Midway locations. The sale is subject to federal approval. Effective Jan. 8, all non-stop service, involving 41 flights, will be discontinued between Philadelphia and the following cities: Albany, Buffalo and Rochester, N.Y.; Boston; Hartford, Conn.; Columbus, Ohio; Las Vegas; New Orleans; Providence, R.I.; and Montreal. Service on 20 daily flights from Philadelphia to Chicago, Toronto, and points in Florida will continue through April 30. Schick said Midway will continue service out of Philadelphia after April 30 by renting at least two gates. At the same time, Midway will accelerate development of its Chicago hub starting Jan. 8 with additional flights to 14 destinations. The airline will use aircraft redeployed from Philadelphia. Midway has offered service between Philadelphia and Chicago since 1981. It made Philadelphia a hub a year ago when Eastern moved out. Schick said Midway had high hopes for its Philadelphia hub and was looking forward to showing a profit in the last three months of 1990 until Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``The shock to the petroleum market more than doubled our fuel costs, and we decided we didn't want that problem to manage us,'' he told reporters in explaining why Midway, established 11 years ago, was going to concentrate its business from Chicago. ``We feel this move back to our core business is the right way to go, and will allow us to continue to grow in the future,'' he said. ``This is a hard business decision, and one we didn't reach easily. We would prefer to stay in Philadelphia but the economic reality forces us to leave,'' Schick said.

DOC.HEAD: GM, UAW Sign New 3-Year Contract
LaserPhoto DT3
DOC.TEXT: Executives of General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union signed a new three-year labor contract Friday guaranteeing the wages of about 300,000 U.S. workers. GM Chairman Robert Stempel and UAW President Owen Bieber signed the documents as more than three dozen members of both bargaining teams sat around the huge bargaining table in GM headquarters. Bieber is now expected to turn up the heat on Chrysler Corp. when bargaining with the No. 3 automaker intensifies next week. But he would talk only of the contract with GM. ``It's clearly a document I think speaks well for the workers and the company, all of us together, to see to it we have a good, successful operation here in the next three years and beyond,'' Bieber said. ``I think it's historic in many ways.'' Stempel said the contract would help GM become more competitive with Japanses automakers operating in the United States. The GM-UAW agreement was reached Sept. 17, two days after the 1987 contract expired. It was ratified in union voting late last month by a 4-to-1 margin. The contract includes three years of wage guarantees for workers laid off due to sales dips, no changes in cost-of-living or health care provisions, and a 3 percent increase in base wages in the first year along with 3 percent lump-sum payments in each of the next two years. The agreement raises the base wage for a GM assembler, the most common classification of worker, by 42 cents an hour to $14.44 before cost-of-living adjustments. The union used its contract with GM as a model for a three-year agreement reached Oct. 7 with Ford. That agreement is expected to be ratified when rank-and-file voting ends Sunday for Ford's 100,000 workers. Next up is Chrysler and its 50,000 workers, and the union intends to use the contracts reached with GM and Ford as the base for negotiations, even though Chrysler is in worse financial shape. The talks are expected to begin Monday or Tuesday at Chrysler headquarters in Highland Park.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Truck Drivers Call Off National Strike
DOC.TEXT: Independent truck drivers on Friday ended an 11-day strike that had forced factory shutdowns, disrupted fresh food distribution and cost the Spanish economy more than $500 million, according to official estimates. Luis Soldevilla, who represented the 8,000 striking drivers in negotiations with the government, announced the decision to end the strike after an eight-hour meeting with Transport Ministry officials. Government officials had agreed to negotiate with the truck drivers on Wednesday after striking drivers agreed to remove pickets from border areas and urban wholesale markets. Early reports indicated the agreement would establish a sliding scale on which hauling rates would increase with the price of fuel. The agreeement also would provide increased government benefits for the self-employed truck drivers, according to reports. The strike began Oct. 9 and forced automobile plants in Spain and France to shut down and restricted production at steel, paper and electrical appliance factories.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mixed as Harvest Advances
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed narrowly mixed Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as harvest-related selling offset buying linked to new export sales of wheat and soybeans. The Midwestern corn and soybean harvest accelerated Friday as dry weather returned to the region, analysts said. Fieldwork was expected to continue at a brisk pace although showers were expected to move into the region late in the weekend. Wheat futures drew light support from an Agriculture Department announcement that China bought about 450,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Government figures showing increased export demand for soybeans provided support in the bean market. At the close, wheat futures were unchanged to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.28{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent higher with December at $1.22{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 3 cents higher with November at $6.11 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: American Brands Reports 39 Percent Increase in Quarterly Income
DOC.TEXT: American Brands Inc. reported Friday that its net income rose 39 percent in the third quarter, due partly to increased cigarette sales and the sale of a Netherlands-based tobacco company. Net income for the consumer products holding company in the quarter ended Sept. 30 was $231 million or $1.16 per share, compared with $166 million or 86 cents per share last year. All per-share amounts reflect a two-for-one stock split effective Oct. 9. Third-quarter revenue rose 26 percent to $3.9 billion, from $3.1 billion last year. ``Our largest core business, tobacco, had another excellent quarter with record results and higher cigarette unit sales both internationally and domestically,'' said William J. Alley, the company's chairman and chief executive officer. Alley reported worldwide cigarette sales increased 6.8 percent over last year's third quarter, while the July sale of Theodorus Niemeyer, a Netherlands tobacco company, brought a net gain of $31 million or 16 cents per share. American Brands' distilled spirits business posted revenue gains of 32 percent to $236 million while operating income rose 12 percent to $28 million. American Brands also makes and markets hardware and home improvement products, office products and life insurance. For the first nine months, the company had net income of $585 million or $2.97 per share, up 27 percent from $459 million or $2.38 per share in the same period last year. Revenues rose 11 percent to a record $10 billion, from $9 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Cable Regulation Bill Dead, Backers Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to clarify compromise. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Senate backers of a bill to regulate cable TV prices said Friday the compromise measure was dead for the year after they failed to move it to a floor vote. The defeat marked the end of three weeks of private negotiations between Sens. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and Tim Wirth, D-Colo., to soften language in the bill that would have prevented cable programmers from making exclusive contracts with cable system operators. It also culminated a two-year effort to meld two dozen cable bills into a law that would address rising concerns about shoddy service and cable charges, which have risen 43 percent in the last three years. Cable fees were deregulated by Congress in 1987. Gore and Wirth had reached a compromise they hoped would make the bill palatable to the White House, which has threatened all along to veto the measure. But White House chief of staff John Sununu this week urged several Republican senators to place a ``hold'' on the bill to prevent its coming up for a floor vote, congressional and industry sources said. In addition, several amendments would have required hours of debate that couldn't be scheduled this late in the congressional session, said the sources, who requested anonymity. Gore, speaking on the chamber's floor Friday, said it had become ``painfully clear that the White House, with anti-consumer ideology, has successfully killed cable legislation for this Congress by urging a number of our Republican colleagues to put `holds' on the cable legislation.'' He predicted ``a new round of rate increases for cable television all over the United States.'' The cable industry was dead-set against the contract exclusivity provisions. The Wirth-Gore amendment would have allowed some exclusive contracts. Gore claimed that proponents of regulating cable charges would propose a stronger bill next year, when telephone companies, which failed in a massively financed lobbying effort this year to be allowed into the cable TV business, are expected to resume their campaign. The ``wireless cable'' and back yard and direct-broadcast satellite industries, championed by Gore, also are expected to seek bigger gains against their wired cable competitors next year. Wirth, whose district includes several major cable companies, had almost single-handedly stalled the bill three weeks ago. He complained that legislation that had started out as a modest attempt to restrain prices and improve service had been loaded down like a ``flatbed truck'' with business restrictions. The House and Senate bills aimed at requiring cable systems to provide a ``basic tier'' of local broadcast and public TV channels and at requiring the FCC to monitor rates for cable-owned programming, such as MTV.
Stock prices swept ahead today, extending the rally they began on Thursday. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 48.52 at 2,501.24.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Can't Overcome Stalemate on Farm Payments
DOC.TEXT: European Community agriculture ministers failed Friday to break a deadlock over a plan to cut government payments to farmers, casting doubt on the outcome of key world trade negotiations. The ministers, struggling with the proposal for the third time in two weeks, gave up and asked their foreign ministers to try to settle the dispute on Monday in Luxembourg. ``It's a very sad day for the EC,'' said British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer, who supported the plan for a 30 percent cut in key farm subsidies. ``It's very sad that some countries have put their own nationalist views ahead of our own interests and those of the whole world,'' he said. The community's proposal was drawn up in attempts to end a bitter fight with the United States over farm supports in the Uruguay Round of world trade talks. The United States, backed by Australia, Argentina and others, wants the community to make deep cuts in its costly farm programs. They contend resolution of the farm dispute is key to a successful outcome of the trade talks. The four year negotiations, involving 100 industrialized and developing nations, are an ambitious effort to overhaul the world trading system and reduce protectionist barriers. But the community's inability to endorse a modest package of farm cuts throws a shadow over the talks, due to end in December in Brussels. ``It's not possible to have a (trade) agreement without an agriculture agreement,'' said Gummer. ``For many poor countries agriculture is all they've got.'' Italian Agriculture Minister Vito Saccemandi told reporters the ministers gave up after failing to get ``total solidarity'' for the proposal put forward by the European Commission, the community's executive body. Germany's farm minister, Ignaz Kiechle, hardened his opposition to the package and demanded compensatory measures to make up for income losses to farmers, officials said. ``If there is no change in the position of the commission, then there will also be no change in our position,'' Kiechle told reporters. The Germans ``clearly did not come for a solution,'' said Gummer. Ray MacSharry, the commission's top farm official, defended the proposal as ``reasonable and realistic'' and said it was ``politically and socially possible to implement.'' The proposal would snip farm subsidies on cereals, rice, sugar and livestock by 30 percent over a 10-year period, starting in 1986. A 10 percent cut was proposed in fruits, vegetables and tobacco. No specific reductions were outlined for the community's export subsidy program, used to help pricey European products find buyers on the world market. But there were hints the community was willing to discuss some cuts. Commission officials who drew up the original plan have so far been unwilling to tamper with the wording. Denmark, Britain and the Netherlands supported the proposal from the outset. Italy and Belgium were said to be leaning toward it at the end. If the foreign ministers failed to act next week, the issue could be added to the agenda of the leaders of the dozen nations at the European Community summit Oct. 27-28 in Rome. Because of the deadlock, the community was forced to miss last Monday's deadline for presenting final offers in the Uruguay Round talks. The community is the only major member of the negotiations which has not yet produced its proposal. In its latest offer, the United States asked trading partners to pare export subsidies by 90 percent and farm income supports by 75 percent over a 10-year period starting in 1991. It also called for converting non-tariff barriers to imported goods into tariffs - giving a numerical value to barriers that restrict imports of foreign goods - and then trimming the rates by an average of 75 percent, again over 10 years. In the Uruguay Round, negotiators are trying to lower barriers to trade in 15 areas, including not only agriculture, but also textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as investment. The talks are held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and an agreement for promoting freer world trade. Community members are: Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of New England Reports Third Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of New England Corp. reported a loss of $123.2 million or $1.78 a share in the third quarter, due largely to a $100 million provision for possible credit losses, company officials said Friday. The company blamed its losses on the slowdown of the New England economy, worsened by rising oil prices and Middle East uncertainties. BNEC also suffered a $48 million loss in operating earnings for the quarter, the company said. A $31 million gain, due partly to reduced pension obligations because of a smaller work force, helped offset the losses. ``It just portrays a picture of how difficult it is for a weak bank to function in an economic environment that is still deteriorating,'' said James Moynihan, a bank stocks specialist for Advest, a Hartford, Conn.-based brokerage firm. The company also presented an exchange offer Friday to the heads of committees representing holders of the company's $706 million in debt. The exchange, if agreed upon, would recapitalize the holding company, officials said. Despite the loss, BNEC has made strides in its strategic recovery program, company Chairman Lawrence K. Fish said in a statement. Non-performing loans decreased $93 million for the quarter to $2.136 billion on September 30, Fish said. Costs dropped from the $90 million a month operating level in January to $71 million a month at the end of September, he said. By September 30, the company's workforce had been reduced to 12,500 from over 17,500 in January. The holding company had planned to reduced its employees by 6,000 by the first quarter of 1991. ``I think they're probably two to three months behind schedule, but nevertheless they are making progress,'' Moynihan said. Bank of New England is a Boston-based bank holding company with assets of $23 billion. It has offices in Maine, Connecticut and Rhode Island.

DOC.HEAD: The Lower the Expectations, the Better Things Look
DOC.TEXT: If only President Bush had tried a little reverse psychology. The nation stumbled into a budget crisis after the president and congressional leaders peddled a plan for tax increases and spending cuts that few constituencies were willing to buy. The budgeteers might better have nursed their plan along with less fanfare, rather than promote such a bitter pill as a miracle cure for the widening federal deficit. The strategy is called lowering expectations and it worked wonders this past week on Wall Street, where the stock market rallied even while digesting big doses of bad news. Lowest of all expectations were those for the repair of the ill-fated budget compromise itself. Investors were prepared for any disappointment after watching the messy collapse of the original deal. The markets were likewise girded for disaster on the corporate and economic fronts. How else to explain a $4.25 rise in Digital Equipment Corp. stock to $51 on Thursday in response to a 83 percent drop in the computer company's quarterly earnings? Answer: The market was prepared for a loss. Any sign of profitability from Digital was cause for celebration. Among other less-than-calamitous results, Citicorp reported a 38 percent plunge in quarterly profits, but staved off a dividend cut. BankAmerica's profit rose 11 percent. Coca-Cola's earnings increased 9 percent. IBM earnings were up 27 percent. That's not to say there weren't some results that smarted even when viewed through rose-colored glasses. Losses for the fiscal year at Macy, the big retailer, were said to have tripled to more than $215 million. MCI, the communications company, suffered a $176 million third-quarter loss after taking a big charge to upgrade equipment. AMR, parent of American Airlines, said quarterly earnings sank 52 percent and predicted worse for the fourth quarter.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Inflation Bad, But Understandable
DOC.TEXT: Low expectations also cushioned the impact of the government's economic numbers. Inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was up 0.8 percent in September, which computes to a 9.5 percent annual rate. But the jump was mostly due to the runup in oil prices from the Persian Gulfcrisis. So-called ``core'' inflation - prices excluding food and energy - was 0.3 percent for the month, down from 0.5 percent in August. The pickup in inflation was good news to 40 million Social Security recipients, who will be getting the biggest boost in benefits in 8{ years. Based on the CPI report, the government announced a 5.4 percent rise in benefits beginning in January. Among other bad numbers, the merchandise trade deficit widened in August, and housing starts extended their slide to eight months in September.
DOC.HEAD: NOBELS: Financial Economists Honored
DOC.TEXT: The Nobel prize for economics went to three Americans who developed theories on how the financial markets work. Harry F. Markowitz of the City University of New York, William Sharpe of Stanford University and Merton Miller of the University of Chicago will share the prize, worth about $700,000. The award was viewed as a victory for financial economists, whose studies are more narrowly focused but often more applicable to everyday life than the esoteric pursuits of other economic theorists. Markowitz and Sharpe developed ideas for balancing risks and rewards in a diversified investment portfolio. Miller analyzed corporate financing techniques.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Milken Hearings Claim Victim
DOC.TEXT: The unusual hearings into the life and times of Michael Milken claimed their first victim, and it wasn't Milken. Richard Grassgreen resigned under pressure as chief of Enstar Group Inc. after disclosures that a federal grand jury was investigating transactions involving him and the former junk-bond king of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Grassgreen's name surfaced at the hearings in connection with Drexel's sale of Storer Communications securities, which prosecutors allege involved bribery and other shady dealings. Milken, who faces up to 28 years in prison on a guilty plea to six felonies, will learn his own fate after the hearings conclude. Unfortunately for people like Grassgreen, Judge Kimba Wood allowed witnesses at the hearing to name real names of Milken associates rather than confuse the court by speaking in code.
DOC.HEAD: DEALS: Trump Threatens Bankruptcy, Sir James Makes a Swap
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump launched an offensive in his debt wars by unveiling a new repayment plan for bondholders of his Taj Mahal casino. The carrot came tied to a stick, in the form of a warning that turning the plan down would land everyone in bankruptcy court. The threat didn't much frighten bondholders, who said a bankruptcy court fight would be preferable to Trump's new deal. The restructuring would give bondholders about a 20 percent equity stake in the Atlantic City casino in return for easier repayment terms on $675 million in junk bonds. The bondholders said their status as first mortgage holders on the palatial Taj would usher them to the front of the creditors' line in bankrupcty court. Across the Atlantic, another big dealmaker was cutting a Trump-sized deal of his own. Sir James Goldsmith, a corporate raider in semi-retirement, re-emerged with a friendly swap of assets with Hanson PLC. The deal involved trading Hanson's 49 percent stake in Newmont Mining, the leading U.S. gold company, for Sir James' Cavenham Forest Industries, a major American timber company. The ``trees-for-gold'' exchange was deemed an even trade at $1.3 billion. Sir James said he liked the long-term outlook for gold despite its recent market slide.
DOC.HEAD: AIRLINES: Final Chapter for UAL Deal
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. filed a record $22 billion order for new Boeing aircraft, then made peace with Conston Partners, its largest shareholder and the inspiration behind a failed takeover attempt by the company's unions. The developments virtually snuffed out any remaining chance for the union buyout, which had been on and off for a year. Coniston agreed not to participate in any attempt to acquire UAL for the next 2{ years in exchange for two seats on the board of the parent of United Airlines. The investment group had threatened to oust UAL directors unless the buyout was approved. But the $4.4 billion bid failed last week when the unions exhausted their financing options. The company now must turn attention to negotiating new contracts with the disgruntled unions. Elsewhere, Northwest Airlines was trying to explain how hand soap got into the hydraulic systems of two jets. The so-called honest mistake was made by an Atlanta mechanic who inadvertantly filled a hydraulic supply tank with a small amount of liquid soap. The planes were flown for about 10 days without incident before the contamination was discovered.
