DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Reports 56 Percent Drop in Third-Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Pulitzer Publishing Co. on Friday reported a 56 percent drop in profits for the third quarter, the third straight quarter of falling profits for the St. Louis-based media company. The company, which reported a 33 percent decrease in profits last quarter and a 70 percent decrease in the first quarter, continued to blame soft newspaper advertising conditions. In addition, third-quarter profits were affected by costs related to the purchase of a television station, WDSU-TV in New Orleans, in December. Net earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were $1.4 million, or 13 cents a share, down from $3.2 million, or 31 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenues of $98 million were up 3.5 percent from last year's $94.6 million. ``While our third-quarter results are disappointing, we are optimistic over the long term as we continue to emphasize market share and cost control,'' said Joseph Pulitzer Jr., chairman of the board. For the first three quarters, net income was $6.9 million or 66 cents a share, down from $13.2 million or $1.26 a share during the same period last year. Revenue for the year increased to $297 million from $256 million. Pulitzer's newspaper operations include two major metropolitan dailies, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson, and newspapers and shoppers in the Chicago area. Pulitzer's broadcasting operations consist of seven network-affilitated television stations in Greenville, S.C.; Lancaster, Pa., Winston-Salem, N.C.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Omaha, Neb.; Louisville, Ky.; and New Orleans. Pulitzer also owns two radio stations in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Company Hoping to Trim Payroll by 1,600
DOC.TEXT: Southwestern Bell Corp. hopes to trim 1,600 management-level employees from its telephone subsidiary by the end of the year with a voluntary incentive program, company officials said Friday. ``That's kind of a target number. If it goes above or falls short then that's what we get. It's not locked in concrete,'' said Bob Dickemper, vice president of human resources for the company. Changes in the way the company is run and improved technology have reduced the company's needs for managers, he said. Southwestern Bell, like many other large corporations, has tried for the past several years to give more responsibility to employees at all levels and decrease the layers of management. The company conducted a similar job-reduction program in 1986 and 2,000 managers left their jobs, Dickemper said. The telephone subsidiary, which provides phone service to 9.5 million homes and businesses in Missouri, Kansas, Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas, will limit by state the number of managers who take advantage of the program. ``There should really be no widespread impact on any particular community,'' he said. Incentives will vary by length of employment, Dickemper said, with a maximum payout of one-year's salary to employees with more than 20 years of service. About 17,000 of the telephone subsidiary's 58,000 workers have managerial positions. On Thursday, the company reported a third-quarter profit of $323 million, or $1.08 a share, an increase of 9.5 percent from the same period a year ago. The cost of the incentive program announced Friday will be charged to fourth quarter operations, Dickemper said, but he declined to estimate how much it would be.

DOC.HEAD: NL Industries May Increasing Lockheed Involvement
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Harold Simmons' NL Industries Inc. may try to increase its investment in Lockheed Corp., documents show. In a filing with the Securities Exchange Commission on Thursday, Houston-based NL Industries said it is again considering buying a controlling interest in the California-based defense contractor. NL holds holds just less than 20 percent of Lockheed's outstanding common shares and has repeatedly sought to increase its stake. Earlier this year, NL lost a bid to unseat Lockheed's board of directors and is currently challenging the voting rights of Lockheed's stock option plan. The plan controls about 17 percent of Lockheed stock, complicating chances for a hostile bid for the company. In September, Lockheed refused NL's offer to acquire 10 million Lockheed shares held in the employee stock plan for $35 each. That would have boosted NL's stake to 35.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Record Company Offering Album Previews over Telephone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A small independent record label, American Gramaphone, is offering customers a chance to listen to albums over the telephone before they buy them. The Omaha record company believes the new ``personal preview'' service that uses a 900 telephone number is the first of its kind. ``As far as I know, for music and for being able to give people their own choice as to what they are going to be able to hear, there is no one else,'' said Richard Musil, director of consumer response marketing for American Gramaphone. A person uses a touch-tone phone to call a 900 number and gets a recorded message asking the caller to choose one of the 60 albums in American Gramaphone's catalogue. Two selections from the album are played, lasting about a minute each. The caller can listen to excerpts from four albums during each call. A $2 charge is automatically added to the caller's monthly telephone bill. If the caller buys an album during the call, $2 is deducted from the price of the album. American Gramaphone is an independent label that is best known for representing the groups Mannheim Steamroller and C.W. McCall.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 169.69 Friday, up 6.29, or 3.85 percent, from a week ago and down 27.59, or 13.99 percent, this year to date. DOC.HEAD: Trade Bill Falters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers who for more than a year have wanted to use trade to punish China's repression of democracy said Friday they have pretty much given up the idea in the waning days of the Congressional session. The House voted 247-174 Thursday to overrule President Bush's decision in May to allow China to retain the low ``most favored nation'' tariffs on its $12 billion in annual exports to the United States through next year. That effort died when the Senate, rather than break off debate on a deficit reduction bill, did not act before a midnight deadline that Congress established in August for passing the resolution. ``I continue to believe that the president's renewal of this special trade status is wrong,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said today. ``It is a signal to the Chinese leadership ... that the United States views its brutal human rights violations with complacency.'' But Mitchell expressed no desire to bring before the Senate its last few days in session a weaker version also approved by the House that to make future renewals of China's most-favored-nation status more difficult. That weaker version would condition the low tariffs on a requirement that Beijing make ``substantial progress'' on meeting several human rights objectives. Even if Mitchell brought the alternative to the Senate floor, lawmakers said supporters lacked the two-thirds majorities needed in both houses to override what administration officials said would be a sure veto by Bush. ``The president was once the ambassador to China and he's got his mind made up on it,'' said Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee's trade subcommittee. ``And we don't have the votes to override him.'' Bush, the American envoy to China during the 1970s before the United States formally recognized its communist government, has maintained that suspending most-favored-nation status would hurt the Chinese people. ``It's no secret that the administration has been consistent in its strong opposition to passage of both the bills,'' State Department spokeswoman MargaretTutwiler said today. She said either measure ``could seriously damage our goal in advancing U.S. economic, human rights and other foreign policy interests in China as well as our interest in reaching a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf and Cambodia.'' Lifting the most-favored-nation trade status - granted to China in 1980 - would increase tariffs on its exports to the United States tenfold, drastically reducing the $18 billion in two-way trade last year. Even though the measure was certain to be vetoed, sponsors said its passage was needed nonetheless to send Chinese leaders a message to end their repression of dissidents. ``We have to play the `good cop-bad cop' routine so the president can tell the Chinese that Congress is tough and means business,'' said Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y. Before the Senate missed the deadline, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said the House vote ``will exert destructive impacts on the economic and trade relations between the two countries and will surely result in a serious slide back of the bilateral relations.''

DOC.HEAD: Profits Surge on Sale of Assets, Earnings up 1 Pct from Continuing Ops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock price in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Meredith Corp. said Friday its earnings shot up more than six times in the first quarter of its fiscal year, reflecting one-time gains from the sale of assets. Earnings from continuing operations nudged up just 1.3 percent for the diversified media company with interests in publishing, broadcasting and real estate. Meredith is best known for its Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal magazines. It reported profit of $60.9 million, or $3.62 a share, in the first quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $9.3 million, or 50 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The latest results included gains of $49.3 million from Meredith's share of thesale of Meredith-Burda printing business to R.R. Donnelley and Sons Co. and almost $3.6 million from the sale of Sail magazine to Cahners Publishing. Revenue rose 3.6 percent to $179.4 million from $173.1 million a year earlier. Earnings from continued operations rose to almost $5.4 million, or 32 cents a share, from nearly $5.2 million, or 28 cents a share. Jack Rehm, Meredith's president, said the improvement in first-quarter earnings from continuing operations reflected increased profits from broadcast operations and higher interest income. The interest income was associated with a note received from the sale of the printing operation that had been jointly owned with the Burda family of Germany. ``The Broadcasting Group benefited from lower operations expenses. The reduction was primarily due to lower programming costs that resulted from the fiscal 1990 write down of syndicated programming investments,'' Rehm said. The broadcast writedown was just one of several factors that produced a $49.9 million loss in the fourth quarter and a loss of $26.4 million for the full fiscal year that ended June 30. Rehm reported operating earnings were held down in the first quarter by a reduction in the number of advertising pages in magazines, a drop in results from real estate operations and heavier returns of book club products. A previously announced program to repurchase stock reduced the average outstanding shares to 16.8 million as of Sept. 30 from 18.7 million a year earlier. In trading Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, Meredith stock gained 50 cents to close at $21.75 per share.

DOC.HEAD: SEC To Share Information With Mexican Counterpart
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Friday it has signed a mutual assistance agreement with its counterpart in Mexico. The pact provides for sharing information and cooperating with the Mexican National Commission of Values. It covers a broad range of securities market regulation matters, including enforcement of insider trading and market manipulation laws. It also provides for the SEC to offer technical assistance to the Mexican agency. The agreement is the 10th international pact made by the SEC. Others are with Switzerland, Great Britain, Japan, Brazil, the Netherlands, France and the Canadian provinces of Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Another Snag in Sale of State-Run Phone Company
DOC.TEXT: The group of European investors that wants to buy part of the state phone company ENTel said Friday it can't come up with the down payment by the Nov. 8 deadline. ``We need a few days more,'' officials from France Cables and Radio and the Italian telecommunications company STET were quoted as saying by the Diarios y Noticias news agency. The government did not have an immediate comment. The U.S. phone company Bell Atlantic Corp. won the bid last June but was forced to withdraw when it could not meet an Oct. 8 deadline to hand over the down payment. STET and France Cables and Radio took Bell's place, and agreed to pay a down payment of more than $100 million cash and assume some Argentine foreign debt by Nov. 8. Representatives have met for two weeks with government officials to iron out the sales contract. ENTel, an aging system of 3 million lines that requires massive investment the government cannot provide, will be divided into two regional companies. A consortium led by the Spanish telecommunications company Telefonica agreed to pay $100 million cash and and nearly $2.9 billion in debt securities for 60 percent of ENTel's southern section. STET, France Cable and Radio, the U.S. bank J.P. Morgan and Co. and the Argentine shipping-banking firm Perez Companc agreed to pay about $2.5 billion in cash and debt securities for 60 percent share of ENTel's northern section.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Offers 20 Percent, Rating Agency Says Try Half
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump has offered investors in his Taj Mahal bonds nearly 20 percent of the hotel and casino's equity, but a debt-rating service says the bondholders are in a strong position to get up to half. The way Fitch Investors Service Inc. figures it, the Taj Mahal's cash flow can only cover half the interest expense on its $675 million in junk bonds that pay 14 percent interest. ``The bonds are worth half their par value based on the company's inability to service the debt on the books,'' said Wayne Josephson, one of the Fitch analysts who prepared the report on Trump's Taj Mahal, one of the debt-dogged developer's most worrisome problems. ``In restructuring we suggest bondholders would demand to be compensated for the loss in the value of their bonds.'' However, Stephen Bollenbach, Trump's new chief financial officer, doesn't agree. On Thursday, Trump announced he had offered Taj bondholders 19.9 percent of the casino in return for reducing the interest rate to 9 percent. Trump said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that bankruptcy court may be the only resort if the offer is turned down. The day before the SEC filing, Bollenbach said the Taj Mahal's long-term prospects are not as bad as the Fitch calculations suggest. ``There's plenty of public data out there that would indicate that on an ongoing basis the property could do much better than that,'' Bollenbach said. ``It's one of the ironies of the world we live in today. Here's the Taj Mahal that's a brand new business that's doing a terrific business but because of the way it's financed it's not currently covering its debt service. ``That doesn't mean it's a business that's permanently impaired. I think the bondholders realize that.'' Wilbur Ross, adviser to bondholders and a senior managing partner at Rothschild Inc., rejected the Trump offer. In a statement, Ross said he is pushing for majority interest in the Atlantic City resort in exchange for an interest-rate cut smaller than the 5 percent reduction suggested by Trump. ``We're miles apart on just about every single issue,'' Ross said. According to the Trump filing, the bondholders earlier this month sought 85 percent of the equity in the hotel and casino. Ross said the bondholders stood to get a better deal than Trump's latest offer if the business filed for bankruptcy protection. In addition to the interest-rate cut, Trump also wants the bondholders to let him make a $47.3 million interest payment Nov. 15 with more bonds, allow some of the interest in the future to be paid with more bonds and extend the issue's maturity two years to September 2000. Fitch concludes that bondholders are bearing most of the risk in Trump's casino bonds, since the developer has not guaranteed them with his own money and his 100 percent ownership in the Taj Mahal, Trump Plaza and Trump Castle is pledged to his bank lenders. The banks, Fitch says, would be willing to relinquish their claim to some of the equity to keep the Taj a going concern. A Taj failure could ripple throughout Trump's empire, making the banks' potential losses extend far beyond Atlantic City. One thing on Trump's side: The bondholders, who stand a good chance of getting the casino from a bankruptcy court, don't have a license to operate the place. The New Jersey Casino Control Commission would represent yet another hurdle for the bondholders trying to keep their investment alive. ``Without a license to operate a casino, bondholders hold the first mortgage on an empty building without any operating business,'' Fitch said. With a shortage of people looking to own an Atlantic City casino, selling the elaborate property could be tough. Casinos are historically thought of as recession-proof, but aren't getting that treatment this time around. Atlantic City casinos, which depend on middle-class daytrippers from the economically slumping Northeast, are seen as particularly vulnerable. While Las Vegas attracts higher-income gamblers who stay for days at a time, the typical Atlantic City visitor has less discretionary income and is likely to feel the pinch of a recession sooner. Also, Atlantic City casinos in general are deeper in debt than those in Las Vegas. ``Their cash flow is so tight to service the debt, that even a mild slowdown could make the difference between having enough cash or not having enough cash,'' Josephson said.

DOC.HEAD: Varity Corp. Clears Way for Move to Buffalo
DOC.TEXT: Varity Corp. has reached an agreement with Canada officials and the Canadian Auto Workers Union allowing the company to move its headquarters from Toronto to Buffalo next year, officials said. Varity, formerly Massey-Ferguson Ltd., was saved from bankruptcy by a multi-million dollar bailout by the Ontario and Canadian federal governments in 1981. The manufacturer of farm equipment and auto parts agreed to pay penalties of $21 million in Canadian dollars ($18 million U.S.) to the Ontario and Canadian governments, as well as about $27 million in Canadian dollars ($23 million U.S.) to pay outstanding claims by workers who lost their jobs after a 1986 plant closing. The agreement, announced Thursday by Ontario Premier Bob Rae and Varity, clears the way for Varity to relocate about 50 workers here after the company's reincorporation in the United States. The company's 1,200 permanent manufacturing and processing jobs would remain in Canada. Sheila Copps, a Canadian parliament member, criticized the settlement, saying it offers ``peanuts and crumbs'' to about 450 Varity workers she said will lose their jobs at a plant in Windsor, Ontario. But Neil D. Arnold, the company's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said Varity was ``determined to reach a reasonable settlement, remembering that the governments' timely investment nearly 10 years ago helped us keep afloat and gave us the opportunity to undertake our strategic recovery plan.'' Varity, with annual sales of $2.4 billion (U.S.), would rank among the top 130 companies in the Fortune 500 list of largest U.S. public firms. Fifty percent of Varity's sales are in the United States, with Canada accounting for just 4 percent of its worldwide business. Varity first announced the move to the United States in July, but the plans had been threatened until Thursday's agreement. The agreement, which has been approved by the two governments and Varity's board of directors, was designed to compensate the Canadian government for its bailout, and to excuse Varity from its 1986 promise to keep its headquarters in Canada. Varity has purchased a mansion in Buffalo that company officials said is the probable site for its headquarters. The move to Buffalo must first be approved by the company's board, then submitted to its shareholders, 82 percent of whom are Americans. A decision on the move could be made by late March, said Jack R. Nowling, a Varity spokesman.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market swept ahead for the second straight session Friday in buying inspired by falling oil prices and lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 68.07 to 2,520.79 on top of Thursday's 64.85-point gain. For the week the average rose 122.77 points. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,129 up, 499 down and 375 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board reached 221.48 million shares, up from 204.12 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 255.82 million shares. Oil prices, which have turned downward of late, took a big drop in Friday's activity. Crude oil futures for November delivery tumbled more than $3 a barrel, to less than $34 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The resulting letup in inflationary worries helped push interest rates lower in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds, which move in the opposite direction from interest rates, rose more than $5 for each $1,000 in face value. Analysts said that gave stock traders the encouragement they needed to follow through on the rally that began Thursday. Many observers agree that a break in oil prices and interest rates would go a long way toward cushioning the impact of the recession that is presumed to have begun around midyear. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up 1{ at 48]; International Business Machines, up 2\ at 107|; Coca-Cola, up 2] at 45}; Exxon, up 1] at 49~, and Procter & Gamble, up 2\ at 80]. Among retailing issues, Sears Roebuck rose 2 to 25~; Woolworth 1[ to 27[; Wal-Mart Stores 1] to 27}; K mart | to 24~; J.C. Penney ~ to 41~, and Toys R Us } to 23[. Federal Home Loan Mortgage fell 5 to 31]. On Thursday the company said it was charging $124 million in losses to reserves on its mortgage portfolios for the third quarter. Applied Materials tumbled 3~ to 19[ in the over-the-counter market. The company said its revenues and profits for the fiscal quarter ending Oct. 28 wouldn't live up to expectations. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $54.15 billion, or 1.90 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 3.27 to 170.40. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 8.56 to 367.42, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 6.74 at 312.48. DOC.HEAD: Precious Metal Rally Continues Amid Hopes Fed Will Ease
DOC.TEXT: Precious metal futures prices rose for the third straight day Friday, partially offsetting recent steep losses as a sharp drop in oil prices stirred speculation that interest rates may fall. On other commodity markets, copper futures rose sharply, livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybean were mixed. Gold futures settled $2.70 to $2.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the spot price, represented by the contract for October delivery, at $372.80 a troy ounce; silver was 5.8 cents to 6.1 cents higher with October at $4.258 a troy ounce. Platinum outpaced the other precious metals. Platinum futures ended $10.50 to $11.50 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with October at $407.70 a troy ounce. The metals virtually ignored a number of traditionally bearish signals including sharply higher stock prices, a stronger dollar and a drop in oil prices. Instead, metal traders focused on the deflationary implications of lower oil prices, which fell on perceptions that the Iraq-U.S. standoff in the Middle East is moving toward a peaceful settlement. The letup in inflationary worries prompted speculation that the Federal Reserve Board may take action to lower bank lending rates. ``The last time the Fed indicated it was easing credit policy back in July, that's when gold accelerated to the upside,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst for PaineWebber Inc. John Jonat, who trades precious metals for Deak International Inc., also said gold's rise was a spillover from the platinum market, which was boosted by strong Japanese demand. Both Jonat and Peter Cardillo, commodity trading adviser for Jesup, Josephthal & Co., said gold could climb as high as $390 an ounce before hitting pressure to fall. In petroleum trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil ended $2 to $3.01 lower with November at $33.79 a barrel; heating oil was 6 cents to 8.11 cents lower with November at 88.40 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4 cents to 5.05 cents lower with November at 87.91 cents a gallon. Strength in the stock market contributed to a strong rally in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange. Copper has many applications in the manufacturing and construction industries, so its price responds strongly to economic signals. Copper futures ended 1.5 cents to 3.8 cents higher with October at $1.267 a pound. Cattle futures rose moderately on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash-market fundamentals. Traders also evened their positions ahead of the government's quarterly cattle-on-feed report, which will be released Monday afternoon. Hog futures fell slightly while pork bellies advanced. Live cattle were unchanged to .50 cent higher with October at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .60 cent higher with October at 86.85 cents a pound; live hogs were .20 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 57.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.17 cents to 1.8 cents higher with February at 67.17 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures were little changed on the Chicago Board of Trade as harvest-related selling offset buying linked to new export sales of wheat and soybeans. Wheat futures drew light support from an Agriculture Department announcement that China bought about 450,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Wheat futures finished unchanged to } cent higher with December at $2.63} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent higher with December at $2.28\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3 cents higher with November at $6.11{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: The Hartford Refutes Consumer Group Claims Of Financial Vulnerability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds two grafs at end with USF&G statement. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The consumer group Public Citizen admitted Friday it made a mistake in putting the ITT Hartford Insurance group on a list of five property and casualty insurance companies it said could fail in the event of a recession. ITT Hartford said it was Public Citizen, not the insurance company, that ``flunked the test.'' The consumer group, affiliated with Ralph Nader, issued a statement acknowledging the error but standing by it's report's ``fundamental conclusion: property and casualty companies should improve their business practices to avoid solvency problems in the future.'' Public Citizen said Monday that the Hartford, Aetna, American International Group, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty each failed four of six tests that it used to measure vulnerability to insolvency. The group said none of the companies was on the edge of insolvency but ``the underlying weakness in their financial condition is clearly evident.'' All five companies, along with the Insurance Information Institute, took issue with the report. Some described it as irresponsible. One of the six tests used by Public Citizen was whether a company's surplus - the available backup funds for use in cases of catastrophic or unexpected losses - had declined since 1972. It found that Hartford's surplus, measured in 1967 dollars, had dropped from $1.1 billion in 1972 to $735 million in 1988, a decline of 33 percent. Jim Westervelt, vice president and group comptroller for the Hartford, said the figure used for 1972 represented the surpluses of all of the Hartford companies. The 1988 figure, on the other hand, represented only the consolidated surpluses of Hartford Fire Insurance Company and its property and casualty subsidiaries. The company said, and Public Citizen acknowledged, that use of the correct figures would have shown that the Hartford's 1988 surplus was up 6 percent from 1972. ``As a result, The Hartford should not have been included among the companies most financially vulnerable in the event of an economic downturn,'' Public Citizen said. It's statement said that data in the industry publication Best's Aggregates and Averages, which it used to determine shrinkage of surpluses, ``does not clearly indicate the pooling arrangements within the Hartford in 1972.'' Using the correct figures, it said, ITT Hartford has failed three, not four, of the vulnerability tests. ``The Hartford's surplus has not deteriorated, and the company should not have been listed as one of the five companies that were found to have failed this test,'' the company said. Joel Freedman, a Hartford vice president in Washington, said the Hartford had not examined whether the figures for the other four companies were wrong. ITT said its independent auditors, Arthur Andersen & Co., had confirmed the error. ``Public Citizen, in fact, has flunked the test,'' ITT Hartford said in a news release. Freedman said the company had been damaged because of policyholders, agents and shareholders becoming concerned about the Public Citizen report. Meanwhile, USF&G issued a statement from its Baltimore headquarters saying that in applying its six tests Public Citizen ``misapplied critical financial data relating to USF&G and overlooked other financial information.'' ``USF&G's own analysis contradicts Public Citizen's conclusions and establishes that USF&G falls safely within the group of other financially strong insurers analyzed in the report who were not singled out,'' the statement said. ``Public Citizen's report was shallow and misdirected.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Stronger in New York, Weaker in Europe; Gold Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly stronger in domestic trading Friday after weakening in Europe, but foreign exchange brokers said the U.S. currency remained wobbly because of American economic uncertainty. Gold and silver prices rose. ``This is volatile stuff,'' said Lloyd G. Atkinson, chief economist for the Bank of Montreal, ``and all indications are that this is going to continue for some time.'' Traders said the foreign exchange markets continued to display pessimism about the dollar, especially in light of the prolonged political stalemate in Washington over the budget deficit. ``Forex players remain skeptical of the dollar's upside potential at this point,'' said Michael Faust, a currency analyst with Money Market Services in Chicago. ``We've had comments all week from Japanese, U.S. and German officials that they're either happy with the dollar right now or they welcome further gains in the yen or the mark at the expense of the dollar,'' Faust said. The dollar had fallen through a psychological barrier of 1.50 German marks to 1.4970 in New York Thursday, but it rebounded Friday, closing at 1.5025 marks. In New York, traders said, the dollar's behavior was largely influenced by the oil market. Oil fell by about $3 a barrel, easing inflation fears and thereby helping the dollar rally a bit. Inflation erodes the value of dollars. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen Friday, ending a long slide. In Tokyo, the dollar finished trading at 125.25 yen, up 0.85 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 125.90. In New York, the dollar closed at 125.95 yen, up from 124.40 late Thursday. In London, the cost for one British pound rose to $1.9590 from $1.9540 late Thursday. At closing in New York, one pound cost $1.9585, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9710. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday included: 1.2680 Swiss francs, up from 1.2590; 5.0295 French francs, up from 5.0165; 1,124.25 Italian lire, up from 1,122.00; 1.1731 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1698. DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise as Dollar Climbs, Oil Price Drops
DOC.TEXT: Government bond prices rose Friday, boosted by a runup in the value of the dollar and a drop in oil prices, traders and analysts said. The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond climbed 11-16 point, or about $6.88 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when the bond's price rises, slipped to 8.75 percent from 8.81 percent late Thursday. Bond prices opened higher, following a rise on overseas markets. Bonds were boosted abroad by a dip in oil prices, said William Pike, a managing director in the government bond-trading department of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. The bond market has closely tracked oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The oil price rise has fueled fears of increasing inflation, which reduces the value of fixed-return securities such as bonds. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the November contract for the benchmark grade of oil fell $3.01 a barrel to settle at $33.79. Oil prices fell amid signs of good supplies and slackened demand, as well as indications that Iraq may be willing to negotiate a pullout from Kuwait. Bond prices also were boosted by a jump in the value of the dollar in foreign exchange, said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. A stronger dollar makes U.S. securities more attractive to global investors. In addition, Ricchiuto said, the bond market was boosted by a report showing the economy continues to decline. The monthly index on regional industrial activity put out by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia fell to its fourth-lowest level ever last month, he said. Signs of economic softening often boost bond prices because they make it more likely the Federal Reserve will ease interest rates. Meanwhile, in the corporate bond market, prices of many high-yield ``junk'' bonds rose sharply, boosted by the overall rise in the bond market and a jump in stock prices. However, the rise did not erase the losses junk bonds have suffered in recent days. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term issues rose from [ point to 9-32 point, intermediate-term issues rose 13-32 point to 23-32 point, and long-term issues rose as much as } point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of one point is equal to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.50 to 1,156.45. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.44 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 7.22 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.54 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point to 7.18 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.51 percent as the discount slipped 5 basis points to 7.04 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7 13-16 percent, down from 7 15-16 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 8-32 point to 88 22-32. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.77 percent from 7.79 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Adopts Economic Reform Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with new economic statistics, clarifies vote was final, details. Picks up 9th graf, `Comrade Yeltsin's. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB5,6,10
DOC.TEXT: In the Soviet Union's most radical departure from Communist economics in 70 years, the legislature voted Friday to transform the economy into the market-oriented system advocated by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But a rift with the Russian Federation, the country's largest republic, threatened to disrupt the effort. The Supreme Soviet voted 333-12, with nine abstentions, in favor of Gorbachev's plan to free most prices of government control, end most government monopolies and encourage free enterprise in this nation of 285 million residents. Lawmakers had given the bill preliminary approval earlier before debating amendments. It is an ambitious outline for ending chronic shortages of food and housing, integrating the Soviet Union in the world market and encouraging people to work harder and enjoy the benefits. The plan partially reverses decades of tight central control of the nation's economy, unleashing market forces to determine prices, what products to make, how to make them and where. Hours after the plan was approved, the government's statistics agency released dismal figures for the economy's first nine months of 1990. Gross national product was down 1.5 percent and inflation was 9 percent, Tass reported. The plan hopes to reverse those trends, but its success rides on officials in the 15 Soviet republics who must put it into effect through local legislation. And the republics - increasingly anxious to break away from central control because of decades of unfair treatment under Kremlin economic policies - may not cooperate as much as necessary. The blueprint came under fire even before Friday's vote from Gorbachev's main political rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation. On Friday, Gorbachev launched a counterattack. ``Comrade Yeltsin's assertions are strange, to say the least,'' Gorbachev told the 542-member legislature. ``I'm under the impression that the Russian leadership is afraid of difficulties and wants to pass responsibility ... onto central organs of power,'' he said. Gorbachev said he shared many of Yeltsin's concerns about deteriorating political and economic conditions and inflation. But he accused the government of the Russian republic of contributing to inflation with its recent decision to raise wholesale meat prices. Yeltsin has lambasted Gorbachev's plan as a ``catastrophe'' that is ``doomed to fail'' within months. He has said his own republic, the largest and richest, may proceed with its own 500-day plan for switching to a market economy as early as Nov. 1. In a 50-minute speech Friday, Gorbachev tried to persuade the republics to sign onto his plan. Supporters say it allows the republics wide latitude to tailor reforms to local conditions. He called the plan the only ``rational'' course of action. But his speech won only five seconds of lukewarm applause. Stanislav Shatalin, author of the 500-day plan that Russia adopted, told a news conference that although the Supreme Soviet did not choose his plan, he endorses Gorbachev's outline. And in a clear reference to Yeltsin, he said the program's success depends on ``political stabilization.'' ``The republics' survival will depend on whether they act in concert or not,'' Shatalin said. Another economist, deputy Soviet premier Leonid Abalkin, said Yeltsin's actions could bring on ``chaos and disintegration,'' and he called for people to express ``confidence in the president.'' That confidence will be crucial to people's willingness to endure the unemployment and inflation expected as the reforms proceed. The reforms touch on the fundamentals of socialism, including private ownership of businesses and of land. The republics were left to decide who should be allowed to have private property and whether to allow private ownership of land. Gorbachev acknowledged that some people were asking whether the transition to a market economy was a departure from socialism. ``We are striving, not through declarations but in reality, to strengthen socialism'' by maximizing potential, he told the lawmakers. Gorbachev's plan would transform the moribund Soviet economy in four stages. It sets no deadline for the switch, but says other countries have achieved similar goals in 18 months to two years. The plan begins by cutting the budget deficit and the nation's money supply, increasing production of consumer goods, raising bank interest rates for savings and introducing land reform.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rejects Request to Halt Planned Joint Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with court ruling
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Friday rejected a request that it halt the planned trial of 20 consolidated asbestos injury claim cases. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals denied a request by USX Corp. for a stay of Monday's scheduled trial before U.S. District Judge Thomas D. Lambros. Chief Judge Gilbert Merritt said the court would give its reasons for the denial in a memo to be issued next week. The Pittsburgh-based USX is a defendant in three of the 20 cases Lambros consolidated in his Cleveland court. Lambros and other judges have consolidated asbestos cases in an effort to get rid of backlogged cases. Still pending before the appeals court is USX's separate request for an order prohibiting Lambros from proceeding with the consolidated cases and requiring assignment of the cases to other judges in northern Ohio. USX argued that the cases in which the company is a defendant are unsuitable for what would amount to class-action grouping with other, dissimilar cases. Lambros, a respondent in the USX petition, has not filed a response to the request that the cases be reassigned, court spokeswoman Debra Nagle said. The appeals court gave him until Tuesday to do so. Plaintiffs in the cases are Gret Lakes mariners who claim they may have contracted cancer or other ailments because they were exposed to asbestos or asbestos-containing material while on board USX Corp. ships. Lambros and the other judges who consolidated the cases have said it appears the defendants do not have enough money to pay all the claims and costs in thousands of pending lawsuits. Defendants in some of the cases have objected to the judges' efforts to consolidate their cases, saying they prefer to go to trial and defend themselves independently of other plaintiffs.

DOC.HEAD: TI Posts $7 Million Loss in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc. lost $7 million in the third quarter, the company said Friday, blaming higher investment spending and lower prices for semiconductors. The Dallas-based company said the loss amounted to 19 cents a share, compared with a profit of $65 million, or 67 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenue totaled $1.68 billion, up 7 percent from $1.57 billion for the same period last year. Third-quarter results also were hurt by the temporary disruption of business at TI's semiconductor assembly-and-test operation in Baguio, Philippines, following an earthquake in July. The plant was closed one month. Jerry R. Junkins, TI's chairman, president and chief executive officer, said in a letter to stockholders that ``although TI's high level of investment is having a negative effect on current financial performance,'' the company is making progress in the semiconductor and defense electronics markets. He also said TI's more aggressive protection of its patents, starting in 1986, ``has thus far generated cumulative royalty revenues of more than $650 million.'' The company is holding talks with Japanese and Korean chip manufacturers to renegotiate patent agreements. Junkins said TI expects to earn ``a significant ongoing stream of royalty revenue'' from those agreements. Junkins said the semiconductor market was sluggish in the third quarter due to a worsening domestic economy.

In the Soviet Union's most radical departure from Communist economics in 70 years, the legislature voted Friday to transform the economy into the market-oriented system advocated by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But a rift with the country's largest republic threatened to disrupt the effort. Gorbachev's plan to free most prices of government control, end most government monopolies and encourage free enterprise is an ambitious outline for ending chronic shortages of food and housing, integrating the Soviet Union in the world market and encouraging people to work harder and enjoy the benefits. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Michael Milken stammered and rose from his desk after learning speculator Ivan Boesky was cooperating with the government's insider trading investigation in late 1986, a Milken subordinate testified. Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond salesman Terren Peizer described on Friday a climate of fear after the Boesky deal. The comments came during a pre-sentencing hearing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on a series of alleged crimes the government says were committed by Milken beyond those to which he has pleaded guilty. Prosecutors hope to convince Wood that Milken deserves a stiff punishment. --- DETROIT (AP) - Executives of General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union have signed a new three-year labor contract guaranteeing the wages of about 300,000 U.S. workers. GM Chairman Robert Stempel and UAW President Owen Bieber signed the documents Friday. Bieber is now expected to turn up the heat on Chrysler Corp. when bargaining with the No. 3 automaker intensifies next week. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Midway Airlines says it will sell off its unprofitable hub operations at the Philadelphia International Airport and end 61 daily flights by April 30 as it faces even greater losses due to fuel prices. The selloff, said Midway President Thomas Schick said, would cost his airline about $30 million. David Hinson, Midway chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement that the sale was necessary to stabilize the airline's financial condition and return it to profitability. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The consumer group Public Citizen has admitted it made a mistake in putting the ITT Hartford Insurance group on a list of five insurance companies it said could fail in the event of a recession. ITT Hartford said it was Public Citizen, not the insurance company, that ``flunked the test.'' The consumer group, affiliated with Ralph Nader, on Friday issued a statement acknowledging the error. Public Citizen said Monday that the Hartford, Aetna, American International Group, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty each failed four of six tests that it used to measure vulnerability to insolvency. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Senate backers of a bill to regulate cable TV prices say the compromise measure is dead for the year, after they failed to move it to a floor vote. Friday's defeat marks the end of three weeks of private negotiations between Sens. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and Tim Wirth, D-Colo., to soften language in the bill to prevent cable programmers from making exclusive contracts with cable system operators. It also culminated a two-year effort to meld two dozen cable bills into a law that would address rising concerns about shoddy service and cable charges, which have risen 43 percent in the last three years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Lawmakers who for more than a year have wanted to use trade to punish China's repression of democracy say they have pretty much given up the idea in the waning days of the Congressional session. The House voted 247-174 Thursday to overrule President Bush's decision in May to allow China to retain ``most favored nation'' status. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he disagreed with Bush's decision, but Mitchell said supporters lacked the two-thirds majorities needed in both houses to override what administration officials said would be a sure veto by Bush. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An international panel said it would include in a list of chemicals to be reviewed in 1992 a drug that could induce cows to give more milk. The drug, bovine somatotropin or BST, is still under review by the Food and Drug Administration for possible use by U.S. dairy farmers. Tests indicate the synthetic hormone could increase a cow's milk production by 10 percent to 25 percent. The Codex Committee on Residues of Veterinary Drugs in Foods met in closed session Friday. --- BOSTON (AP) - More bad news surfaced for one of New England's largest banks. The Bank of New England Corp. reported a loss of $123.2 million or $1.78 a share in the third quarter, due largely to a $100 million provision for possible credit losses. The company blamed its losses on the slowdown of the New England economy, worsened by rising oil prices and Middle East uncertainties. ---

Stocks advanced Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 68.07 to 2,520.79 on top of Thursday's 64.85-point gain. The dollar finished stronger in domestic trading. Oil futures skidded. Precious metal futures prices rose for the third straight day. Copper futures rose sharply; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybean were mixed. Bond prices rose.

DOC.HEAD: Kellogg Says International Sales Boosted 3rd Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Kellogg Co. said Friday that rising international sales of its ready-to-eat cereal overcame slow U.S. sales growth for a 31.8 percent jump in third-quarter profits, exceeding analysts' expectations. The world's largest cereal maker said its net income rose to $162.3 million, or $1.34, for the three months ended Sept. 30, from $123.1 million, or $1.02 a share, for July-September 1989. Net sales reached $1.35 billion for the period, up from $1.20 billion a year earlier, Kellogg said. ``In the United States, our ready-to-eat cereal business continues to be soft,'' said William E. LaMothe, chairman and chief executive officer. Kellogg held about a 38.5 percent share of the U.S. cereal market, down about two percentage points from a year earlier, said food industry analyst Timothy Ramey of County NatWest USA in New York. But the company, which makes cereal in 16 countries and sells it in 130, had substantial gains in sales volume overseas and was helped by favorable currency exchange rates, LaMothe said. Ramey said Kellogg's earnings exceeded his and many other analysts' expectations by about 10 cents a share. He credited strong international sales and cost-control programs by Kellogg. For the first nine months of the year, the company had net earnings of $394.3 million, or $3.26 a share, on net sales of $3.82 billion, compared with net earnings of $412.3 million, or $3.38 a share, on sales of $3.56 billion in the first nine months of 1989. Kellogg said the nine month earnings in 1989 were inflated by an accounting change, however. Without it, net earnings for the year-earlier period would have been $364.2 million, or $2.99 a share, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Climate of Fear Described at Drexel After Boesky Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf after 9th graf, Prosecutors had; picks up 10th graf pvs, Peizer, who.
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken stammered and rose from his desk after learning speculator Ivan Boesky was cooperating with the government's insider trading investigation in late 1986, a Milken subordinate testified Friday. Another witness offered the first evidence Milken may have misled an important client during the $2.5 billion buyout of Storer Communications Inc. in late 1985, then the biggest takeover deal ever. Former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond salesman Terren Peizer described a climate of fear after the Boesky deal in which workers speculated about government wiretaps and turned on water faucets to drown conversations. Milken's lawyers raised the possibility of the first public testimony by Milken after four years at the center of the government's Wall Street probe. Defense lawyer Arthur Liman said he may call Milken to the stand at the end of the special pre-sentencing hearing in Manhattan federal court. The hearing before U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood focuses on alleged crimes by Milken beyond those to which he has pleaded guilty. Prosecutors hope to convince Wood that Milken deserves a stiff punishment by depicting a pattern of systematic lawbreaking by the former head of Drexel's junk-bond operation. Milken, 44, pleaded guilty in April to six felony counts related to illegal trading and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. He faces a maximum 28 years imprisonment. Theodore Ammon of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., an investment firm that was one of Drexel's biggest customers, testified Milken and associates received millions of dollars in equity in KKR's Drexel-financed takeover of Storer without the firm's knowledge. The testimony was important because it suggested Milken may have tried enrich himself, associates and customers while misleading KKR about the reason. Ammon said Milken had told him the equity was intended for third parties as an inducement to buy risky Storer preferred securities. Prosecutors had charged earlier that Milken created partnerships to reward customers who bought the risky Storer securities with company stock. The government said the stock constituted a bribe. But the defense maintains that Milken and his associates had acquired the equity because they had committed to purchasing more than half of the $261 million preferred stock offering. Peizer, who sat beside Milken on Drexel's X-shaped trading desk, said when news of Boesky's November 1986 plea deal crossed the financial news ticker, Milken ``lost his train of thought and concentration and started going, `Uh, uh.''' Boesky became Milken's chief accuser. Milken has admitted lawbreaking with Boesky. But Liman questioned Peizer's version of the events. Peizer said after the Boesky announcement Milken walked into the office of his brother, Lowell. Liman said Lowell Milken was out sick that day. While searching his desk for documents subpoenaed by the government, Peizer said Milken ``said something to the effect that if you don't have them you can't provide them.'' He said Milken then opened one of his desk drawers, which was empty. But under questioning, Peizer said he did not assume Milken was telling him to discard documents. Peizer said Milken never asked him to dispose of any records and he never did. On Thursday, two government witnesses testified that stock warrants were offered to induce big investors to buy risky Storer preferred securities, but neither could link Milken to any bribery or misappropriation. Ammon testified Milken called him late in the Storer deal saying he needed to halve the purchase price of the warrants to $5 million to attract more interest in the preferred. Ammon said he learned about the Milken-led partnerships almost two years later, and argued with a Drexel executive about the firm retaining so much equity. But he said KKR probably would have done the deal regardless, and he conceded KKR had given Drexel broad latitude to constuct the terms. Peizer said he sold a large block of the preferred issue to David Solomon of Solomon Asset Management, a longtime Milken customer, after Milken suggested the equity ``sweetener.'' Peizer said he learned later that Solomon had sold the preferred stock to his own clients but kept the warrants for himself. It was unclear whether Solomon took the warrants on his own or via an arrangement with Drexel. Peizer said he did not believe the equity constituted a bribe. Solomon was involved in one of the transactions in Milken's guilty plea and is cooperating with government prosecutors. Prosecutors said he will not be called as a witness on Storer. Peizer also said Milken ordered him to turn over a blue ledger book tallying possibly rigged trades between Solomon and Drexel. Peizer said the ledger was an accounting of how much money Solomon owed the firm. The witness said he handed the book to a Drexel executive, Lorraine Spurge, in a kitchenette at the junk bond department after turning on a water faucet in case anyone was listening. Liman said Spurge has denied Peizer gave her the book. ``Everyone was running faucets'' at Drexel after Boesky's plea deal, Peizer said.
